PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the Village of Lansing, Illinois. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1969 and 1982 Codes, as supplemented through January 2008, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the Village Board of Trustees. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the Lansing Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER CHT:1 RELATED LAWS RL:1 SPECIAL ACTS SA:1 CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE CHTCT:1 RELATED LAWS COMPARATIVE TABLE RLCT:1 SPECIAL ACTS COMPARATIVE TABLE SACT:1 CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CHARTER INDEX CHTi:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Sandra Fox, Code Attorney, and Daryl Jaquette, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Jean Eisha, Village Clerk, for his cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that his efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the Village readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the Village's affairs.

ORDINANCE NO. 09-015 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code for the Village of Lansing, Illinois; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing a Penalty for the Violation Thereof; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective. 
Be it Ordained by the Village Board of Trustees: 
    Section 1 . The Code entitled "The Code of Ordinances of the Village of Lansing, Illinois," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 56, each inclusive, is adopted. 
    Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before October 21, 2008, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $750 and imprisonment not to exceed six months. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the board of trustees may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 5 : Addition or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the Board of Trustees to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 6: Ordinances adopted after June 17, 2008, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be constructed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code, 
    Section 7: This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect after it passage, approval and publication as provided by law. 
    PASSED this 21st day of July, 2009. 
AYES: 6 Trustees: Butler, Stole, Kapteyn, Lyzenga, Myers and Lucas

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The following chapters and appendixes shall constitute and be designated as the "The Code of Ordinances of the Village of Lansing, Cook County, Illinois," and may be so cited. This Code may also be referred to by the short title "Lansing Code." 
(Code 1969, § 1.101; Code 1982, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Ordinances generally, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1. 
Sec. 1-2. - Official copies of Code. 
    Two copies of this Code shall be maintained so that amendments thereto and all general ordinances hereafter passed will be posted, inserted or noted in their proper place within this Code, so that the two copies show all general ordinances passed to date and ready reference may be had thereto. One of the copies shall be maintained by the village clerk and the second by the village attorney. If any doubt arises as to whether a new ordinance is a general ordinance, the village clerk shall be guided by the advice of the village attorney. 
(Code 1969, § 1.112; Code 1982, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- Proof of ordinances, book or pamphlet as prima facie evidence, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-6. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1969, § 1.104; Code 1982, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - History notes; references. 
    The history notes of the several sections of this Code printed in parentheses at the end of each section are intended as references to indicate the source of the sections. Editorial comments and state law reference appearing at the end of a section are intended as an aid to the reader only, neither shall they be deemed or taken to be any part of the sections or, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of the sections, including the history notes, editorial comments, or state law reference, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1982, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of ordinances existing at the time of the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1982, § 1-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions as to statutes, 5 ILCS 70/2. 
Sec. 1-6. - Minimum requirements. 
    In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience, morals and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provisions imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
(Code 1969, §§ 1.102.2, 2.1210.4; Code 1982, § 1-6) 
State Law reference- Power of village to pass and enforce all necessary police ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 1-7. - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the rules of construction set out in this chapter shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the president and board of trustees. The rules of construction set out herein shall not be applied to any section of this Code which shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or where the subject matter or context of such section may be repugnant thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 1.102; Code 1982, § 1-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 5 ILCS 70/1. 
Sec. 1-8. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Code, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board, village board, board of trustees. The terms "board," "village board," "board of trustees" mean the president and board of trustees of the Village of Lansing, unless otherwise provided. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given, or such act is done, shall be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall not be counted. 
    Corporate or village limits. The terms "corporate limits" or "village limits" mean the legal boundaries of the Village of Lansing. 
    County. The terms "the county" or "this county" mean the County of Cook, in the State of Illinois. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other village officer to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or to make the required inspection, unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
    Director of public safety, fire. The term "fire director of public safety" means a person who is not a member of the fire department, but who is serving in the position of fire chief. 
    Director of public safety, police. The term "police director of public safety" means a person who is not a member of the police department, but who is in service in the position of police chief. 
    Fire chief. The term "fire chief" means a person who is a member of the fire department serving in the position of fire chief (as opposed to a nondepartment member filling that position, who is referred to as the director of public safety, fire). 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper and proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or as servants, agents or employees. 
    ILCS. The term "ILCS" is an abbreviation used throughout this Code and means the Illinois Compiled Statutes, the general and permanent laws of Illinois, as now or hereafter amended. 
    May. The term "may" is permissive. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Officers, generally. Whenever any officer is referred to by title, such as "clerk," "chief of police" or any other village officer or employee, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the Village of Lansing." 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" includes associations, clubs, societies, firms, companies, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property, except real property, as described in this section. 
    Police chief. The term "police chief" means a person who is a member of the police department serving in the position of police chief (as opposed to a nondepartment member filling that position, who is referred to as the director of public safety, police). 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    President. The term "president" means the president of the board of trustees of the Village of Lansing. 
    Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. 
    Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Shall. The term "shall" is mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription. The terms "signature" or "subscription" include a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The terms "the state" or "this state" means the State of Illinois. 
    Street. The term "street" includes streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the village, and shall include all areas thereof embraced between the property lines and dedicated to the public use. 
    Tenant or occupant. The terms "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Time. Terms used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. If a time is given in a.m. or p.m., it shall mean central standard time, except that when the village is on daylight saving time, it shall mean central daylight saving time. 
    Trustee. The term "trustee" means a member of the board of trustees. 
    Village. The terms "the village" or "this village" mean the Village of Lansing, in the State of Illinois. 
    Wholesale, wholesaler. In all cases where the terms "wholesale," "wholesaler" or "wholesale dealer" are used in this Code, unless otherwise specifically defined, they relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who purchase for purposes of resale, as distinguished from a retail dealer, who sells in smaller quantities direct to the consumer. 
    Written, in writing. The terms "written" or "in writing" include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
(Code 1969, §§ 1.102.3, 1.103; Code 1982, § 1-8) 
State Law reference- Similar rules of statutory construction and definitions, 5 ILCS 70/0.01 et seq.; Time Standardization Act, 5 ILCS 440/0.01 et seq. 
Sec. 1-9. - Gender. 
    Words importing the masculine gender may be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
(Code 1969, § 1.102.5; Code 1982, § 1-9) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions as to statutes, 5 ILCS 70/1.04. 
Sec. 1-10. - Number. 
    Words importing the singular number may extend and be applied to several persons or things, and words importing the plural number may include the singular. 
(Code 1969, § 1.102.4; Code 1982, § 1-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions as to statutes, 5 ILCS 70/1.03. 
Sec. 1-11. - Liberal construction. 
    All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the president and board of trustees may be fully carried out. 
(Code 1969, § 1.102.1; Code 1982, § 1-11) 
State Law reference- Liberal construction of statutes, 5 ILCS 70/1.01. 
Sec. 1-12. - Amendments to Code. 
    All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein, or in case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from the reprinted pages affected thereby, and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances, until such time that this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 1.105; Code 1982, § 1-12) 
State Law reference- Amendatory legislation, 5 ILCS 70/1.34; amendatory acts, 5 ILCS 70/5; multiple amendments, conflicts, 5 ILCS 70/6. 
Sec. 1-13. - Supplementation of Code-Generally. 
    By contract or by village personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 1-13) 
Sec. 1-14. - Same-Content. 
    A supplement to this Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the board of trustees or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. 
(Code 1982, § 1-14) 
Sec. 1-15. - Same-Pages. 
    The pages of a supplement to this Code shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(Code 1982, § 1-15) 
Sec. 1-16. - Same-Repealed provisions. 
    In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(Code 1982, § 1-16) 
Sec. 1-17. - Same-Editing. 
    When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ___ through ___" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; 
but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of the ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1982, § 1-17) 
Sec. 1-18. - Effect of repeal of ordinances-Generally. 
    When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision, unless it shall be therein so expressly provided. 
(Code 1969, § 1.106; Code 1982, § 1-18) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions as to statutes, 5 ILCS 70/3. 
Sec. 1-19. - Same-Acts; liabilities; claims. 
    No section of this Code or new ordinance shall be construed to repeal any former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense committed against the former ordinance, or as to any act done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment incurred, or any right accrued, or claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense or act so committed or done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right so accrued, or claim arising before the section of this Code or new ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform so far as practicable, to the laws in force at the time of such proceedings. 
(Code 1969, § 1.106; Code 1982, § 1-19) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions as to statutes, 5 ILCS 70/4. 
Sec. 1-20. - Same-Mitigation of penalty. 
    If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment is mitigated by any provision of this Code or new ordinance, such provision may, by the consent of the party affected, be applied to any judgment pronounced after the section of this Code or new ordinance takes effect. 
(Code 1969, § 1.106; Code 1982, § 1-20) 
Sec. 1-21. - Same-Scope. 
    Sections 1-18 through 1-20 shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or by implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance adopting this Code or new ordinance upon the same subject or in any other ordinance or act. 
(Code 1969, § 1.106; Code 1982, § 1-21) 
Sec. 1-22. - Tampering with Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the village to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the village to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1969, § 1.111; Code 1982, § 1-22) 
Sec. 1-23. - General penalty. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in any village ordinance any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no other specific penalty is provided therefor in the code section or chapter or by state statute, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any ordinance shall be punished by a fine of no more than $750.00 for any one offense. 
(b)  No imprisonment for failure to pay any fine, penalty or cost required under the provisions of this Code shall exceed six months for one offense. 
(c)  A penalty imposed for violation of this Code or any village ordinance may include, or consist of, a requirement that the defendant perform some reasonable public service work such as, but is not limited to, the picking up of litter in public parks or along public highways or the maintenance of public facilities. 
(d)  In the event a fine or penalty is assessed pursuant to any provision of this Code, a default in the payment of a fine, penalty, or any installment of a fine or penalty may be collected by any means authorized for the collection of monetary judgments. The village may retain attorneys and private collection agents for the purpose of collecting any default in payment of any fine or penalty imposed by the Code, or any installment of a fine or penalty. Any fees or costs incurred by the village with respect to attorneys or private collection agents retained by the village to collect fines or penalties imposed under any provisions of this Code shall be a debt due and owing the village shall be added to any outstanding balance owed to the village by the debtor. 
(Code 1969, § 1.108; Code 1982, § 1-23; Ord. No. 18-032, § 2, 9-18-2018) 
State Law reference- Ordinances and rules, fines or penalties, limitations on punishment, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1. 
Sec. 1-24. - Separate offenses. 
    Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1982, § 1-24) 
Sec. 1-25. - Election as to section under which to prosecute. 
    In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or created by different clauses or sections of this Code or other village ordinances, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not more than one recovery may be had against the same person for the same offense. 
(Code 1969, § 1.110; Code 1982, § 1-25) 
Sec. 1-26. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1969, § 1.107; Code 1982, § 1-26) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions as to statutes, 5 ILCS 70/1.31. 
Sec. 1-27. - Summary report; tape recording retention. 
    The chairman shall prepare a summary report to be filed with the mayor and board of trustees summarizing the evidence, the findings of fact, if any, and reporting the roll-call vote on any motions made at the conclusion of a hearing, whether said vote was a recommending vote or a final action. The tape recordings of all meetings shall be held for a minimum of three years from the date of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 86-037, § 1, 12-16-1986) 
Sec. 1-28. - Fees; schedule. 
    Fees for permits, licenses, and other village services shall be as established from time to time by resolution or ordinance, as required by law, of the board of trustees and set forth in the separate fee schedule adopted and maintained by the village. A copy of the fee schedule is available for inspection and copying in the village clerk's office. 
Sec. 1-29. - Official time. 
    The official time within the village shall be central standard time, except that from 2:00 a.m. on the last Sunday in April in each year (or such other date as may be established in the state for the beginning and ending dates of daylight saving time) official time shall be advanced one hour and that at 2:00 a.m. on the last Sunday in October in each year (or such other date as may be established in the state for the beginning and ending dates of daylight saving time) the official time shall be, by the retarding of one hour, returned to central standard time. 
(Code 1969, § 2.102; Code 1982, § 2-5) 
State Law reference- Time Standardization Act, 5 ILCS 440/0.01 et seq. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal officers generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-5-5; boards of trustees, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Inspection of records. 
    All books, papers, vouchers, warrants, entries, accounts and memoranda of each and every officer and employee of the village may be examined at any time by the village president. The president and board of trustees may, by resolution, call upon any officer to make a report in writing on any subject matter which the board may designate in such resolution and within such time as the resolution prescribes. 
(Code 1969, § 2.106; Code 1982, § 2-15) 
Sec. 2-2. - Surrender of village property. 
    Every village officer or employee, upon the termination of his term or service for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his successor all property, books, records and effects which may be village property within five days after notice and request. 
(Code 1969, § 2.107; Code 1982, § 2-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-35. 
Sec. 2-3. - Insufficient funds or closed bank account charges; procedure. 
(a)  A fee in the amount of $40.00, or such amount as the village board may from time to time determine and set forth on a fee schedule maintained by the village clerk, will be assessed against any person who issues his check, draft, or remittance payable to the village which is returned to the paying bank or depository for insufficient funds or closed account. The obligation for which the dishonored instrument was issued shall become immediately due and payable. 
(b)  The maker of the dishonored instrument shall have five days after issuance of notice by the village to redeem the aforesaid instrument and pay the charge assessed. Notice shall be deemed issued when it is deposited in the U.S. mail, postage prepaid, in the city and addressed to the maker at its last known address. 
(c)  Failure of the maker of the dishonored instrument to redeem the instrument as provided in subsection (b) of this section will be the basis, at the village's option, for the imposition of other sanctions as provided by state statutes. 
(Code 1982, § 2-17; Ord. No. 632, § 1, 1-20-1981; Ord. No. 10-017, § 1, 7-20-2010; Ord. No. 18-023, § 2, 6-19-2018) 
Sec. 2-4. - Public records requests. 
(a)  The executive assistant to the village administrator is hereby designated as the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) officer to whom all initial requests for access to the records of the village are to be referred. Such requests are to be made at the offices of the executive assistant to the village administrator at 3141 Ridge Road, Lansing, Illinois, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday. In the event that the executive assistant to the village administrator is not available during the times described above, the executive assistant to the village administrator shall designate deputy FOIA officers to whom such initial requests are to be made. Except in instances when records are furnished immediately, the FOIA officer, or his designees, shall receive requests submitted to the village under the Freedom of Information Act, ensure that the village responds to requests in a timely fashion, and issue responses under the Act. The FOIA officer shall develop a list of documents or categories of records that the village shall immediately disclose upon request. 
(b)  Upon receiving a request for a public record, the FOIA officer shall: 
(1)  Note the date the village receives the written request; 
(2)  Compute the day on which the period for response will expire and make a notation of that date on the written request; 
(3)  Maintain an electronic or paper copy of a written request, including all documents submitted with the request until the request has been complied with or denied; and 
(4)  Create a file for the retention of the original request, a copy of the response, a record of written communications with the requester, and a copy of other communications. 
(c)  The FOIA officer and deputy FOIA officer shall, within six months after January 1, 2010, successfully complete an electronic training curriculum to be developed by the public access counselor of the State of Illinois and thereafter successfully complete an annual training program. Whenever a new freedom of information officer is designated by the village, that person shall successfully complete the electronic training curriculum within 30 days after assuming the position. 
(d)  Any records which are the subject of a request under the Freedom of Information Act shall be retrieved from such place as they are stored, by the FOIA officer, or by an employee of the village acting under the direction of the FOIA officer. In no event shall records be retrieved by the party requesting them or by any person who is not employed by the village. 
(e)  If copies of records are requested, the fees for such copies, whether certified or not, shall be as determined from time to time by the FOIA officer pursuant to Section 6(b) of the Freedom of Information Act. The village clerk shall maintain a written schedule of current fees in the clerk's office. The fees so charged shall reflect the actual cost of copying the records, and the cost of certifying copies, if certification is requested. 
(f)  In the event that a request to inspect village records is denied by the FOIA officer, the denial may be appealed to the public access counselor of the State of Illinois. 
(g)  The village clerk shall prepare: 
(1)  A village information directory; 
(2)  A block diagram of the functional subdivisions of the village; 
(3)  A village records directory; and 
(4)  A records catalogue, all of which shall be substantially in the same form as the documents attached hereto and made a part hereof as Exhibits "A," "B," "C," and "D." This information shall also be posted on the Village's website. 
(Ord. No. 10-007, §§ 1-7, 4-20-2010; Ord. No. 13-025, § 1, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 2-5. - Identity protection policy. 
(a)  Policy adopted: The identity protection policy of the village is fully set forth in Exhibit "A" attached to Ord. No. 10-016 hereto and made a part hereof. 
(b)  Delegation of authority: Management and administrative responsibility for the identity protection program is hereby delegated to the village clerk, who under the delegation of the board of trustees shall establish written procedures for the operation of the identity protection policy program. 
(Ord. No. 10-016, §§ 1, 2, 7-20-2010) 
Editor's note- Exh. "A" to Ord. No. 10-016 is not set out herein but is available at the office of the village clerk. 
Secs. 2-6-2-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-11. - Oath of officers. 
    Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, all village officers shall take the oath of their office, as prescribed by law. Appointed officers shall subscribe their oath of office upon the back of their certificate of appointment. Said certificate of appointment, along with the oath of office, shall thereupon be filed with the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.103.2, 2.202, 2.303; Code 1982, § 2-1; Ord. No. 287, § 1, 5-1-1973; Ord. No. 426, § 1, 1-18-1977; Ord. No. 428, § 1, 2-15-1977) 
State Law reference- Oath of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25. 
Sec. 2-12. - Warrants, signatures. 
(a)  The authorized signers of village warrants are the president, village clerk and village treasurer. All village warrants drawn upon the village treasurer which are for $5,000.00 or less must be: 
(1)  Signed by two of the three authorized signers; 
(2)  State the particular fund; 
(3)  State the appropriation to which the warrant is chargeable; and 
(4)  State the person to whom payable. 
(b)  No money shall be paid other than upon such warrants, except as otherwise provided. 
(c)  The signatures required may be made by the use of an approved check-writing machine. 
(d)  All village warrants drawn upon the village treasurer which are greater than $5,000.00 must contain the signatures of the president, village clerk and village treasurer and must contain the actual signature of at least one of the above officers, in addition to complying with [subsections] (a)(3), (a)(4), (a)(5) and (b). 
    All bank depositories of village funds must be in the name of The Village of Lansing. Designated authorized signers are to be: the president, the village clerk and the village treasurer. 
(Code 1969, § 2.109; Code 1982, § 2-2; Ord. No. 15-034, § 1, 11-17-2015) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/8-1-8. 
Sec. 2-13. - Fiscal year. 
    The village fiscal year is hereby fixed and determined to commence on May 1 of each year and end on April 30 of each year, following. 
(Code 1969, § 2.101; Code 1982, § 2-3) 
State Law reference- Fiscal year defined, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2. 
Sec. 2-14. - Annual independent audit. 
    At the close of each fiscal year the president and board of trustees shall cause an independent audit of all village accounts to be made by an accountant licensed to practice under state law. 
(Code 1969, § 2.108; Code 1982, § 2-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/8-8-3. 
Sec. 2-15. - Fulltime positions. 
(a)  Created. The following fulltime appointive village offices are hereby created and established: 
(1)  Superintendent of public works; 
(2)  Superintendent of aviation. 
(b)  Appointment; term. The superintendent of public works and superintendent of aviation shall be appointed by the president by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees for a term of one year beginning May first and until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(c)  Removal. Removal shall be by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(d)  Vacancies. All vacancies in the fulltime village positions may be filled in the same manner as the original appointments. 
(Code 1982, §§ 2-6-2-9; Ord. No. 287, § 1, 5-1-1973; Ord. No. 85-009, § 2, 4-4-1985; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000; Ord. No. 13-023, § 1, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 2-16. - Parttime positions 
(a)  Created. The following parttime appointive village offices are hereby created and established: 
(1)  Village engineer; 
(2)  Village attorney; 
(3)  Village prosecutor; 
(4)  Village health officer. 
(b)  Appointment; term. The appointed officers created in subsection 2-16(a) shall be appointed by the president by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees for a term of one year beginning May first and until their successor is appointed and qualified. 
(c)  Removal. Removal shall be by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(d)  Vacancies. All vacancies in parttime village positions shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. 
(Code 1969, § 2.104; Code 1982, §§ 2-10-2-13; Ord. No. 287, § 1, 5-1-1973; Ord. No. 84-105, § 5, 8-7-1984; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000; Ord. No. 13-023, § 2, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 2-17. - Compensation. 
(a)  Salary. Unless otherwise specified in this Code, the salary as determined from time to time by the board of trustees of all officers and employees shall be paid as provided by resolution or ordinance of the president and board of trustees to each person entitled thereto. No officer, deputy to an officer, employee, inspector or person acting as a village representative shall retain any license fee, permit fee, inspection fee or compensation for any service in his capacity as such, for any thing, act or service required to be done or authorized by this Code. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(Code 1969, § 2.105; Code 1982, § 2-14; Ord. No. 04-034, § 4, 10-5-2004; Ord. No. 12-032, § 5, 9-18-2012) 
Editor's note- Section 5 of Ord. No. 12-032, adopted Sept, 18, 2012, states "Commencing May 1, 2013, and continuing thereafter, there shall be no automatic increase in the salaries of the village president (mayor), members of the board of trustees and village clerk, as was set forth in Ordinance 04-034, and shall include no cost of living or other increase or adjustment in the salaries of the village president (mayor), members of the board of trustees and village clerk." 
State Law reference- Compensation of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-50-5. 
Sec. 2-18. - Prevailing wages for workers engaged in public works construction. 
(a)  To the extent, and as required by the Prevailing Wage Act, 820 ILCS 130/1 et seq., (the "Act"), regulating the wages of laborers, mechanics and other workers employed in any public works by state, county, city or any public body or any political subdivision or by anyone under contract for public works, approved June 26, 1941, as amended. The general prevailing rate of wages in this locality for laborers, mechanics and other workers engaged in construction of public works coming under the village's jurisdiction is hereby ascertained to be the same as the prevailing rate of wages for construction in the Cook County area as determined by the state department of labor, as of June 1995, a copy of that determination being available for inspection in the village clerk's office. The definition of any terms appearing in this section that are also used in the aforesaid Act shall be the same as in such Act. Such general prevailing rate of wages shall, in the future, be the same as the prevailing rate of wages for construction work in the county, as determined from time to time by the state department of labor. 
(b)  Nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply such general prevailing rate of wages as herein ascertained to any work or employment, except village public works construction to the extent required by the aforesaid Act. 
(c)  The village clerk shall publicly post or keep available for inspection by any interested party in the village main office this determination of such prevailing rate of wage, as determined from time to time by the state department of labor. 
(d)  The village clerk shall mail a copy of this determination to any employer, and to any association of employers and to any person or association of employees who have filed their names and addresses, requesting copies of any determination stating the particular rates and the particular class of workers whose wages will be affected by such rates. 
(Code 1982, § 2-14.1; Ord. No. 90-019, §§ 1-4, 7-3-1990; Ord. No. 93-028, §§ 1-4, 6-15-1993; Ord. No. 95-015, §§ 1-4, 6-20-1995) 
Sec. 2-19. - Date elected officials take office. 
    The term of office for village elected officials shall begin at the first regular or special meeting after the county has completed its review and announced the election winners. 
(Code 1982, § 2-18; Ord. No. 648, § 1, 4-14-1981) 
Sec. 2-20. - Mourning period for deceased officials or village commission members; mourning bunting. 
(a)  A mourning period of seven days shall be observed whenever any past or present elected official or appointed member of any village commission dies. 
(b)  During this period, mourning bunting shall be draped over the entrance to the village municipal office. 
(Code 1982, § 2-19; Ord. No. 84-015, § 8, 8-7-1984) 
Sec. 2-21. - Employee Handbook adopted; conflicting provisions. 
(a)  The village hereby adopts the Employee Handbook attached to Ordinance No. 17-005 and made a part hereof as if set out fully herein. 
(b)  All ordinances or portions of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of the Employee Handbook are hereby amended to be in compliance with the provisions of the Employee Handbook. 
(Code 1982, § 2-20; Ord. No. 87-023, §§ 1, 2, 10-20-1987; Ord. No. 17-005, § 1, 3-7-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-005, § 1, adopted March 7, 2017, changed the title of § 2-21 from "Employee Personnel Policy Manual adopted; conflicting provisions" to read as herein set out. 
Secs. 2-22-2-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - APPOINTMENTS TO CITY OFFICES 

Sec. 2-26. - Authority. 
    Appointments to any office, board or commission for the village shall be made by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 2-26; Ord. No. 287, §§ 1, 8, 5-1-1973; Ord. No. 459, § 4, 12-6-1977; Ord. No. 538, § 1, 9-4-1979) 
Sec. 2-27. - Rejection; new appointee. 
    In the event that the village board fails or refuses to approve an appointee to the office, board or commission for which the appointee has been nominated, the village president shall submit a new appointee within 30 days for the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 2-27; Ord. No. 538, § 2, 9-4-1979) 
Sec. 2-28. - Nonapproved officers; time of service. 
    No person who has been appointed by the village president to any village office, board or commission, and whose appointment has not been approved by the board of trustees, shall serve in such office or receive any compensation for such office for more than 30 days after his appointment. 
(Code 1982, § 2-28; Ord. No. 538, § 3, 9-4-1979) 
Sec. 2-29. - Bonds required. 
    The village officers shall give bonds in the sums and within the times prescribed by law. In all cases not specifically provided for, the village officers shall give such bonds and within such time as the president and board of trustees may require, or as may be required by law. Should good cause exist in the judgment and discretion of the president and the board of trustees, any officer may be required, from time to time, to give additional bonds in such sum and within such time as the board may by resolution direct. 
(Code 1969, § 2.103.3; Code 1982, § 2-29) 
Sec. 2-30. - Licensed surety; conditions. 
    The bond of each officer shall be executed to the village with any responsible surety company licensed to do business in the state as surety thereon, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office and the payment to the proper officer of all moneys coming into his hands by virtue of his office. 
(Code 1969, § 2.103.3; Code 1982, § 2-30) 
Sec. 2-31. - Bond approval; filing. 
    All village officer bonds shall be subject to the approval of the president and board of trustees. Upon approval, the village clerk shall endorse thereon the date thereof and file the same in his office; except, however, the village clerk bond which shall be filed with the village treasurer. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.103.3, 2.402; Code 1982, § 2-31) 
Secs. 2-32-2-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESIDENCY OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 2-41. - Requirement; prior to term. 
    No person shall be eligible to hold any village office, unless he is a qualified elector of the village and has resided within the village at least one year prior to his election or appointment. Provided, however, that these requirements shall not apply to the village engineer, village attorney, village health officer or other village officers who require technical training or knowledge. 
(Code 1969, § 2.103; Code 1982, § 2-41) 
Sec. 2-42. - Requirement throughout term of office or length of employment; exceptions. 
    All employees, department heads, supervisory and administrative personnel and appointed officers including, but without limitation thereto, all police officers and firemen, are hereby required to reside with the village throughout their term of office or length of employment; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not be applicable to persons providing services on a limited contractual basis who are in the employ of another governmental unit or private organization, or to independent contractors or to the village engineer, village health officer, village attorney or to other such persons who require such specialized technical training or knowledge where so determined by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, §§ 2-42, 2-43; Ord. No. 425, § 1, 1-18-1977) 
Sec. 2-43. - Failure to comply. 
    Any employee, department head, supervisor, administrator or appointed officer, including, without limitation thereto, any police officer or fireman, who shall fail to comply with this division's provisions, shall be discharged from his position with the village; except that the president and board of trustees upon presentation to the village board may, where certain specific extenuating circumstances exist, waive the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1982, § 2-43; Ord. No. 425, § 2, 1-18-1977) 
Secs. 2-44-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INDEMNIFICATION OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 2-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Appointed official means any officer, member of a board, commission or committee whether or not compensated who has been appointed by the mayor or village corporate authorities. 
    Elected official means any official who is elected to an office in the village by the citizens of the village. 
    Injury means death, injury to a person or damage to or loss of property. The term "injury" also includes his person, reputation, character or estate which does not result from circumstances in which a privilege is otherwise conferred by law and which is of such a nature that it would be actionable if inflicted by a private person. 
    Public employee means an employee of the village. 
(Code 1982, § 2-51; Ord. No. 499, § 1, 11-21-1978) 
Sec. 2-52. - Against acts causing injury. 
    All elected and appointed village officials and public employees are hereby indemnified by the village for any and all suits, causes of actions, judgments, damages or other proceedings which may arise as a result of any act committed or omitted on the part of the officials or public employees within the scope of their employment which causes an injury 
(Code 1982, § 2-52; Ord. No. 499, § 1, 11-21-1978) 
Sec. 2-53. - Limitations; notice of civil action; dismissal. 
    The indemnification of elected and appointed officials and public employees does not alter the present statutory requirements: 
(1)  Limitations. To commence a civil action within two years from the date an injury was received or the cause of action accrued; 
(2)  Notice. To serve notice within one year from the date that the injury or case of action accrued; and 
(3)  Dismissal. The dismissal of a civil action for failure to serve such notice as required by 745 ILCS 10/8-101 through 10/8-103. 
(Code 1982, § 2-53; Ord. No. 499, § 1, 11-21-1978) 
State Law reference- Local Governmental and Governmental Employees Tort Immunity Act, 745 ILCS 10/1-101 et seq. 
Secs. 2-54-2-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PURCHASE OF IMPROVEMENTS AND SUPPLIES 

Sec. 2-66. - Bids not required-Approval. 
    Contracts for work, public improvement or supplies that exceed the cost of $20,000.00 may be entered into without advertising for bids if authorized by vote of two-thirds of all the trustees then holding office. 
(Code 1982, § 2-66; Ord. No. 477, § 2, 4-18-1978; Ord. No. 82-023, § 2(c), 8-17-1982; Ord. No. 86-002, § 1, 2-4-1986; Ord. No. 98-039, § 1, 12-15-1998; Ord. No. 05-024, § 1, 10-18-2005) 
Sec. 2-67. - Same-Certain components. 
    In the event that an item is to be purchased which is a specified component for a piece of equipment, or is the only kind or type that can be reasonably combined with existing equipment, the advertising for bids will not be required. 
(Code 1982, § 2-67; Ord. No. 477, § 2, 4-18-1978; Ord. No. 82-023, § 2(d), 8-17-1982) 
Sec. 2-68. - Bids required-Improvements. 
    Any work or other public improvement, the cost of which exceeds the sum of $20,000.00, shall be awarded by a contract to the lowest responsible bidder after advertising for bids. 
(Code 1982, § 2-68; Ord. No. 477, § 2, 4-18-1978; Ord. No. 82-023, § 2(a), 8-17-1982; Ord. No. 86-002, § 2, 2-4-1986; Ord. No. 98-039, § 1, 12-15-1998; Ord. No. 05-024, § 1, 10-18-2005) 
Sec. 2-69. - Same-Supplies. 
    Supplies needed for village use, the cost of which exceeds $20,000.00, shall be furnished by contract award to the lowest responsible bidder after advertising for bids. 
(Code 1982, § 2-69; Ord. No. 477, § 2, 4-18-1978; Ord. No. 82-023, § 2(b), 8-17-1982; Ord. No. 86-002, § 3, 2-4-1986; Ord. No. 98-039, § 1, 12-15-1998; Ord. No. 05-024, § 1, 10-18-2005) 
Sec. 2-70. - Procedure. 
(a)  The village clerk shall advertise for bids when so directed by either the village board or the mayor. All bids shall be returned to the village clerk's office at the date and time set forth in the advertisement. On the date set in the advertisement for the time and date of the bid opening, the clerk shall publicly open the bids at village hall and list the following: 
(1)  Name of the bidder; 
(2)  Item bid upon; 
(3)  Total cost; and 
(4)  Any other pertinent data. 
(b)  After the bids are opened, the clerk shall deliver the bids and list created in [subsection] (a) to the village administrator, who shall confer with the village engineer in the case of construction project bids, in order to prepare a recommendation to the president and village board. 
(Code 1982, § 2-70; Ord. No. 477, § 2, 4-18-1978; Ord. No. 82-023, § 2(f), 8-17-1982; Ord. No. 07-007, § 1, 2-20-2007; Ord. No. 11-025, § 1, 8-16-2011; Ord. No. 12-037, § 1, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 2-71. - Emergencies; finance committee's approval required. 
    Emergency purchases may be made or contracts entered into by village department heads in excess of $20,000.00 after receiving the finance committee's prior approval. 
(Code 1982, § 2-71; Ord. No. 477, § 2, 4-18-1978; Ord. No. 82-023, § 2(e), 8-17-1982; Ord. No. 86-002, § 4, 2-4-1986; Ord. No. 98-039, § 1, 12-15-1998; Ord. No. 05-024, § 1, 10-18-2005) 
Secs. 2-72-2-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SALE OF REAL PROPERTY 

Sec. 2-80. - Unnecessary property designation. 
    The president and board of trustees shall determine which village real property is no longer necessary, appropriate or in the best interest of the village to retain for municipal purposes. 
(Code 1982, § 2-80; Ord. No. 609, § 1, 7-15-1980) 
Sec. 2-81. - Elected or appointed official to negotiate and report offer. 
    The corporate authorities shall appoint either an elected or appointed official of the village to commence the negotiations for the sale or exchange of the municipal real property and to return to the president and board of trustees with an offer from a prospective purchaser or transferor. 
(Code 1982, § 2-81; Ord. No. 609, § 1, 7-15-1980) 
Sec. 2-82. - Board action. 
(a)  The corporate authorities at a regular meeting of the president and board of trustees shall determine the following: 
(1)  Whether or not the offer presented is the real property's fair market value; and 
(2)  The specific use of the real estate and any conditions with respect to the further use of the real estate as the corporate authorities may deem necessary and desirable to the public interest. 
(b)  After considering subsection (a) of this section, the corporate authorities shall either: 
(1)  Accept the offer, subject to any conditions it may impose, by a three-fourths' vote; or 
(2)  Reject the offer by a majority vote. 
(Code 1982, § 2-82; Ord. No. 609, § 1, 7-15-1980) 
Sec. 2-83. - Ordinance required. 
    When the sale or exchange of any municipal real estate is approved, an ordinance shall be prepared directing the sale or exchange of the real estate and shall include any provisions imposed by the corporate authorities. 
(Code 1982, § 2-83; Ord. No. 609, § 1, 7-15-1980) 
Sec. 2-84. - Conveyance. 
    When the ordinance required under this division has been adopted and the consideration paid or secured, the village president and the village clerk may convey the real estate and transfer it, by proper deed of conveyance, stating therein the consideration therefor, with the village seal attached thereto. 
(Code 1982, § 2-84; Ord. No. 609, § 1, 7-15-1980) 
Secs. 2-85-2-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VILLAGE PRESIDENT 

Sec. 2-101. - Chief executive. 
    The village president shall be the village chief executive officer. The position of village president may be his principal occupation and, if so, such village president shall devote regular working hours to this position. The village president may, however, elect to be a parttime village president within 60 days after being elected to the office of village president. 
(Code 1969, § 2.203.1; Code 1982, § 2-101; Ord. No. 426, § 2, 1-18-1977; Ord. No. 428, § 2, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 520, § 2, 5-1-1979) 
Sec. 2-102. - May be called mayor. 
    Pursuant to law, the president of the board of trustees may be referred to under the title of "mayor." 
(Code 1969, § 2.205; Code 1982, § 2-102) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2.1. 
Sec. 2-103. - Term; duties. 
(a)  The village president shall be elected for a four-year term. 
(b)  The village president shall serve according to the following: 
(1)  Until his successor has been elected and qualified; and 
(2)  Be the president of the board of trustees, as provided by statute. 
(Code 1969, § 2.201; Code 1982, § 2-103) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-5 and 5/3.1-35-5. 
Sec. 2-104. - Definitions; limitation; exceptions. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Candidate means an individual who seeks to be elected to public office and includes incumbents of that office. 
    Elected officials means the village president, village clerk and village trustees. 
    Resignation means the voluntary formal withdrawal as an elected public official. As defined in this section, the term "resignation" does not affect the term of office. 
    Successive term means one term that immediately follows a prior term. 
    Term of office means the four-year period for which elected. 
(b)  Limitation. Once a candidate has been elected to a term as village president, the candidate may not be reelected to more than one-successive term in that office. 
(c)  Exceptions. 
(1)  The limitation shall not apply to any unexpired term that an individual is appointed to fill. 
(2)  After being elected to two successive terms as village president, an individual may be elected to any other office in the village. 
(3)  An individual who does not run for village president after the second successive term may do the following: 
a.  Be appointed to fill the unexpired term of his successor in office. 
b.  Be a candidate for election to fill the unexpired term of his successor in office. 
c.  Be a candidate at the next regular municipal election for the office of village president and again be subject to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section. 
(Code 1982, § 2-103.1; Ord. No. 657, §§ 1, 4, 9-1-1981; Ord. No. 90-035, § 1, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 2-105. - Bond required. 
    Before entering upon the duties of the office, the village president shall give a bond with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees conditioned upon his faithful performance of his duties in the sum of $3,000.00. 
(Code 1969, § 2.202; Code 1982, § 2-104; Ord. No. 426, § 1, 1-18-1977; Ord. No. 428, § 1, 2-15-1977) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25. 
Sec. 2-106. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 12-032, adopted Sept. 18, 2012, repealed § 2-106, which pertained to salary-fulltime, and derived from the Code of 1969, § 2.202; the Code of 1982, § 2-105; Ord. No. 204, § 3, adopted April 1, 1969; Ord. No. 426, § 1, adopted Jan. 18, 1977; Ord. No. 428, § 1, adopted Feb. 15, 1977; Ord. No. 520, § 1, adopted May 1, 1979; Ord. No. 664, § 1, adopted Oct. 6, 1981; Ord. No. 88-036, § 1, adopted Dec. 20, 1988; Ord. No. 93-003, § 1(exh. A), adopted Jan. 19, 1993; and Ord. No. 04-034, § 1, adopted Oct. 5, 2004. 
Sec. 2-107. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 12-032, adopted Sept. 18, 2012, repealed § 2-107, which pertained to salary-change to parttime, and derived from the Code of 1982, § 2-106; and Ord. No. 428, § 1, adopted Feb. 15, 1977. 
Sec. 2-108. - Salary. 
    Following the election of the village president in April of 2017, the compensation of the village president shall be as follows: 
    The weekly salary of the village president (mayor) is hereby set at $1,000.00. In addition, the village president shall also receive compensation in the amount of $5,000.00 per annum for his or her duties as local liquor commissioner. The village president's compensation shall be payable in the same installments as all other employees. This compensation is intended to cover any expenses which may be incurred by the village president and the village president shall accordingly receive no expense reimbursement nor shall the village president be furnished with an automobile for his or her use. The village president shall not be eligible for, accrue, or upon departure, retirement or resignation be paid out for sick or vacation time. The village president shall not be eligible for health, dental or life insurance through the village. 
(Code 1969, § 2.202; Code 1982, § 2-107; Ord. No. 428, § 1, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 520, § 1, 5-1-1979; Ord. No. 664, § 1, 10-6-1981; Ord. No. 12-032, § 2, 9-18-2012; Ord. No. 16-004, § 1, 2-2-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-004, § 1, adopted Feb. 2, 2016, changed the title of § 2-108 from "Salary-part-time" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 2-109. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 12-032, adopted Sept. 18, 2012, repealed § 2-109, which pertained to salary-change to fulltime, and derived from the Code of 1982, § 2-108; and Ord. No. 428, § 1, adopted Feb. 15, 1977. 
Sec. 2-110. - Same-Illness; vacation. 
    Nothing in this article is intended to affect the village president's compensation should he be incapacitated through illness or accident, and nothing herein is intended to affect the village president's compensation during such periods of time as he is on vacation. 
(Code 1982, § 2-109; Ord. No. 428, § 1, 2-15-1977) 
Sec. 2-111. - General duties. 
    The village president shall perform all such duties as may be required of him by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1969, § 2.203.2; Code 1982, § 2-110) 
State Law reference- General duties of village president, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-5. 
Sec. 2-112. - Supervisor. 
    The village president shall supervise the conduct of all appointed officers and see that they faithfully and efficiently discharge the duties of their respective offices. 
(Code 1969, § 2.203.3; Code 1982, § 2-111) 
Sec. 2-113. - Delegation. 
    Whenever there is a question as to the respective powers or duties of any appointed officer of the village, this shall be settled by the village president; and he shall have the power to delegate to any such officer any duty that is to be performed when no specific officer has been directed to perform the duty. 
(Code 1969, § 2.204; Code 1982, § 2-112) 
Sec. 2-114. - Inspection power. 
    The village president shall have the power and authority to inspect and to examine all books, records and papers kept by any village officer, agent or employee at any reasonable time. 
(Code 1969, § 2.203.4; Code 1982, § 2-113) 
Sec. 2-115. - Inform board of trustees. 
    The village president shall from time to time give the board of trustees information relative to the village affairs as he may deem proper and may recommend for its consideration such measures as he believes expedient. 
(Code 1969, § 2.203.5; Code 1982, § 2-114) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-5. 
Sec. 2-116. - Vacancy. 
    In the event of a vacancy in the village president's office during the term thereof, the vacancy shall be filled for the remainder of the term as provided by law. Until a new president is elected and qualified, any acting president elected by the board of trustees shall be entitled to the same compensation provided in sections 2-106 through 2-110 and shall perform all the duties of the village president as provided by law and ordinances. 
(Code 1982, § 2-115; Ord. No. 426, § 4, 1-18-1977; Ord. No. 428, § 4, 2-15-1977) 
State Law reference- Vacancy in office of president, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-5. 
Sec. 2-117. - President pro tem. 
    During the village president's temporary absence or disability, the board of trustees shall elect one of its number to act as president pro tem, who during the president's absence or disability shall perform the duties pertaining to the office. The president pro tem shall receive compensation at the rate of $1,000.00 per month or such lesser proportionate amount as the number of days served to the total number of days in the month. The president pro tem shall also be reimbursed for all expenses incurred on the village's behalf. 
(Code 1969, § 2.206; Code 1982, § 2-116; Ord. No. 426, § 3, 1-18-1977; Ord. No. 428, § 3, 2-15-1977) 
Secs. 2-118-2-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES 

Sec. 2-130. - Established; election. 
    The board of trustees, consisting of six members, shall be elected to office for a four-year term, according to the method provided by statute. 
(Code 1969, § 2.301; Code 1982, § 2-131) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-50; Election Code, 10 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-131. - Definitions; limitation; exceptions. 
(a)  Definitions. The definitions in section 2-104(a) are applicable to this section. 
(b)  Limitation. Once a candidate has been elected to a term as village trustee, the candidate may not be reelected to more than one successive term in that office. 
(c)  Exceptions. 
(1)  The limitation shall not apply to any unexpired term that an individual is appointed to fill. 
(2)  After being elected to two successive terms as village trustee, an individual may be elected to any other office in the village. 
(3)  An individual who does not run for a village trustee office after the second successive term may: 
a.  Be appointed to fill the unexpired term of a successor in office. 
b.  Be a candidate for election to fill the unexpired term of a successor in office. 
c.  Be a candidate at the next regular municipal election for the office of village trustee and again be subject to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section. 
(4)  Notwithstanding any of the foregoing exceptions to the contrary, an individual may be a candidate for village trustee at an election for this office conducted two years after leaving the board of trustees following two successive terms. 
(Code 1982, § 2-131.1; Ord. No. 657, § 2, 9-1-1981; Ord. No. 90-035, § 2, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 2-132. - Annual compensation-Amount. 
    The members of the board of trustees shall receive annual compensation of $13,000.00, payable in the same installments as all other village employees. This compensation is intended to cover any expenses which may be incurred by a trustee and the trustees, accordingly, they shall not receive any expense reimbursement. Trustees shall not be eligible for, accrue, or upon departure, retirement or resignation be paid-out for, sick or vacation time. Trustees shall not be eligible for health, dental, or life insurance through the village. 
(Code 1969, § 2.303; Code 1982, § 2-132; Ord. No. 204, § 1, 4-1-1969; Ord. No. 664, § 2, 10-6-1981; Ord. No. 88-036, § 2, 12-20-1988; Ord. No. 04-034, § 2, 10-5-2004; Ord. No. 12-032, § 3, 9-18-2012) 
Sec. 2-133. - Same-Number of payments. 
    No trustee shall receive compensation for more than one meeting in each week. All trustees are permitted to receive compensation, as provided in this article, for up to two absences in each year. 
(Code 1982, § 2-133; Ord. No. 204, § 2, 4-1-1969) 
Sec. 2-134. - General duties. 
    The board of trustees shall be the legislative department of the village government and shall perform such duties and have such powers as may be delegated by statute. 
(Code 1969, § 2.302; Code 1982, § 2-134) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of board of trustees, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-5. 
Sec. 2-135. - Committees-Standing. 
    The following shall be the standing committees of the board of trustees: 
(1)  Finance and insurance; 
(2)  Public works; 
(3)  Youth center and LNN; 
(4)  Public safety; 
(5)  Aviation and economic development; 
(6)  Building and code enforcement. 
(Code 1969, § 2.313; Code 1982, § 2-135; Ord. No. 288, § 1, 5-1-1973; Ord. No. 85-009, § 3, 4-4-1985; Ord. No. 85-017, § 1, 5-21-1985; Ord. No. 89-009, § 1, 5-16-1989; Ord. No. 14-004, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 2-136. - Same-Special. 
    Special committees shall be created by the president and board of trustees from time to time as occasion and circumstances demand. 
(Code 1969, § 2.313; Code 1982, § 2-136; Ord. No. 288, § 1, 5-1-1973) 
Sec. 2-137. - Same-Membership. 
    All standing and special committees shall consist of two members of the board of trustees, one of whom shall be its chairman, and, in addition, the president shall be ex officio a member of each such committee. The members of said committees shall be appointed and the chairman designated by the president of the board of trustees after each municipal election. 
(Code 1969, § 2.313; Code 1982, § 2-137; Ord. No. 288, § 1, 5-1-1973; Ord. No. 85-017, § 2, 5-21-1985) 
Sec. 2-138. - Meetings-Regular. 
(a)  The regular meetings of the board shall be held on the first and third Tuesday of each calendar month, at 7:00 p.m., at the Lansing Municipal Court Complex at 2710 170th Street, Lansing, Illinois. There shall be no meeting on the first Tuesday during the months of January, July and August, unless otherwise called by the village president or board of trustees. 
(b)  After each regular meeting of the board, there shall be a committee of the whole meeting. 
(c)  Matters requiring extended deliberation may be listed on the regular agenda under new business or old business, as appropriate. However, no official action shall be taken on such items until it appears as an action item on a meeting agenda. 
(Code 1969, § 2.304.1; Code 1982, § 2-138; Ord. No. 626, § 1, 12-12-1980; Ord. No. 85-025, § 1, 8-6-1985; Ord. No. 90-002, § 1, 3-6-1990; Ord. No. 07-020, § 1, 6-19-2007; Ord. No. 12-023, §§ 1-4, 6-19-2012; Ord. No. 14-004, § 2, 3-18-2014; Ord. No. 15-041, § 1, 12-15-2015; Ord. No. 16-019, § 1, 5-3-2016; Ord. No. 18-003, § 2, 2-20-2018) 
Sec. 2-139. - Same-Special. 
    Special meetings of the president and board of trustees may be called by the president or any three trustees upon at least 24 hours' notice to all members and the president; provided, that, if all the trustees are present at a special meeting, no notice of the meeting shall be necessary and such notice shall be deemed waived. Public notice will be given as provided by law. 
(Code 1969, § 2.304.2; Code 1982, § 2-139) 
Sec. 2-140. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the president and board of trustees constitute a quorum to do business at a meeting. 
(Code 1969, § 2.312; Code 1982, § 2-140; Ord. No. 14-004, § 3, 3-18-2014) 
State Law reference- Quorum of city council, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-20; composition of board of trustees and manner of acting same as city councils, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-5. 
Sec. 2-141. - Presiding officer. 
    The village president shall be the presiding officer of all regular and special meetings of the board of trustees and at all times when the board meets as a Committee of the Whole. 
(Code 1969, § 2.305; Code 1982, § 2-141) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-5. 
Sec. 2-142. - Order of business. 
    The board of trustees' order of business shall be as follows: 
(1)  Roll call of members; 
(2)  Presentation of the minutes of the preceding meeting and approval thereof; 
(3)  Reports of village administrator, village attorney and village engineer; 
(4)  Reports of standing committees; 
(5)  Public comment; 
(6)  New business; 
(7)  Unfinished business. 
(Code 1969, § 2.306; Code 1982, § 2-142; Ord. No. 14-004, § 4, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 2-143. - Robert's Rules of Order. 
    The village president shall decide all questions of order and be governed in his decisions by parliamentary law as set forth in the Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. 
(Code 1969, § 2.311; Code 1982, § 2-143) 
Sec. 2-144. - Suspension of rules. 
    The rules of order, other than those prescribed by statute, may be suspended at any time by the consent of a majority of the members present at any meeting. 
(Code 1969, § 2.310; Code 1982, § 2-144) 
Sec. 2-145. - Addressing meetings. 
    No person other than the president or a member of the board shall address that body at any regular or special meeting, except upon consent of a majority of the members present. 
(Code 1969, § 2.309; Code 1982, § 2-145) 
Sec. 2-146. - Disturbing meetings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any meeting of the board of trustees or any committee thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 2.315; Code 1982, § 2-146) 
State Law reference- Municipal power to prevent or suppress disturbances, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-2. 
Sec. 2-147. - Voting. 
(a)  The passage of all ordinances for whatever purpose, and of all resolutions or motions which are of the following type shall require the concurrence of a majority of all members elected to the board of trustees, including the village president, unless otherwise expressly provided by any applicable law governing the passage of any ordinance, resolution or motion: 
(1)  Create any liability against the village; or 
(2)  Provide for the expenditure or appropriation of its money. 
(b)  The passage of any ordinance, resolution or motion to sell any village property shall require the concurrence of two-thirds of all village trustees elected, or as otherwise provided by statute. 
(c)  Yeas and nays shall be taken on the question of the passage of the designated ordinances, resolutions or motions and recorded in the journal of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 2.316; Code 1982, § 2-147) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-5. 
Sec. 2-148. - Bills against the village. 
    No bill against the village shall be approved by the board of trustees for payment until it has first been examined by the finance committee. 
(Code 1969, § 2.314; Code 1982, § 2-148) 
Sec. 2-149. - Ordinance procedure. 
(a)  All of the resolutions and motions which: 
(1)  Create any liability against the village; 
(2)  Provide for the expenditure or appropriation of its money; or 
(3)  Are for the sale of village property; 
and all ordinances passed by the board of trustees shall be deposited with the village clerk. 
(b)  If the president approves of them, he shall sign them. 
(c)  The ordinances, resolutions or motions of which the president disapproves shall be returned to the board, with his written objections, at the next regular meeting of the board occurring not less than five days after their passage. 
(d)  The president may disapprove of any one or more sums appropriated in any ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation, and if so, the remainder shall be effective. The president may disapprove entirely of an ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation. 
(e)  If the president fails to return any ordinance or any specified resolution or motion with his written objections, within the designated time, it shall become effective despite the absence of his signature. 
(Code 1969, § 2.317; Code 1982, § 2-149) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-5. 
Sec. 2-150. - Passage over veto. 
    Every resolution and motion, specified in section 2-149, and every ordinance, which is returned to the board of trustees by the president, shall be reconsidered by the board at the next regular meeting. If, after such reconsideration, two-thirds of all the trustees elected to the board shall agree at such regular meeting to pass an ordinance, resolution or motion, notwithstanding the president's refusal to approve it, then it shall be effective. The vote on the question of passage over the president's veto shall be by yeas and nays, and shall be recorded in the board of trustees' journal. 
(Code 1969, § 2.318; Code 1982, § 2-150) 
State Law reference- Similar provision applicable to board of trustees, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-45. 
Sec. 2-151. - Resolutions. 
    Any resolutions submitted to the board of trustees shall be reduced to writing before being voted upon on request of any two members of the board. 
(Code 1969, § 2.308; Code 1982, § 2-151) 
Sec. 2-152. - Rescinded action. 
    No vote or action of the board of trustees shall be rescinded at any board of trustees' special meeting, unless there are present at such special meeting as many board members as were present at the meeting when such vote or action was taken. 
(Code 1969, § 2.307; Code 1982, § 2-152)
