State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-5. 
Secs. 2-153-2-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - VILLAGE CLERK[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Election of village clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-90; duties of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 

Sec. 2-166. - Bond required. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his office, the clerk shall execute a bond with good and sufficient surety to be approved by the board of trustees, payable to the village in the sum of $10,000.00, or in the sum as required by statute, whichever is lower, conditioned for the faithful and proper performance of the duties of his office; a full and correct account of all moneys received by him, and the payment of said moneys by him according to law and the ordinances of said village. 
(Code 1969, § 2.402; Code 1982, § 2-166) 
State Law reference- Bond of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30. 
Sec. 2-167. - Ex officio collector. 
    The clerk shall act as and perform all the duties of collector, unless and until a separate collector is appointed. As of May 7, 2013, the village treasurer is appointed the collector. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.404, 2.902; Code 1982, § 2-167; Ord. No. 13-023, § 3, 5-7-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority for ex officio collector, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-15. 
Sec. 2-168. - Salary. 
    The village clerk shall receive annual compensation in the amount of $45,000.00 payable in the same installments as all other village employees. This compensation is intended to cover any expenses which may be incurred by the village clerk and the village clerk, accordingly, shall not receive any expense reimbursement. In addition, the village clerk, when acting as village collector, shall receive additional compensation in the amount of $15,000.00 representing the annual compensation due the village collector. The village clerk shall not be furnished an automobile for his or her use. Upon departure, retirement or resignation, the village clerk shall not be eligible for the pay-out of any unused sick or vacation time. If the clerk functions as a full-time employee, he or she is eligible for health and dental insurance benefits in the same manner as all other nonunion employees. 
(Code 1982, § 2-168; Ord. No. 204, § 4, 4-1-1969; Ord. No. 88-036, § 3, 12-20-1988; Ord. No. 93-003, § 2(exh. A), 1-19-1993; Ord. No. 04-034, § 3, 10-5-2004; Ord. No. 12-032, § 4, 9-18-2012) 
State Law reference- Compensation of municipal officers fixed by ordinance, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-50-5. 
Sec. 2-169. - General duties. 
    The village clerk shall, in addition to the duties as may be required by statute or ordinance, perform the duties required by this article. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403; Code 1982, § 2-169) 
Sec. 2-170. - Maintain files. 
    The clerk shall maintain proper files for the correspondence filed in his office. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.12; Code 1982, § 2-170) 
Sec. 2-171. - List of officers. 
    The clerk shall keep on file in his office a list of all village officers, whether elected or appointed, giving their full names, addresses, title of office, date of election or appointment and term of office. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.10; Code 1982, § 2-171) 
Sec. 2-172. - Notice to persons elected and appointed. 
    Within five days after the result of any election is declared or appointment is made, the clerk shall notify all persons elected or appointed to any village office of his election or appointment. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.10; Code 1982, § 2-172) 
Sec. 2-173. - Custodian of documents. 
    The clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the village that are not assigned to the custody of some other officer. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.7; Code 1982, § 2-173) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
Sec. 2-174. - Indices. 
    The clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records filed with, or kept by him, so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.403.8, 2.403.12; Code 1982, § 2-174) 
Sec. 2-175. - Seal. 
    The clerk shall be the village seal custodian, and shall affix its impression on documents whenever required. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.6; Code 1982, § 2-175) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
Sec. 2-176. - Records. 
    In addition to the record of ordinances and other records which the clerk is required by statute to keep, he shall also keep the following: 
(1)  A register of all licenses and permits issued and the payments thereon; 
(2)  A record showing all village officers and regular employees; and 
(3)  Such other records as may be required by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.4; Code 1982, § 2-176) 
State Law reference- Record of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-5. 
Sec. 2-177. - Notices. 
    The clerk shall issue notices of special meetings of the president and board of trustees and shall issue notice to all persons whose attendance is required at any meeting of the president and board of trustees, or any committee thereof and provide for public notice as required by law. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.2; Code 1982, § 2-177) 
Sec. 2-178. - Attendance at meetings. 
    The clerk shall attend all meetings of the president and board of trustees and shall keep a full record of its proceedings in the journal. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.3; Code 1982, § 2-178) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
Sec. 2-179. - Publication of ordinances. 
    The clerk shall arrange for the publication of those ordinances where publication is required. If, at any time there is no newspaper published in the village, he shall then arrange for the posting of those ordinances which require posting, unless another method of publication is authorized by statute and approved by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.9; Code 1982, § 2-179) 
State Law reference- Publication of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-4. 
Sec. 2-180. - Signatures. 
    The village clerk shall seal and attest to all village contracts and all licenses, permits and such other documents as shall require this formality. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.1; Code 1982, § 2-180) 
Sec. 2-181. - Copies. 
    The clerk shall make copies of all ordinances, resolutions and other papers duly filed in his office and transcripts of the journals and other records and files of this office certified by him under the corporate seal, and furnish such copies to any of the trustees or officers of the village without the payment of any fee therefor. He shall deliver a certified copy of any ordinance or resolution to any other person upon the payment to him of a fee in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk per page, whichever is greater. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.5; Code 1982, § 2-181; Ord. No. 628, § 1, 12-30-1980) 
State Law reference- Copies certified by clerk used as evidence in court, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
Sec. 2-182. - Accounts. 
    The clerk shall keep accounts showing all moneys received by him and the source and disposition thereof; and such other accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.14; Code 1982, § 2-182) 
Sec. 2-183. - Deposit and disposition of monies. 
    The clerk shall maintain a checking account under his official title and not in his individual name. Upon application in writing by him to the president and board of trustees, that body shall designate by ordinance a place of deposit for all monies received by the clerk, and the clerk shall thereupon be discharged from responsibility for all such monies deposited in the designated depository. The clerk shall deliver and pay to the village treasurer all monies received by him at intervals of every two weeks, together with a statement showing the sources from which said monies were received. The clerk may, if he so desires or deems it necessary, account to the treasurer as aforesaid at more frequent intervals. 
(Code 1969, § 2.403.13; Code 1982, § 2-183) 
State Law reference- Municipal depository, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-50. 
Sec. 2-184. - Term. 
    The village clerk's term shall be in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-5 and 65 ILCS 5/3.12-25-90. 
(Code 1969, § 2.401; Code 1982, § 2-184) 
State Law reference- Term of village clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-5 and 65 ILCS 5/3.12-25-90. 
Sec. 2-185. - Definitions; limitation; exceptions. 
(a)  Definitions. The definitions in section 2-104(a) are applicable to this section. 
(b)  Limitation. Once a candidate has been elected to a term as village clerk, the candidate may not be reelected to more than one successive term in that office. 
(c)  Exceptions. 
(1)  The limitation shall not apply to any unexpired term that an individual is appointed to fill. 
(2)  After having been elected to two successive terms as village clerk, an individual may be elected to any other elected office in the village. 
(3)  An individual who does not run for the office of village clerk after his second successive term may: 
a.  Be appointed to fill the unexpired term of his successor in office. 
b.  Be a candidate for election to fill the unexpired term of his successor in office. 
c.  Be a candidate at the next regular municipal election for the office of village clerk and again be subject to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section. 
(Code 1982, § 2-184.1; Ord. No. 657, § 3, 9-1-1981; Ord. No. 90-035, § 3, 12-18-1990) 
Sec. 2-186. - Vacancies. 
    In case the office of village clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the president and board of trustees shall appoint an acting clerk as provided by statute. 
(Code 1969, § 2.405; Code 1982, § 2-185) 
Sec. 2-187. - Deputy clerk-Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of deputy clerk. The finance clerk supervisor is appointed the deputy clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 2.406; Code 1982, § 2-186; Ord. No. 13-023, § 4, 5-7-2013; Ord. No. 18-017, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
State Law reference- Deputy clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-10 and 5/3.1-35-95. 
Sec. 2-188. - Same-Duties; signature; seal. 
(a)  The deputy clerk shall have the power and duty to execute all documents required by any law or ordinance to be executed by the clerk, and to affix the village seal thereto, whenever required. 
(b)  When signing any documents the deputy clerk shall sign the name of the village clerk followed by the word "by" and the deputy clerk's own name and the words "deputy clerk." 
(Code 1969, § 2.406; Code 1982, § 2-187; Ord. No. 13-023, § 5, 5-7-2013) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-10 and 5/3.1-35-95. 
Sec. 2-189. - Same-General power. 
    The deputy clerk shall have the authority and power described in this article, and such further power and authority as may be provided by statute. 
(Code 1969, § 2.406; Code 1982, § 2-188) 
Sec. 2-190. - Same-When duties exercised. 
    The powers and duties described in sections 2-187 and 2-188 shall be exercised by the deputy clerk only in the village clerk's absence from his office, and only when either written direction has been given by the village clerk to such deputy to exercise such power, or the board of trustees has determined by resolution that the village clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform such function. 
(Code 1969, § 2.406; Code 1982, § 2-189) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-95. 
Secs. 2-191-2-210. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sections 6-10 of Ord. No. 13-023, adopted May 7, 2013, repealed §§ 2-191-2-195, which pertained to personnel; applicant qualifications; employment exceptions; authority to dismiss personnel; notice of dismissal required; and derived from the Code of 1982, §§ 2-190-2-194; and Ord. No. 569, § 1, adopted Jan. 22, 1980. 
ARTICLE VIII. - VILLAGE ATTORNEY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Village attorney exempt from residence and registration requirements, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-5. 

Sec. 2-211. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of village attorney, which office shall be subject to the provisions of sections 2-11 through 2-13. 
(Code 1969, § 2.501; Code 1982, § 2-211; Ord. No. 287, § 2, 5-1-1973) 
Sec. 2-212. - General duties. 
    The village attorney shall be the village legal advisor, and shall render advice and opinions on all legal questions affecting the village whenever requested to do so by the president and board of trustees, or by such other village official as the village president may direct. 
(Code 1969, § 2.502; Code 1982, § 2-212) 
Sec. 2-213. - Ordinances and documents. 
    It shall be the village attorney's duty to draft or supervise the phraseology of any contract, lease or other documents or instruments in which the village may be a party, and upon request of the board of trustees to draft ordinances covering any subject within the village's power. 
(Code 1969, § 2.505; Code 1982, § 2-213) 
Sec. 2-214. - Representation. 
(a)  The village attorney shall represent the village in all suits or actions at law or in equity to which the village may be a party or in which it may be interested, or which may be brought against or by any village officer on the village's behalf, or in the capacity of such person as an village officer, except those matters which have been referred to the village prosecutor in accordance with article IX of this chapter, creating the office of village prosecutor. 
(b)  It shall be the village attorney's duty to see to the full enforcement of all judgments or decrees entered in favor of the village and all similar interlocutory orders. 
(Code 1969, § 2.503; Code 1982, § 2-214) 
Sec. 2-215. - Special assessments; condemnation. 
    It shall be the village attorney's duty to see to the completion of all special assessment proceedings and condemnation proceedings. 
(Code 1969, § 2.504; Code 1982, § 2-215) 
Sec. 2-216. - Written opinions. 
    Upon request by the president or by the board of trustees, the village attorney shall reduce his legal opinion to writing. 
(Code 1969, § 2.502; Code 1982, § 2-216) 
Sec. 2-217. - Other duties. 
    The village attorney shall perform such other legal duties as shall be assigned to him by the president or by the board of trustees from time to time. 
(Code 1969, § 2.502; Code 1982, § 2-217) 
Secs. 2-218-2-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - VILLAGE PROSECUTOR[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Appointment of necessary village officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5. 

Sec. 2-231. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of village prosecutor, which office shall be subject to the provisions of sections 2-11 through 2-13. 
(Code 1969, § 2.601; Code 1982, § 2-231; Ord. No. 287, § 3, 5-1-1973; Ord. No. 438, § 1, 4-26-1977) 
Sec. 2-232. - General duties. 
    The village prosecutor shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  Village. Prosecute all violations of village ordinances before the presiding judge or magistrate of the circuit court; 
(2)  State. Prosecute all violations of state statutes when the arrest has been made by a village police officer when the state's attorney does not prosecute such violations. 
(Code 1969, § 2.602; Code 1982, § 2-232; Ord. No. 438, § 1, 4-26-1977) 
Secs. 2-233-2-245. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - VILLAGE TREASURER 

Sec. 2-246. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of village treasurer. 
(Code 1969, § 2.701; Code 1982, § 2-246; Ord. No. 287, § 4, 5-1-1973; Ord. No. 84-015, § 6, 8-7-1984) 
Sec. 2-247. - Bond required. 
    The treasurer shall give a bond before entering upon the duties of his office in the sum required by the board of trustees, but the bond shall not be less than that required by statute. The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance by the treasurer of his duties of office, and to indemnify the village for any loss due to any neglect of duty or wrongful act on the part of the treasurer. 
(Code 1969, § 2.702; Code 1982, § 2-247) 
Sec. 2-248. - General duties. 
    The treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by this Code, statute or ordinance. He shall receive all money paid into the village, whether directly from the person paying the money or from the hands of such other officer or employee as may receive it, and he shall pay out money only on vouchers or orders properly signed as described in section 2-12 of this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 2.703; Code 1982, § 2-248; Ord. No. 15-035, § 1, 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 2-249. - Maintain accounts. 
    The treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by the board of trustees and shall keep them in the manner required by law. 
(Code 1969, § 2.706; Code 1982, § 2-249) 
Sec. 2-250. - Maintenance of records. 
    The treasurer shall keep records showing all moneys received by him, showing the source and the purpose for which paid. He shall keep records at all times showing the village's financial status, in such manner as required by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 2.705; Code 1982, § 2-250) 
Sec. 2-251. - Deposits. 
    The treasurer shall deposit the village funds in such depositories as may be selected from time to time as provided by law; and he shall keep the deposit of the village money separate and distinct from his own money, and shall not intermingle his own money with it or make private or personal use of any village money. 
(Code 1969, § 2.704; Code 1982, § 2-251) 
Sec. 2-252. - Register of warrants. 
    The treasurer shall keep a register of all warrants, bonds or orders filed with him or paid by him, and all vouchers, as is required by statute. 
(Code 1969, § 2.708; Code 1982, § 2-252) 
Sec. 2-253. - Reports. 
(a)  Monthly. The treasurer shall make and file monthly reports with the board of trustees showing the following: 
(1)  The state of village finances; and 
(2)  The amounts received and spent during the month. 
(b)  Annually. The treasurer shall make an annual report at the close of the fiscal year including the following: 
(1)  The total amount of all village receipts and expenditures; and 
(2)  His transactions during the preceding year. 
(Code 1969, § 2.707; Code 1982, § 2-253) 
Secs. 2-254-2-265. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - VILLAGE COLLECTOR 

Sec. 2-266. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of village collector. 
(Code 1969, § 2.901; Code 1982, § 2-266; Ord. No. 287, § 6, 5-1-1973) 
Sec. 2-267. - General duties. 
    It shall be the village collector's duty to collect and receive all moneys due on special assessments and special taxes that are not paid directly to the treasurer, and to keep such records pertaining to such collections as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1969, § 2.903; Code 1982, § 2-267) 
Sec. 2-268. - Reports 
(a)  Generally. The collector shall make such reports regarding delinquent special assessments as are required by statute, and shall make a monthly report to the board of trustees, showing what moneys have been received and the source thereof. 
(b)  Annually. The collector shall make an annual report, during the last month of the fiscal year, showing all the activities of his office. 
(Code 1969, § 2.904; Code 1982, §§ 2-268, 2-269) 
Secs. 2-269-2-287. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - DEPARTMENTS 

Sec. 2-288. - Establishment. 
    The following departments and the following heads thereof are hereby established for the village: 
(1)  Department of police; chief of police. 
(2)  Department of fire; fire chief. 
(3)  Department of public works; superintendent of public works. 
(4)  Department of health; health officer. 
(5)  Airport department; airport manager. 
(6)  Legal department; village attorney. 
(7)  Planning and development department; director of planning and development. 
(8)  Building department; building commissioner. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1001; Code 1982, § 2-281; Ord. No. 90-031, § 1, 10-16-1990; Ord. No. 93-029, § 1, 6-15-1993) 
Sec. 2-289. - Department of public works. 
    The department of public works shall consist of the following: 
(1)  The superintendent of public works; 
(2)  The village engineer; 
(3)  A mechanical and custodial force comprising artificers, storekeepers and janitors; 
(4)  A permanent labor force for outside maintenance and repair work; and 
(5)  Such other personnel as may be provided for by the president and board of trustees from time to time. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1002.1; Code 1982, § 2-282; Ord. No. 90-031, § 2, 10-16-1990) 
Sec. 2-290. - Superintendent of public works. 
(a)  Office created; appointment; term. There is hereby created the office of superintendent of public works. The superintendent of public works shall be appointed by the president by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees for a term of one year beginning May first and until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(b)  General duties. The superintendent of public works shall have control and supervision over all officers and employees assigned to the department, subject to the village president's control, and shall be responsible for the faithful and efficient conduct of the department. 
(c)  Public property. The superintendent of public works shall have charge of and supervision over all village public property, including all streets, parkways, sidewalks, municipal buildings and all other village property not specifically assigned to some other officer. 
(d)  Equipment. The superintendent of public works shall have charge of, and responsibility for, the condition of all motor vehicles, trucks and other equipment of the village; and of all buildings or places in which the same are housed or kept. And he shall have charge of all radio equipment owned or operated by the village, except police and fire department radio equipment. 
(e)  Construction, repairs, maintenance. All construction, repair or extension of any pavement, building, sewer or lighting system, water mains and any appurtenances thereto and all other construction, repair or maintenance work conducted by the village shall be done by or under the supervision of the superintendent of public works, unless specific direction to the contrary is made by the board of trustees. 
(f)  Utilities; drainage. The superintendent of public works shall have charge of, and responsibility for, the care, maintenance and operation of the village water distribution system; the sanitary sewer system and disposal plant; the streetlighting system and the drainage of all streets and sidewalks. 
(g)  Solid waste. The superintendent of public works shall have charge of the collection and disposal of garbage and refuse. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.1002.2, 2.1002.3; Code 1982, §§ 2-283-2-289; Ord. No. 287, § 8, 5-1-1973; Ord. No. 459, § 4, 12-6-1977; Ord. No. 13-023, § 11, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 2-291. - Engineer. 
(a)  Office created. There is hereby created the office of village engineer, which office shall be subject to the provisions of sections 2-11 through 2-13. 
(b)  Registered. No person shall be appointed village engineer, unless such person is registered under the provisions of The Professional Engineering Practice Act of 1989 (225 ILCS 325/1 et seq.), as heretofore and hereafter amended. 
(c)  General duties. 
(1)  Advise. The village engineer shall advise the board of trustees and village officials on all engineering matters referred to him and shall perform such duties as are provided by law or ordinance, and in addition thereto, such other duties as from to time may be imposed upon him by the board of trustees or by the village president. 
(2)  Reports. He shall make reports from time to time, as required by the board of trustees, regarding public improvements, repairs of streets, bridges and sidewalks or such other work as the board of trustees may request, and shall make such suggestions regarding the same, as shall in his judgment, seem best and proper. 
(d)  Maps, plats, records. The village engineer shall have custody of official certified copies of the village plan; plats of dedication; other documents establishing official grades and alignments of public streets, sanitary sewers and storm drains; records of all public works, lands or property owned by the village; and of the zoning map. 
(e)  Advising plan commission. The village engineer shall furnish engineering advice in writing to the village plan commission whenever requested to do so by the chairman of the plan commission; or in the event that he finds himself unable to do so in a particular instance, he shall recommend a competent source for the required advice. 
(f)  Specifications for construction, materials or equipment. It shall be the duty of the village engineer to prepare specifications for the performance of any construction work, or for the purchase of any materials of construction or mechanical equipment, whenever it is proposed that the village should advertise for bids to contract for the same; or in the event specifications for construction, materials or equipment are prepared by another, the superintendent of public works shall make his written recommendations thereon before bids are requested. Whenever the village becomes a party to any such contract, the superintendent of public works shall make inspections as necessary to ensure the contractor's compliance with specifications. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.1002.41-2.1002.43; Code 1982, §§ 2-290-2-295; Ord. No. 287, § 7, 5-1-1973) 
Sec. 2-292. - Director of planning and development. 
(a)  Office created; appointment; term. There is hereby created the office of director of planning and development. The director of planning and development shall be appointed by the president by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees for a term of one year beginning May first and until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(b)  General duties. The director of planning and development shall be responsible for the village planning and development functions, which would include, but is not be limited to, promoting and working with new development, applications for grants and other related functions as may be assigned by the mayor or the board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, §§ 2-296, 2-297; Ord. No. 90-031, §§ 3, 4, 10-16-1990; Ord. No. 93-029, § 2, 6-15-1993; Ord. No. 13-023, § 12, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 2-293. - Building commissioner. 
(a)  Office created; appointment; term. There is hereby created the office of building commissioner. The building commissioner shall be appointed by the president by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees for a term of one year beginning May first and until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(b)  General duties. The building commissioner shall have direct control and supervision of the building department, plumbing inspector, electrical inspector and all other inspectors, the code enforcement officer and other related staff. 
(Code 1982, §§ 2-298, 2-299; Ord. No. 93-029, §§ 3, 4, 6-15-1993; Ord. No. 13-023, § 13, 5-7-2013) 
Secs. 2-294-2-304. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-305-2-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Board of fire and police commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-311. - Created. 
    There is hereby created for the village a board of fire and police commissioners. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1101; Code 1982, § 2-311) 
Sec. 2-312. - Appointments. 
    The president, with the consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint the members of the board of fire and police commissioners. The board shall consist of five members, and each member's term shall be for a period of five years, with a term ending each year so as to be staggered. The members shall serve until their respective successors are appointed and have qualified, except as provided in section 2-313. No such appointment, however, shall be made by any president within 30 days before the expiration of his term of office, and no more than three members of the board shall belong to the same state or national political party. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1102; Code 1982, § 2-312; Ord. No. 85-037, § 1, 12-3-1985) 
Sec. 2-313. - Qualifications, oath, bond, removal. 
    The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall possess the qualifications required of other village officers, shall take an oath or affirmation of office and shall give bond in the same manner as other village appointive officers. Members of the board shall be subject to the removal from office as such other officers and as provided by law. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1104; Code 1982, § 2-313) 
Sec. 2-314. - Secretary; duties. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners may employ a secretary or may designate one of its own members to act as such. The secretary shall keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, shall be custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of the board, shall keep a record of all examinations held and shall perform such other duties as the board shall prescribe and as set forth by statute. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1105; Code 1982, § 2-314) 
Sec. 2-315. - Statutory powers and duties. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall have the rights and powers and be subject to the duties provided by state statutes and subject to the duties reserved to the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1107; Code 1982, § 2-315) 
Sec. 2-316. - Appointment of police and fire employees. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers and members of police and fire departments, except the chief of police, fire chief and police and fire deputy chiefs. The board of fire and police commissioners shall prepare all eligibility lists for original appointment and promotions and shall contract with outside agencies to assist in the conduct of written examinations and oral interviews. All appointments by the board of fire and police commissioners to the police department or fire department, other than that of the lowest rank, shall be from the rank next below that to which the appointment is made. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1106; Code 1982, § 2-316; Ord. No. 90-004, § 3, 3-20-1990; Ord. No. 13-023, § 14, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 2-317. - Annual report. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall, on or before the last regular meeting of the village board in each year, make to the president, to be by him transmitted to the village board, a report of its actions and duties, rules in force and the practical effect thereof, and may in such report make such suggestions as the board believes will result in the greater efficiency of the police department and the fire department. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1108; Code 1982, § 2-317) 
Secs. 2-318-2-325. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BOARD OF HEALTH[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal board of health authorized, 65 ILCS 5/11-16-1. 

Subdivision I. - Generally 

Sec. 2-326. - Created. 
    There is hereby created and established for the village a board of health. 
(Code 1969, § 12.101.1; Code 1982, § 14-16) 
Sec. 2-327. - Composition. 
    The board of health shall consist of the president, who shall be ex officio president of the board of health, and the trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 12.101.1; Code 1982, § 14-17) 
Sec. 2-328. - Meetings. 
    The board of health shall meet at such times and places as it may determine. 
(Code 1969, § 12.101.2; Code 1982, § 14-18) 
Sec. 2-329. - Powers and duties-Generally. 
    The board of health shall have the power to make reasonable rules and regulations for the protection and betterment of the health of the village residents, for the abatement of nuisances to health and for the prevention and suppression of disease. Such rules and regulations shall take effect and be in force ten days after publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the village, except in cases of emergency as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1969, § 12.101.3; Code 1982, § 14-19) 
Sec. 2-330. - Same-Emergency. 
    In case of contagious or epidemic disease, or of danger from anticipated or impending contiguous or epidemic disease, or in cases where the village sanitary condition shall be so dangerous as to warrant it, it shall be the board of health's duty to make such rules and regulations, and to take such measures, and to do, order and cause to be done such acts for the preservation of the public health (though not specifically authorized) as it may in good faith believe and declare to be a public safety and health demand. All such rules and regulations declared by the board of health to be emergency rules and regulations, shall take effect immediately, or as soon as may be, after the promulgation of the same by said board of health. The said emergency rules and regulations shall also be published in such manner as the board of health shall determine, with notice that they are in force in the village. 
(Code 1969, § 12.101.3; Code 1982, § 14-20) 
Secs. 2-331-2-341. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Health Officer 

Sec. 2-342. - Parttime position. 
    The office of village health officer shall be subject to the provisions of sections 2-11 through 2-13 of this chapter. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.801, 12.102.1; Code 1982, § 14-31; Ord. No. 287, § 5, 5-1-1973) 
Sec. 2-343. - Qualifications. 
    The village health officer shall be a person trained or experienced in public health administration. 
(Code 1969, § 12.102.1; Code 1982, § 14-32) 
Sec. 2-344. - General powers and duties. 
(a)  The health officer shall be the enforcing officer for the board of health. 
(b)  It shall be the health officer's duty to perform the following functions: 
(1)  Execute and enforce all the sections of this chapter, village ordinances, state laws and the board of health's rules and regulations, relating to health; and 
(2)  To take such other action as is necessary for the promotion and improvement of the public health, not inconsistent with this chapter, statutes, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.802, 2.803, 12.102.2; Code 1982, § 14-33) 
Sec. 2-345. - Board of health's orders; attendance at meetings. 
    The health officer shall enforce all the board of health's orders and attend the meetings of said board when requested to do so by the presiding officer or the board. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.803, 12.102.3; Code 1982, § 14-34) 
Sec. 2-346. - Provide information and advice to board. 
    The health officer shall give to the board of health such information or advice as it may desire. 
(Code 1969, § 12.102.3; Code 1982, § 14-35) 
Sec. 2-347. - Inspections, etc. 
    It shall be the health officer's duty to make inspections of foodstuffs and of the premises used for storing or selling of provisions as may be provided by ordinance; and shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1969, § 2.802; Code 1982, § 14-36) 
Sec. 2-348. - Reports; recommendations. 
    The health officer shall make such reports to the board of trustees as may be required. He shall also make recommendations for rulings, orders or ordinances respecting the public health whenever he is requested to do so, or whenever he deems it necessary or advisable. 
(Code 1969, § 2.804; Code 1982, § 14-37) 
Secs. 2-349-2-361. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Board of local improvements, 65 ILCS 5/9-2-7 et seq. 

Sec. 2-362. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the board of local improvements for the village in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/9-2-7. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1301; Code 1982, § 2-331) 
Sec. 2-363. - Composition. 
    The board of local improvements for the village shall consist of the village president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1302; Code 1982, § 2-332) 
Sec. 2-364. - President. 
    The village president is hereby designated as president of the board of local improvements. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1303; Code 1982, § 2-333) 
Sec. 2-365. - Secretary. 
    The village clerk is hereby designated as the secretary of the board of local improvements. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1304; Code 1982, § 2-334) 
Sec. 2-366. - Meetings. 
(a)  The board of local improvements shall meet on the call of the president of the board of local improvements or any two members. Twenty-four hours' notice of such call shall be given each member; provided that, a meeting may be held when all members are present, without notice. Public notice shall be given by the secretary as required by law. 
(b)  If the meeting date falls on a holiday or if there is no quorum present, the board of local improvements shall meet on the next succeeding day. A special meeting may be called by the president of the board of local improvements in the same manner provided for calling special meetings of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1306; Code 1982, § 2-335) 
Sec. 2-367. - General duties. 
    The board of local improvements shall have the powers and perform the duties designated to it by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1305; Code 1982, § 2-336) 
Sec. 2-368. - Professional assistance-Authorized. 
    The board of local improvements is hereby given full authority to contract with and/or employ all necessary expert professional assistance, consisting of engineers, attorneys and public accountants for the purpose of assisting said board in the preparation and completion of any local improvements that the board shall institute. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1307.1; Code 1982, § 2-337) 
Sec. 2-369. - Same-Compensation. 
    The board of local improvements is herewith given full authority, by this village board, to perform the following: 
(1)  Provide for the payment of expert professional assistants aiding the board, either on: 
a.  A contingent fee basis, computed on the total costs of constructing local improvements; or 
b.  A per diem fee basis for the time expended. 
(2)  Request the board of trustees to make the necessary appropriations to the expert providing the professional assistance through village board warrants. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1307.2; Code 1982, § 2-338) 
Sec. 2-370-2-388. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - COMMISSION ON DISABILITIES 

Sec. 2-389. - Established. 
    There is established the Lansing Commission on Disabilities. 
(Code 1982, § 2-340; Ord. No. 92-011, § 1, 3-17-1992) 
Sec. 2-390. - Composition; terms; appointment. 
    The commission shall consist of seven members. Each member shall serve a two-year term. The commission members, the chairman and vice-chairman shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 2-341; Ord. No. 92-011, § 2, 3-17-1992) 
Sec. 2-391. - Meetings; records. 
(a)  The chairman shall call the commission's first meeting within 30 days of its creation and further meetings as needed shall be scheduled by the chairman with notice to the members. 
(b)  The members shall elect a secretary who shall keep minutes and records of the meetings. The village will assist the secretary with the mailing and copying of the minutes and notices. 
(c)  The vice-chairman shall conduct the meeting in the absence of the chairman. 
(Code 1982, § 2-342; Ord. No. 92-011, §§ 3-5, 3-17-1992) 
Sec. 2-392. - Duties. 
    The duties of the commission shall be to investigate, inquire and evaluate the current services, policies and practices of the village and to make written recommendations to the village board. 
(Code 1982, § 2-343; Ord. No. 92-011, § 6, 3-17-1992) 
Secs. 2-393-2-411. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - YOUTH COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-412. - Established. 
    There is hereby established and created the Lansing Youth Commission. 
(Code 1982, § 2-344; Ord. No. 97-004, § 1, 1-21-1997) 
Sec. 2-413. - Membership. 
(a)  The commission shall consist of nine members, including two members of the village board of trustees. The commission members, including the chairman and vice-chairman, shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the village board of trustees. 
(b)  The commission members, except for the village trustees, shall be appointed for four-year terms, subject to the fact that certain of the initial appointments shall be for a lesser period, in order to ensure an experienced membership and a smooth transition of appointments. 
(c)  The initial appointments shall be, as follows: 
(1)  One member appointed to serve until April 30, 1998. 
(2)  Two members appointed to serve until April 30, 1999. 
(3)  Two members appointed to serve until April 30, 2000. 
(4)  Two members appointed to serve until April 30, 2001. 
The terms of the two members who are village trustees shall be the duration of the time they are in office as village board members. 
(Code 1982, § 2-345; Ord. No. 97-004, §§ 2-4, 1-21-1997) 
Sec. 2-414. - Meetings; secretary. 
(a)  The chairman shall call the commission's first meeting within 30 days of its creation and further meetings as needed shall be scheduled by the chairman with notice to each member. 
(b)  The members shall select a secretary who shall keep the minutes and records of the meetings. The village will assist the secretary with the mailing and copying of the minutes and notices. 
(c)  The vice-chairman will conduct the meeting in the absence of the chairman. 
(Code 1982, § 2-346; Ord. No. 97-004, §§ 5-7, 1-21-1997) 
Sec. 2-415. - Duties. 
    The duties of the commission shall be to plan and supervise the implementation of a comprehensive program for the Lansing Youth Center, specifically, and the village youth, generally. The commission, from time to time, shall make written recommendations to the village board. 
(Code 1982, § 2-347; Ord. No. 97-004, § 8, 1-21-1997) 
Secs. 2-416-2-419. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - THE VILLAGE OF LANSING HUMAN RELATIONS COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-420. - Established. 
    There is hereby created for the village a board of human relations commissioners. The commission established herein shall be known as the "Village of Lansing Human Relations Commission." 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-421. - Membership/compensation. 
    The human relations commission (HRC) shall consist of nine members who shall reside in the village and who shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees and shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-422. - Terms and initial appointments. 
    The commission members shall be appointed for a term of four years. The initial appointments shall be as follows: 
(1)  Three members appointed to serve two-year terms. 
(2)  Three members appointed to serve three-year terms. 
(3)  Three members appointed to serve four-year terms. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-423. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the HRC shall be filled for an unexpired term of a member whose seat is vacant by appointment by the village president, and confirmation by the village board of trustees. No such appointment, however, shall be made by any president within 30 days before the expiration of his/her term of office. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-424. - Village president's authority to remove. 
    The village president, with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees, shall have the authority to remove any commission member from office whenever, in his/her discretion, the best interests of the village shall be served thereby. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-425. - Officers. 
    The village president, with the village board of trustees' consent, shall appoint a member of the (HRC) as chairperson. The HRC chairperson shall serve as the chairperson until a successor is appointed. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-426. - Duties of officers. 
    Chairperson. It shall be the duty of the chairperson to preside over all commission meetings. In his/her absence, a chairperson pro tempore may be elected to preside. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-427. - Secretary. 
    The village president shall appoint a secretary to serve the HRC. It shall be the secretary's duty to keep a record of all commission proceedings, transmit its recommendations to the village president, the village board of trustees, and commission members, and perform such other duties as are usually performed by the secretary of a deliberative body. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-428. - Meetings and procedures. 
(a)  The commission shall meet in regular session at least once a month at a time and place selected by vote of its members. 
(b)  All hearings conducted by the HRC shall be open to the public. 
(c)  The commission shall adopt a set of rules to govern its own meetings and procedures not in conflict with state statutes or village ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-429. - Mission statement. 
    The mission of the Lansing Human Relations Commission is to promote inclusion to the village administration on community-related issues. The commission is responsible for designing and recommending innovative programs that enhance community involvement among all Lansing entities in order to increase cultural competency and improve inter-group relations. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-430. - Goals. 
(a)  The commission shall strive to unite all community entities to build a mutual understanding and respect for diverse cultures. 
(b)  The commission shall strive to be a catalyst in developing civic pride among all Lansing residents to foster personal equity. 
(c)  The commission shall strive to communicate via channels and methods that enhance accessibility to and solicit involvement from all Lansing entities. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-431. - Acting in an advisory capacity. 
    Except as may otherwise be provided by ordinance, the powers and duties of the HRC are of an advisory nature only, and the commission shall not have any powers or duties which conflict with or supersede the powers and duties of other village commissions or boards. The HRC shall perform such further duties as may be delegated to it by the village president and the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-432. - Cooperation. 
    All officials and division heads of the village shall cooperate with the commission and render all reasonable assistance. The commission shall cooperate with the village president, the village board of trustees, village departments, agencies, and officials. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-433. - Prohibited from incurring liability. 
    Neither the commission, nor any member thereof, shall incur any financial liability in the village's name. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Sec. 2-434. - Annual report required. 
    The HRC, on or before the last regular meeting of the village board in each year, shall render a full report of its work to the village president and the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
ARTICLE XIV. - PROCEDURES FOR INCURRING INDEBTEDNESS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-435. - Compliance with article. 
    The procedures set forth in this article for the issuance of full faith and credit general obligation bonds or notes shall be controlling and shall be complied with by the village in the borrowing of money through the issuance of village general obligation bonds or notes, notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary contained in 65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq., and all acts amendatory thereof and supplementary thereto, and in any other state law. 
(Code 1982, § 2-351; Ord. No. 427, § 8, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 8, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-436. - General borrowing power. 
    The village, acting by its president and board of trustees, may from time to time borrow money for proper public purposes and in evidence of such borrowing issue its full faith and credit general obligation bonds or notes payable from ad valorem taxes to be levied without limitation as to rate or amount against all taxable property situated within the village. Such bonds or notes may be issued without the submission of the question of their issuance to the village electors for their approval, and the procedures for the issuance of such bonds or notes shall be substantially as provided in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 2-352; Ord. No. 427, § 1, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 1, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-437. - Ordinance-Required. 
(a)  The president and board of trustees shall adopt an ordinance (designated as the "ordinance") describing the public purpose to be accomplished by borrowing hereunder and in such ordinance shall make a finding and determination that such borrowing of money meets the following criteria: 
(1)  Is necessary for the government welfare and village affairs; 
(2)  Is for a proper public purpose; and 
(3)  Is in the public interest. 
(b)  The president and board of trustees' finding and determination shall be deemed conclusive. 
(Code 1982, § 2-353; Ord. No. 427, § 2, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 2, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-438. - Same-General contents. 
    The ordinance shall indicate the following: 
(1)  The amount of money necessary to be borrowed; 
(2)  The amount of bonds or notes to be issued in evidence thereof; 
(3)  Fix the details of such bonds or notes, including: 
a.  The date; 
b.  Number; 
c.  Denomination and maturity, which shall not exceed 40 years from the date of said bonds or notes; 
d.  The terms of redemption, if redeemable prior to maturity; and 
e.  The rate of interest. 
(Code 1982, § 2-354; Ord. No. 427, § 3, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 3, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-439. - Same-Publication. 
    Upon the adoption of any ordinance under this article by the village, and its approval by the president, the same shall be published in pamphlet form or in a newspaper published and of general circulation in the village, and said ordinance shall become effective ten days after the date of such publication. 
(Code 1982, § 2-355; Ord. No. 453, § 6, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-440. - Filed ordinance as authority for tax. 
    A copy of the ordinance, as adopted, certified to by the village clerk, shall be filed in the county clerk's office of the county or counties within which any part of the village may be situated. Such ordinance, as so filed, shall constitute the authority for the county clerks in and for each of the years for which taxes are levied in said ordinance, to extend such taxes for collection against all of the taxable property situated within the village. 
(Code 1982, § 2-356; Ord. No. 427, § 5, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 5, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-441. - Effect of taxes. 
    The taxes levied under this article for the payment of principal and interest on the bonds or notes issued hereunder shall be extended annually by the several county clerks without limitation as to rate or amount, and such taxes shall be in addition to, and in excess of, all other taxes levied or authorized to be levied by the village. Except as provided herein, such taxes so levied shall not be subject to repeal or abatement in any manner whatsoever until such time as all of the bonds or notes authorized and issued under the terms of the ordinance have been paid in full, both principal and interest thereof, up to and including, the date of maturity; provided, however, that if the village has other funds available, the president and board of trustees may appropriate such funds and deposit them in trust with the paying agent for the purpose of the payment of any of the maturities of the bonds or notes or interest thereon, in which event the taxes so levied to pay such principal or interest may be abated by the amount so deposited, such abatement to be directed by the village ordinance, duly adopted and placed on file with the respective county clerks at anytime prior to the extension of such taxes for collection. 
(Code 1982, § 2-357; Ord. No. 427, § 5, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 5, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-442. - Appropriation. 
    The provisions of any ordinance under this article shall constitute an appropriation of the amounts required as therein referred to and described, and upon the delivery of the bonds or notes therein authorized, the proceeds thereof shall be used solely and only for the purpose for which the bonds or notes were authorized. 
(Code 1982, § 2-358; Ord. No. 427, § 6, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 6, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-443. - Refunding bonds or notes. 
    Any bonds or notes authorized and issued pursuant to the provisions of any ordinance adopted pursuant to the provisions of this article, and any bonds heretofore issued and outstanding, which by their terms are payable from taxes unlimited as to rate or amount and levied against all of the taxable property within the village, or any other village obligations heretofore issued and outstanding, may be refunded prior to their maturity or at their maturity, and including the refunding of matured or unmatured interest coupons evidencing interest upon such unpaid bonds. The issuance of refunding bonds or notes shall be authorized by an ordinance which shall be adopted in the manner and subject to the terms, conditions and provisions as herein required for the issuance of bonds or notes for public purposes. Any such refunding shall be authorized by the president and board of trustees in such a manner that funds will be produced in an amount sufficient to pay maturing principal of and interest on the obligations being so refunded. 
(Code 1982, § 2-359; Ord. No. 427, § 7, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 7, 11-1-1977) 
Secs. 2-444-2-462. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BONDS OR NOTES 

Sec. 2-463. - Sale. 
    The bonds or notes issued under this article shall be sold in such a manner and at such a time as may be determined by the president and board of trustees. If the bonds or notes are sold to bear interest at the maximum rate fixed by the president and board of trustees, they shall be sold at a price of not less than par. If the bonds or notes are sold at a price of less than par, the price shall be such that the interest cost to the village of the money received as proceeds of the sale of said bonds or notes shall not exceed the maximum rate of interest fixed by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 2-371; Ord. No. 427, § 3, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 3, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-464. - Execution procedure. 
    The ordinance shall direct the execution of the bonds or notes therein authorized on the village's behalf by the signatures of the village president and clerk, and shall require the following: 
(1)  The village seal to be affixed to such bonds or notes; 
(2)  Determine whether such bonds or notes to be issued shall be registered in the name of the owner as to principal only or whether the same shall be fully registered as to both principal and interest; 
(3)  Indicate the place of payment of the principal and interest maturing on said bonds or notes; and 
(4)  Set forth the form of the bond or note. 
(Code 1982, § 2-372; Ord. No. 427, § 4, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 4, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-465. - Signatures. 
    The president may designate a deputy to affix his signature to any full faith and credit bonds or notes of the village that are required to be signed by the president. In such case, the president shall deliver to the vice-president and board of trustees a written notice of such designation, such notice stating the name of the person so selected and the specific bonds or notes which such person shall have authority to sign as proxy for the president. Said notice shall have attached thereto a written signature of the president executed by the person so designated to sign, together with the personal signature of the deputy authorized to sign on the president's behalf. Each notice shall be recorded in the official journal of the proceedings of the president and board of trustees and then filed with the village clerk. When the president's signature is placed on a full faith and credit bond or note of the village at his direction in the specified manner, such signature in all respects shall have the same legal effect as if signed by the president in person. 
(Code 1982, § 2-373; Ord. No. 427, § 4, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 4, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-466. - Contract for sale, when made; abatement of taxes. 
    A contract for the sale of bonds or notes issued under this article may be entered into prior to the ordinance's adoption, or the ordinance may provide for the subsequent sale of the bonds or notes therein authorized. In the event of such subsequent sale, and the bonds or notes are sold bearing interest at a rate less than that authorized in the ordinance, prior to the delivery of such bonds or notes, the taxes levied in the ordinance shall be abated by that amount representing the savings resulting from the sale of said bonds or notes at a lower rate of interest than authorized in the ordinance. 
(Code 1982, § 2-374; Ord. No. 427, § 3, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 3, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-467. - Redemption prior to maturity. 
    Bonds or notes issued under this article may be redeemable prior to their maturity either with or without a premium. 
(Code 1982, § 2-375; Ord. No. 427, § 3, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 3, 11-1-1977) 
Sec. 2-468. - Repayment from property taxes. 
    The ordinance shall make provision for the payment of bonds or notes issued under this article, both principal and interest until maturity, by levying a direct annual tax upon all the taxable property within the village sufficient for such purpose. 
(Code 1982, § 2-376; Ord. No. 427, § 5, 2-15-1977; Ord. No. 453, § 5, 11-1-1977) 
Secs. 2-469-2-487. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER 

Sec. 2-488. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the position of village code enforcement officers. Said officers shall be hired by and report to the building commissioner. 
(Code 1982, § 2-451; Ord. No. 90-003, § 1, 3-20-1990; Ord. No. 13-023, § 15, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 2-489. - Duties. 
(a)  The village code enforcement officer shall have the duty to perform the following functions: 
(1)  Enforce the village housing and property maintenance codes on existing structures to detect violations; 
(2)  Prepare and issue notices of violation; 
(3)  Prepare follow-up letter and/or telephone call when notice is not complied with; 
(4)  Perform further inspections until violations are corrected; and 
(5)  Perform such other duties as directed by the mayor. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(Code 1982, § 2-452; Ord. No. 90-003, § 2, 3-20-1990; Ord. No. 13-023, § 15, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 2-490. - Qualifications. 
    To be eligible for appointment as the village code enforcement officer, said officer shall possess the following general knowledge: 
(1)  Good engineering practices with respect to the design and construction of a building; 
(2)  The basic principles of fire prevention; 
(3)  The accepted requirements for means of egress and other service equipment necessary for the health, safety and general welfare of the occupant. 
(Code 1982, § 2-453; Ord. No. 90-003, § 3, 3-20-1990) 
Secs. 2-491-2-509. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - INVESTMENT POLICY 

Sec. 2-510. - Policy. 
(a)  Policy. It is the village's policy to invest public funds in a manner which will provide the highest investment return with the maximum security while meeting the daily village cash flow demands and conforming to all state and local statutes governing the investment of public funds. 
(b)  Scope. This policy includes all funds governed by the board of trustees. 
(c)  Prudence. 
(1)  Investments shall be made with judgment and care, under circumstances then prevailing, which persons of prudence, discretion and intelligence exercise in the management of their own affairs, not for speculation, but for investment, considering the probable safety of their capital, as well as the probable income to be derived. 
(2)  The standard of prudence to be used by investment officials shall be the "prudent person" standard and shall be applied in the context of managing an overall portfolio. 
(d)  Objective. The primary objective, in order of priority, shall be: 
(1)  Legality. Conformance with federal, state and other legal requirements. 
(2)  Safety. The preservation of capital and the protection of investment principal. 
(3)  Liquidity. The maintenance of sufficient liquidity to meet operating requirements. 
(4)  Yield. The attainment of market rates of return. 
(e)  Delegation of authority. Management and administrative responsibility for the investment program is hereby delegated to the village treasurer, who under the delegation of the board of trustees shall establish written procedures for the investment program's operation. 
(f)  Ethics and conflicts of interest. Officers and employees involved in the investment process shall refrain from personal business activity that could conflict with the investment program's proper execution and management, or that could impair their ability to make impartial decisions. 
(g)  Authorized financial dealers and institutions. 
(1)  The village treasurer will maintain a list of financial institutions authorized to provide investment services. 
(2)  In addition, a list will also be maintained of approved security brokers/dealers selected by credit worthiness. 
(h)  Authorized and suitable investments. 
(1)  Investments may be made in any type of security allowed by state statutes regarding the investment of public funds. 
(2)  Investments shall be made that reflect the cash flow needs of the fund type being invested. 
(i)  Collateralization. Funds on deposit (checking accounts, certificates of deposit, etc.,) in excess of FDIC limits must be secured by some form of collateral, witnessed by a written agreement and held at an independent third-party institution in the municipality's name. 
(j)  Safekeeping and custody. All security transactions, including collateral for repurchase agreements, entered into by the village shall be conducted on a delivery-verses-payment (DVP) basis. Securities will be held by an independent third-party custodian designated by the village treasurer and evidenced by safekeeping receipts and a written custodian agreement. 
(k)  Diversification. The entity shall diversify its investments to the best of its ability based on the type of funds invested and the cash flow needs of those funds. Diversification can be accomplished by any of the following: 
(1)  Type of investment; 
(2)  Number of institutions invested in; and 
(3)  Length of maturity. 
(l)  Maximum maturities. To the extent possible, the village shall attempt to match its investments with anticipated cash flow requirements. Unless matched to a specific cash flow, the village will not directly invest in securities maturing more than one year from the date of purchase. Reserve funds may be invested in securities exceeding one year if the maturity of such investments are made to coincide as nearly as practicable with the expected use of the funds. 
(m)  Internal control. The village treasurer is responsible for establishing and maintaining an internal control structure designed to ensure that the assets of the entity are protected from loss, theft or misuse. The internal control structure shall be designed to provide reasonable assurance that these objections are met. The internal controls shall address the following points: 
(1)  Control of collusion; 
(2)  Separation of transaction authority from accounting; 
(3)  Custodian safekeeping; 
(4)  Written confirmation of telephone transactions for investments and wire transfers. 
(n)  Performance standards. This investment portfolio will be managed in accordance with the parameters specified within this policy. The portfolio should obtain a comparable rate of return during a market/economic environment of stable interest rates. The portfolio's performance should be compared to benchmarks with similar maturity, liquidity and credit quality. 
(o)  Reporting. The village treasurer shall prepare an investment report at least monthly. The report should be provided to the board of trustees and available on request. The report should be in a format suitable for review by the general public. An annual report should also be provided to the board. 
(p)  Marking to market. A quarterly statement of the portfolio's market value shall be issued to the board of trustees. 
(q)  Investment policy adoption. The investment policy shall be adopted by the board of trustees. The policy shall be reviewed on an annual basis by the village treasurer and any modifications made thereto must be approved by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 2-471; Ord. No. 99-026, §§ 1-17, 10-19-1999) 
Secs. 2-511-2-528. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - ETHICS PROVISIONS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-08, adopted Feb. 19, 2013, repealed art. XVII, § 2-529, and enacted a new art. XVII as set out herein. The former art. XVII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 04-017, § 1, adopted May 18, 2004. 

Sec. 2-529. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply to this article: 
    Act on a matter or acting on a matter shall mean: (1) participating in the discussion or vote on a matter when it is before the village board for the purpose of discussion or vote; and (2) participating in the discussion or vote on a matter when it is before a committee of the village board for the purpose of discussion or vote; and (3) participating in the discussion of a matter at a meeting sanctioned by the village board when specifically designated by the village board to do so. 
    Actively pursuing an opportunity to establish an economic relationship shall mean engaging in activities related to securing an economic relationship beyond an initial solicitation or offer made by the village official, the village official's business or the village official's spouse to enter into an economic relationship or an initial inquiry made by an individual to the village official, the village official's business or the village official's spouse. For example, an advertisement in a newspaper, church bulletin, or direct-mail piece is not "actively pursuing an opportunity to establish an economic relationship" under this policy. Providing an estimate of costs for services, price list or rate to an individual is "actively pursuing an opportunity to establish an economic relationship." If the individual then engages the services or places an order, an economic relationship is created. If the individual expressly declines the offer, and the village official takes no further action, the village official is no longer "actively pursuing an opportunity to establish an economic relationship" with the individual. If the individual expressly declines the offer and the village official submits a new offer, the village official is "actively pursuing an opportunity to establish an economic relationship" with the individual. 
    Business entity shall mean any organization or enterprise (operated for profit), including, but not limited to, a sole proprietorship, partnership, limited liability partnership, corporation, limited liability company, firm, business, trust, joint venture, syndicate or association. 
    Campaign for elective office means any activity in furtherance of an effort to influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any individual to any federal, state, or local public office or office in a political organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice-presidential electors, but does not include activities (i) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action, (ii) relating to collective bargaining, or (iii) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
    Candidate means a person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a regular election, as defined in Section 1-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/1-3). 
    Collective bargaining has the same meaning as that term is defined in Section 3 of the Illinois Public Labor Relations Act (5 ILCS 315/3). 
    Compensated time means, with respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited to the employee that counts toward the minimum work time requirement imposed as a condition of his or her employment, but for purposes of this article, does not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal time, compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on leave of absence. With respect to officers or employees whose hours are not fixed, "compensated time" includes any period of time when the officer is on premises under the control of the employer and any other time when the officer or employee is executing his or her official duties, regardless of location. 
    Compensatory time off means authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee to compensate in whole or in part for time worked in excess of the minimum work time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment. 
    Consideration from the village shall include zoning variations, zoning text amendments, zoning map amendments, subdivision, development approval, appointment to a village office, employment by the village, use of or interest in village property, transfer of village property and contracting with or product or service vending to the village. 
    Contract or doing business with the village shall include any agreement between the village and any person, firm, corporation or other business entity for the purchase of materials, goods, services or real estate. Contract shall also mean a deposit of monies, loans, or other financial service provided to the village by banks and thrift institutions. Contract shall include employment by the village. 
    Contribution has the same meaning as that term is defined in Section 9-1.4 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-1.4). 
    Corporate authorities shall mean the village president and trustees of the Village of Lansing. 
    Direct business competition occurs when one or more business entities provide a similar product or service and as a matter of practice compete for the same market or customers. 
    Disclosure shall mean the filing, with the village attorney, of a written statement that describes the economic relationship. 
    Economic relationship shall mean any financial dealing, business relationship or client representation. This shall include any transaction or dealing of any kind or nature with a petitioner, where the value of the goods, service or other benefit exchanged exceeds $150.00. However, in no event shall the term economic relationship be deemed to include a transaction in which the village official is the consumer of a good (for example, clothing purchased from a merchant) or service (for example, dinner at a restaurant or the procurement of medical services), where the consumption of the good or service occurs in the ordinary course of the petitioner's business and the price of the good or service is fixed by the merchant or service provider and is no different from that which is offered to the general public. Economic relationship shall also specifically include campaign contributions totaling more than $150.00 (whether in cash or in kind) by the petitioner made to or for the benefit of the village official or the village official's campaign committee or campaign fund in the past four-year time period. 
    Employee shall mean any person employed by the Village of Lansing whether part-time or full-time whose duties are subject to the direction and control of an employer with regard to the material details of how the work is to be performed, but does not include an independent contractor. 
    Employer means the Village of Lansing. 
    Entity shall include the definition of a person and business entity and shall include not-for-profit corporations. 
    Financial interest [means] any economic interest or relationship, whether by ownership, trust, purchase, sale, lease, contract, option, investment, employment, gift, fee or otherwise. This shall include any such interest whether present, promised or reasonably expected; whether direct or indirect; whether or not legally enforceable; whether in the person or in a parent or subsidiary corporation, or in another subsidiary of the same parent corporation. A financial interest shall include, but is expressly not limited to, any economic interest, as set forth above, of a spouse or dependent child, as well as any economic interest held by an agent on behalf of an official or employee, a spouse or dependent child. It shall also include any economic interest held by an agent on behalf of an official or employee by a business entity managed or controlled by or by a trust in which an official or employee has a substantial interest. A business entity is controlled by an official or employee when that person or that person's spouse or dependent child, singly or in the aggregate, possess a majority ownership interest in the entity. An official or employee has a substantial interest in a trust when that person, the spouse or dependent child, singly or in the aggregate has a present or future interest worth more than $1,000.00. "Financial interest" shall not include ownership through purchase at fair market value of less than one percent of the shares of a corporation whose shares are registered and traded on a nationally recognized securities market. "Financial interest" shall also not include authorized compensation or salary paid to an official or employee for services rendered to the Village of Lansing, or any economic benefit generally available to the residents of the Village of Lansing. 
    Gift means any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of an officer or employee. 
    Immediate family means an individual's spouse, dependent children or others claimed by the individual as dependents for income tax purposes. All reference to a "person" or "person filing the statement" shall include spouse and dependent children. 
    Leave of absence means any period during which an employee does not receive (i) compensation for employment, (ii) service credit towards pension benefits, and (iii) health insurance benefits paid for by the employer. 
    Official or officer means any person appointed or elected to any board, commission, or other office of the village created by statute or ordinance, regardless of whether the officer is compensated for service in his or her official capacity, and the village administrator, each department head, the village attorney and village prosecutor. 
    Ownership interest means a person has an ownership interest if the person is the sole proprietor, partner, stockholder, other equity interest owner, joint-venturer, beneficial owner or holds any other legally recognized interest normally indicating ownership. 
    Past year means the preceding calendar year plus any time elapsed during the current year prior to the filing of the disclosure statement. 
    Person shall include any individual or business entity such as a partnership, corporation or joint venture. 
    Petitioner shall include any person seeking consideration from the village. 
    Political activity means any activity in support of or in connection with any campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not include activities (i) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action, (ii) relating to collective bargaining, or (iii) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
    Political organization means a party, committee, association, fund, or other organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement of organization with the state board of elections or a county clerk under Section 9-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-3), but only with regard to those activities that require filing with the state board of elections or a county clerk. 
    Prohibited acts are set forth in section 2-531 of this article. A prohibited act is an act that is forbidden under penalty of law. A prohibited act differs from a conflict of interest under this article as a conflict of interest may be cured pursuant to section 2-531. 
    Prohibited political activity means: 
(1)  Preparing for, organizing, or participating in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration, or other political event; or 
(2)  Soliciting contributions, including but not limited to the purchase of selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political fundraiser, political meeting, or other political event; or 
(3)  Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or report regarding anything of value intended as a campaign contribution; or 
(4)  Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question; or 
(5)  Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question; or 
(6)  Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question; or 
(7)  Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in an effort to get voters to the polls; or 
(8)  Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question; or 
(9)  Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office; or 
(10)  Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires; or 
(11)  Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question; or 
(12)  Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum question; or 
(13)  Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against any referendum question; or 
(14)  Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party convention; or 
(15)  Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any election. 
    Prohibited source means any person or entity who: 
(1)  Is seeking official action (i) by an officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or
