(a)  Each license shall expire on the January 1 after it was issued and may be renewed only by making an application as provided in section 4-23. An application for renewal shall be made at least 30 days prior the expiration date and when made less than 30 days prior the expiration date, the expiration of the license will not be affected. 
(b)  If the village denies the renewal of a license, the applicant shall not be issued a license for one year from the date of denial. If subsequent to the denial the village finds that the basis for the license denial has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a license. 
(Code 1982, § 16-347; Ord. No. 98-015, § 7, 5-5-1998) 
Sec. 4-27. - Suspension. 
(a)  The village may suspend a license for a period not to exceed 30 days if, after a hearing, it determines that a licensee or an employee of a licensee has done any of the following: 
(1)  Violated or is not in compliance with any section of this article; 
(2)  Refused to allow an inspection of the adult use business premises as authorized by this article; or 
(3)  Knowingly permitted gambling by any person on the adult use business premises. 
(b)  If the licensee or an employee of the licensee has been found guilty in a court of law of a violation of this article, no hearing is necessary prior to the suspension of the license. 
(Code 1982, § 16-348; Ord. No. 98-015, § 8, 5-5-1998) 
Sec. 4-28. - Revocation. 
(a)  The village shall revoke a license if a cause of suspension in section 4-27 occurs and the license has been suspended within the preceding 12 months or if the licensee is convicted of any specified criminal activity. 
(b)  The village may revoke a license if it determines, after a hearing, that any of the following occurred: 
(1)  A licensee gave false or misleading information in the material submitted during the application process; 
(2)  A licensee or management personnel has knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of alcohol or controlled substances on the premises; 
(3)  A licensee or management personnel has knowingly allowed prostitution on the premises; 
(4)  A licensee or management personnel knowingly operated the adult use business during a period of time when the licensee's license was suspended; 
(5)  A licensee or management personnel has knowingly allowed any act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, masturbation or other sex act to occur in or on the licensee's premises; 
(6)  A licensee is delinquent in payment to the village, county or state for any taxes or fees past due; 
(7)  A licensee or management personnel has knowingly facilitated another's commission of the offense of public indecency; 
(8)  The adult use business is a public nuisance as defined by any statute, ordinance or case law. 
(c)  If the village revokes a license, the revocation shall continue for one year and the licensee shall not be issued an adult use business license for one year from the effective date of the revocation. If subsequent to the revocation, the village finds that the factual basis for the revocation did not occur, the applicant may be granted a license. 
(d)  After denial of an application, or denial of a renewal of an application, or suspension or a revocation of any license, the applicant or licensee may seek prompt judicial review of such action in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1982, § 16-349; Ord. No. 98-015, § 9, 5-5-1998) 
Sec. 4-29. - Transfer. 
    A licensee shall not transfer his license to another, nor shall a licensee operate an adult use business under the authority of a license at any place other than the address on the license. 
(Code 1982, § 16-350; Ord. No. 98-015, § 10, 5-5-1998) 
Secs. 4-30-4-48. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 4-49. - Records. 
(a)  Annual report. All adult use businesses shall file a verified report with the village showing the licensee's gross receipts and amounts paid to employees during the preceding calendar year. 
(b)  Employee information. All adult use businesses shall maintain and retain for a period of two years the names, addresses and ages of all persons employed, including independent contractors, by the licensee. 
(Code 1982, § 16-351; Ord. No. 98-015, § 11, 5-5-1998) 
Sec. 4-50. - Liquor license. 
    No adult use may be issued a liquor license, nor shall any establishment with a liquor license operate as an adult use. 
(Code 1982, § 16-352; Ord. No. 98-015, § 12, 5-5-1998) 
Sec. 4-51. - Restrictions-Adult entertainment cabarets. 
    All dancing or other performances shall occur on a stage intended for that purpose which is raised at least two feet from the level of the floor. No dancing or other performances shall occur closer than ten feet to any patron. In addition, no dancer or performer shall fondle, caress or otherwise touch any patron and no patron shall fondle, caress or otherwise touch any dancer or performer. No patron shall directly pay or give any gratuity to any dancer or performer and no dancer shall solicit any pay or gratuity from any patron. Gratuities may be indirectly given to dancers or performers by placing the gratuity on the stage. 
(Code 1982, § 16-353; Ord. No. 98-015, § 13, 5-5-1998) 
Sec. 4-52. - Same-Video viewing booths. 
    No booths, stalls or partitioned portions of a room or individual rooms used for the viewing of motion picture or other forms of entertainment shall have doors, curtains or portal partitions, but all such booths, stalls or partitioned portions or a room or individual rooms so used shall have at least one side open to an adjacent public room so that the area inside is visible to persons in the adjacent public room. All such described areas shall be lighted in such a manner that the persons in the areas used for viewing motion pictures or other forms of entertainment are visible from the adjacent public rooms, but such lighting shall not be of such intensity as to prevent the viewing of the motion picture or other offered entertainment. 
(Code 1982, § 16-354; Ord. No. 98-015, § 14, 5-5-1998) 
Sec. 4-53. - Hours of operation. 
    No adult use business shall be open prior to 10:00 a.m. or after 2:00 a.m. 
(Code 1982, § 16-355; Ord. No. 98-015, § 15, 5-5-1998) 
Chapter 6 - ADVERTISING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of signs, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-14 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Compliance. 
    No person shall post or maintain any advertisement or sign on any billboard or signboard that does not fully comply with this Code or village ordinances. 
(Code 1969, § 14.305; Code 1982, § 3-1) 
Sec. 6-2. - Size of off-premises signs. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code, no person shall construct, install, erect or post any advertisement, sign or billboard that is more than ten feet in overall height or which contains more than 20 square feet, within 500 feet of any dedicated street or highway within the village, except such advertisements, signs or billboards which are upon the premises where the activities of the business or other organization being announced or advertised are actually conducted. 
(Code 1982, § 3-2; Ord. No. 230, § 1, 8-18-1970; Ord. No. 86-030, § 7, 10-28-1986) 
Sec. 6-3. - Inspection of outdoor advertising. 
    The village building commissioner or his designee shall inspect annually each billboard or outdoor advertising sign and sign structure for the purpose of ascertaining whether the advertising structure is secure and safe or whether it is in need of removal or repair. To meet the expense of the annual inspection an inspection fee per each square foot of sign surface area, in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk, shall be paid by each sign owner. 
(Ord. No. 07-002, § 1, 1-16-2007) 
Secs. 6-4-6-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROHIBITED ACTIONS 

Sec. 6-23. - Unlawful advertising. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to post or display any advertisement of an obscene or immoral character, any advertisement tending to promote or cause a riot or breach of the peace, any advertisement for an unlawful gathering or advertisements of unlawful businesses, commodities or sales. This prohibition extends to both print and electronic advertisement. 
(Code 1969, §§ 14.308, 17.101.2; Code 1982, § 3-3; Ord. No. 12-033, § 4, 10-16-2012; Ord. No. 18-006, § 2, 3-6-2018) 
State Law reference- Obscenity, 720 ILCS 5/11-20; fraudulent advertising, 720 ILCS 295/1a et seq. 
Sec. 6-24. - Portable electric signs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to temporarily install, place, use or allow any type of portable electric sign in front of, near or around his place of business for advertising purposes. 
(Code 1982, § 3-4; Ord. No. 365, § 1, 2-18-1975) 
Sec. 6-25. - Injuring, defacing advertisements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, deface, mutilate, disfigure or destroy any lawful sign or advertisement that is lawfully posted within the village. 
(Code 1969, §§ 14.309, 17.101.3; Code 1982, § 3-6) 
Chapter 8 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority for local control of retail sales of alcoholic beverages, 235 ILCS 5/4-1; Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context otherwise requires, all terms, words and phrases used in this chapter shall be construed according to the definitions contained in the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 
(Code 1969, § 4.102; Code 1982, § 5-1) 
Sec. 8-2. - Construction; purpose. 
    This chapter shall be liberally construed to the end that the health, safety and welfare of the village residents shall be protected and temperance in the consumption of alcoholic liquors shall be fostered and promoted by the sound and careful control and regulation of the sale, offering for sale and distribution of alcoholic liquors. 
(Code 1969, § 4.101; Code 1982, § 5-2; Ord. No. 87-015, § 1, 6-16-1987) 
Sec. 8-3. - Local liquor control commissioner-Office created; authority. 
    There is hereby created the office of local liquor control commissioner, who shall be the president of the board of trustees. The local liquor control commissioner shall be charged with the administration of this chapter and of the appropriate provisions of the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 
(Code 1969, § 4.201; Code 1982, § 5-3) 
State Law reference- Local liquor control commissioner, 235 ILCS 5/4-2 et seq. 
Sec. 8-4. - Same-General powers and duties. 
    The local liquor control commissioner shall have the following powers, functions and duties: 
(1)  Grant and/or suspend for not more than 30 days or revoke for cause all local licenses issued to persons for premises within the village. 
(2)  To enter or to authorize any law-enforcing officer to enter at any time upon the premises licensed under this chapter to determine whether any provisions of this chapter, the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., or any rules or regulations adopted by the state liquor control commission have been or are being violated, and at such times to examine the premises of said licensee in connection therewith. 
(3)  To receive complaints from any village citizen that any of the provisions of this chapter, the Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., or any rules or regulations adopted pursuant thereto, have been or are being violated and to act upon such complaints in the manner provided by law. 
(4)  To receive, or cause to be received, all local license fees and pay the same forthwith to the village treasurer. 
(5)  To perform such other duties as may be required by statute. 
(Code 1969, § 4.202; Code 1982, § 5-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/4-4. 
Sec. 8-5. - Gifts. 
(a)  The local liquor control commissioner, his agent, or any committee member appointed by him to assist in local control, and any member of the board of trustees are hereby prohibited from soliciting or accepting any gift, gratuity, emolument or employment from any licensee under this chapter. 
(b)  Every licensee or employee, agent, or officer of such licensee is prohibited from offering or making such gift, gratuity or emolument to any person mentioned in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1969, § 4.411; Code 1982, § 5-5; Ord. No. 00-009, §§ 1, 2, 5-16-2000) 
Sec. 8-6. - Complaint. 
(a)  Any five village residents shall have the right to file a complaint with the local liquor control commissioner stating that any retail licensee has been or is violating the provisions of this chapter or the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 
(b)  The complaint shall conform to the following: 
(1)  Be in writing and shall be signed and sworn to by the parties complaining. 
(2)  State the particular provisions believed to have been violated and the facts in detail upon which the belief is based. 
(c)  If the local liquor control commissioner is satisfied that the complaint substantially charges a violation and that from the facts alleged therein reasonably creates a cause for such belief, he shall set the matter for hearing and shall serve notice upon the licensee of the time and place of such hearing and of the particulars charged in the complaint. 
(Code 1969, § 4.501; Code 1982, § 5-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/7-7. 
Sec. 8-7. - Peddling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to peddle alcoholic liquor in the village. 
(Code 1969, § 4.413; Code 1982, § 5-7) 
Sec. 8-8. - Owner's responsibility. 
    If the owner of the licensed premises under this chapter or any person from whom the licensee derives the right to possession of such premises, or the agent of such owner or person, shall knowingly permit the licensee to use said licensed premises in violation of the terms of this chapter, or of the applicable provisions of the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., said owner, agent or other person shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter to the same extent as said licensee and shall be subject to the same penalties. 
(Code 1969, § 4.505; Code 1982, § 5-8) 
Sec. 8-9. - Acts of agent or employee. 
    Every act or omission constituting a violation of any provisions of this chapter or the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., by any officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee, shall be deemed and held to be the act of such employer or licensee, and said employer or licensee shall be punished in the same manner as if the act or omission had been personally done or omitted by him. 
(Code 1969, § 4.506; Code 1982, § 5-9) 
Sec. 8-10. - Bar; saloon. 
    No person licensed to sell alcoholic liquor shall use the words "bar" or "saloon" in any advertisements or signs. 
(Code 1969, § 4.407; Code 1982, § 5-10) 
Sec. 8-11. - Access to dwelling quarters from licensed premises; exceptions. 
    There shall be no access from premises licensed under this chapter to dwelling quarters, except as permitted under the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 
(Code 1969, § 4.406; Code 1982, § 5-11) 
Sec. 8-12. - Visibility of premises-Generally. 
(a)  In premises upon which the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption upon the premises is licensed (other than as a restaurant, hotel, club or any bowling alley other than one situated on the first, or ground floor) no screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall be permitted in the windows or upon the doors of such licensed premises nor inside such premises, which shall prevent a clear view into the interior of such licensed premises from the street, road or sidewalk at all times. 
(b)  No booth, screen, partition or other obstruction nor any arrangements of lights or lighting shall be permitted in or about the interior of such licensed premises which shall prevent a full view of the entire interior of such premises from the street, road or sidewalk, and said premises must be so located that there shall be a full view of the entire interior of such premises from the street, road or sidewalk. 
(c)  All rooms where liquor is sold for consumption upon the premises shall be continuously lighted during business hours by natural light or artificial white light so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall be clearly visible. 
(Code 1969, § 4.402; Code 1982, § 5-12) 
Sec. 8-13. - Same-Violation. 
    In case the view into any licensed premises, required by the section 8-12, shall be willfully obscured by the licensee or by him willfully suffered to be obscured or in any manner obstructed, then such licensee shall be subject to revocation in the manner provided in this chapter. In order to enforce the provisions of this chapter, the local liquor control commissioner shall have the right to require the filing with him of plans, drawings and photographs showing the clearance of the view as required herein. 
(Code 1969, § 4.402; Code 1982, § 5-13) 
Sec. 8-14. - Sanitation-Generally. 
    All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor or for the storage of such liquor for such sale shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition in full compliance with the sections of this Code or village ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human consumption. 
(Code 1969, § 4.403.1; Code 1982, § 5-14) 
Sec. 8-15. - Same-Water, washing facilities, etc. 
    Every person licensed to sell alcoholic beverages at retail who shall sell any alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises of such licensee shall keep and maintain the licensed premises equipped with running hot and cold water and adequate sanitary washing facilities for the cleansing of glasses and service utensils, and shall provide adequate toilet facilities. 
(Code 1969, § 4.403.2; Code 1982, § 5-15) 
Sec. 8-16. - Same-Health of employees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to employ in any premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with or who is a carrier of, any contagious, infectious or venereal diseases; and it shall be unlawful for any person who is affected with or is a carrier of any such disease to work in or about any premises or to engage in any way in the handling, preparation or distribution of such liquor. 
(Code 1969, § 4.404; Code 1982, § 5-16) 
Sec. 8-17. - Minimum size container for unmixed whiskey, rum or gin. 
    No unmixed whiskey, unmixed rum or unmixed gin shall be sold or offered for sale at retail for consumption on the premises, except in a container having a minimum capacity of at least one fluid ounce and which contains at the time of sale at least one fluid ounce of the beverage being sold. 
(Code 1969, § 4.410; Code 1982, § 5-17) 
Sec. 8-18. - Original packages-Refilling. 
    No person except a manufacturer, distributor or importing distributor shall fill or refill, in whole or in part, any original package for alcoholic liquor with the same or any other kind or quality of alcoholic liquor with any dilutant. 
(Code 1969, § 4.409; Code 1982, § 5-18) 
Sec. 8-19. - Same-Retail sales. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession for sale at retail any bottles, casks or other containers containing alcoholic liquor, except in the original package. 
(Code 1969, § 4.409; Code 1982, § 5-19) 
Sec. 8-20. - Containers of deceptive size. 
    No person licensed to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for consumption on the premises shall use in such sales or possess on the premises any glass or other container so constructed as to be deceptive in appearance or to mislead the consumer as to its true capacity. 
(Code 1969, § 4.410; Code 1982, § 5-20) 
Sec. 8-21. - Persons under 21 years-Sales to. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this chapter or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee to sell, give away or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of 21 years. 
(Code 1969, § 4.414.1; Code 1982, § 5-21; Ord. No. 336, § 1, 6-4-1974) 
Sec. 8-22. - Same-Employment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person described in section 8-21 to engage or employ or permit any person under the age of 21 years to work, entertain or act as a host in or upon a licensed premises where the principal business is the sale of alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption, while such premises are open for the sale of alcoholic liquor at retail. 
(Code 1969, § 4.414.2; Code 1982, § 5-22; Ord. No. 336, § 1, 6-4-1974) 
Sec. 8-23. - Same-Handling liquor. 
    Any person under the age of 21 years engaged or employed or permitted to work in or upon a licensed premises where the sale of alcoholic liquor is not the main or principal business may not work as an entertainer or host in connection with the handling, serving or delivering of alcoholic liquor. 
(Code 1969, § 4.414.3; Code 1982, § 5-23; Ord. No. 336, § 1, 6-4-1974) 
Sec. 8-24. - Same-Purchase, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to purchase, attempt to purchase or accept a gift of an alcoholic beverage or have an alcoholic beverage in his possession. 
(Code 1969, § 4.415.1; Code 1982, § 5-24) 
Sec. 8-25. - Same-Identification demanded. 
    If a licensee or his agent or employee believes that a sale or delivery of alcoholic beverage is prohibited because of the nonage of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making such sale or delivery, demand presentation of some form of positive identification, containing proof of age, issued by a public officer in the performance of his official duties. 
(Code 1969, § 4.415.2; Code 1982, § 5-25) 
Sec. 8-26. - Same-Illegal identification. 
    The following actions concerning identifications cards are prohibited; no person shall: 
(1)  Transfer, alter or deface an identification card described in section 8-25; 
(2)  Use the identification card of another; 
(3)  Carry or use a false or forged identification card; or 
(4)  Obtain an identification card by means of false information. 
(Code 1969, § 4.415.3; Code 1982, § 5-26) 
Sec. 8-27. - Removal from premises. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to be in the possession of any alcoholic liquor, as defined in 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., as amended from time to time, on a public street or other place unless the alcoholic liquor is in the original package and the seal unbroken, unless such possession is on the premises of an establishment having a valid village liquor license. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the term "public street" and/or "public place" shall include, but not be limited to, all village streets, alleys, and public locations. The term "public places" shall also include, but are not limited to, public sidewalks within the village, village-owned parking facilities and lots, common areas and parking lots serving commercial establishments, parking areas and common areas serving multifamily residential structures, public parks, playgrounds, recreation areas and school and church parking lots and properties within village limits. 
(c)  Waiver. The prohibitions of this section, other than age limitations for possession of alcohol, may be waived by the mayor or the village board for block party requests or other specific special events. 
(Code 1969, § 4.412; Code 1982, § 5-27; Ord. No. 07-027, § 2, 8-21-2007) 
Sec. 8-28. - Closing hours-Regular. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person licensed as a regular-hour retailer of alcoholic liquor to be consumed off the premises and/or to be consumed on the premises to sell, permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor on any of the following days between the hours specified: 
(1)  Monday through Friday, between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(2)  Saturdays, between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(3)  Sundays, between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon. 
(4)  Individuals, partnerships or corporations (either "for profit" or "nonprofit") that have been issued a municipal liquor license and conduct a restaurant in conjunction with the sale of their alcoholic beverages, may, upon the written application to and the approval of the village liquor control commissioner, open on Sunday mornings at 10:00 a.m. and serve wine products with an alcoholic content of no more than 19 percent in connection with a "Sunday brunch" which is open to the general public. 
(Code 1969, § 4.405.1; Code 1982, § 5-29; Ord. No. 547, § 1, 8-7-1979; Ord. No. 83-025, § 1, 10-4-1983) 
State Law reference- Power of board of trustees to restrict hours of sale, 235 ILCS 5/6-14. 
Sec. 8-29. - Same-Late. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person licensed as a late-closing hour retailer of alcoholic liquor to be consumed off the premises and/or to be consumed on the premises to sell, permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor on any of the following days between the hours specified: 
(1)  Monday through Friday, between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(2)  Saturdays, between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(3)  Sundays, between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon. 
(4)  Individuals, partnerships or corporations (either for "profit" or "nonprofit") that have been issued a municipal liquor license and conduct a restaurant in conjunction with the sale of their alcoholic beverages, may, upon the written application to and the approved of the village liquor control commissioner, open on Sunday mornings at 10:00 a.m. and serve wine products with an alcoholic content of no more than 19 percent in connection with a "Sunday brunch" which is open to the general public. 
(Code 1969, § 4.405.2; Code 1982, § 5-30; Ord. No. 547, § 2, 8-7-1979; Ord. No. 83-025, § 1, 10-4-1983) 
State Law reference- Power of board of trustees to restrict hours of sale, 235 ILCS 5/6-14. 
Sec. 8-30. - Persons allowed to remain after closing. 
    No person other than authorized employees of a licensee shall be permitted to remain on the premises after the designated closing hour; however, this shall not be construed to prohibit clubs from admitting members nor restaurants from admitting the public; provided, that, the right to remain open for other activities shall not be deemed a right to sell, permit to be sold or to give away alcoholic liquor during restricted hours. 
(Code 1969, § 4.405.3; Code 1982, § 5-31) 
Sec. 8-31. - Adult entertainment and fashion shows at licensed establishments prohibited. 
(a)  Fashion shows. Fashion shows and adult entertainment are not to be conducted upon premises holding liquor licenses. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult entertainment means any exhibition of any adult-oriented motion pictures, or any live performance, display or dance of any type, which has a portion of such performance, display or dance, any actual or simulated performance of specified sexual activities or exhibition and viewing of specified anatomical areas, removal of articles of clothing or appearing unclothed or dancing in a lewd or provocative manner. 
    Adult-oriented motion picture means a motion picture having as a dominant theme or presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or related to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by the public, patrons or club members. 
    Fashion show means any entertainment, modeling, demonstrations or any other activity at which male or female undergarments, bathing suits or lingerie is displayed on a human body. 
    Specified anatomical areas means: 
(1)  Less than completely or opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region; buttocks; female breasts below a point immediately above the top of the areola; and 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely or opaquely covered. 
    Specified sexual activities means: 
(1)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal; 
(2)  Acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy; 
(3)  Fondling or erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock or female breasts. 
(c)  Adult entertainment. No licensee or other person shall offer or permit any adult entertainment or fashion show on any portion of the licensed premises. 
(d)  Selling or raffling undergarments, etc. No licensee or other person shall sell or offer for sale or offer as a prize for a raffle any clothing that constitutes male or female undergarments, bathing suits or lingerie on any portion of the licensed premises. 
(Code 1982, § 5-32; Ord. No. 94-017, §§ 1, 2, 8-16-1994) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate certain adult entertainment and alcoholic beverage establishments, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-10.2. 
Sec. 8-32. - Appeals. 
    All appeals to the state liquor control commission by a village liquor licensee of a decision, order or action by the local liquor control commissioner or his designee having the effect of fining a licensee, suspending or revoking the village liquor license, shall be limited to review of the official record of the formal proceedings before the commissioner. 
(Code 1982, § 5-33; Ord. No. 98-021, § 1, 7-21-1998) 
Sec. 8-33. - Consumption of alcoholic liquor at unlicensed premises prohibited. 
(a)  No business establishment operating within the village shall permit the consumption of alcoholic liquor on its premises unless there is a valid state and local liquor license issued for the subject premises. No person shall consume alcoholic liquor on a business premises, unless there is a valid state and local liquor license issued for the subject premises. 
(b)  The holder of the business license for the premises at which a violation of this section occurs and the person consuming the alcoholic liquor shall each be considered in violation of this section and shall be subject to the general penalty set forth in section 1-23. The act of each person consuming alcoholic liquor in violation of this section shall be deemed a complete and separate offense. 
(c)  The holder of any business license found to be in violation of this section shall be subject to having such business license revoked. Said revocation shall only take place upon a vote of the majority of the corporate authorities after a hearing. The business licensee shall be given not less than ten days, written notice of the hearing and shall be given an opportunity to be heard at the hearing. 
(Code 1982, § 5-34; Ord. No. 98-018, §§ 2-4, 6-16-1998) 
Secs. 8-34-8-52. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Local jurisdiction over retail selling, 235 ILCS 5/4-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-53. - Privilege; subject to revocation, to cease upon death of licensee. 
    A license for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages shall be purely a personal privilege, subject to revocation and shall not constitute property; nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution; nor shall it be alienable, transferable or assignable, voluntarily or involuntarily; nor shall it be subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license shall not descend by the laws of the testate or intestate devolution, but it shall cease upon the death of the licensee; provided, that, the executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale of alcoholic liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of such decedent, or such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license, but not longer than six months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee. 
(Code 1969, § 4.309; Code 1982, § 5-46) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-1. 
Sec. 8-54. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, either by himself, his agent, or any person acting as an agent, barkeeper, clerk or servant of another, to sell, or offer for sale, at retail, any alcoholic beverage or engage in any sale, in the village without first having obtained for the current fiscal year a village retail liquor license, in addition to a state license, for each place, location or premises where the person is located. 
(b)  Definitions. The terms "sale" and "offer for sale" mean any transfer or exchange in any manner or by any means whatsoever for a consideration. The terms "sale" and "offer for sale" also include all sales made by any person, whether as principal, proprietor, agent, servant, or employee, and include, but are not limited to, all of the following acts when done for consideration: 
(1)  The selling of liquor; 
(2)  The giving away of liquor; 
(3)  The dispensing of liquor; 
(4)  The providing of mix, ice, water or glasses for the purpose of mixing drinks containing alcoholic liquor for consumption on the same premises; 
(5)  The pouring of liquor; 
(6)  The providing of "set-ups" containing alcoholic liquor; 
(7)  The storage of any alcoholic beverage. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the terms and conditions of any such license or to violate any provisions of this chapter or the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 
(Code 1969, § 4.301; Code 1982, § 5-47; Ord. No. 386, § 1, 10-7-1975; Ord. No. 87-015, § 2, 6-16-1987) 
State Law reference- State liquor licenses, 235 ILCS 5/5-1. 
Sec. 8-55. - Exceptions. 
    The requirements of section 8-54 are not applicable to physicians, dentists, pharmacists, hospitals or other institutions caring for the sick and diseased or churches when these persons or institutions possess or dispense alcoholic liquor in accordance with the provisions of 235 ILCS 5/2-1. 
(Code 1969, § 4.302; Code 1982, § 5-48) 
State Law reference- Scope of Act, 235 ILCS 5/2-1. 
Sec. 8-56. - Application. 
    Applications for a license to sell alcoholic liquors shall be made in writing to the president of the board of trustees, signed by the applicant if an individual, or signed by at least two members of a partnership, or signed by the president and secretary thereof if a firm, association, club or corporation, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall state: 
(1)  The name, age and address of: 
a.  The applicant in the case of an individual; 
b.  Of all persons entitled to share in the profits in the case of a copartnership; or 
c.  In the case of a club or corporation: 
1.  The name; 
2.  Date of incorporation; 
3.  The address; 
4.  The objects for which it was organized; 
5.  The names and addresses of the officers and directors; 
6.  The names and addresses of all stockholders of a corporation and the proportion of stock held by each; and 
7.  The names and addresses of all members of a club. 
(2)  The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and, if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization. 
(3)  The character of the business or operation with which the desired license is to be used and the class of license for which application is made. 
(4)  The length of time that the applicant has been in that business or operation and the date at which that business or operation was started in the village and, in the case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was issued. 
(5)  The location and description of the premises or place of business that is to be operated under the desired license. 
(6)  A statement whether the applicant has ever made an application for license to retail alcoholic liquor on premises other than those described in this application and the disposition of such application. 
(7)  A statement whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony or is disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing contained in this chapter, other village ordinances or state laws. 
(8)  Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof, or by the federal government, has been revoked and the reasons therefor. 
(9)  The date of incorporation if a state corporation or the date of becoming qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act, 805 ILCS 5/1.01 et seq.; to transact business in the state, if a foreign corporation. 
(10)  A statement that the applicant is familiar with the federal, state and village laws as they relate to retailers of alcoholic liquors and that neither the applicant, nor his principals have ever violated these laws and that the applicant will not violate, nor permit his employees or agents to violate any federal, state or village laws in the conduct of his business. 
(11)  That he has not received nor borrowed money or anything else of value, and that he will not receive nor borrow money or anything else of value (other than merchandising credit in the ordinary course of business for a period permitted by statute) as provided in the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. ("Act"), directly or indirectly from any manufacturer, importing distributor or distribution representative of any such manufacturer, importing distributor or distributor, nor to be a party in any way directly or indirectly to any violation by a manufacturer, distributor or importing distribution of said Act. 
(Code 1969, § 4.303; Code 1982, § 5-49) 
Sec. 8-57. - Additional information to be prescribed by commissioner. 
    In addition to the information described in section 8-56, the application for a license to sell alcoholic liquors shall contain such other and further information as the local liquor control commissioner may prescribe by rule or regulation not inconsistent with law. 
(Code 1969, § 4.303; Code 1982, § 5-50) 
Sec. 8-58. - Examination of applicant. 
(a)  Local liquor control commissioner. The local liquor control commissioner shall have the right to: 
(1)  Examine, or cause to be examined, under oath, any applicant for a local license or for a renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of the revocation or suspension has been served in the manner provided by law; 
(2)  Examine or cause to be examined the books and records of any such applicant or licensee; 
(3)  Hear testimony and take proof for his information in the performance of his duties and for such purpose to issue subpoenas which shall be effective in any part of this state. 
(b)  Police department. The village police department shall also conduct a background investigation into each applicant for a liquor license, including the topics covered in sections 8-56 and 8-59. 
(Code 1969, § 4.202; Code 1982, § 5-51; Ord. No. 84-020, § 1, 11-20-1984) 
Sec. 8-59. - Disqualified persons. 
    No village retail liquor license shall be issued by the local liquor control commissioner to the following applicants: 
(1)  A person who is not a village resident in which the premises covered by the license are located; 
(2)  A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides; 
(3)  A person who is not a United States citizen; 
(4)  A person who has been convicted of a felony under any federal or state law, if the commissioner determines, after investigation, that such person has not been sufficiently rehabilitated to warrant the public trust; 
(5)  A person who has been convicted of being the keeper of or is keeping a house of ill fame; 
(6)  A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality; 
(7)  A person whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for cause; 
(8)  A person who at the time of an application for renewal of any license issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first application; 
(9)  A copartnership, unless all of the members of such copartnership shall be qualified to obtain a license; 
(10)  A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the political subdivision; 
(11)  In addition to subsection (10) of this section, no license shall be issued by the local liquor control commissioner to the following applicants: 
a.  A copartnership, unless one of the members of the copartnership is a village resident; 
b.  A corporation, unless said corporation has a registered agent and a manager who reside within the village; 
(12)  A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent, unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the licensee; 
(13)  A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, subsequent to the passage of this chapter, or shall have forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such violation; 
(14)  A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is to be issued; 
(15)  The president of the village board of trustees, any member of the village board of trustees and all other village officers, and no such official shall be interested in any way, either directly or indirectly, in the sale of alcoholic liquor, except insofar as they may be officers, directors or members of private clubs; 
(16)  A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated by the licensee; 
(17)  A person who has been convicted of a gambling offense as prescribed by 720 ILCS 5/28-1 or 720 ILCS 5/28-3, as heretofore or hereafter amended, or as prescribed by a statute replaced by any of the aforesaid statutory provisions; 
(18)  A person to whom a federal gaming device stamp or a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period; 
(19)  A copartnership to which a federal gaming device stamp or a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period, or if any of the partners have been issued a federal gaming device stamp or federal wagering stamp by the federal government for the current tax period; 
(20)  A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder owning in the aggregate more than 20 percent of the stock of such corporation, has been issued a federal gaming device stamp or a federal wagering stamp for the current tax period; 
(21)  Any premises for which a federal gaming device stamp or federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period. 
(Code 1969, § 4.304; Code 1982, § 5-52) 
Sec. 8-60. - Classes. 
    Licenses issued by the local liquor control commissioner permitting the sale at retail of alcoholic liquor in the village shall be of the following classes: 
(1)  Class 1: General. Permitting the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption only, either with or without meals, and either at a counter or tables. 
(2)  Class 2: Package. Permitting the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor in the original package only for off-premises consumption. 
(3)  Class 3: Club. Permitting the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor for on-premises and off-premises consumption by only members and their bona fide guests. The term "club" means: 
a.  A group organized not for pecuniary profit, but solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale of or consumption of alcoholic liquors; 
b.  Kept, used and maintained by its members through the payment of annual dues; 
c.  Owning, hiring or leasing a building or space in a building, of such extent and character as may be suitable and adequate for the reasonable and comfortable use and accommodation of its members and their guests; 
d.  Provided with suitable and adequate kitchen and dining room space and equipment; 
e.  Providing a sufficient number of employees for cooking, preparing and serving food and meals for its members and their guests; 
f.  Provided, that such club files with the local liquor control commissioner at the time of its application for a license under this chapter two copies of a list of names and residences of its members, and similarly files within ten days of the election of any additional member, his name and address; 
g.  Provided further, that its affairs and management are conducted by a board of directors, executive committee or similar body chosen by the members at their annual meetings; and 
h.  That no member or any officer, agent or employee of the club is paid, or directly or indirectly receives, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits from the distribution or sale of alcoholic liquor to the club or the members of the club or its guests introduced by members beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed and voted at any annual meeting of the members or by its board of directors or other governing body out of the club's general revenue. 
(4)  Class 4: Alcoholic liquor and beer. Permitting the retail sale of alcoholic liquor and beer, only for consumption on bowling alley premises, and only to be served within an enclosure that is separated from the other facilities within the building. 
(5)  Class 5: Special license. Permitting special licenses for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor and/or beer to be granted from time to time in the discretion of the local liquor control commissioner to local clubs, associations and lodges organized for at least two years prior to the date of the application for such special license. No more than two such special licenses shall be granted to any one club during any calendar year. Each special license shall not exceed seven days in duration. 
(6)  Class 6: Commercial planned unit development of 50 acres or more. The following requirements shall apply to commercial planned developments of 50 acres or more. 
a.  Permitting the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption only, in an establishment wherein the primary business is the serving of food, and which contains not less than 5,000 square feet of enclosed dining area and/or banquet facilities. 
b.  Permitting the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in the original package only, for off-premises consumption in an establishment wherein the primary business is the sale of food. 
c.  Permitting the retail sale of beer and wine for on-premises consumption, in an establishment wherein the primary business is the serving of food. 
All such establishments shall not be located within one-half mile of any church or school, and shall only be issued to establishments located within the commercial planned unit development. 
(7)  Class 7: Motel and hotel (50 or more rooms or units with a dining room seating a minimum of 50 persons). Permitting the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption either with or without meals and either at a counter, table or in the rooms. 
(8)  Class 8: Club for profit (containing 35 acres or more). Permitting the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption by only members and their bona fide guests. The term "club for profit" means: 
a.  A group organized for pecuniary profit solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale of or consumption of alcoholic liquors; 
b  Kept, used and maintained by its members through the payment of annual dues; 
c.  Owning or leasing a building of such extent and character as may be suitable and adequate for its members and their guests; 
d.  Provided with suitable and adequate kitchen and dining room space and equipment; and 
e.  Providing sufficient number of employees for working and preparing food for the members and their guests. 
(9)  Class 9: Restaurant. Permitting the retail sale of beer and wine for on-premises consumption only, in an establishment wherein the primary business is the serving of food. 
(10)  Class 10: Commercial planned unit development of 101/2 acres or more. Permitting the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption only, in an establishment wherein the primary business is the serving of food, and which contains not less than 5,000 square feet of enclosed dining area and banquet facilities. Such establishment shall not be located within one-half mile of any church or school. The term "commercial planned unit development" means: 
a.  One planned as a single development of 101/2 acres or more; 
b.  Including, but not limited to, some or all of the following commercial activities: 
1.  Motel; 
2.  Gourmet restaurant; 
3.  Office buildings; 
4.  Fast-food franchises; and 
5.  Commercial shopping, including specialty and import shops. 
(11)  Class 11: Beer and wine, Ridge Road TIF District Historic Theater building license. Permitting the retail sale of beer and wine for on-premises consumption in an establishment located within the boundaries of the area commonly referred to as the Ridge Road TIF area, under the following conditions: 
a.  Where more than 50 percent of the gross sales are attributed to the sale of food. 
b.  Where beer and wine is only served at tables or booths. 
c.  Where there is no bar for the serving of food or beer and wine. 
d.  Where the hours are from noon to 11:00 p.m. on Sunday, from 11:00 a.m. through 11:00 p.m. on Monday through Thursday, and 11:00 a.m. until midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
(12)  Class 12: Special church social center license. The class 12 license will permit the licensee to operate a service-bar only so as to permit the serving of alcoholic liquor (beer, wine and hard liquor) in conjunction with the serving of meals at the events held in the social center hall or building. The holder of a class 12 license shall be required to comply with all applicable terms and provisions of this chapter, including those regarding operating hours. 
(13)  Class 13: Special brewery license. 
a.  The holder of such a license shall be required to comply with the closing hours set forth in section 8-28 of the Lansing Municipal Code, and with all other applicable terms and provisions of said Code. 
b.  Said local license shall permit the holder to engage in only those sales and activities expressly permitted and authorized by the State of Illinois to holders of a state "craft brewers license." 
c.  No such license shall be issued unless and until the applicant provides sufficient documentation to the village that the applicant either owns or is the lessee of the premises described in the license application. 
(14)  Class 14: Airport property license. Permitting the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption only, either with or without meals, and either at a counter or tables. All such establishments shall be located on the property that comprises the Lansing Municipal Airport. 
It shall be unlawful for any person licensed as an airport property licensee to allow alcoholic liquor to be consumed on the premises, to sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the hours of 12:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday, and 12:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m., on Sundays. 
(Code 1969, § 4.305; Code 1982, § 5-53; Ord. No. 265, § 2, 7-13-1972; Ord. No. 488, § 2, 6-20-1978; Ord. No. 83-025, § 2, 10-4-1983; Ord. No. 86-026, § 1, 10-7-1986; Ord. No. 94-002, § 1, 1-18-1994; Ord. No. 95-011, § 1, 5-16-1995; Ord. No. 03-034, § 5, 12-2-2003; Ord. No. 11-029, §§ 1, 5-7, 9-20-2011; Ord. No. 16-013, § 1, 4-5-2016) 
State Law reference- Power of board of trustees to determine the classification of licenses, 235 ILCS 5/4-1. 
Sec. 8-61. - Number. 
(a)  The number of licenses that the local liquor control commissioner shall issue for each class of liquor license shall be as follows: 
(1)  Class 1 licenses shall be limited to 11; 
(2)  Class [2] licenses shall be limited to six; 
(3)  Class 3 licenses shall be limited to four; 
(4)  Class 4 licenses shall be limited to one; 
(5)  Class 5 licenses shall not be limited, except as provided in this chapter; 
(6)  Class 6 licenses: 
a.  Section 8-60(6)a licenses shall be limited to one; 
b.  Section 8-60(6)b licenses shall be limited to one; 
c.  Section 8-60(6)c licenses shall be limited to one; 
(7)  Class 7 licenses shall be limited to two; 
(8)  Class 8 licenses: Reserved; 
(9)  Class 9 licenses shall be limited to four; 
(10)  Class 10 licenses shall be limited to one; 
(11)  Class 11 licenses shall be limited to one; 
(12)  Class 12 licenses shall be limited to one. 
(13)  Class 13 licenses shall be limited to one. 
(14)  Class 14 licenses shall be limited to one. 
(b)  Any license classifications contained in subsections (a)(1) through (a)(11) of this section which have been available, but not issued for 90 days, shall be cancelled and the number of licenses permitted for issuance in the classifications affected shall be reduced by the number of licenses so cancelled. 
(Code 1969, § 4.308; Code 1982, § 5-54; Ord. No. 265, §§ 1, 4, 7-13-1972; Ord. No. 488, § 1, 6-20-1978; Ord. No. 84-014, § 2, 7-3-1984; Ord. No. 84-015, § 4, 8-7-1984; Ord. No. 84-020, § 1, 11-20-1984; Ord. No. 86-026, § 2, 10-7-1986; Ord. No. 88-013, § 1, 6-7-1988; Ord. No. 94-002, § 2, 1-18-1994; Ord. No. 95-011, § 2, 5-16-1995; Ord. No. 98-040, § 1, 12-15-1998; Ord. No. 03-034, § 3, 12-2-2003; Ord. No. 05-029, § 1, 12-20-2005; Ord. No. 07-039, § 1, 12-18-2007; Ord. No. 09-029, § 1, 10-20-2009; Ord. No. 11-029, § 3, 9-20-2011; Ord. No. 16-013, § 2, 4-5-2016; Ord. No. 17-017, § 2, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 17-018, § 2, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 18-035, § 2, 10-16-2018) 
State Law reference- Power of board of trustees to determine the number of licenses, 235 ILCS 5/4-1. 
Sec. 8-62. - Sale in residential and industrial use areas prohibited; exception. 
(a)  No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor within any area zoned for residential or for industrial use; provided, that, this prohibition shall not prevent the renewal of a license issued prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived for premises so located. 
(b)  No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor in any premises, the location of which would violate any of the provisions of the state liquor control law. 
(Code 1969, § 4.312; Code 1982, § 5-62) 
Note- A Class 13 license shall be issued as a special exception to the terms and provisions of subsection (a), which prohibits the issuance of a liquor license for sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor within any area zoned for industrial use. 
Sec. 8-63. - Contents. 
    All licenses issued under this chapter shall, on its face, state the following: 
(1)  Class of license; 
(2)  Terms of issuance; 
(3)  Name of the licensee; 
(4)  Address and description of the premises for which the license was granted; and 
(5)  Date of issuance and expiration. 
(Code 1969, § 4.306; Code 1982, § 5-63) 
Sec. 8-64. - Records. 
    The president, as local liquor control commissioner, shall perform the following functions: 
(1)  Keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all licenses for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages issued by him; and 
(2)  Furnish the clerk, treasurer and police chief, each, with a copy thereof. 
Upon the issuance of any new license or the revocation of any old license, the president shall give written notice of such action to each of the officers listed in subsection (2) of this section within 48 hours of such action. 
(Code 1969, § 4.204; Code 1982, § 5-64; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 8-65. - Display. 
    Every licensee under this chapter shall cause his license to be framed and hung in plain view in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. 
(Code 1969, § 4.402; Code 1982, § 5-65) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-24. 
Sec. 8-66. - Change in location of premises. 
(a)  A village retail alcoholic liquor license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only in the premises described in the application and license. Only one location shall be described in each license. 
(b)  Such location, upon application by a licensee, may be changed only upon the written endorsement by the local liquor control commissioner upon said license granting permission to abandon the premises thereon described and to remove the license to other premises approved and described in the endorsement. No change of location shall be permitted, unless the proposed location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor under state law, this chapter and village ordinances. 
(Code 1969, § 4.311; Code 1982, § 5-66) 
State Law reference- Location of retail sale of alcoholic liquor, 235 ILCS 5/6-11 et seq. 
Sec. 8-67. - Duration. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the licensing year shall commence on January 1 and expire on December 31. All licenses shall terminate on December 31, next following issuance, unless sooner revoked or suspended. 
(Code 1969, § 4.306; Code 1982, § 5-67; Ord. No. 95-011, § 4, 5-16-1995) 
Sec. 8-68. - Renewal. 
(a)  Authorized. Any licensee may renew his license to sell alcoholic beverages at retail at the expiration thereof; provided that: 
(1)  He is then qualified to receive a license; 
(2)  The premises for which such renewal license is sought are suitable for such purposes; and 
(3)  The renewal privilege shall not be construed as a vested right which shall in any case prevent the board from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within its jurisdiction. 
(b)  Application. An application for the renewal of a license under this chapter shall not be construed as such, unless made prior to the expiration of the licensing year, i.e., December 31, and unless submitted with the appropriate licensing fee. 
(c)  Fee. The renewal fee for a license under this chapter shall be the full annual fee, payable as provided in sections 8-92 through 8-97. 
(Code 1969, § 4.310; Code 1982, §§ 5-68-5-70; Ord. No. 95-011, § 4, 5-16-1995) 
Sec. 8-69. - Conviction of licensee. 
    Whenever any village licensee under this chapter shall have been convicted by any court of a willful violation of any provision of this chapter or the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., he may, in addition to the penalties for such offenses, incur a forfeiture of his liquor license and all monies that have been paid therefor; the local liquor control commissioner may thereupon revoke his license. 
(Code 1969, § 4.504; Code 1982, § 5-71) 
Sec. 8-70. - Revocation. 
(a)  Generally. The local liquor control commissioner may revoke or suspend any license issued by him if he determines that the licensee has violated any provision of this chapter, any applicable village ordinance, the Illinois Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., or any applicable rule or regulation established by the local liquor control commissioner or the state commission which is not inconsistent with law. 
(b)  Period. When any license under this chapter shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to any person for the period of one year thereafter for the manufacture, distribution or sale of alcoholic liquor on the premises described in such revoked license. 
(Code 1969, §§ 4.502, 4.503; Code 1982, §§ 5-72, 5-73) 
Sec. 8-71. - License in municipal airport building; insurance. 
    A license for the sale and delivery of alcoholic liquors may be issued to a tenant occupying a building belonging to or under the control of the village in connection with an established food serving facility. Any tenant, who is issued such a license, shall provide dram shop liability in maximum insurance coverage limits so as to save harmless the state, village and village municipal airport from all financial loss, damage or harm. 
(Code 1982, § 5-74; Ord. No. 84-014, § 1, 7-3-1984) 
Sec. 8-72. - BASSET training required. 
(a)  Effective July 1, 2015, all alcohol servers (persons who sell or serve open containers of alcohol at retail and anyone who checks identification for the purchase of open containers of alcoholic beverages at retail or for entry into the licensed premises) of alcoholic beverages at a business issued a Class 1, 3, 4, 5, 6(a), 6(c), 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12 or 13 liquor license must complete a state-certified beverage alcohol sellers and servers education and training (BASSET) training program as defined in this section. 
(b)  A state certified BASSET training program shall be defined as program licensed by the State of Illinois Liquor Control Commission pursuant to 235 ILCS 5/3-12(a)(11.1) and 6-27 and Title 77 of the Illinois Administrative Code, Chapter XVI, Section 3500, as amended from time to time. 
(c)  A copy of a valid certificate of completion for each person required to have BASSET training shall be available for inspection at the premises identified in the liquor license for inspection by the Lansing Police Department, the local liquor commissioner, or his designee. 
(d)  After July 1, 2015, any newly hired alcohol server working on the premises and anyone whose job description entails the checking of identification for the purchases of alcoholic beverages at a business issued a Class 1, 3, 4, 5, 6(a), 6(c), 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12 or 13 liquor license, shall complete BASSET training within 90 days of beginning employment. Until completion of BASSET training, all new hires shall work under the supervision of a person who has completed BASSET training as required by this section. 
(Ord. No. 15-020, § 1, 6-16-2015) 
Secs. 8-73-8-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FEES 

Sec. 8-91. - Required. 
    No license issued under this chapter shall be valid, unless the proper fee has been paid. The appropriate fee will be established from time to time by resolution or ordinance, as required by law, of the board of trustees as set forth in a separate fee schedule and adopted and maintained by the village. A copy of the fee schedule is available for inspection and copying in the village clerk's office. 
(Code 1969, § 4.306; Code 1982, § 5-55) 
State Law reference- Power of board of trustees to determine the amount of local license fees, 235 ILCS 5/4-1; state license fees, 235 ILCS 5/5-3. 
Sec. 8-92. - Regular hours. 
(a)  The annual fee for a village retail liquor license for the various classes issued by the local liquor control commissioner for regular closing hours as set forth in section 8-28 shall be due and payable on January 1 of each year and shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(b)  The classes of licenses are as follows: 
(1)  Class 1; General. 
(2)  Class 2; Package. 
(3)  Class 3; Club. 
(4)  Class 4; Alcoholic liquor and beer. 
(5)  Class 5; Special license. 
(6)  Class 6; Sale of all liquor and beer in original package and all liquor for on-premises consumption in commercial planned unit developments of 50 or more acres. 
(7)  Class 7; Motel and hotel (50 or more rooms or units with a dining room seating a minimum of 50 persons). 
(8)  Class 8; Club for profit (containing 35 acres or more). 
(9)  Class 9; Restaurant, beer and wine. 
(10)  Class 10; Planned unit development. 
(11)  Class 11; Ridge Road TIF District Historic Theater Building, beer and wine only. 
(12)  Class 12; Special church social center license. 
(13)  Class 13; Special brewery license. 
(Code 1969, § 4.307.1; Code 1982, § 5-56; Ord. No. 265, § 3, 7-13-1972; Ord. No. 488, § 3, 6-20-1978; Ord. No. 628, § 3, 12-30-1980; Ord. No. 83-025, § 3, 10-4-1983; Ord. No. 84-014, § 2, 7-3-1984; Ord. No. 84-020, § 1, 11-20-1984; Ord. No. 95-011, § 3, 5-16-1995; Ord. No. 03-034, § 5, 12-2-2003; Ord. No. 11-029, § 1, 9-20-2011) 
Sec. 8-93. - Late hour. 
    The annual fee for a village retail liquor license for the various classes issued by the local liquor control commissioner for late closing hours shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk, plus the regular-hour license fee as set forth in section 8-63. 
(Code 1969, § 4.307.2; Code 1982, § 5-57; Ord. No. 628, § 4, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 8-94. - New license. 
    For a new license issued under this chapter after commencement of the licensing year, the fee shall be the annual fee reduced in proportion to the number of full months that have expired since the commencement of the licensing year. 
(Code 1969, § 4.307.3; Code 1982, § 5-58) 
Sec. 8-95. - Payment. 
    All retail license fees under this chapter shall be paid to the village clerk. The license fee shall be established from time to time by resolution or ordinance, as required by law, of the board of trustees as set forth in a separate fee schedule and adopted and maintained by the village. A copy of the fee schedule is available for inspection and copying in the village clerk's office. 
(Code 1969, § 4.307.5; Code 1982, § 5-59) 
Sec. 8-96. - Disposition. 
    When a license is issued under this chapter the fee shall be deposited in the general corporate fund or in such other fund as shall have been designated by the president and board of trustees, by proper action. 
(Code 1969, § 4.307.5; Code 1982, § 5-60) 
Sec. 8-97. - Rebate. 
    The license fees under this chapter shall be for the whole or any portion of the license period for which application is made, and no rebate shall be made for the unexpired term of a license. 
(Code 1969, § 4.307.4; Code 1982, § 5-61) 
Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Animal Control Act, 510 ILCS 5/1 et seq.; Animal Welfare Act, 225 ILCS 605/1 et seq.; Humane Euthanasia in Animal Shelters Act, 510 ILCS 72/1 et seq.; Humane Care for Animals Act, 510 ILCS 70/1 et seq.; Illinois Domestic Animals Running at Large Act, 510 ILCS 55/1 et seq.; Domesticated Wild Animal Act, 510 ILCS 60/0.01 et seq.; authority of municipalities to regulate dogs and other animals, 510 ILCS 5/24. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to promote the public health, safety, and welfare of the village citizens and to ensure the humane treatment of animals by regulating the care and control of animals within the village. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-1), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any live creature, both domestic and wild, except humans. The term "animal" includes fowl, fish and reptiles. 
    Animal control officer means a village employee or agent, designated by the president or chief of police to administer and enforce the licensing, inspection and enforcement requirements contained within this chapter. 
    Animal hospital means any establishment maintained and operated by a licensed veterinarian for surgery, diagnosis, and treatment of animal diseases and injuries. 
    Animal nuisance means any nuisance arising out of the keeping, maintaining or owning of, or failure to exercise sufficient control of, an animal. 
    Animal shelter means any facility operated by the humane society for the temporary care, confinement and detention of animals and for the humane euthanization and other disposition of animals. The term "animal shelter" also includes any private facility authorized by the animal control officer to impound, confine, detain, care for or destroy any animal. 
    At heel means a dog is directly behind or next to a person and obedient to that person's command. 
    At large means that an animal is off the owner's premises, and not on a leash or otherwise under the immediate control of a person physically capable of restraining the animal. 
    Cruelty means: 
(1)  Any act of omission whereby unjustifiable physical pain, suffering or death of an animal is caused or permitted, including the failure to provide: 
a.  Proper drink, air, space, shelter or protection from the elements; 
b.  A sanitary and safe living environment; or 
c.  Veterinary care or nutritious food in sufficient quantity. 
(2)  The term "cruelty" also means a failure to employ the most humane method reasonably available. 
(3)  The term "cruelty" does not include activities where physical pain is necessarily caused, such as: 
a.  Medical and scientific research; 
b.  Food processing; 
c.  Customary and normal veterinary and agricultural husbandry practices; 
d.  Pest elimination; and 
e.  Animal training and hunting. 
    Dangerous animal means any animal that: 
(1)  Attacks, bites, or physically injures human beings, domestic animals, or livestock without provocation; 
(2)  Because of its temperament or training, has a known propensity to attack, bite or physically injure human beings, domestic animals, or livestock; or 
(3)  The term "dangerous animal" also includes any wild animal or any animal that without provocation has bitten or attacked a human being or other animal shall be prima facie presumed dangerous. 
    Disposition means adoption, quarantine, voluntary or involuntary custodianship or placement, or euthanasia humanely administered to an animal. The term "disposition" includes placement or sale of an animal to the general public, or removal of an animal from any pet shop to any other location. 
    Domestic animal means and includes dogs, cats, domesticated sheep, horses, cattle, goats, swine, fowl, ducks, geese, turkeys, confined domestic hares and rabbits, pheasants, and other birds and animals raised or maintained in confinement. 
    Exotic animal means any of the following live animals: 
(1)  Monkey, alligator, crocodile, cayman, raccoon, skunk, fox, bear, sea mammal or poisonous snake; 
(2)  Member of the feline species other than a domestic cat ( felis domesticus ); 
(3)  Member of the canine species other than a domestic dog ( canis familiaris ); or 
(4)  Any other animal that would require a standard of care and control greater than that required for a customary household pets sold by commercial pet shops or domestic farm animals. 
    Guard or attack dog means a dog trained to attack on command or to protect persons or property, and who will cease to attack upon command. 
    Impoundment means the taking into custody of an animal by any police officer, animal control officer, or any authorized representative thereof. 
    Kennel means any premises wherein any person engages in the business of boarding, breeding, buying, letting for hire, training for a fee, or selling dogs or cats. 
    Muzzle means a device constructed of strong, soft material or of metal, designed to fasten over the mouth of an animal to prevent the animal from biting any person or other animal. 
    Owner means any person having temporary or permanent custody of, sheltering or having charge of, harboring, exercising control over, or having property rights to, any animal covered by this chapter. An animal shall be deemed to be harbored if it is fed or sheltered for three or more consecutive days. 
    Public nuisance animal means any animal that unreasonably annoys humans, endangers the life or health of persons or other animals, or substantially interferes with the rights of citizens, other than their owners, to the enjoyment of life or property. The term "public nuisance animal" includes, but is not be limited to: 
(1)  Any animal that is found running at large unattended; 
(2)  Any dog or cat in any section of a park or public hall, restaurant, coffee shop, ice cream parlor, office, store, grocery, meat market, bakery or any store or shop for the sale of food, except shops for the sale of animal pets or upon any school premises or public playgrounds; 
(3)  Any animal that damages, soils, defiles or defecates on any property other than that of its owner; 
(4)  Any animal that makes disturbing noises, including, but not limited to, continued and repeated howling, barking, whining, or other utterances causing unreasonable annoyance, disturbance, or discomfort to neighbors or others in close proximity to the premises where the animal is kept or harbored; 
(5)  Any animal that causes fouling of the air by noxious or offensive odors and thereby creates an unreasonable annoyance or discomfort to neighbors or others in close proximity to the premises where the animal is kept or harbored; 
(6)  Any animal in heat that is not confined so as to prevent the attraction or contact with other animals; 
(7)  Any animal, whether or not on the property of its owner, that without provocation, molests, attacks, or otherwise interferes with the freedom of movement of persons in a public right-of-way; 
(8)  Any animal that chases motor vehicles in a public right-of-way; 
(9)  Any animal that attacks domestic animals; 
(10)  Any animal that causes unsanitary conditions in enclosures or surroundings where the animal is kept or harbored; 
(11)  Any animal that is offensive or dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare by virtue of the number of animals maintained at a single residence or the inadequacy of the facilities; and 
(12)  Any animal used in organized fighting to determine its strength or skill in combat against another animal. 
    Sanitary means a condition of good order and cleanliness to minimize the possibility of disease transmission. 
    Under restraint means that an animal is secured by a leash, lead under the control of a person physically capable of restraining the animal and obedient to that person's commands, or securely enclosed within the real property limits of the owner's premises. 
    Wild animal means any live monkey, nonhuman primate, raccoon, skunk, fox, leopard, panther, tiger, lion, lynx or other warm-blooded animal that can normally be found in the wild state. Chickens, ducks, geese, pigeons, guinea hens, and turkeys shall also be considered wild animals. The term "wild animal" does not include: 
(1)  Domestic dogs (excluding hybrids with wolves, coyotes or jackals); 
(2)  Domestic cats (excluding hybrids with ocelots or margays); 
(3)  Captive-bred species of common cage birds. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-2), 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 14-022, § 1, 5-6-2014; Ord. No. 18-036, § 2, 10-16-2018) 
Sec. 10-3. - Nuisances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any animal located within the village corporate limits when the keeping the animal constitutes a public nuisance or menace to public health or safety. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-3), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-4. - Exotic or wild animals prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to own, harbor, or permit at large any exotic or wild animal. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-4), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-5. - Number of dogs and cats permitted; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep more than three dogs or cats within the village; except that a litter of pups or kittens may be kept for a period of time not exceeding four months from birth. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-5), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-6. - Owner's or custodian's duty to provide proper care; abandonment prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any animal to refuse or fail to provide the animal with sufficient wholesome and nutritious food, potable water, veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering, humane care and treatment, or to unnecessarily expose any animal to hot, stormy, cold or inclement weather. 
(b)  No owner or custodian of any animal shall willfully abandon the animal on any street, road, highway or public place, or on private property when not in the care of another person. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-6), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-7. - Sanitation. 
(a)  No owner or custodian of any animal shall cause or allow the animal to soil, defile or defecate on any public property or upon any street, sidewalk, public way, play area or common grounds owned jointly by the members of a homeowners or condominium association, or upon private property other than that of the owner, unless the owner or custodian immediately removes and disposes of all feces deposited by the animal by the following methods: 
(1)  Collection of the feces and placement in a paper or plastic bag or other container; and 
(2)  Removal of the bag or container to the property of the animal owner or custodian and disposition thereafter in a manner as otherwise may be permitted by law. 
(b)  No person owning, harboring or keeping an animal within the village shall permit any waste matter from the animal to collect and remain on the property of the owner or custodian, or on the property of others so as to cause or create an unhealthy, unsanitary, dangerous or offensive living condition on the owner's or custodian's property, or to abutting property of others. 
(c)  No person owning, harboring, keeping or in charge of any animal shall cause unsanitary dangerous or offensive conditions by virtue of the size or number of animals maintained at a single location or due to the inadequacy of the facilities. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-7), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-8. - Cruelty to animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously strike, beat, abuse, or intentionally run down with a vehicle any animal, or otherwise engage in any act to cause or inflict unnecessary pain, injury, suffering or death to the animal; except that reasonable force may be used to drive away vicious or trespassing animals. 
(b)  No person, except a licensed veterinarian for humanitarian purposes, shall administer poison to any animal, or knowingly leave any poisonous substance of any kind or ground glass in any place with the intent to injure any animal. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-8), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-9. - Restraint and confinement-Generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any animal to do the following: 
(1)  Fail to keep the animal secured by a leash or lead under the control of a person physically capable of restraining the animal and obedient to that person's commands; 
(2)  Fail to keep the animal securely enclosed within the owner's real property limits; or 
(3)  Permit the animal to run at large upon the village streets and public ways. 
(b)  Any dog, while on a street, sidewalk, public way, public square, other public space, or upon any private property without the consent of the owner, shall be secured by a leash or chain of no more than six feet in length and of sufficient tensile strength to restrain the particular dog. 
(c)  No owner or custodian of any animal shall fail to exercise proper care and control of the animal to prevent the same from becoming a public nuisance. 
(d)  Every female dog or cat in heat shall be confined in a building or other enclosure in such a manner that the female dog or cat cannot come into contact with another animal, except for planned breeding. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-9), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-10. - Same-Guard dogs.
