(a)  Every owner of a guard or attack dog shall keep the dog confined in a building, compartment or other enclosure. The enclosure shall be completely surrounded by a fence at least six feet in height and shall be topped with an anticlimbing device constructed of angle metal braces with at least three strands of equally separated barbed wire stretched between them. 
(b)  All anticlimbing devices shall extend inward at an angle of not less than 45 degrees, nor more than 90 degrees when measured from the perpendicular. 
(c)  The areas of confinement shall all have gates and entrances thereto securely closed and locked, and all fences properly maintained and escape proof. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to dogs owned or controlled by government law enforcement agencies. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-10), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-11. - Same-Dangerous animals. 
(a)  Every dangerous animal shall be confined by its owner or the owner's authorized agent within a building or secure enclosure. 
(b)  Whenever off the owner's premises, the dangerous animal shall be securely muzzled and restrained with a chain having a minimum tensile strength of 500 pounds and a length of no more than three feet, or caged. 
(c)  Every person harboring a dangerous animal is charged with an affirmative duty to confine the animal in a way that children do not have access to the animal. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-11), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-12. - Licenses. 
(a)  Required. No person shall own, keep, or harbor any dog or cat within the village, unless the dog or cat is licensed as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Application. An application for the license shall be made by the owner on a form to be provided by the village clerk within ten days after acquiring any dog or cat. 
(c)  Fee. A license fee shall be paid at the time of making the application. The license fee shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(d)  Exemption. The fees shall not be required for seeing-eye dogs, government police dogs or dogs in the care of the village fire department. 
(e)  Penalties. Any owner of a dog or cat who fails to obtain a license within the time period specified in this chapter shall be subject to a fine as determined by the village board. 
(f)  [Late payments.] Owners of dogs and cats shall be required to purchase a license before July 1 of each year. Licenses purchased between July 1 and July 31 are deemed late and will incur a late payment penalty and require payment of two times the original fee. Licenses purchased August 1 or later are deemed substantially late and will incur a late payment penalty and require payment of three times the amount of the original fee. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-11), 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 13-02, § 1, 2-5-2013) 
Sec. 10-13. - Visiting dogs and cats. 
    Visiting dogs and cats are subject to all the applicable sections of this article, except those sections relating to licensing. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-12), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-14. - License tags. 
(a)  Upon payment and acceptance of the license fee, the licensing authority shall issue a durable license tag, stamped with the year of issuance and an identification number for the animal for which the license has been obtained. Any license issued for the keeping of a dog shall take effect on the date of issuance and shall be valid for the period from July 1 of each year to June 30 of the following year. Every dog for which the owner is required to obtain a license must wear a valid license tag at all times when the animal is off the premises of its owner. 
(b)  No person may use a license for any animal other than the animal for which the license was issued. It shall also be unlawful for any person to remove from the neck of any dog the license tag issued pursuant to this section or alter the tag in any manner. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-13), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-15. - Impoundment. 
(a)  In addition to any other remedies provided in this chapter, an animal control officer or a police officer may seize, impound and humanely confine to an animal shelter, police department facility or hospital any of the following animals: 
(1)  Any dog without a valid license tag; 
(2)  Any animal at large; 
(3)  Any animal constituting a public nuisance or considered a danger to the public; 
(4)  Any animal in violation of any village quarantine or confinement order; 
(5)  Any unattended animal that is ill, injured or otherwise in need of care; 
(6)  Any animal that is reasonably believed to have been abused or neglected; 
(7)  Any animal that is reasonably suspected of having rabies; 
(8)  Any animal charged with being potentially dangerous, or dangerous where an animal control officer or police officer determine there is a treat to the public health and safety; 
(9)  Any animal ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction to be impounded or destroyed; 
(10)  Any animal considered unattended or abandoned, as in situations where the owner has been arrested or evicted from his regular place of residence or is deceased; 
(11)  Any unattended dog found in a public park. 
(b)  An animal control officer or police officer may also, or in lieu of impoundment, issue the owner a notice of violation. Such notice shall impose upon the owner a penalty of no more than $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-14), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-16. - Notice and redemption. 
(a)  Notice. Upon impounding an animal, the animal control officer shall immediately attempt to notify the owner by telephone or certified mail. If the owner is unknown, the animal control officer shall post a written notice for three days at the village clerk's office. The written notice shall contain the following information: 
(1)  A description of the animal; 
(2)  The time and place of taking; 
(3)  The location of the shelter or hospital where the animal is confined; 
(4)  The hours during which the animal can be reclaimed; 
(5)  The fees to be charged the owner; and 
(6)  The failure to claim the animal within five days after the expiration of the three-day posting period may result in the animal's disposal. 
(b)  Notice to owner of licensed animals. When any licensed animal shall be impounded, notice thereof shall be given to the owner or keeper of such licensed animal, informing such owner or keeper of the impounding of his animal and that if such animal is not redeemed within three days of the date of such notice, such animal may be redeemed by any person paying the required fees. 
(c)  Fees. An owner reclaiming an impounded animal shall pay a fee to the facility at which the animal is impounded for each day the animal was impounded. The daily rate charged for any subsequent impoundment occurring within 12 months shall be double that charged for each day of confinement during the first impoundment. 
(d)  Disposition of animal. Any animal not redeemed by his owner within three days after impoundment may be redeemed by any person paying the required fees, or released to an animal welfare agency, or destroyed in a humane manner. Further, any normally domestic animal, obviously homeless, injured, or feral in nature, may after a period of twenty-four hours, be released to an animal welfare agency, or destroyed in a humane manner. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-15), 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 09-014, §§ 1, 2, 6-21-2009) 
Sec. 10-17. - Administrative sanctions and remedies. 
    Matters brought before the administrative hearing officer, pursuant to ordinance violation citations, shall be decided by the administrative hearing officer as in the case of other municipal ordinance violations. However, in addition to the authority to fine violators for ordinance violations, the administrative hearing officer shall also have the authority to issue the following administrative sanctions and remedies in appropriate cases: 
(1)  Obedience training for the animal in question; 
(2)  Muzzling the animal while off the owner's property; 
(3)  Confinement of the animal indoors; 
(4)  Confinement of the animal in a secure enclosure; 
(5)  Reduction of the number of animals kept at any one location; 
(6)  Removal of the animal from the custody of the animal's owner or custodian in cases of neglect or cruelty; 
(7)  The sterilization of the animal; 
(8)  A ban on maintaining other animals in the village; and 
(9)  Any other measure or sanction designed to eliminate a violation, prevent future violations, or protect the health and safety of the public. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-16), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-18. - Hunting prohibited. 
    Hunting is not permitted within the village. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-17), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-19. - Owner responsible for property damage. 
    Owners shall be liable for any damage their animal causes to another person's property and shall replace or repair to the original condition or make financial restitution. A police report must support and accompany the claim. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-18), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-20. - Beekeeping. 
    The keeping of honeybees within the residential districts of the Village of Lansing is declared to be a public nuisance unless: 
(1)  A beekeeper registers the colonies (one or more) with the Illinois Department of Agriculture and the Village of Lansing. A registration certificate (including a registration number) is provided to beekeepers who register with IDOA. A copy of this registration certificate, when delivered to the Village of Lansing, will serve the dual purpose of registering the beekeeper with the Village of Lansing. 
(2)  A beekeeper shall purchase queens from reputable breeders/beekeepers, and shall re-queen an aggressive colony immediately. 
(3)  A beekeeper maintains a number of colonies that would produce enough honey to sustain the hives and provide a supply of honey that is sufficient only for the beekeeper and his/her neighbors or family members. 
(4)  A beekeeper places said colonies in a stable, appropriate apiary, kept in sound and usable conditions, which include hive bodies, supers, frames, top and bottom boards and extractors. 
(5)  A beekeeper encloses the property where the colonies live in a fence or landscaped area not less than four feet high that would prevent a person from inadvertently walking into the colonies. The apiaries must be entirely within the property of the owner and not near an adjoining property line, with sufficient wind screening. 
(6)  A beekeeper maintains the colony in such a manner so as to not cause any unhealthy conditions, interfere with normal use and enjoyment of public property, or the property of others. 
(7)  A beekeeper employs commonly known best practices for maintaining the colonies, and maintains a contact with a local beekeepers association capable of entering the beekeepers property to remove a hive or swarm when necessary. 
(Ord. No. 18-036, § 2, 10-16-2018) 
Secs. 10-21-10-37. - Reserved. 
Sec. 10-38. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Authority. Animal control officers or other designees of the mayor or police chief shall be the enforcement officials for this chapter. These officials, along with police officers, shall have the authority to act on the village's behalf and perform the following functions: 
(1)  Investigate complaints; 
(2)  Impound and destroy animals; 
(3)  Issue citations; and 
(4)  Take other lawful actions that are required to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Interference with official. It shall be a violation of this chapter to interfere with any animal control officer or other enforcement official in the performance of his duties. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-19), 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 18-036, § 2, 10-16-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-036, § 2, adopted Oct. 16, 2018, renumbered former § 10-20 as § 10-38. 
Sec. 10-39. - Owner's duty to know and comply with this chapter; kennels and pet shops; public parks. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each animal owner to familiarize himself with and abide by this chapter. 
(b)  Only licensed kennels and pet shops may breed and offer animals for sale within the village. The breeding or sale of animals is prohibited on residential property. 
(c)  Dogs are absolutely prohibited in all public parks. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-20), 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 18-036, § 2, 10-16-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-036, § 2, adopted Oct. 16, 2018, renumbered former § 10-21 as § 10-39. 
Sec. 10-40. - Penalty. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter to fail to comply with the following: 
(1)  Any provision of this chapter; 
(2)  Any lawful order of an animal control officer or police officer, unless the order is lawfully stayed or reversed; or 
(3)  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the general penalty contained in section 1-23. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-21), 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 18-036, § 2, 10-16-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-036, § 2, adopted Oct. 16, 2018, renumbered former § 10-22 as § 10-40. 
ARTICLE II. - DANGEROUS DOGS 

Sec. 10-41. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare of the village citizens. It is intended to be applicable to dangerous dogs by ensuring responsible handling by their owners through registration, confinement, and liability insurance. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-30), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-42. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dangerous dog means any dog that, because of its aggressive nature, training or characteristic behavior, presents a risk of serious physical harm or death to human beings, or would constitute a danger to human life, physical well-being, or property if not kept under the direct control of the owner. 
(1)  The term "dangerous dog" includes any dog that according to the records of the animal control officer or any law enforcement agency: 
a.  Has aggressively bitten, attacked, endangered, or inflicted severe injury on a human being on public or private property, or when unprovoked, has chased or approached a person upon the street, sidewalks, or any public grounds in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack; provided that the actions are attested to in a sworn statement by one or more persons and dutifully investigated by any of the authorities referenced in section 10-20; 
b.  Has severely injured or killed a domestic animal while off the owner's property; or 
c.  Has been used primarily or in part for the purpose of dogfighting, or is a dog trained for dogfighting. 
(2)  The term "dangerous dog" does not apply to dogs utilized by law enforcement officers in the performance of their duties. 
    Impoundment means the taking or picking up and confining of an animal by any police officer, animal control officer or any other public officer under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Muzzle means a device constructed of strong, soft material or of metal, designed to fasten over the mouth of an animal to prevent the animal from biting any person or other animal. 
    Under restraint means: 
(1)  An animal is secured by a leash, led under the control of a person physically capable of restraining the animal and obedient to that person's commands; or 
(2)  An animal securely enclosed within the owner's real property limits. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-31), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-43. - Declaration. 
    If the animal control officer or his designee, police watch commander or the mayor or his authorized representative have reason to believe that a dog falls within any of the categories rendering it dangerous, the animal control officer, police watch commander or the mayor or his authorized representative, shall investigate the circumstances to determine whether the dog falls within the definition of a dangerous dog. In the event, following an investigation, the animal control officer, police watch commander or mayor or his designee determine that the dog is dangerous, the animal control officer, police watch commander or mayor or his designee may declare the dog as dangerous in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-32), 9-21-2004) 
State Law reference- Dangerous dog determination, 510 ILCS 5/15.1. 
Sec. 10-44. - Notice of declaration. 
    Within seven calendar days of a determination by the appropriate officer that a dog is dangerous, the officer making the determination shall notify the dog's owner, if known, in writing, of the declaration. This notice shall identify the requirements and conditions for maintaining a dangerous dog as set forth in this article. If the owner is unknown or cannot be located, the dog may be immediately impounded. If the owner's address is known, but the owner cannot be located, the notice shall be posted on the owner's property, personally served upon the owner or sent by certified mail to the owner's last known address. 
(1)  The owner of a dog that has been declared dangerous in accordance with this article shall have the right to file a written request for a hearing to contest the declaration. Such a request must be filed with the village clerk within seven calendar days after the owner received notice of the dangerous dog declaration. In the event the owner fails to file a written request for a hearing within the requisite seven-day period, or fails to appear at a schedule hearing, the owner will be deemed to have waived the right to a hearing on the declaration. In this situation, the dog shall be deemed dangerous and the owner shall be required to comply with all the requirements and conditions for maintaining a dangerous dog as set forth in this article. 
(2)  Within seven calendar days of the receipt of a written request for a hearing or as soon thereafter as is practical for the mayor, or his authorized representative, a hearing shall be scheduled by the village. The hearing shall be conducted by the mayor or his authorized representative. The hearing will be informal and strict rules of evidence shall not apply. The owner and the village may be represented by counsel, present oral and written evidence, and cross examine witnesses. 
(3)  The mayor or his authorized representative shall issue a written decision within seven business days after the hearing's conclusion. The owner shall be mailed a copy of the written decision. The decision of the mayor or his authorized representative shall be final. 
(4)  In the event the mayor or his authorized representative upholds the dangerous dog declaration, the owner shall comply with all of the requirements and conditions for maintaining a dangerous dog as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-34), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-45. - Requirements for maintaining a dangerous dog. 
    In order to keep or permit a dangerous dog within the village corporate limits, the owner of a dangerous dog shall be required to act in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Confinement. All dangerous dogs shall be securely confined indoors or in an enclosed and locked pen or structure upon the owner's premises. The pen or structure must have minimum dimensions of five feet by ten feet, and must have secure sides and a secure top attached to the sides. If no bottom is secured to the sides, the sides must be embedded into the ground no less than two feet. 
(2)  Leash/muzzle. The owner of a dangerous dog shall not allow the animal to go outside its kennel, pen or structure, unless the animal is muzzled, restrained by a chain or leash no more than three-feet long, and under the physical control of a person at least 18 years of age. 
(3)  Signs. The owner of a dangerous dog shall display a clearly visible warning sign, in a prominent place on his premises, indicating that there is a dangerous dog on the premises. The sign must be legible from the public streets or thoroughfares upon which the owner's property adjoins. The owner shall also display a sign with a symbol warning children of the presence of a dangerous dog. Exact or similar signs shall be posted on the dog's kennel, pen or enclosed structure. 
(4)  Insurance. The owner of a dangerous dog must maintain public liability insurance providing a minimum of $100,000.00 of coverage, insuring the owner for any damage or personal injury that may be caused by his dangerous animal. Upon a declaration that a dog is dangerous, the owner of the animal must provide proof to the village clerk that the owner possesses the required insurance. Upon village request, the owner shall be required to present proof of insurance, upon occasion, demonstrating that the owner is maintaining the insurance. 
(5)  Change of status. The owner of a dangerous dog shall notify the village police department immediately upon learning that the dangerous animal is unconfined, on the loose or if the dog has attacked a human being or domestic animal. 
(6)  Change of ownership. If the owner of a dangerous dog sells, gives away or otherwise transfers custody or ownership of the dangerous animal, the owner shall, within three days of the sale or transfer, provide the village police department with the name, address and telephone number of the dangerous dog's new owner or custodian. The owner shall notify the new owner or custodian of the animal's designation as a dangerous dog. If the new owner or custodian resides or keeps the animal within the village corporate limits, the owner shall inform the new owner or custodian of the requirements and conditions for keeping a dangerous dog as established in this article. 
(7)  Microchip. All dangerous dogs shall have a microchip implanted in the skin of the dog by a licensed veterinarian. The microchip shall be required to identify the current owner of the dog by name, address and telephone number. The cost of the microchip and the procedure to implant the microchip shall be borne by the owner of the dangerous dog. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-35), 9-21-2004) 
State Law reference- Leash required for dangerous dog, 510 ILCS 5/15.2. 
Sec. 10-46. - Impoundment and destruction-Order. 
    The animal control officer or police watch commander may order the impoundment and destruction of a dangerous dog upon occurrence of one of the following: 
(1)  The dog has attacked, bitten, injured or killed a human being or domestic animal; 
(2)  The dog has been declared to be dangerous and the owner has failed to comply with the requirements and conditions for keeping a dangerous dog in accordance with this article; or 
(3)  The dog poses a threat of serious harm to the public health or safety. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-36), 9-21-2004) 
State Law reference- Apprehension of dangerous dog, 510 ILCS 5/17. 
Sec. 10-47. - Same-Notice. 
    Within seven calendar days of an impoundment, the officer ordering the impoundment or destruction of a dog shall notify the animal's owner, if known, in writing, of the impoundment or destruction. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-37), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-48. - Same-Hearing. 
    The known owner of a dangerous dog shall have the opportunity to have a hearing on the impoundment or recommended destruction in accordance with the following procedures: 
(1)  The owner of a dog that has been impounded pursuant to the provisions of this article shall have the right to file a written request for a hearing to contest the impoundment. Such a request must be filed with the village clerk within seven calendar days after the owner received notice of the impoundment. In the event the owner fails to file a written request for a hearing within the requisite seven-day period, or fails to appear at a schedule hearing, the owner will be deemed to have waived the right to a hearing on the impoundment. In this situation, the mayor or his authorized representative may order the destruction of the animal or take any other steps he deems necessary to protect the public health or safety from the potential danger posed by the dog. 
(2)  Within seven calendar days of the receipt of a written request for a hearing, or as soon thereafter as is practical for the mayor or his authorized representative, a hearing shall be scheduled by the village. The hearing shall be conducted by the mayor or his authorized representative. This hearing will be informal and strict rules of evidence shall not apply. The owner and the village may be represented by counsel, present oral and written evidence, and cross examine witnesses. 
(3)  The mayor or his authorized representative shall issue a written decision within seven business days after the conclusion of the hearing. The owner shall be mailed a copy of the written decision. The decision of the mayor or his authorized representative shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-38), 9-21-2004) 
State Law reference- Appeal of dangerous dog determination, 510 ILCS 5/15.3. 
Sec. 10-49. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Dogs used by the village police department, a private security company, or a law enforcement agency in performance of their duties. 
(2)  A dog shall not be declared dangerous if it is determined that the conduct of the dog was justified because: 
a.  The threat or attack was sustained by a person who at the time was committing a crime or offense upon the owner, a member of its household, or custodian of the dog. 
b.  The threatened person was tormenting, abusing, assaulting, or physically threatening the dog or its offspring. 
c.  The injured, threatened, or killed domestic animal was attacking or threatening the dog or its offspring. 
d.  The dog was responding to pain or injury or was protecting itself, its owner, custodian, or a member of its household, kennel, or offspring. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-39), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 10-50. - Penalty. 
    Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provisions of this article for which no penalty is otherwise provided, is subject to the general penalty provisions of section 1-23. 
(Ord. No. 04-032, § 1(7-40), 9-21-2004) 
Chapter 12 - AMUSEMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Power of village to license, tax, regulate or prohibit certain amusements, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1 et seq.; authority for local regulation of carnivals, 65 ILCS 5/11-54.1-2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 12-1-12-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BOWLING ALLEYS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power of village to license, tax, regulate or prohibit bowling alleys, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2; minor under 16 not to work for bowling alley, 820 ILCS 205/7. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-19. - Gambling. 
    Except as allowed by the Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq., it shall be unlawful for any person to gamble, bet or permit any form of gambling or betting in any premises used for a bowling alley, pin or ball alley. 
(Code 1969, § 14.204.4; Code 1982, § 6-16; Ord. No. 12-033, § 2, 10-16-2012) 
State Law reference- Gaming, 230 ILCS 5/1 et seq. 
Sec. 12-20. - Disorderly conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating, maintaining or conducting a bowling alley, pin or ball alley, to permit the patrons of the same to make loud and boisterous noises so as to disturb the peace or to use profane language. 
(Code 1969, § 14.204.4; Code 1982, § 6-17) 
State Law reference- Disorderly conduct, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-3. 
Sec. 12-21. - Closing hours. 
    No person shall open, operate or use any bowling alley between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Code 1969, § 14.204.4; Code 1982, § 6-18) 
Secs. 12-22-12-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 12-41. - Required. 
    No person shall operate, maintain or conduct within the village any bowling alley, pin or ball alley, open to the public, without first securing a license therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 14.204.1; Code 1982, § 6-31) 
State Law reference- Power of city to license bowling alleys, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2. 
Sec. 12-42. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for a license under this division shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 14.204.3; Code 1982, § 6-32; Ord. No. 628, § 13, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 12-43. - Application. 
    Applications for a license under this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk, in accordance with the provisions of chapter 16, article I, and shall state the location of the intended place of business and the number of alleys to be operated. 
(Code 1969, § 14.204.2; Code 1982, § 6-33) 
Sec. 12-44. - Revocation. 
    The president may revoke any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this division, if the licensee shall have violated any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinances of the village or any statutes of the state in the conduct of his business. 
(Code 1969, § 14.204.4; Code 1982, § 6-34) 
Secs. 12-45-12-63. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BILLIARD AND POOL HALLS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to license, tax, regulate or prohibit pool tables, etc., 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-64. - Minors. 
    Minors under the age of 16 years shall, under no circumstances, frequent, loiter, go or remain in any billiard room or poolroom within the village at any time, for any purpose, unless accompanied by the parent, guardian or other person having the legal custody and control of said minor. Proprietors of billiard rooms or poolrooms shall not permit minors under the age of 16 years to frequent, loiter or remain within said billiard rooms or poolrooms, unless accompanied by such parent or guardian. 
(Code 1969, § 14.203.4; Code 1982, § 6-51) 
State Law reference- Minor under 16 years not to work for poolroom or billiard room, 850 ILCS 205/7. 
Sec. 12-65. - Gambling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to gamble, bet or permit any form of gambling or betting in any premises used for a billiard table, pool table or any other similar gaming table. 
(Code 1969, § 14.203.4; Code 1982, § 6-52) 
Sec. 12-66. - Disorderly conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating, maintaining or conducting a billiard table, a pool table or any other similar gaming table, to permit the patrons of the same to make loud and boisterous noises so as to disturb the peace in the vicinity or to use profane language. 
(Code 1969, § 14.203.4; Code 1982, § 6-53) 
Sec. 12-67. - Closing hours. 
    No person shall open, operate or use any billiard table, pool table or any other similar gaming table between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Code 1969, § 14.203.4; Code 1982, § 6-54) 
Secs. 12-68-12-86. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 12-87. - Required. 
    No person shall operate, maintain or conduct, within the village, a billiard table, a pool table or any other similar gaming table, open to the public, without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 14.203.1; Code 1982, § 6-66) 
Sec. 12-88. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for a license under this division shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 14.203.3; Code 1982, § 6-67; Ord. No. 628, § 12, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 12-89. - Application. 
    Applications for a license under this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk, in accordance with the provisions of chapter 16, article I and shall state the location of the intended place of business and the number of tables to be used therein. 
(Code 1969, § 14.203.2; Code 1982, § 6-68) 
Sec. 12-90. - Revocation. 
    The president may revoke any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article, if the licensee has violated any provisions of this Code, village ordinance or state statute in the conduct of his business. 
(Code 1969, § 14.203.4; Code 1982, § 6-69) 
Secs. 12-91-12-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Power of village to license, tax, regulate or prohibit certain amusements, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-110. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement arcade means a business located in a B-2 (or higher) business district as a special use that contains more than five mechanical amusement devices. During the time it is open to the public, it must be attended by the owner or manager who must be at least 21 years of age. 
    Amusement park means an area for which a B-3 special use zoning designation is required that contains a multiplicity of rides, games, and mechanical amusement devices. 
    Mechanical amusement device means any machine which upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, may be operated by the public generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not registering a score as well as any amusement device on which time is leased by the public. It shall include such devices as marble machines, pinball machines, electronic games, skill ball, mechanical grab machines and all games, operations, or transactions similar thereto under whatever name they may be indicated. The term "mechanical amusement device" does not mean and include mini-computers, macro-computers micro-computers or home computers for personal use that contains read only memory, random access memory either within the central processing unit or separate storage unit even though it is possible to play certain games by inserting a floppy disk or cartridge into the computer system. 
    Person, firm, corporation or association means any person, firm, corporation or association which owns or leases any such machine; the person, firm, corporation or association in whose place of business any such machine is placed for use by the public; or the person, firm, corporation, or association having control over such machine. 
(Code 1982, § 6-81; Ord. No. 83-012, § 1(14.207.1), 12-7-1982) 
Sec. 12-111. - Establishment operating conditions. 
    Licensees, having been issued a license as herein provided, shall operate under the following conditions: 
(1)  Distance from school or church. No amusement arcade shall be located within 500 feet of any school or church. 
(2)  Fire alarms. A fire alarm system shall be installed on the premises to be connected to the village police department and fire department in a manner prescribed by the police chief and fire chief in each amusement arcade. 
(3)  Minors. No person shall be allowed on the licensed premises in violation of section 26-138 (curfew for minors). In addition, no person who is enrolled in a school and is under 18 years of age shall be allowed on the licensed premises during school hours, unless accompanied by a parent, guardian, or an adult member of the immediate family. 
(4)  Attendant. During the time a licensed premises is open to the public, it shall be attended by the owner or manager who must be at least 21 years of age. 
(5)  Hours. No amusement arcade shall be open for business prior to 9:00 a.m. and shall close no later than 11:00 p.m. on Sunday through Thursday and no later than midnight on Friday and Saturday of each week. 
(Code 1982, § 6-82; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.9), 12-7-1982; Ord. No. 83-012, § 1, 6-21-1983; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 12-112. - Seizure and destruction of machine. 
    If the police chief has reason to believe any mechanical amusement device is being used as a gambling device, such machine shall be seized by the police and impounded, and if after court proceedings, the exhibitor is found guilty, such machine shall be destroyed by the police. 
(Code 1982, § 6-83; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.11), 12-7-1982; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
State Law reference- Seizure of gambling devices, 720 ILCS 5/28-5. 
Secs. 12-113-12-131. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 12-132. - Required. 
    Any person either leasing, displaying for public patronage, or keeping for operation any mechanical amusement device, (which games use a video screen or electrical impulses) within the village corporate boundaries, shall be required to obtain a license from the village, upon payment of a license fee. It shall be the duty of said person of such mechanical amusement devices to apply for such license. 
(Code 1982, § 6-91; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.2), 12-7-1982) 
Sec. 12-133. - Age requirement. 
    No license shall be issued to any applicant, unless such applicant shall be at least 21 years of age. 
(Code 1982, § 6-92; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.2), 12-7-1982) 
Sec. 12-134. - Application. 
    The application for such license shall be made upon a form to be supplied by the village clerk and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Corporation. 
a.  Corporate name and address. 
b.  Date and place of incorporation. 
c.  Corporate purposes as set forth in the charter. 
d.  Names, dates of birth, and addresses of the corporate officers and directors. 
e.  Statement of the principal kind of business in which the corporation engages. 
f.  Statement of whether the corporate business will be conducted by a manager, and the name, address and authority of any such manager or agent. 
g.  Statement whether any officer, manager, director or five percent shareholder of the corporation has ever been convicted of a felony, or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality, or have ever forfeited an appearance bond on a felony charge. 
h.  Names, dates of birth, and addresses of all persons owning five percent or more of the corporation's stock. 
i.  A ten-year history of the corporation's addresses and the corporate president's residential address. 
j.  The place where the mechanical amusement device is to be displayed, and a description of the machine. 
k.  Statement of other village licenses held by the applicant. 
l.  Statement of personal history by the manager or agent conducting business for corporation. 
m.  An affidavit signed by the corporation's president and secretary, and bearing the corporate seal verifying the information listed in this section. 
(2)  Individual, partnership or association. 
a.  Name, address, and date of birth of the applicant. 
b.  Location of the place of business. 
c.  Principal kind of business engaged in. 
d.  Statement of interests of any public officials. 
e.  Statement of whether the business will be conducted by a manager or agent, and the name, address and date of birth of any such manager or agent. 
f.  Statement of other village licenses held by applicant. 
g.  Statement whether any person named under subsections (2)a and (2)e of this section has ever been convicted of a felony, or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality, or has ever forfeited an appearance bond on a felony charge. 
h.  A ten-year history of the applicant's business and residential addresses. 
i.  The place where the mechanical amusement device is to be displayed, and a description of the machine. 
j.  Statement of personal history by the manager or agent conducting business for the applicant. 
k.  An affidavit signed by the applicant verifying the information listed in this section. 
(Code 1982, § 6-93; Ord. No. 82-037, §§ 1(14.207.2), 1(14.207.3), 12-7-1982) 
Sec. 12-135. - Inspection. 
    The village clerk, police chief, fire chief and the building inspector, or their respective representatives, shall investigate the information contained in the application and shall determine the following: 
(1)  That the premises designated by the applicant as the business' location is within a district zoned for business within the village and there is no less than 40 square feet per machine; 
(2)  That the premises and the manager comply with the provisions of this article; 
(3)  That the applicant and each manager meet the standards for issuance of licenses; 
(4)  If the investigation shows the compliance of the applicant, its business and its managers with each of the requirements established herein, the mayor shall instruct the village clerk to issue the license, and upon payment by the applicant of the license fee, such license shall be issued. 
(Code 1982, § 6-94; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.4), 12-7-1982; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 12-136. - Fees. 
    Every applicant, before being granted a license, shall pay an annual license fee for the privilege of leasing, operating or maintaining for operation mechanical amusement devices. The amount of such license fee shall be based upon the number of mechanical amusement devices leased, operated and/or maintained in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1982, § 6-95; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.5), 12-7-1982) 
Sec. 12-137. - Display. 
    The license and sticker provided by the village clerk shall be posted permanently and conspicuously at the premises wherein the device is to be operated or maintained to be operated. 
(Code 1982, § 6-96; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.6), 12-7-1982) 
Sec. 12-138. - Nontransferability. 
    A license shall not be transferable from person-to-person or place-to-place, and shall be usable only at the place and by the party designated in the license. 
(Code 1982, § 6-97; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.6), 12-7-1982) 
Sec. 12-139. - Number. 
    The number of such licenses which shall be issued in the village shall be unlimited, but in accordance with section 12-90. 
(Code 1982, § 6-98; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.7), 12-7-1982) 
Sec. 12-140. - Location restrictions. 
(a)  No license shall be issued under this section for the use, leasing, display for public patronage, or keeping for operation of any amusement park at any premises for which a special use permit has not been obtained pursuant to chapter 56. 
(b)  No license shall be issued under this section for the use, leasing, display for public patronage or keeping for operation of any mechanical amusement device at any amusement arcade on premises that are not in a district zoned for business. 
(c)  No person may be issued a license for more than five mechanical amusement devices, unless said person has an amusement arcade or amusement park license. 
(Code 1982, § 6-99; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.10), 12-7-1982) 
Sec. 12-141. - Revocation. 
(a)  Authority. Every license issued under this section is subject to the right, which is hereby expressly reserved, to revoke the same should the licensee, directly or indirectly, permit the operation of any mechanical amusement device contrary to the provisions of this article, village ordinances or state laws. 
(b)  Notice; hearing. A license may be revoked by the mayor after written notice to the licensee, which notice shall specify the ordinance or law violations with which the licensee is charged, if after a hearing by the corporate authorities the licensee is found to be guilty of such violations. Ten days' notice of said hearing shall be given to the licensee. At such hearing the licensee and his attorney may be present and submit evidence or witnesses in his defense. 
(Code 1982, § 6-100; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.8), 12-7-1982) 
Sec. 12-142. - Expiration. 
    Licenses shall expire on July 1 of each calendar year at which the renewal application and fees are due. 
(Code 1982, § 6-101; Ord. No. 82-037, § 1(14.207.5), 12-7-1982) 
Secs. 12-143-12-161. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OUTDOOR AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND CARNIVALS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal carnival permit, 65 ILCS 5/11-54.1-1 et seq.; Carnival Regulation Act, 225 ILCS 205/2 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-162. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Carnival means a group of amusement devices, such as a roller coaster, Ferris wheel, merry-go-round, and other rides of a similar nature, having the following characteristics: 
(1)  Owned by any person; 
(2)  Not having a permanent site within the village territorial limits; 
(3)  Being employed by a nonprofit corporation, charitable organization, church, lodge or club with its permanent site within the village territorial limits; and 
(4)  To conduct the operation of the component parts of said carnival on a royalty basis or other similar basis for the benefit of said local nonprofit corporation, charitable organization, lodge, church or club for a period not exceeding seven consecutive calendar days in any one calendar year. 
    Other outdoor amusement device means a single amusement device having a temporary site within the village territorial limits. 
    Outdoor amusement park means a park having a permanent site within the village and containing one or more amusement devices. 
(Code 1969, § 14.201; Code 1982, § 6-121; Ord. No. 343, § 1, 8-13-1974) 
Sec. 12-163. - Street shows. 
    No license shall be granted or given for any carnival, outdoor amusement park or other outdoor amusement device to be given on any public street, sidewalk or other such public place in the village, except by order of the president and the board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 14.202.4; Code 1982, § 6-122) 
Sec. 12-164. - Police presence. 
    Sufficient members of the police department shall be admitted free of charge to all carnivals, outdoor amusement parks or other outdoor amusement locations for the purpose of preserving and maintaining order. 
(Code 1969, § 14.202.4; Code 1982, § 6-123) 
Sec. 12-165. - Inspections. 
(a)  For the safety and general welfare of those attending carnivals, it shall be the building department's duty to inspect the following: 
(1)  All amusement rides; 
(2)  All power connections to the rides; and 
(3)  The power supply available for each ride. 
(b)  In the event the building commissioner deems it advisable to obtain an opinion from an outside professional concerning the configuration, erection, construction or power for any such ride, he may authorize such services. 
(c)  The sponsor of any carnival shall pay a sum in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk for the inspection of each ride, in addition to any other services authorized by the building commissioner. 
(d)  The sponsor of any carnival shall furnish the village with a certificate of insurance wherein the village is an additional named insured, with minimum policy limits of $1,000,000.00 for liability, and $500,000.00 for property damage, and execute an indemnity agreement approved by the village attorney which shall hold the village harmless from any and all causes of action which may arise as a result of the operation of said carnival. 
(Code 1969, § 14.202.4; Code 1982, § 6-124; Ord. No. 596, § 1, 3-4-1980; Ord. No. 84-015, § 2, 8-7-1984) 
Secs. 12-166-12-184. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 12-185. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate any carnival, outdoor amusement park or other outdoor amusement device that is open to the public and for admittance to which a fee is charged, without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 14.202.1; Code 1982, § 6-136) 
State Law reference- Municipal carnival permit, 65 ILCS 5/11-54.1-1. 
Sec. 12-186. - Fee-Carnival. 
    The annual license fee for a carnival shall be the sum determined by the village board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule and maintained and made available in the village clerks office with the understanding that every seven-day period shall be considered a calendar year and thus be construed to require a separate and distinct license. 
(Code 1969, § 14.202.3; Code 1982, § 6-137; Ord. No. 628, § 11, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 12-187. - Same-Outdoor amusement park. 
    The annual license fee for an outdoor amusement park shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 14.202.3; Code 1982, § 6-138; Ord. No. 343, § 2, 8-13-1974; Ord. No. 628, § 9, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 12-188. - Application. 
    An application for a license under this article shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with all the provisions of chapter 16, article I. 
(Code 1969, § 14.202.2; Code 1982, § 6-139) 
Secs. 12-189-12-207. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CIRCUSES[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Child under the age of 14 years not to be employed as gymnast, wire walker, etc., 720 ILCS 150/1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-208. - Parades; bond. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct any parade connected with a circus in or on any public street, alley, other public way or public place in the village, unless a permit therefor is first obtained from the police chief. Such permit shall specify the route to be followed, and shall be accompanied by a bond in the sum of $25,000.00, conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss, damage or liability incurred or caused by the conduct of such parade. 
(Code 1969, § 14.205.6; Code 1982, § 6-151) 
Sec. 12-209. - Inspections. 
(a)  For the safety and general welfare of those attending circuses, it shall be the building department's duty to inspect the following: 
(1)  All amusement rides; 
(2)  All power connections to the rides; and 
(3)  The power supply available for each ride. 
(b)  In the event the building commissioner deems it advisable to obtain an opinion from an outside professional concerning the configuration, erection, construction or power for any such ride, he may authorize such services. 
(c)  The sponsor of any circus shall pay a fee in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk for the inspection of each ride, in addition to any other services authorized by the building commissioner. 
(d)  The sponsor of any circus shall furnish the village with a certificate of insurance wherein the village is an additional named insured, with minimum policy limits of $1,000,000.00 for liability, and $500,000.00 for property damage, and execute an indemnity agreement approved by the village attorney which shall hold the village harmless from any and all causes of action which may arise as a result of the operation of said circus. 
(Code 1969, § 14.205.5; Code 1982, § 6-152; Ord. No. 84-015, § 3, 8-7-1984) 
Secs. 12-210-12-228. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 12-229. - Required. 
    No person shall conduct or operate a circus in the village without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 14.205.1; Code 1982, § 6-161) 
State Law reference- Municipal power to fix the amount, terms and manner of issuing and revoking licenses, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-1. 
Sec. 12-230. - Fee-Generally. 
    The fee for circus licenses shall be the sum determined by the village board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village clerk and available in the village clerk's office, with the understanding that every seven-day period shall be considered a calendar year and thus be construed to require a separate and distinct license. 
(Code 1969, § 14.205.3; Code 1982, § 6-162; Ord. No. 628, § 14, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 12-231. - Same-Sideshows, concessions. 
    The license fee for each sideshow and concession operated in connection with a circus shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 14.205.4; Code 1982, § 6-163; Ord. No. 628, § 15, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 12-232. - Application. 
    An application for a license under this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall comply with all the provisions of chapter 16, article I. 
(Code 1969, § 14.205.2; Code 1982, § 6-164) 
Chapter 14 - AVIATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Establishment and maintenance of municipal airport, 65 ILCS 5/11-101-1 et seq.; air transportation generally, 620 ILCS 5/1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Scope. 
    All persons on any part of the property comprising the airport shall be governed by the rules and regulations prescribed in this chapter and by others and instructions of the airport manager relative to the use or occupation of any part of the property comprising the airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-1; Ord. No. 401, § 100.2, 4-20-1976) 
State Law reference- Airport rules and regulations, 65 ILCS 5/11-103-5. 
Sec. 14-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Airport means all property belonging to the village airport department, including areas not used for aeronautical purposes. 
    Airport manager means the manager of the Lansing Municipal Airport (airport department) as appointed by the village president and approved by the village board of trustees. 
    Driver means any person who is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Emergency vehicle means vehicles of the police department, fire department, ambulances or any vehicle conveying an airport official or airport employee in response to an emergency official call. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle that is self-propelled. 
    Person means any individual, firm, copartnership, corporation, company or association; and includes any trustee, receiver or similar representative thereof. 
    Police officer means every officer authorized and empowered by the village board to direct or regulate traffic and to enforce the ordinances of the village and the airport department. 
    Public aircraft facilities means the following facilities as they are from time to time provided and made available by the village airport department as approved by the village board of trustees for public use by all aircraft and their operators: 
(1)  Public runways for the purpose of landing and taking off of aircraft. 
(2)  Public taxiways for the purpose of ground movement of aircraft. 
(3)  Public aircraft parking space for the following purposes: 
a.  Parking and storing aircraft; 
b.  Loading and unloading passengers, baggage, freight, mail and other cargo upon and from aircraft; 
c.  Performing operations incidental to the immediate arrival and departure of aircraft; and servicing with fuel; and 
d.  Parking mobile equipment actively used in connection with the purposes of this chapter. 
(4)  Any other space provided by the airport department for public use by aircraft operators at the airport. 
    Vehicle means every device in repose, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including bicycles. 
(Code 1982, § 8-2; Ord. No. 401, § 100.1(A)-(I), 4-20-1976) 
State Law reference- Definitions under Illinois Aeronautics Act, 620 ILCS 5/1 et seq. 
Sec. 14-3. - Penalties. 
    The airport manager or the village board may remove or evict from the airport premises any person who knowingly or willfully violates any rule or regulation prescribed in this chapter, or any rule or regulation in effect by the Federal Aviation Administration or the state; and may deny the use of the airport and its facilities to any such person if it is determined that such denial is in the public interest. 
(Code 1982, § 8-3; Ord. No. 401, § 100.3, 4-20-1976) 
State Law reference- Enforcement of aeronautics laws, 620 ILCS 5/33. 
Sec. 14-4. - Liability. 
(a)  The village and airport department assume no responsibility for loss, injury or damage to persons or property by reason of fire, theft, vandalism, wind, flood, earthquake or collision damage. 
(b)  The village and airport department also do not assume any liability for injury to persons while on the airport premises or while using the facilities of it. 
(Code 1982, § 8-4; Ord. No. 401, § 100.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-5. - Lost articles. 
    All lost articles shall be turned in to the airport manager's office by the finders. Any such articles not claimed in 60 days will be disposed of as determined by the airport manager. 
(Code 1982, § 8-5; Ord. No. 401, § 100.4, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-6. - Accident reports. 
    All persons involved in any accident, personal, aircraft or automotive, occurring on the village municipal airport premises, shall make a report to the village police department as soon as possible, giving all pertinent information as requested by the officer in charge. 
(Code 1982, § 8-6; Ord. No. 401, § 100.6, 4-20-1976) 
Secs. 14-7-14-17. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC AND TENANT USAGE 

Sec. 14-18. - Maintenance. 
    All tenants on the airport shall be required to maintain their leased property in the following manner: 
(1)  A condition of repair, cleanliness and general maintenance in a manner agreeable to the airport manager and in accordance with their individual lease agreements; and 
(2)  Free from all fire hazards. 
(Code 1982, § 8-18; Ord. No. 401, § 500.16, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-19. - Shop area usage. 
    All shops, garages, equipment and facilities are expressly for the conduct of the owner's or lessee's business and operations. No persons other than employees of the owner or lessee shall make use of these facilities or loiter around such premises without individual and specific permission of the owner or lessee. This section applies to the village municipal airport department premises as well as all others. 
(Code 1982, § 8-19; Ord. No. 401, § 500.10, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-20. - Storage. 
    No tenant or lessee on the village municipal airport shall store or stack materials or equipment in such a manner as to constitute a hazard to personnel or property. 
(Code 1982, § 8-20; Ord. No. 401, § 500.15, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-21. - Fire equipment. 
    All tenants, lessees, and licensees on the airport shall supply and maintain such adequate and readily accessible fire extinguishers as are approved by the Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., for the particular hazard involved. 
(Code 1982, § 8-21; Ord. No. 401, § 500.17, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-22. - Direct line or radio communications prohibited without prior approval. 
    No tenants, lessees or grantees on the village municipal airport will be permitted to install any type of direct line or radio communications without prior permission of the airport manager. 
(Code 1982, § 8-22; Ord. No. 401, § 500.18, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-23. - Structural and decorative changes prohibited without prior approval. 
    No tenants, lessees or grantees on the airport will be permitted to effect structural or decorative changes or additions of any type without prior permission of the airport manager with the approval and supervision of the airport engineer. 
(Code 1982, § 8-23; Ord. No. 401, § 500.18, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-24. - Damages. 
    Tenants, lessees and grantees on the airport shall be fully responsible for all damages to buildings, equipment, real property and appurtenances in the ownership or custody of the village municipal airport department caused by their negligence, abuse or carelessness, or caused by the negligence, abuse or carelessness on the part of their employees, agents, customers, visitors, suppliers or persons with whom they may do business. 
(Code 1982, § 8-24; Ord. No. 401, § 500.19, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-25. - Bills due upon presentation. 
    All billings on the airport are payable upon presentation, unless otherwise noted thereon. 
(Code 1982, § 8-25; Ord. No. 401, § 500.20, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-26. - Default. 
    When any tenant, user or grantee on the airport is formally notified that he is held in default of any written or implied obligation to the airport department, whether it is for the breach of performance or service covenants or nonpayment, he will thereafter be billed for all losses of revenue, expenses incurred to reestablish performance or service and other costs, unless the tenant, user or grantee files with the airport manager within ten days of receipt of the formal notification a statement that corrective or preventative measures have been initiated and will diligently be carried to completion. If the promises contained in the statement are not fulfilled, the tenant, user or grantee will be considered in absolute default and appropriate lawful steps will be taken by the village. 
(Code 1982, § 8-26; Ord. No. 401, § 500.20, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-27. - Enforcement. 
    Any person who shall refuse to comply with the rules and regulations in this chapter, after proper request to so do by the airport manager or other authorized representative, shall be requested to leave the airport; and in the event of his failure to comply with a proper request to abide by the rules and regulations of the village municipal airport department, he shall be regarded as a trespasser. 
(Code 1982, § 8-28; Ord. No. 401, § 500.9, 4-20-1976) 
State Law reference- Power of municipal corporate authorities to prevent or suppress trespasses, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-2. 
Sec. 14-28. - Roads, walks, etc.-Use required. 
    No person shall travel on the airport other than on the roads, walks or places provided for that particular class of traffic. 
(Code 1982, § 8-29; Ord. No. 401, § 500.8, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-29. - Same-Obstructions. 
    No person shall occupy the roads or walks on the airport in such a manner as to hinder or obstruct their proper use. 
(Code 1982, § 8-30; Ord. No. 401, § 500.8, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-30. - Sanitation. 
    No person shall do the following: 
(1)  Dispose of garbage, papers, refuse or other material on the airport, except in the receptacles provided for that purpose; 
(2)  Use a comfort station other than in a clean and sanitary manner; or 
(3)  Expectorate on the floors, walls or other surfaces of any airport building. 
(Code 1982, § 8-32; Ord. No. 401, § 500.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-31. - Trash containers. 
(a)  No person shall keep uncovered trash containers in any area on the airport. No vehicle used for hauling trash, dirt or any other material shall be operated on the airport, unless such vehicle is constructed so as to prevent the contents thereof from dropping, sifting, leaking or otherwise escaping therefrom. 
(b)  Areas to be used for trash or garbage containers shall be designated by the airport manager, and no other areas shall be so used. Such areas shall be kept clean and sanitary at all times. 
(Code 1982, § 8-33; Ord. No. 401, § 500.13, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-32. - Lessees' duty to keep airport areas free of oil, grease, etc. 
    All lessees on the airport shall keep the floors of hangars, hangar areas, terminal aprons and ramp areas leased by them respectively or used in their operation, clean and clear of oil, grease and other materials or stains, except as may be provided to the contrary in any specific leases or contracts. 
(Code 1982, § 8-34; Ord. No. 401, § 500.14, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-33. - Disorderly conduct prohibited. 
    No person shall be or become intoxicated or drunk, commit any disorderly, obscene or indecent act or commit any act of nuisance, nor conduct or engage in any form of gambling on the airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-35; Ord. No. 401, § 500.1, 4-20-1976) 
State Law reference- Power of municipal corporate authorities to prevent disorderly conduct, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-3. 
Sec. 14-34. - Smoking prohibited. 
    No person shall smoke in the following areas: 
(1)  On the airport apron; 
(2)  In any hangar or shop; 
(3)  In any service station area; 
(4)  In any gasoline storage area; 
(5)  In any building, room or place on the village municipal airport where smoking is specifically prohibited; or 
(6)  Within 100 feet of any fueling or defueling operation. 
(Code 1982, § 8-36; Ord. No. 401, § 500.12, 4-20-1976) 
State Law reference- Smoke Free Illinois Act, 410 ILCS 82/1 et seq. 
Sec. 14-35. - Open-flame operations prohibited without airport manager's authorization. 
    No person shall conduct any open-flame operations in any hangar or on the airport, unless specifically authorized by the airport manager. 
(Code 1982, § 8-37; Ord. No. 401, § 500.11, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-36. - Property maintenance. 
    No person shall do any of the following: 
(1)  Destroy, injure, deface or disturb in any way any building, sign, equipment, marker or other structure; trees, flowers, lawn or other property on the airport; 
(2)  Alter, make additions to, erect any building or sign or make any excavations on the airport; 
(3)  Willfully abandon any personal property on the airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-38; Ord. No. 401, § 500.3, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-37. - Interfering or tampering with aircraft, etc., prohibited. 
    No person shall interfere or tamper with any aircraft, nor put in motion the engine of such aircraft, nor use any aircraft, aircraft parts, instruments or tools, without the owner's permission or by specific direction of the airport manager. 
(Code 1982, § 8-39; Ord. No. 401, § 500.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-38. - Weapons, explosives, inflammable materials prohibited; exceptions. 
    No person, except peace officers, duly authorized post office, airport and air carrier employees or members of the United States armed forces on official duty, shall carry any weapons, explosives or inflammable material on the airport, except cased sporting guns carried for transshipment. 
(Code 1982, § 8-40; Ord. No. 401, § 500.4, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-39. - Entering restricted areas prohibited; exceptions. 
    No person shall enter upon the field area, utilities and service rooms or areas or other areas as may be designated restricted, except: 
(1)  Persons assigned to duty therein; 
(2)  Persons authorized by the airport manager; 
(3)  Passengers, under appropriate supervision, entering the apron for the purpose of embarkation or debarkation. 
(Code 1982, § 8-41; Ord. No. 401, § 500.7, 4-20-1976) 
Secs. 14-40-14-58. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FUELING AND INFLAMMABLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-59. - Permits-Transfer; expiration. 
    The permits described in this article shall not be transferable and shall expire one year from the date of issuance. 
(Code 1982, § 8-91; Ord. No. 401, § 400.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-60. - Same-Refund of fees. 
    No refund of any part of the annual fee for a fueling permit will be made in the event the vendor ceases to exercise the privileges granted by the permit at any time during the term of the permit. 
(Code 1982, § 8-92; Ord. No. 401, § 400.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-61. - Same-Flowage fees. 
    All holders of applicable permits under this article shall pay whatever flowage fees the airport department establishes from time to time. 
(Code 1982, § 8-93; Ord. No. 401, § 400.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-62. - Class "A" permit-Authorization. 
    Each holder of a class "A" fueling permit may operate mobile refueling equipment on the ramps and roadways of the village municipal airport, and may refuel aircraft on any part of the public parking areas and hangar areas. 
(Code 1982, § 8-94; Ord. No. 401, § 400.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-63. - Same-Equipment. 
    A holder of a class "A" fueling permit shall provide all necessary equipment for the ground support of all aircraft requiring fuel, including bulk storage, fueling trucks, electrical starting units, air start units, passenger stairs, deicing units, baggage loading carts, towing equipment, preheating units, portable water units, lavatory servicing units and any other necessary line equipment. 
(Code 1982, § 8-95; Ord. No. 401, § 400.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-64. - Same-Indemnity. 
    A holder of a class "A" fueling permit shall agree to indemnify and save harmless the village from any and all claims and shall agree to carry product liability insurance and hangar keeper's liability insurance in any amount sufficient to protect the interests of the village municipal airport department. 
(Code 1982, § 8-98; Ord. No. 401, § 400.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-65. - Same-Fees. 
    The annual fee for a class "A" fueling permit shall be in an amount determined by the village board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village clerk and available in the village clerk's office, payable upon issuance of the permit, plus any flowage fees in force at the village municipal airport department. 
(Code 1982, § 8-99; Ord. No. 401, § 400.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-66. - Cleaning of aircraft. 
    No person shall use inflammable volatile liquids having a flashpoint of less than 100 degrees Fahrenheit in the cleaning of aircraft, aircraft engines, propellers, appliances or for any other purpose, unless such operations are conducted in open air, or in a room specifically set aside and approved for that purpose, which room must be properly fireproofed and equipped with adequate and readily accessible fire extinguishing apparatus. 
(Code 1982, § 8-100; Ord. No. 401, § 400.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-67. - Storage-Generally. 
    No person shall keep or store any inflammable liquids, gases, signal flares or other similar material in the hangars, or in any building on the airport; except that such materials may be kept in an aircraft for such purpose, or in rooms or areas specifically approved for such storage by the airport manager, or in safety cans approved by the Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. 
(Code 1982, § 8-101; Ord. No. 401, § 400.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-68. - Same-Gasoline, oil and solvent receptacles. 
    Gasoline, oil and solvent drums or receptacles shall not be stored on apron and ramp areas in excess of the amounts actually needed as current stock. Any material of this type that is kept in the subject areas shall be kept enclosed and covered in housing of a design and type that meets the airport manager's approval. 
(Code 1982, § 8-102; Ord. No. 401, § 400.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-69. - Same-Lubricating or waste oil. 
    No person shall keep or store lubricating or waste oil in or about hangars, except in sealed cans or in containers of a design and type that meets the airport manager's approval. 
(Code 1982, § 8-103; Ord. No. 401, § 400.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-70. - Receptacles for rubbish. 
    Lessees on the village municipal airport shall provide suitable metal receptacles with self-closing covers for the storage of waste, rags and other rubbish. All used waste and rags or other rubbish shall be removed by the lessee daily, or in regular scheduled pickups, but no later than once each week. 
(Code 1982, § 8-104; Ord. No. 401, § 400.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-71. - Doping processes done only in specifically designated areas. 
    Doping processes on the village municipal airport shall be conducted only in properly designated fireproofed and ventilated rooms or buildings in which all illuminations, wiring, heating, ventilation equipment, switches, outlets and fixtures shall be explosion-proof, spark-proof and vapor-proof; and all windows and doors shall open easily. 
(Code 1982, § 8-105; Ord. No. 401, § 400.3, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-72. - Painting. 
    Painting on the airport will not be permitted, except in airport-department approved shops and other approved areas. 
(Code 1982, § 8-106; Ord. No. 401, § 400.3, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-73. - Liquid disposal. 
    No fuels, oils, dopes, paints, solvents or acids shall be disposed of or dumped in drains, on the ramp areas, catchbasins, ditches or elsewhere on the village municipal airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-107; Ord. No. 401, § 400.4, 4-20-1976) 
Secs. 14-74-14-92. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FUELING OPERATIONS 

Sec. 14-93. - Prerequisite. 
    No person shall transport inflammable liquids into any aircraft area or refuel aircraft on any portion of the village municipal airport prior to securing from the airport department a class "A" permit. 
(Code 1982, § 8-121; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-94. - Prohibited. 
    No aircraft shall be fueled or defueled while the engine is running or being warmed by applications of exterior heat, or while such aircraft is in a hangar or enclosed space. 
(Code 1982, § 8-122; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-95. - Smoking prohibited. 
    No person shall smoke within 100 feet of an aircraft being fueled or defueled. 
(Code 1982, § 8-123; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-96. - Operation of radio transmitter or electrical appliances prohibited. 
    No person shall operate any radio transmitter or receiver or switch electrical appliances off or on in an aircraft during fueling or defueling. 
(Code 1982, § 8-124; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-97. - Grounding-Device required. 
    All houses, funnels and appurtenances used in aircraft fueling and defueling operations shall be equipped with a grounding device to prevent ignition of volatile liquids. 
(Code 1982, § 8-125; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-98. - Same-Zero electrical potential. 
    During refueling, the aircraft and the fueling dispensing apparatus shall both be grounded to a point of zero electrical potential. 
(Code 1982, § 8-126; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-99. - Duty to prevent spark or ignition. 
    No person shall use any material or equipment during fueling or defueling of aircraft that is likely to cause a spark or ignition. 
(Code 1982, § 8-127; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-100. - Fire extinguishers required. 
    Adequate fire extinguishers shall be within ready reach of all persons engaged in fueling or defueling aircraft. 
(Code 1982, § 8-128; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-101. - Starting engine prohibited when gasoline is on ground. 
    No person shall start the engine of any aircraft when there is any gasoline on the ground under such aircraft. 
(Code 1982, § 8-129; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-102. - Equipment maintenance; approval. 
    Fueling hoses and equipment on the airport shall be maintained in a safe, sound and nonleaking condition and shall be approved by the National Board of Fire Underwriters in all respects and parts. 
(Code 1982, § 8-130; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-103. - Restricted when passengers are present. 
    No aircraft shall be fueled or defueled while passengers are on board the aircraft, unless: 
(1)  A passenger loading ramp is in place at the cabin door of the aircraft; 
(2)  The aircraft door is in the open position; and 
(3)  A cabin attendant is present at or near the cabin door. 
(Code 1982, § 8-131; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-104. - Duty to prevent overflow and remove when spilled. 
    Persons engaged in the fueling and draining of aircraft shall exercise care to prevent overflow of fuel. Persons responsible will take proper measures to remove volatile liquids when spilled during transfer. 
(Code 1982, § 8-132; Ord. No. 401, § 400.5, 4-20-1976) 
Secs. 14-105-14-123. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AIRCRAFT OPERATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-124. - Violations. 
    Violations of state or federal statutes will be punishable under those statutes and the penalties will be as provided by law. 
(Code 1982, § 8-146; Ord. No. 401, § 300.17, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-125. - Registration-Required. 
    The owners of all aircraft based on the village municipal airport will register their aircraft with the airport manager's office prior to beginning operation. 
(Code 1982, § 8-147; Ord. No. 401, § 300.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-126. - Same-Change in ownership. 
    Any change in the ownership of aircraft based on the village municipal airport will require a change in registration. 
(Code 1982, § 8-148; Ord. No. 401, § 300.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-127. - Same-Federal. 
    No person shall operate from the village municipal airport any aircraft that is not: 
(1)  Fully certificated by the Federal Aviation Administration; 
(2)  Registered with the Federal Aviation Administration; and 
(3)  Carrying a current certificate of airworthiness. 
(Code 1982, § 8-149; Ord. No. 401, § 300.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-128. - Compliance. 
    All aeronautical activities at the village municipal airport, and all flying of aircraft departing from or arriving in the airspace above this airport, shall be conducted in conformity with the current pertinent regulations of the Federal Aviation Administration, the state and the airport department. 
(Code 1982, § 8-150; Ord. No. 401, § 300.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-129. - Equipment. 
    Except when an appropriate Federal Aviation Administration special flight permit or authorization has been issued, and the airport manager's approval has been obtained, no aircraft shall be operated on the airport, unless that aircraft contains the instruments and equipment specified by current federal aviation regulations for that type of operation, and those instruments and items of equipment are in operable condition and functioning properly. 
(Code 1982, § 8-151; Ord. No. 401, § 300.12, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-130. - Wheel and brake requirements. 
    No airplane shall be operated on the village municipal airport unless it is equipped with a tail wheel or a nose wheel, and wheel brakes, except with the permission of the airport manager. 
(Code 1982, § 8-152; Ord. No. 401, § 300.12, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-131. - Moving planes without adequate brakes. 
    When any pilot of an airplane that is not equipped with adequate brakes receives permission from the airport manager to taxi such airplane, such pilot shall not taxi such airplane near buildings or parked aircraft, unless an attendant is at the wing of the airplane to assist the pilot; provided, that, an airplane with wings and tail higher than five feet from the ground that does not have adequate brakes shall not be taxied on the airport, but shall be towed if it is necessary to move such an airplane. 
(Code 1982, § 8-153; Ord. No. 401, § 300.12, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-132. - Engine starting and run-up-Performed in designated area; exception. 
    Aircraft run-up or other engine test operations at the village municipal airport shall not be performed in any area of the airport other than that specifically designated for such purposes by the airport manager: Except that minor adjustments may be made while the aircraft is on a loading ramp preparatory to takeoff, and when such adjustment is necessary to prevent a delayed departure. 
(Code 1982, § 8-154; Ord. No. 401, § 300.7, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-133. - Same-Competent person attending engine controls. 
    No person shall start or run any engine in an aircraft unless a competent person is in the aircraft attending the engine controls. 
(Code 1982, § 8-155; Ord. No. 401, § 300.7, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-134. - Same-Wheel blocks required; exception.
