    Blocks shall always be placed in front of the wheels before starting the engine, unless the aircraft is provided with adequate parking brakes. 
(Code 1982, § 8-156; Ord. No. 401, § 300.7, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-135. - Same-Safety. 
    No person shall run the engine of any aircraft at any location on the aircraft in such manner as to cause damage to other aircraft or property or in such a manner as to blow paper, dirt or other materials across taxiways or runways in such a manner as to endanger the safety or operations on the village municipal airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-157; Ord. No. 401, § 300.7, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-136. - Experimental demonstrations permitted with airport manager's approval. 
    No experimental flight or ground demonstrations shall be conducted on the airport without the express approval of the airport manager. 
(Code 1982, § 8-158; Ord. No. 401, § 300.10, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-137. - Parachuting on or over the airport prohibited; emergency exception. 
    No person may parachute over or on the village municipal airport or on land within the village, except in an emergency. If a parachute drop is made in an emergency, a full report of the emergency will be given to the village police department and to the Federal Aviation Administration as to the type and extent of the emergency. 
(Code 1982, § 8-159; Ord. No. 401, § 300.13, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-138. - Parking. 
    No person shall park aircraft in any area on the airport other than that prescribed by the airport manager, and there shall be no overnight parking on the ramp in front of any hangar doors. 
(Code 1982, § 8-160; Ord. No. 401, § 300.9, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-139. - Procedure for closing/opening airfield. 
    In the event the airport manager believes the conditions of the airport or any part of the airport to be unsafe for landing or taking off, it shall be within his authority to issue a notam closing the entire airport or any part thereof. This shall be filed with the Federal Aviation Administration flight service station, over the signature of the person authorizing such closing. The same procedure will be followed when the field is again usable. 
(Code 1982, § 8-161; Ord. No. 401, § 300.5, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-140. - Airport manager's authority to restrict operations. 
    The airport manager may delay or restrict the flight or other operations of any aircraft at the airport for any justifiable reason. 
(Code 1982, § 8-162; Ord. No. 401, § 300.4, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-141. - Duty to report facility damage; liability for repair/replacement costs. 
    Any person damaging any light, fixture or other airport facility by means of contact with any aircraft shall report such damage to the airport manager's office immediately and shall be fully responsible for any costs required to repair or replace the damaged facility. 
(Code 1982, § 8-163; Ord. No. 401, § 300.11, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-142. - Accident and incident reports required. 
(a)  Persons involved in aircraft accidents occurring on the airport shall, as soon as possible, make a full report thereof to the airport manager for transmittal to the state department of aeronautics, which report shall include names, addresses and all pertinent information. 
(b)  When a written report of an accident or incident is required by the regulations of the National Transportation Safety Board, and as may be requested by the Federal Aviation Administration as the board's authorized representative, such report shall be promptly submitted. 
(c)  A copy of such report may be submitted to the village municipal airport department in lieu of the report to the airport manager required in this section. 
(Code 1982, § 8-164; Ord. No. 401, § 300.3, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-143. - Disabled aircraft or parts-Prompt removal from public view. 
    All disabled aircraft and parts thereof on the village municipal airport shall be promptly removed from public view by the owners. 
(Code 1982, § 8-165; Ord. No. 401, § 300.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-144. - Same-Refusal to move. 
    If any person refuses to move a disabled aircraft as directed by the airport manager, said aircraft may be towed or otherwise removed by the airport manager at the owner's or operator's expense, and without liability for damage which may result in the course of or after such moving. The same shall apply to the removal of a wrecked or damaged aircraft and its parts. 
(Code 1982, § 8-166; Ord. No. 401, § 300.6, 4-20-1976) 
Secs. 14-145-14-163. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TAXIING 

Sec. 14-164. - Airport advisory. 
    The village municipal airport office will operate the Unicom when possible. Weather advisory information is available from AWOS on frequency 119.270. 
(Code 1982, § 8-176; Ord. No. 401, § 300.14, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-165. - Patterns. 
    Aircraft shall be taxied in accordance with prescribed taxiing patterns at all times. 
(Code 1982, § 8-177; Ord. No. 401, § 300.14, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-166. - View of area. 
    No person shall taxi an aircraft until he has ascertained that there will be no danger of collision with any person or object in the immediate area after visual inspection of the area. 
(Code 1982, § 8-178; Ord. No. 401, § 300.14, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-167. - Careless or reckless operation prohibited. 
    No aircraft shall be operated in a careless or reckless manner or taxied, except at a safe and reasonable speed. 
(Code 1982, § 8-179; Ord. No. 401, § 300.14, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-168. - On runway when safe. 
    Pilots shall not taxi onto or across any runway until they have determined that their aircraft movement can be made safely. 
(Code 1982, § 8-180; Ord. No. 401, § 300.14, 4-20-1976) 
Secs. 14-169-14-187. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LANDINGS AND TAKEOFFS 

Sec. 14-188. - Taking off-Large airplanes, etc. 
    Pilots of turbine-powered or large airplanes shall, unless otherwise required by the departure procedure or the applicable distance from clouds criteria, climb to an altitude of 1,500 feet above the surface as rapidly as practicable. 
(Code 1982, § 8-196; Ord. No. 401, § 300.15, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-189. - Same-Small airplanes. 
    Pilots of all airplanes not described in section 14-188 shall, unless otherwise required by the departure procedure or the applicable distance from clouds criteria, climb to an altitude of 800 feet above the surface as rapidly as practicable. 
(Code 1982, § 8-197; Ord. No. 401, § 300.15, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-190. - Landing-Large airplanes, etc. 
    Pilots of turbine-powered or large airplanes shall, unless otherwise required by the applicable distance from clouds criteria, enter the airport traffic area at an altitude of at least 1,500 feet above the surface of the airport and maintain at least 1,500 feet until further descent is required for a safe landing. 
(Code 1982, § 8-198; Ord. No. 401, § 300.15, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-191. - Same-Small airplanes. 
    Pilots of all airplanes not described in section 14-190 shall, unless otherwise required by the applicable distance from clouds criteria, enter the airport traffic area at an altitude of at least 1,000 feet above the surface and maintain at least 1,000 feet until further descent is required for a safe landing. 
(Code 1982, § 8-199; Ord. No. 401, § 300.15, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-192. - Circling; helicopters. 
    Unless otherwise authorized or directed by applicable traffic pattern indicators, pilots approaching to land an airplane must circle the airport to the left, and pilots approaching to land in a helicopter must avoid the flow of fixed-wing traffic. 
(Code 1982, § 8-200; Ord. No. 401, § 300.15, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-193. - Fixed-wing aircraft must take off and land on runways. 
    Fixed-wing aircraft shall take off or land on runways only. 
(Code 1982, § 8-201; Ord. No. 401, § 300.15, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-194. - Populated areas; noise. 
    Takeoffs and landings over populated areas shall be kept to a minimum in the interest of public safety and convenience, and pilots using the village municipal airport shall conform to any applicable noise abatement procedures established by the airport department. 
(Code 1982, § 8-202; Ord. No. 401, § 300.15, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-195. - Prior authorization required for airships, dirigibles, etc. 
    Prior authorization is required before airships, dirigibles, motorless aircraft or aircraft with a total gross weight in excess of 40,000 pounds land or takeoff at the village municipal airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-204; Ord. No. 401, § 300.15, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-196. - No conflicting traffic required. 
    No pilot may taxi an aircraft on a runway, or take off or land an aircraft, unless he has determined that there is no other conflicting air or ground traffic. 
(Code 1982, § 8-205; Ord. No. 401, § 300.15, 4-20-1976) 
Secs. 14-197-14-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COMMERCIAL OPERATIONS 

Sec. 14-216. - Written agreement required. 
    No person shall engage in the sale or rental of any commodities, supplies or services, or any business or commercial activity whatsoever within the airport limits without a current commercial operation agreement, contract, lease or other written agreement with the village municipal airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-221; Ord. No. 401, § 600.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-217. - Violations. 
    Any lessee or operator of any business or commercial activity on the airport who shall be subject to any of the rules and regulations in this chapter and who shall violate any of the provisions thereof shall have his lease or operating agreement cancelled and terminated at the discretion of and upon notice by the village board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 8-222; Ord. No. 401, § 600.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-218. - Services must be fair, reasonable and nondiscriminatory. 
    No person shall engage in any aeronautical activity for furnishing services to the public at the airport, unless: 
(1)  Said service is conducted on a fair, equal and not unjustly discriminatory basis to all users thereof, and 
(2)  Fair, reasonable and not unjustly discriminatory prices are charged for each unit or service; provided that reasonable and nondiscriminatory discounts, rebates or other similar types of price reductions may be made to volume purchasers. 
(Code 1982, § 8-223; Ord. No. 401, § 600.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-219. - Business solely liable for financial responsibilities. 
    Any person engaging in any business or commercial activity on the airport shall accept all the moral and financial responsibilities of its operation, and hold the airport department harmless of any liability incurred because of such operations. 
(Code 1982, § 8-224; Ord. No. 401, § 600.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-220. - Insurance required. 
(a)  Any person engaging in any business or commercial activity on the village municipal airport shall carry insurance for the protection of the customer and village covering all risks. 
(b)  The amount of insurance coverage shall be as established in the commercial operating agreement, contract, lease or other written agreement with the airport department. 
(Code 1982, § 8-225; Ord. No. 401, § 600.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-221. - Commercial aviation services-Agreement required; defined. 
(a)  Commercial operating agreement. No person shall use the airport as a base or terminal for the carrying on of commercial aviation without a current commercial operating agreement authorizing such activity with the airport authority. 
(b)  Definition. The term "commercial aviation services" includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Fixed-base operations; 
(2)  Aircraft maintenance; 
(3)  Scheduled or nonscheduled air carrier carrying passengers, freight, express or mail; 
(4)  Student instruction; 
(5)  Communications; 
(6)  Any other commercial flying. 
(Code 1982, § 8-226; Ord. No. 401, § 600.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-222. - Same-Departmental authorization. 
    No person shall engage or employ any person to provide commercial aviation services as described in section 14-221, except from those persons officially authorized by the airport department to conduct such commercial activities on the airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-227; Ord. No. 401, § 600.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-223. - Maintenance service and repair must comply with federal regulations; certificate. 
    Unless otherwise permitted by his operating agreement, any person desiring to conduct maintenance service for the repair or aircraft engines, airframe, propellers, instruments, accessories or radios shall comply with the regulations established in Federal Aviation Regulation Part 145; and shall hold a suitable valid repair station certificate issued by the administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, authorizing such repair service. 
(Code 1982, § 8-228; Ord. No. 401, § 600.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-224. - Small aircraft for hire; federal regulations; certificate required. 
    Any person desiring to fly small aircraft for hire for the transportation of people or property shall comply with the economic regulations established in Federal Aviation Regulation Part 121, as applied to certification and operation of air carriers and commercial operators of large aircraft. Any person shall, upon the request of the airport manager or his representative, produce evidence of such certification. 
(Code 1982, § 8-229; Ord. No. 401, § 600.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-225. - Fulltime manager required; business should be profitable, safe and promote the airport. 
    Any person engaging in commercial aviation operations shall have a fulltime employee managing and promoting the operation. Such management shall endeavor to have a profitable business while supplying safe, efficient services for the users of the village municipal airport and shall also serve the promotion and advancement of the village municipal airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-230; Ord. No. 401, § 600.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-226. - Applicant must demonstrate that the standard qualifications and requirements are met. 
    Any person making application for a commercial aeronautical concession will be required to show that he will be able to meet the standard qualifications and requirements therefor as set forth in the specimen commercial operating agreement, sections 4 through 10, appended to Ordinance No. 401 as appendix I, a copy of which is available for inspection in the village clerk's office. 
(Code 1982, § 8-231; Ord. No. 401, § 600.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-227. - Soliciting prohibited without airport manager's permission. 
    The soliciting of fares, alms or funds for any purpose on the village municipal airport without the airport manager's permission is prohibited. 
(Code 1982, § 8-232; Ord. No. 401, § 600.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-228. - Student training must comply with federal regulations; certificate required. 
    Unless otherwise permitted by his operating agreement, any person desiring to conduct a pilot school or engage in student training in aviation shall comply with the regulations as set forth in Federal Aviation Regulation Part 141 (14 CFR 141.1 et seq.); and shall have a valid air agency certificate issued by the administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, authorizing such activity. 
(Code 1982, § 8-233; Ord. No. 401, § 600.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-229. - Discrimination prohibited; airport department's authority to remedy. 
(a)  Federal regulations. No person shall, in the use of the village municipal airport or any of the facilities located thereon, discriminate or permit discrimination against any other person or group of persons on the grounds of race, color, creed or national origin, in any manner prohibited by Part 21 of the regulations of the office of the secretary of transportation (49 CFR 21.1 et seq.) and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 USC 2000e et seq.). 
(b)  Airport department's authority. In the event of noncompliance with the regulations mentioned in this section, the airport department may take such action as the federal government may direct to enforce such compliance. 
(Code 1982, § 8-234; Ord. No. 401, § 600.1, 4-20-1976) 
Secs. 14-230-14-248. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VEHICLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-249. - Registration required. 
    No person shall operate any motor vehicle in the aircraft facilities area or landing area without having first registered with the airport manager and obtained permission for the operation of such equipment. 
(Code 1982, § 8-251; Ord. No. 401, § 200.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-250. - Operator's license or permit required. 
    No person shall operate motorized ground equipment of any kind on the airport without a valid state operator's license, or a permit issued by the airport manager. 
(Code 1982, § 8-252; Ord. No. 401, § 200.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-251. - Permit-Operator must carry at all times. 
    Permission to operate a motor vehicle in aircraft areas shall be granted to qualified persons in the form of a permit which shall be carried by that person at all times during vehicle operation in the aircraft facilities area. 
(Code 1982, § 8-253; Ord. No. 401, § 200.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-252. - Same-Restrictive areas. 
    The airport manager may restrict vehicle operations to a certain portion or segment of aircraft facility areas. Such restrictions shall prohibit vehicle operations by a permit holder outside designated areas. 
(Code 1982, § 8-254; Ord. No. 401, § 200.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-253. - Same-Nontransferable; expiration; notice and renewal. 
    Permits under this article will not be transferable, and will expire two years from the date of issue. No notice upon expiration shall be given the permit holder, whose sole responsibility it shall be to renew said permit. 
(Code 1982, § 8-255; Ord. No. 401, § 200.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-254. - Same-Revocation. 
    Three violations of this article in any 12-month period shall be sufficient cause for revocation of a permit. 
(Code 1982, § 8-256; Ord. No. 401, § 200.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-255. - Compliance with division 2 of this article. 
    Vehicle operations on the airport must be in strict compliance with division 2 of this article regarding speed limits and exercising caution, etc. 
(Code 1982, § 8-257; Ord. No. 401, § 200.1, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-256. - Designated areas for cleaning and repair; exception; owner's or airport manager's permission to remove. 
    No person shall clean or make any repairs to motor vehicles anywhere on the village municipal airport other than in designated areas, except those minor repairs necessary to remove such motor vehicle from the airport; nor shall any person move, interfere or tamper with any motor vehicle, or put in motion the engine, or take or use any motor vehicle part, instrument or tool thereof, without the owner's permission or satisfactory evidence of the right to do so duly presented to the airport manager. 
(Code 1982, § 8-258; Ord. No. 401, § 200.3, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-257. - Ground transportation designated areas; contract or airport manager's approval required; exceptions. 
    No carrier for hire shall load or unload passengers at the airport at any place other than that designated by the airport manager; nor shall such conveyance operate on the airport without a contract with the village or without the airport manager's express approval. This section shall also apply to rentals and all vehicles for hire. 
(Code 1982, § 8-259; Ord. No. 401, § 200.5, 4-20-1976) 
Secs. 14-258-14-276. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RULES OF OPERATION 

Sec. 14-277. - Distinctive color required. 
    All vehicles that are authorized to operate in the aircraft facilities area shall be painted a distinctive color, easily identified, when operating within the confines of the public aircraft area and hangar area. 
(Code 1982, § 8-271; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-278. - Lights must be fully operational. 
    All vehicles operating on the airport between the hours of sunset and sunrise shall have fully operating headlights and taillights visible at least 500 feet, and all gasoline trucks and service trucks shall carry an overhead 360 degree revolving red beacon. 
(Code 1982, § 8-272; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-279. - Screens or baffles required on exhaust systems. 
    No person shall operate a motor scooter, truck or other motor vehicle without exhausts protected by screens or baffles to prevent the escape of sparks or propagation of flame in any hangar on the airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-273; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-280. - Pedestrians and aircraft have right-of-way. 
    Pedestrians and aircraft shall at all times have right-of-way over vehicular traffic. All vehicles shall pass to the rear of taxiing aircraft. 
(Code 1982, § 8-274; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-281. - A reasonable speed must be maintained. 
(a)  Speed that will not endanger life, limb or property. No person shall drive a motor vehicle or a motor bicycle upon any public street or road within the territorial limits of the village municipal airport at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper having regard for the traffic and the use of the street and road, or so to endanger the life or limb or injure the property of any person. 
(b)  Prima facie evidence. If the rate of speed of any motor vehicle or motor bicycle operated upon a public street or road within the village municipal airport, which is not a state or national highway, exceeds 35 miles per hour, such rate of speed shall be prima facie evidence that the person operating such motor vehicle or motor bicycle is running at a rate of speed greater than is reasonable or proper. 
(Code 1982, § 8-275; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-282. - Speed limit of 35 miles per hour; emergency exception. 
    The rate of speed on the street or road shall not exceed 35 miles per hour, and it shall be unlawful for any person, except in or on emergency vehicles, to drive a motor vehicle or motor bicycle at a rate of speed greater than 35 miles per hour upon any street or road within the territorial boundaries of the village municipal airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-276; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-283. - Operator's duty to signal properly and observe posted traffic signs. 
    No person operating a motor vehicle on the village municipal airport shall fail to give proper signals, or fail to observe the directions of posted traffic signs. 
(Code 1982, § 8-277; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-284. - Familiarity with the airport light signal required. 
    It is the responsibility of all vehicle operators in airport runway areas to be conversant with the standard airport light signal, regardless of whether or not the vehicle is radio-equipped. 
(Code 1982, § 8-278; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-285. - Unsafe travel prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall operate any motor vehicle on the village municipal airport overloaded or carrying more passengers than the vehicles was designed to carry. No person shall perform any of the following actions: 
(1)  Riding on the running board; 
(2)  Standing up in the body of a moving vehicle; or 
(3)  Riding on the outside of the body of a vehicle or with his arms or legs protruding from the body of a motor vehicle. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be operated on the village municipal airport if it is so constructed, equipped or loaded as to endanger persons or property. 
(Code 1982, § 8-279; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-286. - Driving near runway areas. 
    Any vehicles that have been permitted to operate on the village municipal airport will not proceed closer than 200 feet from a runway's edge, nor cross any of the runways prior to being cleared by the airport manager. 
(Code 1982, § 8-280; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-287. - Driving while under the influence of liquor or drugs prohibited. 
    No person under the influence of liquor or narcotic drugs shall operate a motor vehicle or aircraft on the airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-281; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-288. - Reckless driving prohibited; speed limits to be observed. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle of any kind on the village municipal airport in a reckless or negligent manner, or in excess of the speed limits prescribed by the airport department. 
(b)  Speed limits shall not exceed 15 miles per hour in the following areas: 
(1)  On the ramp; 
(2)  On the apron; or 
(3)  In aircraft parking and hangar areas. 
(Code 1982, § 8-282; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-289. - Operator fully responsible for damage to airport property. 
    Any person damaging any light, fixture or other airport facility by means of contact with a vehicle shall report such damage to the airport manager's office immediately and shall be fully responsible for any costs required to repair or replace the damaged facility. 
(Code 1982, § 8-283; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-290. - Emergencies-Private vehicles prohibited on airport property. 
    During times of emergency caused by natural disaster, windstorms, aircraft accidents and other mishaps, no private vehicles shall be allowed in the aircraft facilities area. Permits issued under section 14-251 shall be rendered invalid until the emergency situation has been alleviated. The airport manager shall determine when normal operations may be resumed. 
(Code 1982, § 8-284; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-291. - Same-Only authorized equipment and personnel to be used. 
    In the event of an emergency on the village municipal airport, only that equipment and personnel so authorized by the airport manager shall be used. 
(Code 1982, § 8-285; Ord. No. 401, § 200.2, 4-20-1976) 
Secs. 14-292-14-304. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RAMP VEHICLE SAFETY PERMITS 

Sec. 14-305. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Vehicle, unit, equipment or device includes manual and mobile steps and stairs, wagons, carts, tugs, heating and electrical service units, station wagons, other passenger automobiles, hoists, derricks, and any other type of movable device used in servicing aircraft and persons on said public ramp and apron area. 
(Code 1982, § 8-296; Ord. No. 401, § 200.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-306. - Standing, moving and parking of permitted vehicles on public ramp and apron. 
    Only units carrying evidence of a current permit shall be allowed to stand, move or park on the public ramp and apron area on the village municipal airport; and the parking and standing of such units, while not actively in service, shall be in such areas as shall be designated from time to time by the airport department. 
(Code 1982, § 8-307; Ord. No. 401, § 200.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-307. - Safe speed and manner of movement required for vehicle or device on public ramp or apron. 
    The speed and manner of movement of any mobile vehicle or device on the public ramp and apron area of the airport shall be such as not to endanger life or property; and the operator thereof shall at all times regulate and control such speed and movement with the highest degree of care, having regard for the circumstances and conditions of traffic and the presence or movement of other property. 
(Code 1982, § 8-308; Ord. No. 401, § 200.6, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-308. - Division's safety provisions in addition to those set forth in other sections. 
    This division is in addition to all safety provisions set forth in other sections of these rules and regulations. 
(Code 1982, § 8-309; Ord. No. 401, § 200.6, 4-20-1976) 
Secs. 14-309-14-327. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PARKING 

Sec. 14-328. - Prohibited areas. 
    No person shall park a motor vehicle in the following ways: 
(1)  In such a manner as to obstruct roadways; 
(2)  In aircraft parking areas; or 
(3)  On grassy areas. 
(Code 1982, § 8-319; Ord. No. 401, § 200.4, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-329. - Airport manager's authority to tow; owner liable for expense and damage. 
    The airport manager shall have the authority to tow or otherwise move motor vehicles that are parked by their owners or operators on the village municipal airport in violation of the rules and regulations of the airport, at the operator's expense and without liability for damage that may result in the course of such moving. 
(Code 1982, § 8-320; Ord. No. 401, § 200.4, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-330. - Designated areas. 
    No person shall park a motor vehicle for loading, unloading or any other purpose on the village municipal airport other than in the areas specifically established for parking and in the manner prescribed by signs, lines or other means. 
(Code 1982, § 8-321; Ord. No. 401, § 200.4, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-331. - Employee areas. 
    All employees of firms engaged in business at the village municipal airport shall park in areas designated for employee parking and none other. 
(Code 1982, § 8-322; Ord. No. 401, § 200.4, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-332. - T-hangar tenants. 
    Tenants of T-hangars must park their automobiles inside their respective T-hangars when leaving the field via their airplane. 
(Code 1982, § 8-323; Ord. No. 401, § 200.4, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-333. - Overtime parking and nonpayment of fees prohibited. 
    No person shall park any motor vehicle in excess of the time limit prescribed for the particular parking area, nor shall any person park any motor vehicle in an area requiring payment for parking thereon without paying the required parking fee. The required parking fee shall be established from time to time by resolution or ordinance, as required by law, of the board of trustees as set forth in a separate fee schedule and adopted and maintained by the village. A copy of the fee schedule is available for inspection and copying in the village clerk's office. 
(Code 1982, § 8-324; Ord. No. 401, § 200.4, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-334. - Prohibited in T-hanger areas when snow accumulation reaches one inch. 
    No person shall park in any T-hangar area at any time when snow accumulates to a total of one inch. Parking is prohibited until snow removal operations are complete. 
(Code 1982, § 8-325; Ord. No. 401, § 200.4, 4-20-1976) 
Sec. 14-335. - Abandoned vehicles prohibited on airport property. 
    No person shall abandon any motor vehicle on the village municipal airport. 
(Code 1982, § 8-326; Ord. No. 401, § 200.4, 4-20-1976) 
Chapter 16 - BUSINESSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal licenses, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-1, municipal powers over certain businesses, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1 et seq.; constitutional authority to license, Ill. Const. Art. 7, § 6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Fair housing. 
(a)  The Village of Lansing is pursuing compliance with fair housing standards and practices as they apply in Cook County in recognition of protected classes. 
(b)  It is a violation of this section for any real estate, agent realtor or any other person who sells housing or operates rental housing to deny housing to any person because of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, disability, parental status, sexual orientation, source of income, military discharge status, gender identity, retaliation, housing status, aiding/abetting and willful interference. 
(c)  The village does not discriminate, and does not condone discrimination, against any person in the price, terms, effective marketing plans, conditions or privileges related to the sale or rental of any dwelling, or in the providing of facilities, repairs, improvements or services in connection with the sale or rental of any dwelling. 
(d)  The village does not discriminate, and does not condone discrimination, against any person by refusing to sell or rent, negotiate for the sale or rental or to withdraw from the market or otherwise make unavailable, any dwelling due to limited proficiency of the English language. 
(e)  The village does not discriminate, and does not condone discrimination, against any person by making false representations or by withholding material information with respect to the inspection, sale or rental of any dwelling, including, but not limited to, representing to any person that any dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental, when such dwelling is, in fact, available. 
(f)  The village does not discriminate, and does not condone discrimination, against any person in connection with borrowing or lending money, guaranteeing loans, accepting a deed of trust or mortgagee or otherwise obtaining or making available funds for the purchase, construction, improvement, repair or maintenance of any dwelling; or discriminate by delaying the processing of or denying such loans or other financial assistance; or discriminate in the fixing of the amount, interest rate, duration or other terms or conditions of such loans or other financial assistance. 
(g)  The village does not discriminate, and does not condone discrimination, against any person in appraising the value of any dwelling in connection with the sale or rental of such dwelling. 
(h)  No person shall solicit any owner or occupant of a dwelling to sell or rent, or list for sale or rental, such dwelling at any time after such owner or occupant has notified the village that he/she does not desire to be solicited. 
(i)  The village will undertake activities to promote fair housing in its community, such as seminars, speakers forums to interested parties such as bankers, financial institutions, local and regional realtors, real estate associations, appraisers, appraisal associations, as well as local publications and newsletters. 
(j)  The village will partner with area agencies specializing in fair housing issues for the conciliation of resolving complaints relative to discriminatory fair housing practices. 
(k)  The village hereby declares the aforementioned to be lawful and in compliance with fair housing practices for any real estate agent, appraisal service, lending institution, private owner or other persons to whom any provisions of this section applies 
(Ord. No. 09-017, 7-21-2009) 
Sec. 16-2. - Paid sick leave; minimum wage-Employers. 
    For the purposes of this section, the term "employee" means an individual permitted and/or hired to work by an employer regardless of the number of persons the employer employs, or the number of hours worked, and the term "employer" means any person, firm or corporation employing one or more employees, or seeking to employ one or more employees, if the employer has its principal place of business within the village, or does business within the village. The term "employer" shall include: 1) the government of the United States or a corporation wholly owned by the government of the United States; 2) an Indian tribe or a corporation wholly owned by an Indian tribe; 3) the government of the state or any agency or department thereof; or 4) any unit of local government or school district. 
    Employers located within the village shall comply with all federal and state employment laws and guidelines with regard to paid sick leave and the payment of minimum wage. Employee eligibility for paid sick leave and payment of minimum wage shall be pursuant to all federal and state employment laws and guidelines. 
    No additional obligations with regard to paid sick leave or payment of minimum wage, including, without limitation, any additional obligations adopted by the County of Cook Board of Commissioners, shall apply to employers located within the village, and the village opts out of any such regulations or requirements, except those required by federal and state law or the village. 
(Ord. No. 17-008, § 3, 6-20-2017) 
Secs. 16-3-16-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES AND PERMITS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-19. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, engage in, maintain, operate, carry on or manage a business or occupation for which a license is required by this Code, without a license first having been procured for such business or occupation. 
(Code 1969, § 14.101; Code 1982, § 16-16) 
Sec. 16-20. - President's authority to enforce provisions. 
    It shall be the president's duty to examine or cause to be examined all persons and places of business subject to a license for the purpose of ascertaining whether or not such license has been procured. In case of the neglect or refusal of any person to procure a license, as required by any section of this chapter, the president shall have the authority, and it shall be his duty, to take such action as he deems necessary to enforce said license requirement. 
(Code 1969, § 14.112; Code 1982, § 16-17) 
Sec. 16-21. - Does not create any property or vested right. 
    No license issued by the village shall operate to create any property or vested right. 
(Code 1969, § 14.106.5; Code 1982, § 16-18) 
Sec. 16-22. - Fees-Paid with application. 
    All applications for a license made to the village clerk shall be accompanied by the full amount of the fee payable for such license. 
(Code 1969, § 14.104.1; Code 1982, § 16-19) 
Sec. 16-23. - Same-Advanced payment receipt. 
    Whenever a license cannot be issued at the time the application is made, the village clerk shall issue a receipt to the applicant for the money paid in advance. All such receipts shall have plainly indicated thereon that the receipt of payment for the license fee is not to be construed as the issuance of a license. 
(Code 1969, § 14.104.2; Code 1982, § 16-20) 
Sec. 16-24. - Same-Advanced payment receipt does not entitle holder to any rights and privileges of licensees. 
    No receipt for license fees or the payment of any license fee in advance of the issuance of the license in due form shall entitle or authorize any person to any of the rights or privileges conferred by the issuance of any license or to the opening or maintaining of any business or establishment contrary to any of the provisions of any section of this Code. 
(Code 1969, § 14.104.3; Code 1982, § 16-21) 
Sec. 16-25. - Same-Part of corporate fund. 
    Except as otherwise provided, all license fees shall become a part of the corporate fund. 
(Code 1969, § 14.104.4; Code 1982, § 16-22) 
Sec. 16-26. - Application-Form provided by village clerk. 
    All applications for licenses of any character whatsoever, except those licenses specifically excepted, shall be made in writing to the village clerk on a form provided for that purpose. 
(Code 1969, § 14.102.1; Code 1982, § 16-23) 
Sec. 16-27. - Same-Contents. 
    Every application for a license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name of the person desiring the license; 
(2)  The place of business of such applicant; 
(3)  If the applicant is a partnership or firm: 
a.  Names and residence addresses of each of its members; 
b.  If a limited partnership, the names and residence addresses of each general partner thereof; 
(4)  If a corporation, the application shall contain the names and residences of its principal officers; 
(5)  Location of the place of business, or proposed location thereof, for which the license is sought; 
(6)  Such other information as may be required by the village clerk in conformity with the provisions prescribing the requirements of such license; and 
(7)  Such other and further information as the president and board of trustees may, in their discretion, deem pertinent and material after the application has been submitted to the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 14.102.2; Code 1982, § 16-24) 
Sec. 16-28. - Same-Verification by sworn affidavit. 
    All applicants may be required to swear to any statement made in connection with the application for the issuance of any license. Such affidavit may be made by the applicant before a notary in the village clerk's office and shall be sworn to before any officer authorized to administer oaths. Sworn affidavits shall be required for the following: 
(1)  When any applicant for a license is required to make any statement contained in the application under oath; 
(2)  When the sureties on the bond to be executed in connection with the issuance of a license are required to be sworn to any statement made therein; or 
(3)  When any affidavit is required to be made in connection with the issuance of a plate or emblem by the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 14.102.3; Code 1982, § 16-25) 
Sec. 16-29. - Same-Village clerk as custodian. 
    The village clerk shall be the custodian of all applications for licenses which, under the provisions of any section of this Code, are required to be made to him. 
(Code 1969, § 14.102.6; Code 1982, § 16-26) 
Sec. 16-30. - Same-Factors concerning the public's general welfare considered. 
    In considering an application for a license, the president and board of trustees may consider the citizens' general welfare, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Congestion and traffic on public streets and rights-of-way; 
(2)  Adequacy of personnel to control and police the activity involved in the license; 
(3)  The public convenience and necessity of the activity sought to be licensed; 
(4)  Nuisances; 
(5)  Morals; and 
(6)  Health and safety. 
(Code 1969, § 14.102.4; Code 1982, § 16-27) 
Sec. 16-31. - Division of license year; effect on renewal. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided, when provision is made for the division of any license year into periods and the issuance of a license for any such period is provided for, a new application for the purpose of renewing such license need not be made in such case by the beginning of each succeeding period, unless required by the village clerk or the head of the department charged with enforcement of a provision under which the license is issued. 
(Code 1969, § 14.102.5; Code 1982, § 16-28) 
Sec. 16-32. - Investigations. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a license which requires an investigation or an inspection by any village department or board, and the approval thereof as to the character or fitness of any applicant for a license, or as to the proper location or condition of the premises in which the business for which a license is applied is to be managed, conducted or operated, or carried on, the village clerk shall transmit to each department or board charged with the investigation and approval of any such application such information as may be necessary in order that the required investigation or inspection may be made. Each department head or chairman of a board so charged with such investigation or inspection shall, immediately upon receipt of such information from the village clerk, cause an investigation or inspection to be made and shall, within ten days after the receipt of said information from the village clerk, either approve or disapprove the issuance of such license, and shall notify the village clerk accordingly. 
(Code 1969, § 14.103; Code 1982, § 16-29) 
Sec. 16-33. - Grounds for issuance. 
    Upon receiving satisfactory proof from the village clerk that the applicant for a license or each of the principal officers, if the applicant is a corporation, is a fit and proper person to be granted such license, and that all laws, sections of this Code and village ordinances regulating the business or occupation for which such license is applied for have been complied with, the president may authorize the issuance of the said license by the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 14.106.2; Code 1982, § 16-30) 
Sec. 16-34. - Granted by president. 
    In all cases where licenses are required to be procured, such licenses shall be granted by the president and attested by the village clerk, except where provision is expressly made for the granting of licenses by some other officer of the village. 
(Code 1969, § 14.105.1; Code 1982, § 16-31) 
Sec. 16-35. - Issuance by village clerk. 
    All licenses authorized to be issued and required to be procured by any section of this Code, which are granted by the president, shall be issued by the village clerk, except where otherwise specifically provided, upon instruction or direction from the president. 
(Code 1969, § 14.105.2; Code 1982, § 16-32) 
Sec. 16-36. - Contents. 
    All licenses issued by the village shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Village seal; 
(2)  Name of the licensee; 
(3)  Address of the business; 
(4)  Nature or kind of business or occupation licensed; 
(5)  Amount of fee paid; and 
(6)  Such other material information as the president and the village clerk shall prescribe. 
(Code 1969, § 14.106.3; Code 1982, § 16-33) 
Sec. 16-37. - Proof of license mailed by village clerk. 
    When all requirements provided in this Code have been complied with, the village clerk shall be permitted to transmit by mail any license certificates and license plates, tags, badges, emblems and other insignia to qualified applicants therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 14.106.6; Code 1982, § 16-34) 
Sec. 16-38. - Licensee's duty to display certificate on premises. 
    When a license certificate is delivered to any licensee who has designated therein a building, room, store, office or place in which the licensed business or occupation is to be conducted, it shall be the duty of such licensee to post the same in a conspicuous place upon the licensed premises. 
(Code 1969, § 14.111; Code 1982, § 16-35) 
Sec. 16-39. - Change of location; notice required. 
    If any person licensed to engage in a business or occupation at a particular place shall, before the expiration of the license period, desire to change the location of such place of business, he shall forthwith notify the village clerk of such fact. No business or occupation shall be engaged in under the authority of such license at such new location until notice of such change has been given as provided in this section, and until such licensee shall have complied with all the applicable provisions of this Code, relating to the engaging in of such business or occupation at such new location, including the approval of the department heads or boards which originally approved the application for said license. 
(Code 1969, § 14.107; Code 1982, § 16-36) 
Sec. 16-40. - License year. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall have a uniform license year beginning July 1 and ending with June 30, next, unless the same shall be suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1969, § 14.106.1; Code 1982, § 16-37) 
Sec. 16-41. - Duration. 
    Except where otherwise expressly provided, no license shall be granted for a period longer than one year, and except where otherwise expressly provided, every license shall expire on June 30 following the date of issuance. No license shall be issued for any period of time less than a year, except when otherwise expressly provided. 
(Code 1969, § 14.106.4; Code 1982, § 16-38) 
Sec. 16-42. - Renewal-Authorization. 
    The village clerk, upon the president's order, shall have the authority to authorize the renewal of any license at the beginning of a new license period, upon the payment of the required fee, unless he has been notified prior to the beginning of the license period not to renew any such license by one or more department heads who are required to make such investigation or inspection, in which event no renewal shall be had until such notice is withdrawn or a new investigation or inspection has been made and renewal of the license approved. 
(Code 1969, § 14.109; Code 1982, § 16-39) 
Sec. 16-43. - Same-New investigation; village clerk to notify department heads. 
    At least 30 days prior to the expiration of any license or class of licenses, the village clerk shall notify each department that is required to make an investigation or inspection of the following information: 
(1)  The character or fitness of any applicant for a license; 
(2)  The proper location or condition of the premises in which the business or occupation is to be conducted or engaged in; and 
(3)  To submit to him a list of licenses which such department head desires not to have renewed without a new investigation as to any matter which it is charged with the duty of investigating. 
(Code 1969, § 14.108; Code 1982, § 16-40) 
Sec. 16-44. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
(a)  Emergency suspension of business operations. 
(1)  When the conduct or operation of any commercial establishment or activity, whether licensed or unlicensed, shall constitute a nuisance in fact and a clear and present danger to the public health, safety, or general welfare, the president shall be authorized to summarily order the cessation of business and the closing of the premises for a period not to exceed ten days. 
(2)  Within eight days after a license or permit is suspended, the president shall call a hearing as provided in subsection (d) of this section for the purpose of determining whether or not the license or permit should be revoked or further suspended. 
(b)  Suspension or revocation of license. 
(1)  Licenses issued by the village may be suspended for up to 30 days, revoked or the licensee required to perform other actions, in addition to payment of any fine as imposed by the president after notice and hearing as provided in subsection (d) of this section for any of the following causes: 
a.  Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for the license; 
b.  Failure by the applicant to comply with any provision of this code or any statutes of the State of Illinois relating to the business, occupation or to the premises occupied; 
c.  Conviction of the applicant of any felony or of a misdemeanor where such conviction indicates their inability to operate a safe, honest, and legitimate business operation within the village; 
d.  Failure of the licensee or permittee to pay any fine, penalty or debt owed to the village; 
e.  Any deceptive trade practices as defined by state or federal law or regulation and shall comply with all applicable laws and regulations regarding consumer protection and deceptive trade practices; 
f.  Failure to comply with all village zoning, building, fire and health codes, and ordinances, as well as all other applicable village codes, ordinances, rules, and regulations and failure to maintain the premises in good repair, free of litter and debris and in a safe condition for employees, customers and other persons present therein or thereon; 
g.  Refusal to permit an inspection or sampling or any interference with a duly authorized village officer or employee while in the reasonable performance of his duties in making such inspections; 
h.  The license was issued in error; or 
i.  Any other violation of any village ordinance, resolution or regulation. 
(2)  At or prior to the hearing, the parties may enter into an agreement which establishes a series of actions to be taken and/or fines to be paid which will avoid suspension or revocation at that time. 
(c)  Prosecution and other penalties. Such revocation, if ordered, shall not preclude prosecution and imposition of any other penalties provided for the violation of other applicable provisions of this chapter or other ordinances of the village. No person whose license has been revoked shall be eligible for a new license for a period of 12 months. 
(d)  Hearing procedures. 
(1)  Notice: 
a.  Notice of a hearing shall set forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. 
b.  Such notice shall be served by certified mail (return receipt requested) to the licensee at his last known residence or business address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing or personally served on the licensee at least three days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
c.  If the licensee shall request a continuance in the date of the hearing, any suspension in effect shall be continued until the continued hearing date. 
d.  All pleadings, motions, notices, and orders shall be filed with the village attorney. 
(2)  Procedures rules: 
a.  Prior to the beginning of any hearing, the president or his designee may adopt additional procedural rules as may be necessary for that hearing. 
b.  At the hearing, the licensee shall be permitted counsel and shall have the right to respond, present evidence, and cross examine witnesses. 
c.  All proceedings shall be stenographically or electronically recorded. 
d.  Irrelevant, immaterial, or unduly repetitious evidence shall be excluded. The rules of evidence as applied in civil cases in the circuit courts of the state shall be followed. Evidence not admissible under those rules of evidence may be admitted, however, if it is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent men in the conduct of their affairs. Objections to evidentiary offers may be made and shall be noted in the record. 
e.  No discovery procedure shall be used prior to a hearing except by leave of the president or his designee who shall supervise all or any part of any discovery procedures. 
f.  The standard for proof for hearing shall be by the preponderance of the evidence. 
g.  The president or his designee shall preside and render the decision within a reasonable time after the conclusion of the hearing, but not later than 20 days after such conclusion. The decision shall be in writing and shall summarize the evidence and state the reasons for the decision. 
(3)  Hearing costs: 
a.  Any licensee whose license is suspended or revoked, or a business that operates without a license, shall pay to the village the costs of the hearing before the president or his designee. The president or his designee shall determine the costs incurred by the village for said hearing, including, but not limited to, court reporter fees, the costs of transcripts or records, attorney fees, the cost of preparing the mailing notices and orders, and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the village or such lesser sum as the president may allow. 
b.  The licensee shall pay said costs to the village within 30 days of notification of the costs by the president. Failure to pay said costs within 30 days of notification is a violation of this section and may be cause for license suspension, revocation or the levy of a fine. 
(Code 1969, § 14.110.1; Code 1982, § 16-41; Ord. No. 12-019, § 1, 6-19-2012; Ord. No. 13-11, § 1, 3-5-2013) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 12-019, adopted June 19, 2012, changed the title of § 16-44 from "Revocation-Good cause" to "Suspension or revocation of license." 
Sec. 16-45. - Same-Nonpayment. 
    Whenever it shall appear from the books or records kept by the village clerk that any person holding any license, permit or any kind of privilege granted by the village has failed to pay the amount due thereon, the clerk shall report the fact to the president, and the president may revoke such license, permit or privilege. 
(Code 1969, § 14.110.3; Code 1982, § 16-42) 
Sec. 16-46. - Same-Violation. 
    If at any time after the granting of any license, any licensee shall have violated any of the applicable provisions of state law or this Code in the conduct of his business, the president may revoke the license therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 14.110.2; Code 1982, § 16-43) 
Sec. 16-47. - Limitation on number of certain licenses issued. 
    The following business licenses shall be limited in the number of such licenses issued within the village: 
(1)  Pay day loan stores ..... 3 
(2)  Dry cleaners ..... 6 
(3)  Nail salons ..... 8 
(4)  Hair salons ..... 27 
(5)  Barbershops ..... 5 
(6)  Secondhand dealers (not including jewelers) ..... 2 
(7)  Consignment/resale/shop/thrift shop (not including antique dealers) ..... 3 
(8)  Tattoo shops ..... 1 
(9)  Massage parlors ..... 3 
(10)  Child day care centers ..... 25 
(11)  Banks and financial institutions ..... 13 
(Ord. No. 13-10, § 1, 3-5-2013) 
Sec. 16-48. - Donation and recycle containers. 
(a)  Generally. Donation or recycle storage containers (hereinafter referred to in this section as "bins") are prohibited in the Village of Lansing. 
(b)  Exceptions. Registered nonprofit organizations are permitted to place donation and/or recycle bins on nonresidential property in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Nonresidential premises devoted to nonprofit purposes, and churches, are permitted to have one bin per location and no more than two bins in total in the village. 
(2)  The bin(s) shall be appropriately located so as not to interfere with sight triangles, on-site circulation, required setbacks, landscaping, parking, and any other requirements that may have been imposed as part of the site plan approval for the premises. Bin(s) shall be placed on a concrete or asphalt surface and securely anchored to the surface below. A basic site plan showing the proposed location of the bin(s) must be submitted at time of application. 
(3)  The bin(s) shall be of the type that are enclosed by use of a one-way receiving door so that the contents of the bin(s) may not be accessed by anyone other than those responsible for the retrieval of the contents. 
(4)  Each bin shall not cover a ground surface area in excess of five feet by five feet, nor be more than six feet in height. The color of the bin(s) shall be green, blue or white only. 
(5)  The physical appearance of the bin must be without damage, corrosion or any other signs of aging. Markings, stickers and logos on the bin shall not cover more than 50 percent of the visible surface and must be germane to the organization's purpose. The name and valid phone number of the registered non-profit organization must be clearly and conspicuously displayed on the exterior of the bin. 
(6)  Each bin must be regularly emptied of its contents so that it does not overflow, resulting in items being stacked or strewn about the surrounding area. 
(7)  A permit for donation and/or recycling bins shall be required and shall be good for one calendar year. The permit shall be issued by the building commissioner, but can only be granted when it is determined by the building commissioner that: 
a.  The bin(s) are for use by a duly registered non-profit organization; 
b.  The proper types of bin(s) are being used as described by this section; 
c.  The bin(s) are being placed in a proper location as described by this section; 
d.  Letter of authority/permission from the owner of the property upon which the bin(s) are to be and/or are already located; and 
e.  Name, address and phone number of the nonprofit organization or church displayed on each bin. 
(c)  If any donation and/or recycling bins are placed without a permit, the bin(s) shall be removed immediately. If bins are not maintained in conformity with this section, citations shall be issued to the bin and property owner. If any bin is cited for two or more violations in any permit period, the permit shall be revoked and the bin removed from the village immediately. 
(d)  Any bin(s) located in the village at the time this section is enacted which are illegal, must be removed within 60 days of the date of this section. 
(Ord. No. 13-12, § 1, 3-5-2013) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 13-12, adopted March 5, 2013, added provisions to the Code designated as § 16-47. Inasmuch as § 16-47 already exists, said provisions have been redesignated as § 16-48 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 16-49-16-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NEW BUSINESSES 

Sec. 16-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business means the occupation of a store, office building, or structure by any type of entity, commercial or otherwise, whether or not the unit occupied is open to the general public, except for those businesses whose licensure or regulation is preempted by state law. 
(Code 1982, § 16-56; Ord. No. 635, § 1(14.802.1), 3-3-1981) 
Sec. 16-67. - Permit required; scope. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hereafter commence the operation of a new business upon or within the premises until a permit for the commencement of business is first secured and the provisions of this article are fully complied with. The term "new business" includes a transfer of ownership or location. 
(Code 1982, § 16-57; Ord. No. 635, § 1(14.801), 3-3-1981) 
Sec. 16-68. - Application. 
    An application for such permit shall be made to the village clerk which shall state, in addition to the other requirements set forth in the application, the following: 
(1)  Name of the owner of the business; 
(2)  Name under which business is to be conducted; 
(3)  Address of the business premises; and 
(4)  Type of business. 
(Code 1982, § 16-58; Ord. No. 635, § 1(14.802), 3-3-1981) 
Sec. 16-69. - Fees. 
    The applicant for a permit shall, at the time of making the application, pay to the village clerk a fee in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. This fee shall be waived if the business is to be conducted in a newly constructed building for which a certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
(Code 1982, § 16-59; Ord. No. 635, § 1(14.807), 3-3-1981) 
Sec. 16-70. - Fire inspection. 
    No permit shall be issued until the fire inspector has conducted an inspection of the business premises and certified that there are no violations of the fire code. 
(Code 1982, § 16-60; Ord. No. 635, § 1(14.803), 3-3-1981) 
Sec. 16-71. - Building code inspection; violation. 
    No permit shall be issued until the building commissioner has conducted an inspection of the business premises and certified that there are no violations of the building code or that, if there are violations of the present building code, such violations existed before the adoption of the present building code and are of a type which are permissible by reason of having existed prior to the adoption of the present building code. 
(Code 1982, § 16-61; Ord. No. 635, § 1(14.804), 3-3-1981) 
Sec. 16-72. - Fire inspector's and building commissioner's authority to close a business. 
    Either the fire chief or his fire inspector, or the building commissioner shall have the right and the duty to close all business activities at any location within the village until a business application is made and the inspections by the fire inspector and building commissioner are completed. A business is subject to closure if any code violation is found and not corrected within the specific time allowed by the official having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1982, § 16-62; Ord. No. 635, § 1(14.805), 3-3-1981; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 16-73. - Appeal; notice. 
    Upon the refusal of the fire inspector or the building commissioner to approve the commencement of business within the village, the business operator may petition to the president and board of trustees, in writing, setting forth the reasons why either the fire inspector or building commissioner is in error in refusing to grant the permit and may request a hearing before the corporate authorities at the next regularly scheduled village board meeting to be held not less than ten days following the filing of the appeal with the village clerk. Notices to the village shall be by mail or delivery to the village clerk's office and to the appellant by mail or delivery to the address shown in the application filed. 
(Code 1982, § 16-63; Ord. No. 635, § 1(14.807), 3-3-1981) 
Sec. 16-74. - Penalty. 
    Any person found guilty of a violation of any provision of this division, shall be subject to the general penalty provisions contained in section 1-23. 
(Code 1982, § 16-64; Ord. No. 635, § 1(14.808), 3-3-1981) 
Secs. 16-75-16-93. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AUCTIONEERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power of municipalities to license, tax and regulate auctioneers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-94. - Exemptions. 
    Nothing in this article shall be held to apply to any public auction or sale made or conducted by a public officer by virtue of any judicial order or process or by nature of any power or authority contained in a mortgage or trust deed. 
(Code 1969, § 14.405; Code 1982, § 16-86) 
Sec. 16-95. - Employees permitted; employer liable for any violation. 
    Every person licensed as an auctioneer may designate employees who may be authorized by him to conduct auctions. The employer shall be liable for any violation of village ordinances committed by such employees in conducting an auction. 
(Code 1969, § 14.404; Code 1982, § 16-87) 
Sec. 16-96. - Use of streets and sidewalks prohibited. 
    No person shall sell or attempt to sell or offer for sale at public auction any goods, chattels or personal or real property of any kind upon the public streets or sidewalks of the village. 
(Code 1969, § 17.104; Code 1982, § 16-88) 
Secs. 16-97-16-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 16-116. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct an auction in the village or to do business as an auctioneer, whether the goods sold are owned by the auctioneer or not, without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 14.401; Code 1982, § 16-101) 
Sec. 16-117. - Fees. 
    The annual fee for an auctioneer's license shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 14.406; Code 1982, § 16-102; Ord. No. 628, § 19, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 16-118. - Applicant's character investigated. 
    No license under this article shall be issued to anyone, but a person of good character; the police chief shall investigate the character of each applicant prior to issuance of the license. 
(Code 1969, § 14.403; Code 1982, § 16-103; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 16-119. - Applications. 
    An application for a auctioneer's license or for a single auction shall be in writing to the village clerk, shall comply with all the provisions in article I of this chapter and shall state the following: 
(1)  Place of business intended to be occupied, if any, or the place of such auction; and 
(2)  Give the names of any employees who are to be authorized to conduct auctions under the authority of the license. 
(Code 1969, § 14.402; Code 1982, § 16-104) 
Secs. 16-120-16-138. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COIN-OPERATED DEVICES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal taxation of coin-operated devices, 65 ILCS 5/11-55-1; Coin-Operated Amusement Device Tax Act, 35 ILCS 510/1 et seq.; power of municipal corporate authorities to license, tax, regulate or prohibit amusements, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-139. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement machine means any machine, not otherwise prohibited by law, whose purpose is to entertain or test the skill of the operator, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Shooting or target devices, or games of any description; 
(2)  Musical devices or record players; and 
(3)  Mechanical rides. 
    Automatic vending machine means any device originally designed and intended for use as a self-service machine for a consideration which dispenses a product including, but not limited to, coin-actuated or operated vending machines. 
    Beverage machine means any machine whose purpose is to dispense: 
(1)  Nonalcoholic beverages in containers sealed prior to insertion in the machine, referred to as "prepackaged," or 
(2)  Nonalcoholic beverages prepared, mixed, cooled and/or heated within each machine prior to dispensing in unsealed containers. 
    Cigarette machine means any machine whose purpose is to dispense cigarettes or tobacco products in containers sealed prior to insertion in the machine. 
    Food machine means any machine whose purpose is to dispense: 
(1)  Food, including candy or other confections, in containers sealed prior to insertion in the machine, referred to as "prepackaged"; or 
(2)  Food, including, but not limited to, candy or other confections, not so prepackaged. 
    Machine means and includes any automatic vending machine. 
(Code 1969, § 8.101; Code 1982, § 16-116; Ord. No. 344, § 1, 8-13-1974; Ord. No. 97-019, §§ 1, 2, 6-3-1997) 
Sec. 16-140. - Inspection; controlling regulations. 
    The provisions of this Code which are applicable to electronic amusement devices, sales of food and drink, or relate to the product being sold, are hereby adopted and shall be controlling in the inspection and use of automatic vending machines of all types in the village. 
(Code 1969, § 8.110; Code 1982, § 16-117; Ord. No. 672, § 2, 12-15-1981) 
Sec. 16-141. - Gambling devices prohibited. 
    Except as allowed by the Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq., nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize, permit or license any gambling devices of any nature whatsoever. 
(Code 1969, § 8.109; Code 1982, § 16-118; Ord. No. 12-033, § 3, 10-16-2012) 
State Law reference- Seizure of gambling devices, 720 ILCS 5/28-5. 
Sec. 16-142. - Kept in plain view. 
    All coin-operated devices shall at all times be kept and placed in plain view of any person who may frequent or be in any place of business where such coin-operated devices are installed, kept, maintained, exhibited or made available for use or play. 
(Code 1969, § 8.109; Code 1982, § 16-119) 
Sec. 16-143. - Police chief's authority to remove. 
    The police chief is authorized to remove and impound any coin-operated devices that are being operated in violation of any provision of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 16-120; Ord. No. 345, § 1, 8-13-1974; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Secs. 16-144-16-162. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 16-163. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, to keep, to maintain, to exhibit or to make available for use or play for a consideration, any amusement machine, automatic vending machine, beverage machine, cigarette machine, food machine, ice machine or any other similar machine, who does not possess a license specifically issued for the particular manufacturer's serial number of that machine from the village. 
(Code 1969, § 8.102; Code 1982, § 16-131) 
Sec. 16-164. - Fees. 
    Each person shall pay to the village clerk an annual license fee per year, or any portion of a year, for each coin-operated machine, in accordance with schedule A, which is incorporated herein by reference. The applicable fees list in schedule A shall apply to each coin-slot on multihead or multislot units. 
(Code 1969, § 8.105; Code 1982, § 16-132; Ord. No. 228, § 1, 6-9-1970; Ord. No. 344, § 2, 8-13-1974; Ord. No. 628, § 5, 12-30-1980; Ord. No. 97-019, §§ 3, 4, 6-3-1997) 
Sec. 16-165. - Application. 
    Applications for automatic vending machine licenses shall be made to the village clerk in writing, signed by the applicant, if an individual, and signed by all partners, if a partnership, or by a duly authorized officer thereof, if a corporation, certified by oath or affidavit, and shall contain the information required by this chapter, and such other information as may be required by the president and board of trustees, in their discretion, after said application has been submitted to the village clerk. The procedure contained in this chapter shall prevail, when applicable. 
(Code 1969, § 8.104; Code 1982, § 16-133) 
Sec. 16-166. - Compliance with state and local regulations required. 
    Only persons who comply with the requirements of this article, all applicable state laws and regulations, provisions of this Code and local ordinances, rules and regulations shall be entitled to receive and retain a license for an automatic vending machine. 
(Code 1969, § 8.103; Code 1982, § 16-134) 
Sec. 16-167. - Displayed predominately upon front of machine. 
    All licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall be conspicuously fastened and displayed upon the front of each machine. 
(Code 1969, § 8.107; Code 1982, § 16-135) 
Sec. 16-168. - Transfer of license to different machine; clerk to record; fee. 
    A license for an automatic vending machine may be transferred to a replacement machine of the same type and carrying the same license fee on the same premises; provided that such transfer shall first have been recorded by the village clerk, the fee for which shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 16-136; Code 1982, § 16-136; Ord. No. 628, § 6, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 16-169. - Suspension, revocation; notice and hearing. 
(a)  Suspension, revocation of license or removal of machine. The village president may suspend an automatic vending machine license upon a violation by the owner of such machine of any of the applicable provisions of this article, the Code, or any ordinance or state law. The president may also revoke such license or remove unlicensed machines after conducting a hearing as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Notice; hearing. A hearing to suspend or revoke licenses or to remove unlicensed automatic vending machines shall be conducted within five working days (Monday through Friday) after notice is personally served upon the owner or his agent of the offending machine and within ten working days after notice is served on the owner or his agent through U.S. mail, certified mail, return receipt requested. The notice shall contain sufficient information to apprise the owner or his agent of the violations, together with the date, time and place of the hearing. 
(c)  Owner; agent. The owner or manager of an establishment in which the machine is located is construed to be an agent of the owner. In the event that the automatic vending machine is not within an establishment and does not bear the owner's name and address, the owner of the product being sold will be construed to be the agent of the owner. 
(d)  Hearing procedure. The village president and two village trustees will conduct the hearing and upon its conclusion or within five working days thereafter enter findings consistent with the evidence presented. 
(Code 1969, § 8.108; Code 1982, § 16-137; Ord. No. 672, § 1, 12-15-1981) 
Sec. 16-170. - License year. 
    The license period shall be from July 1 to the next succeeding June 30. 
(Code 1969, § 8.105; Code 1982, § 16-138; Ord. No. 628, § 5, 12-30-1980) 
Secs. 16-171-16-189. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ICE CREAM FREEZERS 

Sec. 16-190. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to offer or maintain for public use any ice cream freezer or dispenser without first obtaining a permit therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 14.206.1; Code 1982, § 16-161) 
Sec. 16-191. - Fees. 
    The annual fee for a permit under this article shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 14.206.3; Code 1982, § 16-162; Ord. No. 628, § 16, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 16-192. - Application. 
    An application for a permit under this article shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall conform to all the provisions of article I of this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 14.206.2; Code 1982, § 16-163) 
Secs. 16-193-16-211. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FIREARMS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Requirement for submission of municipal ordinances regulating firearms to the department of state police, 430 ILCS 65/13.3. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-212. - Intent and purpose. 
(a)  It is intended that this article shall preempt all Cook County licensing or other regulatory schemes for firearms, firearms dealers, ammunition and assault weapons. 
(b)  It is specifically intended that this article shall preempt the Cook County Firearms Dealer's License and Assault Weapons and Ammunition Ban Ordinance as now in effect or as may be hereafter amended. 
(c)  Licenses issued pursuant to this article shall be issued separate and apart from any general business license issued by the village. 
(Code 1982, § 16-202; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995) 
Secs. 16-213-16-231. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSING OF DEALERS 

Sec. 16-232. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Department means the village police department. 
    Director means the village police chief. 
    Engaged in the business has the same meaning as in 18 USC 921(a)(21). 
    Firearm. 
(1)  The term "firearm" means any device, by whatever name known, which is designed to expel a projectile by the action of an explosion, expansion of gas, or escape of gas. 
(2)  The term "firearm" excludes, however: 
a.  Any pneumatic gun, spring gun, paintball gun or BB gun which either expels a single globular projectile not exceeding 0.18 inches in diameter or breakable paintballs containing washable marking colors; 
b.  Any device used exclusively for signaling or safety and required or recommended by the United States Coast Guard or the Interstate Commerce Commission; 
c.  Any device used exclusively for the firing of stud cartridges, explosive rivets or similar industrial ammunition; 
d.  A antique firearm (other than an assault weapon) which, although designed as a weapon, the state police department finds, by reason of the date of its manufacture, value, design, or other characteristic, is primarily a collector's item and is not likely to be used as a weapon. 
    Firearm ammunition. 
(1)  The term "firearm ammunition" means any self-contained cartridge or shotgun shell, by whatever name known, which is designed to be used or adaptable to use in a firearm. 
(2)  The term "firearm ammunition" excludes, however: 
a.  Any ammunition exclusively designed for use with a device used exclusively for signally or safety and required or recommended by the United States Coast Guard or the Interstate Commerce Commission; or 
b.  Any ammunition designed exclusively for use with a stud or rivet driver or other similar industrial ammunition. 
    Firearms dealer means any federally licensed firearms dealer, excluding any person licensed solely as a "collector" pursuant to 18 USC 923(b) and possessing only a Type 03 federal license. 
    Gun shop means the premises of any federally licensed firearms dealer. 
    President means the village president. 
(Code 1982, § 16-231; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 16-233. - License required.
