(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of dealing in firearms at an address within the village corporate limits without having applied for or obtained a village firearms dealer's license pursuant to this division. A village firearms dealer's license shall be required in addition to any other license required by law. All applicants for a village firearms dealer's license must possess a valid federal firearms dealer's license. Possession of a valid federal firearms dealer's license shall be deemed proof of being engaged in the business of dealing in firearms in the village and thus requiring a village firearms dealer's license. An applicant for a village firearms dealer's license shall meet all other applicable village ordinances and regulations. 
(b)  Any person who becomes a federally licensed firearms dealer and is required under this division to obtain a village firearms dealer's license shall apply for such license within 45 days of receipt of the federal firearms dealer's license. 
(c)  Any person licensed under federal law at more than one location within the village corporate limits must obtain a village firearms dealer's license for each individual location. A separate application and license fee is required for each location. 
(d)  In order to be eligible to receive a village firearms dealer's license, the location and address to which the license will be issued must be one which is zoned for business use only, in which such a use is a permitted use under the business zone in which the premises are located. Prior to issuance of any such license, it shall be required that there be installed on the premises a satisfactory anti-theft alarm system which has been inspected and approved by the police department. Such premises and the business operation contemplated must also meet all other requirements for the issuance of a village business commencement license. 
(e)  No license issued under this division shall be transferable or assignable to any other person or any other location. 
(Code 1982, § 16-232; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995) 
Sec. 16-234. - Administration. 
(a)  Generally. The police chief shall administer the licensing of firearms dealers, and shall approve or deny all applications for licenses and revoke existing licenses pursuant to this division. 
(b)  Promulgation of rules and regulations. 
(1)  The director shall promulgate reasonable rules, definitions and regulations necessary to carry out the duties imposed by this division, including, but not limited to, developing reasonable procedures consistent with existing practices of licensing persons engaged in the business of dealing in firearms, and including seeking the assistance of the village police department or other law enforcement agencies as necessary to conduct investigations or inspections in connection with licensing. 
(2)  Any rules or regulations promulgated under this division shall be filed in the police department's principal office and in the village clerk's office, and shall be made available for public inspection. Copies shall be made available upon request and payment of a reasonable fee, as determined by the police department or the village clerk, to cover the cost of providing the copy. 
(Code 1982, § 16-233; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 16-235. - Fees. 
    The annual fee for a village firearms dealer's license shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1982, § 16-234; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995) 
Sec. 16-236. - Application; issuance. 
(a)  All applications for a license under this division shall be made in writing to the police chief on a form provided for that purpose. In addition to any other information required by the director, each application for a license shall contain: 
(1)  If the applicant is an individual: 
a.  The applicant's full name, residence; and 
b.  The address and telephone number where the person is engaged in the business of dealing in firearms; 
(2)  If the applicant is a corporation: 
a.  The corporate name, business name, and the applicant's principal place of business; 
b.  The date and state of incorporation; and 
c.  The names and resident addresses of the corporate officers and its registered agent; 
(3)  If the applicant is a partnership: 
a.  The name, business address and telephone number of the principal office or place of business; 
b.  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of all partners; and 
c.  The name, address and telephone number of a person authorized to receive notices issued pursuant to this division. 
(b)  The director shall not issue a village firearms dealer's license to any person who fails to provide proof of a valid federal firearms dealer's license and a valid firearm owner's identification card issued by the state. 
(Code 1982, § 16-235; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 16-237. - Denial, suspension or revocation; appeal. 
(a)  Denial; appeal. The director may deny an application for a license if the applicant fails to provide the information required by, or is otherwise not in compliance with, any provisions of this division or any applicable rules or regulations. Such denial shall be in writing and shall state the reasons for the denial. Any person seeking to appeal the denial may do so by filing a written request for a hearing with the village president, with a copy to the director. Such request must be filed within 30 days of the denial, and a hearing must be held within 30 days of receipt of the request. The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures provided herein. 
(b)  Suspension, revocation; notice. The director may revoke or suspend the license of any person who violates any provision of this division or rules or regulations adopted pursuant to this division. Before any such revocation or suspension is imposed, the licensee shall be notified by the mail or personal delivery of the specific basis for the suspension or revocation and the date for a hearing on the matter. Such hearing shall occur not fewer than seven days, and no more than 14 days after the mailing of the notice. The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures provided herein. 
(Code 1982, § 16-236; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 16-238. - Hearing procedures. 
(a)  If a person wishes to appeal the denial of a village firearms dealer's license, or in the event of a revocation of a village firearms dealer's license, the village president shall appoint a hearing officer who shall conduct the hearing. The hearing officer is authorized to conduct hearings concerning any matter covered by this division and may determine factual and legal matters raised by the parties to the hearing. 
(b)  The hearing officer may: 
(1)  Examine any books, papers, records or memoranda bearing upon the business or activities of the licensee; 
(2)  Request the circuit court to issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of any person having personal knowledge of any contested issue; 
(3)  Request the circuit court to issue subpoenas duces tecum for the production of books, records, papers, or memoranda; 
(4)  Administer oaths; 
(5)  Take testimony; 
(6)  Make rulings as to the admissibility of evidence; and 
(7)  Take any other action as may be required for the expeditious conduct of the hearing. 
(c)  The hearing officer is not bound by the technical rules of evidence. No informality in any proceeding or in the manner of taking testimony or receiving evidence shall invalidate any order, decision, ruling or recommendation of the hearing officer or the village president's final administrative decision. 
(d)  The department's books, papers, records and memoranda or parts thereof may be provided in any hearing or legal proceeding by the original documents or by reproduced copy under the director's certificate. Without further proof, the original documents or reproduced copy shall be admissible into evidence at the hearing. 
(e)  If the circuit court issues a subpoena duces tecum, the following rules shall apply: 
(1)  Service shall be made as provided by the state Civil Practice Law, 735 ILCS 5/2-201 et seq.; 
(2)  Fees of witnesses for attendance and travel shall be the same as the fees of witnesses before the circuit court of the county and shall be paid after the witness is excused from further attendance; 
(3)  When a subpoena or subpoena duces tecum is issued at the instance of either party, the hearing officer may require that party to bear the cost of service and witness fees. 
(f)  Any party to a hearing may apply to any circuit court judge of this state for enforcement or any subpoena or subpoena duces tecum issued by a hearing officer holding a hearing authorized by this division. 
(g)  At any hearing held under this division, the director's initial decision to deny or revoke a license shall be presumed prima facie correct and the person contesting the decision shall have the burden of proving by the books, records and other documentary or testimonial evidence that it is incorrect. 
(h)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a recommendation to the village president. The village president shall adopt, reject or modify the recommendation based on a review of the record within seven days of receiving the hearing officer's recommendation, and shall issue a final decision. The village president shall give written notification to the licensee of the decision and the reasons for such decision. The village president's decision shall be a final decision reviewable under State Administrative Review Law, 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq. 
(i)  A person seeking judicial review of the village president's final decision shall bear the cost of certification. If the protesting party prevails on appeal, the village shall reimburse that party for the cost of certification. 
(j)  Items constituting the record may include notices and demands, the initial decision, the written protest and petition for hearing, all relevant pleadings, briefs and memoranda of law, evidence admitted at the hearing, the transcribed testimony given at the hearing, the hearing officer's recommendation and the village president's final decision. 
(Code 1982, § 16-237; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 16-239. - Penalty. 
    Failure to comply with the provisions of this division shall result in a violation subject to the general penalty contained in section 1-23. 
(Code 1982, § 16-238; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995) 
Secs. 16-240-16-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ASSAULT WEAPONS 

Sec. 16-251. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Assault weapon means any weapon which shoots, is designed to shoot, or can be readily restored to shoot, automatically more than one shot without manual reloading by a single function of the trigger. The term "assault weapon" also includes: 
(1)  The frame or receiver of any such weapon; 
(2)  Any part designed and intended for use in converting a weapon into a machine gun; and 
(3)  Any combination of parts from which a machine gun can be assembled, if such parts are in the possession or under the control of a person. 
(Code 1982, § 16-251; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995) 
Sec. 16-252. - Sale prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall sell, offer or display for sale, give, lend, transfer ownership of, acquire or possess, manufacture, or distribute any assault weapon within the corporate limits of the village. 
(b)  This subsection shall not apply to: 
(1)  The sale, distribution, or possession for sale and distribution, by any firearms dealers licensed pursuant to this article, of an assault weapon to any sworn police officer of the village or any other municipality, county, body politic or state or of the United States, members of the armed forces of the United States, or the organized militia of this or any other state, and peace officers to the extent that any such person is otherwise authorized to acquire or possess an assault weapon and is acting within the scope of his duties; 
(2)  Transportation of assault weapons if such weapons are broken down and in a nonfunctioning state and are not immediately accessible to any person. 
(c)  Any assault weapon possessed, sold or transferred in violation of subsection (a) of this section is hereby declared to be contraband and shall be seized and disposed of in accordance with the provisions in section 16-253. 
(d)  Any person found in violation of this section shall be fined not less than $250.00 and not more than $500.00. 
(Code 1982, § 16-252; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 16-253. - Surrendered or confiscated weapons. 
(a)  Whenever any firearm is surrendered or confiscated, pursuant to the terms of this division, the police chief shall ascertain whether such firearm is needed as evidence in any matter. 
(b)  If such firearm is not required for evidence, it shall be destroyed at the police chief's direction. A record of the date and method of destruction and inventory of the firearm so destroyed shall be maintained. 
(Code 1982, § 16-253; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Secs. 16-254-16-272. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TATTOO AND BODY PIERCING ESTABLISHMENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Tattoo and Body Piercing Establishment Registration Act, 410 ILCS 54/1 et seq. 

Sec. 16-273. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating a tattoo establishment without first obtaining a license to engage in such business in accordance with the provisions hereof. 
Sec. 16-274. - State registration and compliance with state rules required. 
    No license shall be issued hereunder, unless and until, the applicant is duly registered with the state as required by 410 ILCS 54/15 and is otherwise in compliance with all state and federal regulations governing tattoo and body piercing establishments. Licensing hereunder is contingent upon continuous compliance with all local, state, and federal laws, rules, and regulations. 
(Code 1982, § 16-311; Ord. No. 97-009, § 1, 2-18-1997) 
Sec. 16-275. - Application fee. 
    An application for a license shall be accompanied by a fee in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk; provided, however, that no application fee shall be required for the renewal of an existing license. Any change of ownership shall require a new application and license, with payment of fees therefor. 
(Code 1982, § 16-312; Ord. No. 97-009, § 2, 2-18-1997) 
Sec. 16-276. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for engaging in the business of operating a tattoo establishment within the village shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1982, § 16-313; Ord. No. 97-009, § 3, 2-18-1997) 
Sec. 16-277. - Records. 
(a)  Permanent records for each patron or customer shall be maintained by the licensee or operator of the establishment. 
(b)  Before the tattooing operation beings, the patron or customer shall be required personally to enter, on a record form provided for such establishments the following information: 
(1)  The date; 
(2)  Applicant's name, address and age; 
(3)  Applicant's serial number, if a member of the armed forces; and 
(4)  Applicant's signature. 
(c)  The records shall be maintained in the tattoo establishment and shall be available for examination by authorized village, state, and other officers. The records shall be retained by the operator or licensee for a period of not less than two years. 
(d)  In the event of a change of ownership or closing of the business, all such records shall be made available to the health officer. 
(Code 1982, § 16-317; Ord. No. 97-009, § 7, 2-18-1997) 
Sec. 16-278. - Malpractice insurance required. 
    The operator shall keep and maintain malpractice insurance in an amount of at least $100,000.00 and shall provide evidence of such insurance upon application for or renewal of each license. 
(Code 1982, § 16-324; Ord. No. 97-009, § 14, 2-18-1997) 
Sec. 16-279. - Tattooing persons under 18 years of age prohibited. 
    Any person, other than a person licensed to practice medicine in all its branches, who tattoos or offers to tattoo a person under the age of 18, is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1982, § 16-325; Ord. No. 97-009, § 15, 2-18-1997) 
Sec. 16-280. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who shall be convicted of violating any provision of this article, for which another penalty is not provided, shall be fined not less than $25.00, nor more than $750.00 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(b)  In addition to the fines specified in subsection (a) of this section, the license of any operator or tattoo establishment may be suspended or revoked for violations of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 16-326; Ord. No. 97-009, § 16, 2-18-1997) 
Secs. 16-281-16-299. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HOTELS/MOTELS AND TOURIST CAMPS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal licensing and regulation of certain accommodations, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-4, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-3. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-300. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to all hotels/motels and tourist camps located in the village. 
(Code 1969, § 15.101; Code 1982, § 17-1) 
Sec. 16-301. - Health officer to enforce. 
    All provisions of this article shall be administered and enforced by the village health officer. 
(Code 1969, § 15.103; Code 1982, § 17-2) 
Sec. 16-302. - Inspections. 
    The health officer is hereby authorized to make all inspections and issue any order deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 15.103; Code 1982, § 17-3) 
Sec. 16-303. - Conflicts. 
    This article does not nullify any requirements adopted by the village covering all or any part of the matters covered herein. However, in the event there is a conflict between similar matters, covered elsewhere and in this article, the more stringent or restrictive requirements shall prevail or control. 
(Code 1969, § 15.107; Code 1982, § 17-4) 
Secs. 16-304-16-322. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 16-323. - Required. 
    No land or premises shall be occupied, or continue to be occupied, by two or more house trailers, camp cars, tents, camp cottages or cabins, either detached or connected, or hotel/motels which are used by tourists, transients or other persons for sleeping or dwelling purposes, in this article termed a hotel/motel, unless the hotel/motel complies with the requirements of this article, and unless an operating permit has been issued therefor and has not been revoked, all as provided herein. 
(Code 1969, § 15.102; Code 1982, § 17-16) 
Sec. 16-324. - Applicability. 
    The rules in this division apply to operating permits required herein. 
(Code 1969, § 15.106; Code 1982, § 17-17) 
Sec. 16-325. - Fees. 
    The annual fee for each operating permit, payable to the village treasurer, for motels designed to accommodate no more than a total of ten trailers, tents and motel units, plus each additional unit shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. The fee for permits issued for a portion of a calendar year shall be prorated on the basis of the remaining number of whole months in the calendar year. 
(Code 1969, § 15.106; Code 1982, § 17-18; Ord. No. 628, § 23, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 16-326. - Application. 
    Each application for an operating permit under this division shall be made on forms provided by the health officer, and shall be properly filled in and accompanied by such descriptive material in drawn or written form as the forms specify, all of which shall be filed with the health officer. The application, among other things, shall describe the site, buildings and facilities of the hotel/motel in sufficient detail and accuracy, so that upon investigation, their compliance with the provisions of this article may be judged. 
(Code 1969, § 15.104; Code 1982, § 17-19) 
Sec. 16-327. - Issuance. 
    A permit to operate a hotel/motel for the calendar year shall be issued promptly when an application therefor has been made in proper form and the hotel/motel is found to be in compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 15.106; Code 1982, § 17-20) 
Sec. 16-328. - Displayed in hotel/motel manager's office. 
    A permit issued under this division shall be conspicuously displayed in the hotel/motel manager's office. 
(Code 1969, § 15.106; Code 1982, § 17-21) 
Sec. 16-329. - Nontransferable; expiration; renewal. 
    A permit under this division is: 
(1)  Nontransferable; 
(2)  Expires on the last day of the calendar year; and 
(3)  Renewable upon application, if the hotel/motel is found to be still in compliance with this article. 
(Code 1969, § 15.106; Code 1982, § 17-22) 
Sec. 16-330. - Suspension; revocation; notice. 
    A permit issued under this division may be revoked or suspended for violation of any provision of this article, but only after notice has been given the hotel/motel manager and owner or lessee of the motel premises, setting forth in writing the violation and time allowed for abatement thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 15.106; Code 1982, § 17-23) 
Sec. 16-331. - In good standing requirement. 
    To qualify for and to maintain in good standing an operating permit, a hotel/motel shall be developed, equipped, managed and operated as provided in this division. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-24) 
Sec. 16-332. - Resident manager qualifications. 
    The hotel/motel shall be in the charge of a resident manager who shall meet the following criteria: 
(1)  Be of good moral character; 
(2)  Be available and responsible at all times for maintaining the grounds, buildings and facilities in a sanitary, safe, orderly and usable condition. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-25) 
Sec. 16-333. - Office required. 
    There shall be an office or room for the manager where: 
(1)  Incoming hotel/motel occupants will be registered and furnished copies of the hotel/motel rules; and 
(2)  The registration records of the hotel/motel shall be maintained in the approved form and kept available at all times for inspection by the health officer. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-26) 
Sec. 16-334. - Applicability of state health rules and regulations. 
    The hotel/motel manager shall comply with such health and sanitation rules and regulations pertaining to hotels/motels that have been adopted under the powers granted the state department of public health. In the event of conflict between state health and sanitation rules and regulations and the provisions of this article, the more stringent requirement shall prevail. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-27) 
Sec. 16-335. - Persons suffering from a reportable disease prohibited. 
    No person known to be suffering from a reportable disease, as defined by the state department of public health, shall be given accommodation at any hotel/motel. The hotel/motel manager shall immediately notify the health officer of any illness in the hotel/motel which is believed to be reportable. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-28) 
Sec. 16-336. - Building code adopted. 
    The layout, development and facilities of the hotel/motel, which promote or protect the health and safety of its occupants and others who may be affected by its operation, shall conform to the standards and requirements relating thereto, as specified in the village building code, hereby made a part of this division by reference. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-29) 
Sec. 16-337. - Metal refuse containers required. 
    Suitably covered metal containers for garbage, rubbish and other refuse shall be available at hotels/motels at all times and shall be emptied and cleaned at frequent intervals, and their contents to be burned, buried or otherwise disposed of in such manner as not to be or become offensive. Platforms for containers shall be kept clean. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-30) 
Sec. 16-338. - Availability of water required. 
    Hot and cold running water shall be available at all times at lavatory, bathing and laundry fixtures of hotels/motels. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-31) 
Sec. 16-339. - Water and sewage facilities must be properly maintained and operated. 
    Water supply and sewage disposal facilities of hotels/motels shall be maintained and operated so as to properly perform their function. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-32) 
Sec. 16-340. - Plumbing fixtures and floors must be cleaned daily. 
    Plumbing fixtures and floors of hotels/motels shall be thoroughly cleaned at least once daily, or more often if necessary. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-33) 
Sec. 16-341. - Bathroom facilities to maintain constant temperature. 
    A minimum temperature of at least 68 degrees Fahrenheit shall be maintained during all hours in lavatory, bath and toilet rooms of hotels/motels from September 15 to June 1. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-34) 
Sec. 16-342. - Comfortable temperature for other rooms required. 
    A comfortable temperature shall be maintained in hotel/motel rooms heated from a central plant. Where central heating is not provided, rooms shall be furnished with safe, convenient and adequate heating facilities for use by occupants as necessary. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-35) 
Sec. 16-343. - Adequate lighting required. 
    During hours of darkness adequate lighting shall be maintained within the hotel/motel service buildings and along walks leading to them. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-36) 
Sec. 16-344. - Fire extinguishers must be maintained in a workable condition. 
    Fire extinguishers at hotels/motels shall be maintained in a filled and workable condition. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-37) 
Sec. 16-345. - Beds and bedding to be maintained in a good, clean condition. 
    Hotel/motel rooms shall be furnished with beds and bedding which shall be in good condition, clean and adequate to maintain body comfort. Beds shall be made up with clean, freshly laundered sheets and pillowcases as often as they are assigned to different persons, and at least weekly when used by the same person. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-38) 
Sec. 16-346. - Soap and towels must be provided. 
    Each occupant of a hotel/motel room shall be furnished with soap and at least one clean, freshly laundered bath towel and hand towel daily. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-39) 
Sec. 16-347. - Health officer's authority to remove trailer. 
    Where any trailer or its appurtenances are deemed hazardous to the health or safety of its occupants or others, the health officer shall order removal of the trailer from the camp. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-40) 
Sec. 16-348. - Trailer wastes to be disposed of properly. 
    Liquid and other trailer wastes shall be disposed of in an approved manner. 
(Code 1969, § 15.105; Code 1982, § 17-41) 
Sec. 16-349. - Criminal activity on premises. 
    The owner or operator shall not permit criminal activity to occur on the premises without taking corrective action or contacting law enforcement officials. 
(Ord. No. 12-036, § 1, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 16-350. - Furnishing room to under 21 prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for a licensee to lease, rent or otherwise furnish a room to a person under 21 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 12-036, § 1, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 16-351. - Obtaining hotel or motel room for illegal use of alcoholic liquor prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to rent, lease or otherwise obtain the use of a hotel or motel room for the purpose of or with the knowledge that such room will be used for the consumption of alcoholic liquor by persons under the age of 21 years. 
(Ord. No. 12-036, § 1, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 16-352. - Duration of room rental. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to rent, lease or otherwise furnish a room more than once in any 24-[hour] period. Rental of a room to an over-the-road truck driver who furnishes a CDL driver's license and is driving a semi-tractor shall be allowed for a period of not less than six hours. In the case of such shortened rental period, the owner shall make a copy of the CDL license and note the vehicle license of the truck and both shall become part of the rental log for the facility. 
(Ord. No. 12-036, § 1, 11-20-2012) 
Secs. 16-353-16-367. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - HOTEL/MOTEL ACCOMMODATION TAX[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Hotel Operators' Occupation Tax Act, 35 ILCS 145/1; municipal authority for levy of gross receipts tax on hotel rooms, 65 ILCS 5/8-3-14. 

Sec. 16-368. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Hotel room or motel room means a room within a structure offered for rental on a daily basis and containing facilities for sleeping. One room offered for rental with or without an adjoining bath shall be considered as a single hotel or motel room. The number of hotel or motel rooms within a suite shall be computed on the basis of those rooms utilized for the purpose of sleeping. 
    Owner means any person having an ownership interest in or conducting the operation of a hotel or motel room or receiving the consideration for the rental of such hotel or motel room. 
    Person means any natural person, trustee, court-appointed representatives, syndicate, association, partnership, firm, club, company, corporation, business trust, institution, agency, government corporation, municipal corporation, district or other political subdivision, contractor, supplier, vendor, vendee, operator, user or owner or any officers, agents, employees or other representative, acting either for himself or for any other person in any capacity, or any other entity recognized by law as the subject of rights and duties. 
(Code 1982, § 17-56; Ord. No. 389, § 1, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-369. - Penalty. 
    Any person found guilty of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting or refusing to comply with or resisting or opposing the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article, except when otherwise specifically provided, upon conviction thereof shall be punished by the general penalty provisions contained in section 1-23. 
(Code 1982, § 17-57; Ord. No. 389, § 8, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-370. - Levied. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and imposed upon the use and privilege of renting a motel or hotel room within the village, a tax of six percent of the room rental rate, not including taxes or other nonroom rental charges added to the motel or hotel bill, or at the rate of $2.00 for each such motel or hotel room, whichever sum is greater, for each such motel or hotel room rented for every 24-hour period or any fraction thereof. 
(b)  The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of the tax is to be borne by the person who seeks the privilege of occupying the motel or hotel room, the person hereinafter referred to as "renter." 
(c)  The tax levied in this section shall be paid in addition to any and all other taxes and charges. It shall be the duty of the owner of every motel or hotel to secure the tax from the renter of the motel or hotel room and to pay over to the village collector the tax under procedures prescribed by the village collector, or as otherwise provided in this article. 
(d)  Every person required to collect the tax levied by this article shall secure the tax from the renter at the time he collects the rental payment for the motel or hotel room. Upon the invoice receipt or other statement or memorandum of the rent given to the renter at the time of payment the amount due under the tax provided in this article shall be stated separately on the documents. 
(e)  The village shall endeavor to apply one-third of the taxes collected pursuant to this section for enhancement of the hospitality and tourism industry in the village. 
(Code 1982, § 17-58; Ord. No. 389, § 2, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977; Ord. No. 87-002, § 1, 1-20-1987; Ord. No. 96-009, § 1, 4-2-1996; Ord. No. 12-035, § 1, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 16-371. - In addition to other taxes. 
    The tax levied in this article shall be paid in addition to any and all other taxes and charges. 
(Code 1982, § 17-59; Ord. No. 389, § 2, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-372. - Village attorney's authority to enforce. 
    Whenever any person shall fail to pay any tax as provided in this article, the village attorney shall, upon the village collector's request, bring or cause to be brought an action to enforce the payment of said tax on the village's behalf in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1982, § 17-60; Ord. No. 389, § 5, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-373. - Books and records. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every owner to keep accurate and complete books and records to which the village collector, or his deputy or representative (authorized by him) shall at all times have full access, which records shall include a daily sheet showing: 
(1)  The number of hotel/motel rooms rented during the 24-hour period, including multiple rentals of the same hotel/motel room where such shall occur; and 
(2)  The actual hotel/motel tax receipts collected for the date in question. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every owner, keeper, proprietor or agent of any lodginghouse, roominghouse, motel, hotel, inn or other transient lodging facility to keep a register wherein all guests, roomers, or lodgers shall inscribe their names and permanent address upon procuring lodging, a room or accommodations. The owner, keeper, proprietor or agent shall also inscribe the room number occupied and the date and time of registration and checkout. 
(c)  Said owner, keeper, proprietor or agent shall request identification of any guest, roomer of lodger paying cash, at the time or registration. Such identification shall be in a valid and current form showing the person's name, date of birth, and may be, but is not limited to, a driver's license, state issued picture identification card, or such other form as will reasonably ensure that the registrant is, in fact, the person under whose name such lodging room or accommodation is being procured. A photocopy of such identification shall be maintained or the identifying information transposed into the registration record. For any guest, roomer or lodger taking occupancy through a prearranged reservation in the name of a corporation, business, association or any other entity, the owner, keeper or proprietor shall request identification of the specific guest, roomer or lodger at the time of registration as will reasonable ensure such person to be the person for whom the lodging, room or accommodations have been procured. Said owner, keeper or proprietor shall verify the credit card signature of each guest, roomer or lodger making payment by way of credit card, with the signature inscribed upon the hotel/motel register. 
(d)  No person may knowingly procure or provide lodging from a roominghouse, motel, hotel, inn or other transient lodging facility, or any services therefrom, through misrepresentation or production of false identification or identification which misrepresents the identify of the person procuring or sharing in such lodging or service. No person may knowingly given, or cause to be given, an incorrect name, address, date of birth, or license plate number to any owner, keeper, proprietor or agent of any establishment required to maintain records under this section. 
(e)  Records required to be maintained in accordance with the provisions of subsections (b) through (d) of this section, together with the vehicle registration information, records of telephone calls and other billing records, when maintained by the establishment in the ordinary course of business, shall be provided to any officer of the village police department upon demand and representation that a reasonable suspicion exists that such information is relevant to a then-pending inquiry or investigation. Nothing in this requirement shall be construed as giving any such officer any greater right or license to enter a room or invade privacy than the officer shall otherwise possess. 
(f)  Records required to be kept in accordance with this section shall be retained for one year after the date the last entry is recorded. 
(Code 1982, § 17-61; Ord. No. 389, § 3, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977; Ord. No. 02-029, § 1, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 16-374. - Village collector's right to inspect. 
    The village collector, or any person certified by him as his deputy or representative, may enter the premises of any hotel/motel for inspection and examination of the books and records in order to effectuate the proper administration of this article and to ensure the enforcement of the collection of the tax imposed. 
(Code 1982, § 17-62; Ord. No. 389, § 3, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-375. - Interference with village collector prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, hinder or interfere with the village collector or his duly authorized deputy or representative in the discharge of his duties in the performance of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 17-63; Ord. No. 389, § 3, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-376. - Owner's duty to collect and pay. 
    It shall be the owner's duty of every hotel/motel to secure the tax from the renter of the hotel/motel room and to pay over to the village collector said tax under the procedures prescribed by the village collector, or as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 17-64; Ord. No. 389, § 2, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-377. - Collected at time room is rented. 
    Every person required to collect the tax levied by this article shall secure said tax from the renter at the time he collects the rental payment for the hotel/motel room. 
(Code 1982, § 17-65; Ord. No. 389, § 2, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-378. - Renter responsible for payment. 
    The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of the tax imposed under this article is to be borne by the person who seeks the privilege of occupying the hotel/motel room, said person shall herein be referred to as the "renter." 
(Code 1982, § 17-66; Ord. No. 389, § 2, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-379. - Amount due to be stated on receipt. 
    Upon the invoice receipt or other statement or memorandum of the rent given to the renter at the time of payment, the amount due under the tax provided in this article shall be stated separately on said documents. 
(Code 1982, § 17-67; Ord. No. 389, § 2, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-380. - Monthly tax return required. 
    Every owner, manager or operator of hotel/motel accommodations within the village shall file a sworn tax return on a monthly basis with the village collector showing the tax receipts received with respect to the hotel/motel accommodation space rented or leased during the preceding monthly period, upon forms prescribed by the village collector. 
(Code 1982, § 17-68; Ord. No. 389, § 4, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-381. - Return due by last day of month following collection. 
    The tax return under this article is due on or before the last day of the month following the month of tax collection. 
(Code 1982, § 17-69; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-382. - Payment to village required with filing of return. 
    At the time of filing a tax return under this article, the owner, manager or operator of hotel/motel accommodations shall pay to the village all taxes due for the period to which the tax return applies. 
(Code 1982, § 17-70; Ord. No. 389, § 4, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-383. - Delinquency penalty. 
    If for any reason any tax under this article is not paid when due, a penalty at the rate of two percent per month on the amount of tax which remains unpaid shall be added and collected. 
(Code 1982, § 17-71; Ord. No. 389, § 4, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-384. - Proceeds to be deposited into the village corporate fund. 
    All proceeds resulting from the imposition of the tax under this article, including penalties, shall be paid into the village treasury and credited to and deposited in the village corporate fund. 
(Code 1982, § 17-72; Ord. No. 389, § 7, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-385. - President's authority to suspend or revoke license for nonpayment. 
    If the village president, after a hearing held by him or for him, shall find that any person has willfully avoided payment of the tax imposed by this article, he may suspend or revoke all village licenses held by such tax evader. 
(Code 1982, § 17-73; Ord. No. 389, § 6, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-386. - Owner's right to hearing regarding suspension or revocation. 
    The owner shall have an opportunity to be heard at a hearing to be held no less than five days after the notice of time and place has been mailed, addressed to the owner's last known place of business. 
(Code 1982, § 17-74; Ord. No. 389, § 6, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Sec. 16-387. - Suspension or revocation not a release from civil liability nor from prosecution. 
    A suspension or revocation of any license pursuant to this article shall not release or discharge the owner from his civil liability for the tax payment, nor from prosecution for the failure to make such payment. 
(Code 1982, § 17-75; Ord. No. 389, § 6, 12-2-1975; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-6-1977) 
Secs. 16-388-16-406. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Foreign fire insurance company fees, 65 ILCS 5/11-10.1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-407. - Compliance with division. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, not incorporated under state law, to engage in the village in effecting fire insurance, or to transact any business of fire insurance within the village, while in default, by not complying fully with any of the requirements of this division, and until such requirements have been fully complied with; but this provision shall not relieve any person from the payment of any risk that may be undertaken in violation of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 10.301; Code 1982, § 11-226) 
Sec. 16-408. - Assessment levied from gross profits of underwriter. 
    Any person not incorporated under state law, which is engaged within the village in writing fire insurance, shall pay to the fire department treasurer for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department or for use for the firemen's pension fund, a sum not exceeding two percent of the gross receipts received from fire insurance upon property situated within the village. The fire department treasurer is hereby authorized to pay the monies when received into the general corporate fund for use of the fire department or into the firemen's pension fund. 
(Code 1969, § 10.302; Code 1982, § 11-227) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 et seq. 
Sec. 16-409. - Annual report required; assessment to be paid with filing. 
    Every person acting as agent or otherwise, for or on behalf of any person upon which an assessment is made pursuant to the provisions of this division shall, on or before July 15 of each year, render to the village treasurer a full, true and just account, verified by his oath, of all premiums which, during the year ending on July 1 preceding such report, shall have been received by him or some other person for him on behalf of any such person. Such agent shall also, at the time of rendering the aforesaid report, pay to the village treasurer the sum of money for which such person is chargeable, by virtue of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 10.303; Code 1982, § 11-228) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1. 
Sec. 16-410. - Village authority to collect through legal action. 
    The sum of money for which any person coming under the provisions of this article is so chargeable may be recovered of him or his agent by action in a court of law in the name of and for the village use as for money had and received. 
(Code 1969, § 10.304; Code 1982, § 11-229) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1. 
Sec. 16-411. - Delinquent underwriters prohibited from future business. 
    No insurance broker in the village shall have any insurance business or dealings with any person not incorporated under state law, which shall be in default for not reporting or making payments, as provided by this division, until it shall have complied with all the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 10.305; Code 1982, § 11-230) 
Secs. 16-412-16-430. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD 

Sec. 16-431. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a foreign fire insurance board. 
(Code 1982, § 11-236; Ord. No. 93-002, § 1, 1-19-1993) 
Sec. 16-432. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board means the foreign fire insurance board. 
    Department means the village fire department, including paid on-call members. 
    Fund means the foreign fire insurance tax fund. 
    Members of the department means any sworn personnel and paid on-call members currently employed by the village fire department. 
(Code 1982, § 11-237; Ord. No. 93-002, § 1, 1-19-1993) 
Sec. 16-433. - Composition; election of officers; terms; vacancies; proceeds. 
(a)  The foreign fire insurance board shall consist of seven trustees; the fire chief, who shall hold office by virtue of rank and six members, who shall be elected at large by the sworn members of the department. If there is an insufficient number of candidates to fill all these positions, the number of board members shall be reduced, but not to fewer than three trustees. 
(b)  The sworn members of the village fire department shall elect six members who shall be elected at large. The fire chief shall be the ex officio seventh member of such board. 
(c)  The members of the foreign fire insurance board shall annually elect the following officers: 
(1)  Chairman; 
(2)  Treasurer; 
(3)  Such other officers as said board may deem necessary or appropriate. 
(d)  The treasurer of the foreign fire insurance board shall give a sufficient bond to the municipality as required by state statute. 
(e)  Members of the board shall serve two-year terms until their successors are elected and installed. 
(f)  Vacancies shall be filled by members of the village fire department for the balance of any unexpired term. 
(g)  The treasurer of the department of the foreign fire insurance board shall receive the appropriated money and shall pay out the money upon the order of the department for foreign fire insurance board for the maintenance, use and benefit of the department. As part of the annual municipal audit, these funds shall be audited to verify that the funds had been expended by that board only for the maintenance, use and benefit of the department. 
(Code 1982, § 11-238; Ord. No. 93-002, § 1, 1-19-1993; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000; Ord. No. 10-012, § 1, 6-15-2010) 
Sec. 16-434. - Election procedure. 
(a)  The sworn members of the village fire department shall meet to elect the initial board. 
(b)  The initial board shall develop a procedure for governing the nomination of members to run for the various offices. The nominating procedure shall be established a minimum of 30 days prior to the expiration of the board members terms of office. 
(c)  The board may adopt rules and regulations governing the election of officers. All rules and regulations with respect to the election process shall be posted throughout the village fire department a minimum of 30 days prior to the election and shall not be effective until approved by the mayor and board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 11-239; Ord. No. 93-002, § 1, 1-19-1993; Ord. No. 10-012, § 1, 7-15-2010) 
Secs. 16-435-16-453. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SPECIAL SALES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 16-454-16-472. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GARAGE SALES 

Sec. 16-473. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garage sale. 
(1)  The term "garage sale" includes all general sales, open to the public, conducted from or on a residential premises in any residential zone, as defined by chapter 56, for the purpose of disposing of personal property. The term "garage sale" includes, but is not limited to, all sales entitled "garage," "lawn," "yard," "attic," "porch," "room," "backyard," "patio," "flea market" or "rummage" sale. 
(2)  The term "garage sale" also includes the sale of any personal property which is displayed at your residence. 
    Personal property. 
(1)  The term "personal property" means property which is owned, utilized and maintained by an individual or members of his residence and acquired in the normal course of living in or maintaining a residence. 
(2)  The term "personal property" does not include merchandise which was purchased for resale or obtained on consignment. 
(Code 1982, § 26-16; Ord. No. 551, § I(1), 8-7-1979; Ord. No. 13-030, § 1, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 16-474. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following: 
(1)  Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
(3)  Any sale conducted by any merchant or mercantile or other business establishment from or at a place of business wherein such sale would be permitted by chapter 56 or under the protection of the nonconforming use section thereof or any other sale conducted by a manufacturer, dealer or vendor and which sale would be conducted from properly zoned premises and not otherwise prohibited in other ordinances. 
(4)  Any bona fide charitable, eleemosynary, educational, cultural or governmental institution or organization when the proceeds from the sale are used directly for the institution or organization's charitable purposes and the goods or articles are not sold on a consignment basis. 
(Code 1982, § 26-17; Ord. No. 551, § I(17), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-475. - Separate violations. 
    Every article sold and every day a sale is conducted in violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1982, § 26-18; Ord. No. 551, § I(18), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-476. - Signs-Number and size regulations. 
    Only the following specified signs may be displayed in relation to a pending garage sale: 
(1)  Two signs permitted. Two signs of no more than four square feet shall be permitted to be displayed on the property of the residence where the garage sale is being conducted. 
(2)  Directional signs. Two signs of no more than two square feet each are permitted; provided, that, the premises upon which the garage sale is conducted is not on a major thoroughfare, and written permission to erect said signs is received from the property owners upon whose property such signs are to be placed. 
(Code 1982, § 26-19; Ord. No. 551, § I(12), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-477. - Same-Permitted two days prior to commencement. 
    No sign or other form of advertisement shall be exhibited for more than two days prior to the day on which a garage sale is to commence. 
(Code 1982, § 26-20; Ord. No. 551, § I(12), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-478. - Same-Must be removal daily. 
    Signs displayed under this article must be removed each day at the close of the garage sale activities or by the end of daylight, whichever first occurs. 
(Code 1982, § 26-21; Ord. No. 551, § I(12), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-479. - Only personal property allowed for sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any individual to sell or offer for sale, under authority granted by this article, property other than personal property. 
(Code 1982, § 26-22; Ord. No. 551, § I(2), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-480. - Hours of operation. 
    Garage sales conducted under this article shall be limited in time to no more than the daylight hours of three consecutive days or two consecutive weekends (Saturday and Sunday). 
(Code 1982, § 26-23; Ord. No. 551, § I(7), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-481. - Display of sale property. 
    Personal property offered for sale under this article may be displayed within the residence, in a garage, carport and/or in a rear yard, but only in those areas. No personal property offered for sale at a garage sale shall be displayed in the front or side yard areas of any such premises or in any public right-of-way. However, a vehicle offered for sale may be displayed on a permanently constructed driveway within such front or side yards. 
(Code 1982, § 26-24; Ord. No. 551, § I(10), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-482. - Public nuisance prohibited; owner or tenant liable for violation. 
    The individual to whom a permit is issued under this article and the owner or tenant of the premises on which such sale or activity is conducted shall be jointly and severally responsible for the maintenance of good order and decorum on the premises during all hours of such sale or activity. No such individual shall permit any loud or boisterous conduct on said premises, nor permit vehicles to impede the passage of traffic on any roads or streets in the area of such premises. All such individuals shall obey the reasonable orders of any member of the police or fire departments in order to maintain the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1982, § 26-25; Ord. No. 551, § I(13), 8-7-1979) 
State Law reference- Municipal power to prevent noises and disturbances, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-2. 
Sec. 16-483. - Inspections. 
    A police officer or any other official designated by any village ordinance to make inspections under the licensing or regulating ordinance or to enforce the same, shall have the right of entry to any premises showing evidence of a garage sale for the purpose of enforcement or inspection and may close the premises from such a sale or arrest any individual who violates the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 26-26; Ord. No. 551, § I(14), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-484. - Parking. 
    All vehicle parking shall be conducted in compliance with all applicable laws and ordinances. Further, the police department may enforce such temporary controls to alleviate any special hazards and/or congestion created by any garage sale. 
(Code 1982, § 26-27; Ord. No. 551, § I(15), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-485. - Permit required. 
    No garage sale shall be conducted, unless and until the individuals desiring to conduct such a sale shall obtain a permit therefor from the village clerk. 
(Code 1982, § 26-36; Ord. No. 551, § I(3), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-486. - Fees. 
    There shall be an administrative processing fee for the issuance of a permit under this article in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1982, § 26-37; Ord. No. 551, § I(5), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-487. - Two or more residences allowed to obtain joint permit. 
    Members of more than one residence may join in obtaining a permit for a garage sale to be conducted at the residence of one of them. 
(Code 1982, § 26-38; Ord. No. 551, § I(3), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-488. - Written statement required prior to sale. 
    Prior to issuance of any garage sale permit, the individuals conducting such sale shall file a written statement with the village clerk, at least five days in advance of the proposed sale (mailed applications must be postmarked at least seven days in advance of the sale), setting forth the following information: 
(1)  Full name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The location at which the proposed garage sale is to be held. 
(3)  The date upon which the sale shall be held. 
(4)  The date of any other garage sales held within the current calendar year. 
(5)  An affirmative statement that the property to be sold was owned by the applicant as his own personal property and was neither acquired or consigned for the purpose of resale. 
(Code 1982, § 26-39; Ord. No. 551, § I(4), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-489. - Village clerk's authority to investigate. 
    Before issuing a permit under this article, the village clerk may conduct an investigation as may reasonably be necessary to determine if there is compliance with this article. 
(Code 1982, § 26-40; Ord. No. 551, § I(9), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-490. - Effect of conviction for violation. 
    If any individual is convicted of an offense under this article, the village clerk is instructed to cancel any existing garage sale permit held by the individual convicted and not to issue such individual another garage sale permit for a period of two years from the time of conviction. 
(Code 1982, § 26-41; Ord. No. 551, § I(16), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-491. - Permit conditions. 
(a)  Contents. A permit issued under this article shall set forth and restrict the time and location of the garage sale. 
(b)  Three per year limit. No more than three such permits may be issued to one residence and/or family household during any calendar year. 
(c)  Joint residences. If members of more than one residence join in requesting a permit, then such permit shall be considered as having been issued for each and all of such residences. 
(Code 1982, § 26-42; Ord. No. 551, § I(6), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-492. - Fourth sale permitted if change of property ownership proven. 
    A fourth garage sale shall be permitted in a calendar year if satisfactory proof of a bona fide change in ownership of the real property is first presented to the village clerk or his duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1982, § 26-43; Ord. No. 551, § I(8), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-493. - Permit must be displayed in conspicuous location. 
    Any permit in possession of the holder of a garage sale shall be posted on the premises in a conspicuous place so as to be seen by the public and the village inspector or village police. 
(Code 1982, § 26-44; Ord. No. 551, § I(11), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-494. - Inclement weather; affidavit required for new permit. 
    If a garage sale is not held on the dates for which the permit is issued or is terminated during the sale's first day because of inclement weather conditions, and an affidavit by the permit holder to this effect is submitted, the village clerk may issue another permit to the applicant for a garage sale to be conducted at the same location within 30 days from the date when the first sale was to be held. No additional permit fee is required. 
(Code 1982, § 26-45; Ord. No. 551, § I(8), 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 16-495. - False information prohibited. 
    Any permit issued under this article may be revoked or any application for issuance of a permit may be refused by the village clerk if the application submitted by the applicant or permit holder contains any false, fraudulent or misleading statement. 
(Code 1982, § 26-46; Ord. No. 551, § I(16), 8-7-1979) 
Secs. 16-496-16-514. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - ALARM SYSTEMS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-515. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm agent means a business, either directly or indirectly, whose duties include any of the following: selling, maintaining, leasing, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing, on or in any building, structure or facility, an alarm system. 
    Alarm business means the business by any person of: Selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing any alarm system or causing to be sold, leased, maintained, serviced, repaired, altered, replaced, moved or installed any alarm system in or on any building, structure or facility. 
    Alarm system. 
(1)  The term " alarm system" means any mechanical or electrical device which is designed or used for the detection of fire, or an unauthorized entry into a building, structure or facility or for alerting others of an emergency situation within a building, structure or facility, or both; and which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message when actuated. The term "alarm system" includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
a.  Direct dial telephone devices; 
b.  Audible alarms; and 
c.  Proprietor alarms. 
(2)  The term "alarm system" does not include devices which are not designed or used to register alarms that are audible, visible or perceptible outside of the protected building, structure or facility. The term "alarm system" also does not include auxiliary devices installed by the telephone company to protect telephone company systems, which might be damaged or disrupted by the use of an alarm system. 
    Audible alarm means a device designed for the detection of fire, or unauthorized entry on the premises, which generates an audible sound on the premises when it is actuated. 
    False alarm means an alarm signal necessitating response by the village police department or fire department or other municipal department where an emergency situation does not exist. 
    Proprietor alarm means an alarm, which is not serviced by an alarm business. 
    Subscriber means any person who purchases, leases, contracts for or otherwise obtains an alarm system or for the servicing or maintenance of an alarm system from an alarm business. 
(Ord. No. 04-001, § 2(art. I), 1-6-2004) 
Sec. 16-516. - Compliance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, use or maintain an alarm system in violation of any of the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-001, § 2(4-1), 1-6-2004) 
Sec. 16-517. - Exemption. 
    The provisions of this article do not include a person who engages in the manufacture or sale of an alarm system from a fixed location and who neither visits the location where the alarm system is to be installed, nor designs the scheme for physical location and installation of the alarm system in a specific location. 
(Ord. No. 04-001, § 2(4-2), 1-6-2004) 
Sec. 16-518. - Police chief's and fire chief's authority to create minimum standards. 
    The police chief or fire chief may propose regulations prescribing minimum standards for the construction and maintenance of all alarm systems and requiring inspection and approval of all such systems. Such regulations shall have the full force and effect of law upon their adoption by ordinance by the village board after public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 04-001, § 2(4-3), 1-6-2004) 
Sec. 16-519. - Audible alarm regulations. 
(a)  Automatic shutoff. Every audible burglary alarm system shall have the capability of affecting an automatic shutoff of the system within 15 minutes after it is first activated. 
(b)  Notice. Every audible alarm shall have posted upon it a notice containing the name and telephone number of the alarm company or responsible person to be notified to render repairs or services during any hours of the day or night that the alarm rings. 
(c)  Occupant information. The occupant of the premises upon which any audible alarm is installed shall notify the police department of their address and the phone number at which they may be contacted at any time. 
(d)  Business or owner responsible for deactivating system. The alarm business or owner of any audible alarm shall be responsible for deactivating any alarm within one hour of notification or after reasonable efforts of notification that such alarm has been activated and ringing. 
(e)  Public nuisance. The ringing of any alarm for a period in excess of one hour after such notification or efforts of notification have been made is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and subject to misdemeanor prosecution, or summary abatement as a nuisance, or both. 
(Ord. No. 04-001, § 2(4-4), 1-6-2004) 
Sec. 16-520. - Telephone device which reproduces prerecorded message, sound or alarm and uses any public trunk line prohibited. 
    No person shall use or cause to be used, in connection with any alarm system, any telephone device or attachment that utilizes any public telephone trunk line and which reproduces any prerecorded message, sound or alarm to report any burglary or other emergency to the police department or fire department. This section does not prevent a telephone device that notifies independent security companies. 
(Ord. No. 04-001, § 2(4-6), 1-6-2004) 
Sec. 16-521. - False alarms; notice. 
(a)  First two responses; warning notice. For the first and second time that police personnel or fire personnel respond to a false alarm within any calendar year they shall document and deliver a false alarm warning notice to the offending party. 
(b)  Three or more responses; violation notice. After two false alarms have been documented, during a calendar year, police personnel and fire personnel may issue a municipal ordinance violation notice to the alarm system subscribers or business. 
(Ord. No. 04-001, § 2(4-24), 1-6-2004) 
Sec. 16-522. - Penalty. 
    Anyone violating this article shall be subject to the following fines or penalties: 
Number of False Alarms in Calender Year Fine/Penalty First and second No fine or penalty Third through fifth $50.00 fine for each offense Sixth through tenth $100.00 for each offense More than ten $250.00 for each offense  
(Ord. No. 05-004, § 2, 2-15-2005) 
Sec. 16-523. - Maintenance and repair; notice required; violation. 
    Alarm subscribers shall keep their alarm systems in good repair and alarm businesses shall notify the village 911 communication center prior to any alarm service, testing, repair, maintenance or installation which might activate a false alarm and shall notify the communication center when any such service has been completed. Any alarms activated where such prior notice has been given shall not constitute a false alarm. Any alarms activated without such notification will constitute a violation of this article and the alarm company may be issued a false alarm municipal ordinance violation notice. 
(Ord. No. 05-004, § 2, 2-15-2005) 
Sec. 16-524. - Inspection, maintenance, etc., records required to be kept. 
    Certificates of inspections, drills, maintenance and repairs of fire alarm systems shall be kept on the premises and shown to village officials upon request. 
(Ord. No. 05-004, § 2, 2-15-2005) 
Secs. 16-525-16-543. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ALARM SYSTEM BUSINESSES 

Sec. 16-544. - License required. 
    No person shall conduct an alarm business in the absence of a currently valid license obtained through the state in accordance with current state regulations. 
(Ord. No. 04-001, § 2(4-21), 1-6-2004) 
Sec. 16-545. - Building permits required; inspections. 
    Alarm businesses must obtain a work permit through the building department, prior to installing any alarm system. After the installation of every alarm system, a village inspector may inspect the system. In addition, fire department personnel will inspect alarm systems. 
(Ord. No. 05-004, § 1, 2-15-2005) 
Sec. 16-546. - Business responsible for officers, agents, and employees conduct; providing contact information to police department. 
    Each alarm business shall be held fully responsible for the conduct of all of its officers, agents or employees. All alarm businesses are required to either call a keyholder whenever an alarm activates, or annually provide the village police department with a listing of all current alarm subscribers within the village. This listing must contain the name and telephone number of at least three current keyholders to be notified when an alarm is activated. 
(Ord. No. 04-001, § 2(4-23), 1-6-2004) 
Sec. 16-547. - Business license tax not waived or exempted. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as a waiver or exemption from any business license tax otherwise applicable under the business license provisions of this chapter or any other provision of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 04-001, § 2(4-5), 1-6-2004) 
Secs. 16-548-16-566. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - SCAVENGERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-567. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Scavenger includes every person engaged in the business of rubbish, refuse or garbage collection by means of the use of any vehicle, including wagons and motor vehicles and vehicles propelled by human power. 
(Code 1969, § 14.701; Code 1982, § 25-96) 
Sec. 16-568. - Regulations. 
    All vehicles used in a business licensed under this article shall be kept in a sanitary condition and have provisions for covering the rubbish, refuse or garbage to prevent offensive odors or to jeopardize the public health and safety of the village citizens. 
(Code 1969, § 14.705; Code 1982, § 25-97) 
Secs. 16-569-16-587. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 16-588. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a scavenger within the village corporate limits, unless a license for such business, and each such vehicle used in said business, is first secured and he is in full compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1969, §§ 11.107, 14.702; Code 1982, § 25-106) 
Sec. 16-589. - Fees. 
    The annual fee for each scavenger license for each business using one vehicle, plus each additional vehicle used shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 14.704; Code 1982, § 25-107; Ord. No. 628, § 22, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 16-590. - Application. 
    An application for a license under this article shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall conform to all the provisions of article I of this chapter. In addition, the application shall recite the makes, models and state license numbers of the vehicles to be engaged in the business. 
(Code 1969, §§ 11.107, 14.703; Code 1982, § 25-108) 
Sec. 16-591. - Each vehicle issued a tag. 
    The village clerk shall issue with a license under this article a tag for each vehicle covered by the license. 
(Code 1969, § 14.707; Code 1982, § 25-109) 
Sec. 16-592. - License and tag to be conspicuously posted on each vehicle. 
    It shall be the duty of any person conducting a business licensed under this article to post the license or tag in a conspicuous place on each vehicle so used. 
(Code 1969, § 14.708; Code 1982, § 25-110) 
Sec. 16-593. - Village president's authority to revoke. 
    Any license issued under this article may be revoked by the village president at anytime during the life of such license for any violation by the licensee of any village ordinances relating to the license; such revocation may be in addition to any fine imposed. 
(Code 1969, § 14.706; Code 1982, § 25-111) 
Secs. 16-594-16-612. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - LANSING RENTAL HOUSING PROGRAM[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 11-030, adopted Nov. 16, 2011, repealed the former Art. XIII, §§ 16-613-16-622, and enacted a new Art. XIII as set out herein. The former Art. XIII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 09-044, §§ 1, 2, adopted Dec. 15, 2009. See the Code Comparative Table for a complete derivation.  Subsequently, section 1 of Ord. No. 13-033, adopted May 21, 2013, changed the title of Art. XIII from "Crime-Free Residential Housing Licensing and Regulation" to "Lansing Rental Housing Program." 

Sec. 16-613. - License required. 
    No person, firm, corporation or business entity, condominium, townhouse or homeowners' association shall engage in the business of renting any dwelling unit to the public, including the rental of a single family residence, rental dwelling or dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit, and including any residential real property that is not owner occupied, unless a valid residential rental license has been issued by the village clerk to the owner for the specific location. This licensing requirement shall not apply to group homes governed by the Specialized Living Centers Act, 405 ILCS 25/1 et seq., dealing with the developmentally disabled, or other similar uses governed by state or federal laws, rules or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 11-030, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-2011) 
Sec. 16-614. - Application for license. 
    Application for a residential rental license shall be made in the name of the legal owner of the premises to be rented, submitted to the village clerk on forms dispensed by the building department. The application shall identify the location of the property; the name, address and telephone of the owner; the name, address and 24-hour telephone(s) of the manager or custodian of the property; the owner's agent for service of process; and such other information as the clerk may reasonably require. 
    Each property address must have a separate application. 
(Ord. No. 11-030, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-2011) 
Sec. 16-615. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for a residential rental license shall be paid at the time of application as follows: 
$100.00 per year/per building, single unit/$25.00 for each additional unit in the building. 
(Ord. No. 11-030, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-2011) 
Sec. 16-616. - Term of license; transfer prohibited; renewal; notice to village to remove from program. 
    A residential rental license shall be issued for a period of one calendar year. All licenses shall expire December 31 next after issuance, unless previously revoked. Annual license fees must be paid to the village clerk no later than January 31 of each year and shall be prorated on a monthly basis. A $25.00 late fee will be added to each late payment received after January 31. The license shall not be transferable. Each new owner of the rental dwelling unit must obtain a license. Application for renewal shall be made in the same manner as for a new license. 
    If ownership of a rental unit or building changes after the yearly license fees have been paid, the fees will be considered paid for the calendar year for that property once the new owner files a new license form and submits a $25.00 processing fee (per building) to the village clerk. 
    In the event that an owner ceases to rent property or properties which are licensed through the program, the owner shall notify the building department that he/she is no longer renting the property. 
(Ord. No. 11-030, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-2011; Ord. No. 13-033, § 2, 5-21-2013; Ord. No. 16-023, § 1, 6-21-2016; Ord. No. 18-040, § 2, 10-16-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-023, § 1, adopted June 21, 2016, changed the title of § 16-616 from "Term of license; transfer prohibited; renewal" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 16-617. - Inspection required. 
    All property manager/owners shall be required to have their units inspected by the Lansing Building and/or fire departments prior to obtaining initial license, and before a new tenant occupies a unit. It is the responsibility of the manager/owner of the property to schedule the inspection. If property owners fail to complete the required inspection after two attempts, the property will be considered in violation of the ordinance and a citation will be issued to the owner, with fines not to exceed $750.00. No residential rental license shall be issued or renewed unless the dwelling unit(s) and common area(s) in connection with which the license is sought are found after inspection to meet all applicable laws and regulations. These inspections are for the purpose of insuring life safety, and sanitary conditions, and to maintain compliance with the Village of Lansing Building Ordinance. These inspections will be conducted by the Village of Lansing Building and/or Fire Departments. Rental dwelling units that change ownership shall be required to be inspected before a new license can be issued. The owner will be provided with an inspection report describing any condition which constitutes a violation of any applicable law or regulation, and shall be afforded reasonable opportunity to correct any such conditions. In the event that more than two inspections are required to determine compliance, subsequent, re-inspections of properties shall include reinspection fees of $150.00 per inspection. Payment must be made in full prior to issuance of the license. 
    The owner or owner's agent must accompany the inspector from the Village of Lansing during the inspection. 
    Failure to maintain a scheduled inspection, or to accompany the village's inspection personnel during an inspection will be considered a failed inspection. 
    Once a rental unit has passed initial inspections, a license must be obtained from the village clerk's office within 30 days. 
    Any property owner not obtaining a license from the village clerk's office within 30 days will be issued a citation. 
(Ord. No. 11-030, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-2011; Ord. No. 13-033, § 3, 5-21-2013; Ord. No. 18-040, § 2, 10-16-2018) 
Editor's note- Exhibit "A" to Ord. No. 11-030, adopted Nov. 16, 2011, is not setout herein, but is available for reference and inspection in the office of the village clerk. 
Sec. 16-618. - Lansing Rental Housing Program seminar required. 
    All persons applying for a residential rental license and all persons administering, managing or controlling the operation of any rental dwelling unit must attend a crime-free multi-housing seminar, administered by the Lansing Police Department, within six months of obtaining license. Licensees may attend other local municipalities crime-free multi-housing seminars and provide proof of attendance within six months of obtaining license in the event licensee cannot attend the seminar administered by the Lansing Police Department.
