Licensees are only required to attend one seminar. 
(Ord. No. 11-030, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-2011; Ord. No. 13-033, § 4, 5-21-2013; Ord. No. 18-040, § 2, 10-16-2018) 
Editor's note- Section 4 of Ord. No. 13-033, adopted May 21, 2013, changed the title of § 16-618 from "crime-free housing seminar required" to "Lansing Rental Housing Program seminar required." 
Sec. 16-619. - Lansing Rental Housing Program lease addendum. 
    Every lease or other agreement for residential rental property is required to utilize a Lansing Rental Housing Program lease addendum or have a clause in the lease similar to a crime free lease addendum for any leases executed after the date of enactment of this article. The police department shall provide at no cost samples of the Lansing Rental Housing Program lease addendum. The addendum is to make criminal activity (not limited to violent criminal activity or drug related criminal activity engaged by, facilitated by or permitted by the renter, member of the household, guest or other party under the control of the renter) a lease violation. The landlord shall have authority under the addendum to initiate an eviction proceeding as specified in the Illinois Compiled Statutes Forcible Entry and Detainer statutes. Proof of criminal violation shall be by a preponderance of the evidence. A copy of each lease shall be provided to the program administrator. The lease must contain the names, age and gender of each person allowed to reside in the rental unit. 
    The aforementioned "Lansing Rental Housing Program" lease addendum shall be written in substantially the following form: 
Lansing Rental Housing Program AddendumIn addition to all other terms of the lease, Landlord and Tenant agree as follows: 1. The Tenant, any member of the Tenant's household, any guest or any other person associated with the Tenant on or near the leased premises:  a) Shall not engage in criminal activity, including drug-related criminal activity, on or near the leased premises . "Drug related criminal activity" means the illegal manufacture, sale, distribution, use, or possession of any illegal or controlled substance as defined in 21 U.S.C. 802.  b) Shall not engage in any act intended to facilitate criminal activity.  c) Shall not permit the dwelling unit to be used for or to facilitate any criminal activity. 2. ANY ACTIVITY PROHIBITED BY THIS AGREEMENT SHALL CONSTITUTE A SUBSTANTIAL VIOLATION OF THE LEASE, MATERIAL NONCOMPLIANCE WITH THE LEASE, AND GROUNDS FOR TERMINATION OF TENANCY AND EVICTION.  
(Ord. No. 11-030, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-2011; Ord. No. 13-033, § 5, 5-21-2013) 
Editor's note- Section 5 of Ord. No. 13-033, adopted May 21, 2013, changed the title of § 16-619 from "Crime-free lease addendum" to "Lansing Rental Housing Program Addendum." 
Sec. 16-620. - Periodic inspection. 
    Every residential rental property is subject to periodic inspection bi-annual. This inspection is done to ensure the continued compliance with the village ordinance. The property owner or owner's agent will be given notice of the inspection. Whenever it appears by inspection that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of the provisions of this chapter or of any applicable laws and regulations, the village shall serve the owner or manager with notice of such violation, stating what action is required to correct the violation and the time period allowed for correction. Such notice shall state that unless the violations cited are corrected within the time allowed, the residential rental license may be suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 11-030, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-2011; Ord. No. 13-033, § 6, 5-21-2013; Ord. No. 18-040, § 2, 10-16-2018) 
Sec. 16-621. - Violation of "Lansing Rental Housing Program lease addendum" prohibited. 
    It is the responsibility of the Lansing Police Department to notify the property owner of any criminal activity which falls within the scope of the "Lansing Rental Housing Program lease addendum" that occurs on or near the property. It shall be the responsibility of the landlord to initiate appropriate action when the Lansing Rental Housing Program lease addendum is violated. If the situation is not addressed by the landlord to the satisfaction of the Lansing Police Department, the Lansing Police Department will notify the village clerk to initiate residential rental license revocation procedures. 
(Ord. No. 11-030, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-2011; Ord. No. 13-033, § 7, 5-21-2013) 
Editor's note- Section 7 of Ord. No. 13-033, adopted May 21, 2013, changed the title of § 16-621 from "Violation of "crime-free lease addendum" prohibited" to "Violation of "Lansing Rental Housing Program lease addendum" prohibited." 
Sec. 16-622. - Suspension or revocation of license; hearing; appeal. 
    The village clerk may suspend or revoke any residential rental license, on not less than five days' notice to the licensee and after affording the licensee an opportunity for a hearing, whenever the clerk finds that the licensee has failed or refused to correct any violation of any law or regulation applicable to the property, after reasonable notice and opportunity to take corrective action. Any person whose license has been suspended or revoked by the village clerk shall be entitled to an appeal to the mayor. Each day that the building remains occupied without a valid license in effect may result in fines up to $750.00 per day. Each day constitutes a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 11-030, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-2011) 
Sec. 16-623. - Nuisance. 
    It is hereby declared a nuisance and unlawful for any property owner, agent or manager to permit the following: (a) rental of a residential unit or residential building within an apartment community or governed by a homeowner's association to a tenant, member of the tenant's household, guest, or other party under control of the tenant, who permits any of the following offenses to occur: murder, kidnapping, aggravated kidnapping, prostitution, solicitation of prostitution, pandering, obscenity, child pornography, harmful materials, sale of obscene publication, criminal housing management, possession of explosives, unlawful use of weapons, sale of firearms, gambling, keeping a gambling place, concealing a fugitive, violation of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act, violation of the Cannabis Control Act or commission of any two or more of any other crimes defined by the State of Illinois or the United States Government, not specifically listed above; (b) rental of a residential unit, or residential building within an apartment community or governed by a homeowner's association to a tenant, including a member of the tenant's household, guest, or other party under control of the tenant, who allows any of the following offenses to occur: commission of four or more village ordinance violations in a six-month period or an unreasonably high number of calls for police service including, but not limited to, calls that may fall within the descriptions listed above that, when compared to other properties in the village of similar type, reasonably indicate that the activity at this property is out of character for the area and is impacting the quality of life of those in the area. 
(Ord. No. 11-030, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-2011) 
Sec. 16-624. - Exemptions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions within this chapter, and consistent with the terms and conditions of 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.5, no property shall be considered a chronic nuisance if the police investigations described in section 16-623 arise from calls for assistance from any victim of domestic abuse or person with a disability. Additionally, no victim of domestic abuse or person with a disability shall be evicted, sanctioned or punished in any way resulting from his or her seeking public assistance or police protection relating to that abuse or condition. However, nothing herein shall prevent the enforcement of this Code against an owner of the property who may be a victim of domestic abuse or be disabled, but whose victimhood or disability is unrelated to the law enforcement activity causing the property to be a chronic nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 16-015, § 1, 5-3-2016) 
Secs. 16-625-16-649. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - SECONDHAND DEALERS 

Sec. 16-650. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article the following words and terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Engaged in or conducting business means the purchase, sale, barter, or exchange of any item aforesaid, including advertising therefore and including such business conducted by an established dealer in a permanent location. 
    Exclusions means the provisions of this article do not apply to the following businesses or dealers: 
(1)  Junk; 
(2)  Used motor vehicles; 
(3)  Antique dealers which for purpose of this exclusion shall be read to be defined as any dealer who engages exclusively in the business or occupation of selling, bartering, or exchanging any painting, furniture, china, or other object painted or made more than 50 years prior to the date of sale, which is valuable primarily by reasons of age, scarcity or the skill and craftsmanship of the article and artisan. Antiques will not include family heirlooms made of gold and silver or other precious metals. 
(4)  Coin collectors or coin shops which engage exclusively in the coin business or occupation. Further, that this exclusion does not exempt such dealers or businesses from compliance with the regulations as hereinafter provided in relation to any gold, silver, platinum or other precious metal or jewelry which they may purchase, trade, barter, or exchange in addition to their coin and bullion operations; 
(5)  Flea market; 
(6)  Neighborhood garage sales; 
(7)  Nonprofit or charitable secondhand goods or thrift type shops. 
    Gems means any item containing or having any precious or semi-precious stones customarily used in jewelry or ornamentation. 
    Precious metals means any item containing as part of its composition in any degree, gold, silver, platinum or pewter. 
    Secondhand dealer is hereby defined to mean an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, trust association, or any other legal entity however organized engaged in or conducting business in the village for purchasing, trading, bartering, or exchanging secondhand personal property, gold, silver, and other precious metals. Secondhand dealer shall include but are not limited to pawn shops, cash for gold stores, and any business that purchases secondhand goods. 
    Secondhand goods shall consist of any item of personal property or object of value such as gold, silver, jewelry, and/or other precious metals, which is not purchased or sold as new. Secondhand or used personal goods do not include property purchased by one licensed, established merchant in the normal course of business from another licensed established merchant. Secondhand or used personal goods shall include but are not limited to the following items: 
(1)  Jewelry of any kind and/or any metal, precious or semiprecious in nature; 
(2)  Gold, silver, and/or other precious metals in whatever identifiable form except for numismatic coins or bullions; 
(3)  Any type of gem or precious stone, including diamonds; 
(4)  Office supplies; 
(5)  Furniture fixtures; 
(6)  Electronic equipment such as televisions, radios, and stereos; 
(7)  Appliances. 
(Ord. No. 12-020, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 16-651. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any violation of this article shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 no more than $750.00. Each violation shall be a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 12-020, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 16-652. - Purchasing from minors; payment by secondhand dealer. 
(a)  No secondhand dealer shall purchase, trade or deal in secondhand articles with a minor (an individual under the age of 18 years of age); or receive any goods or articles from any minors. 
(b)  All articles which are purchased by secondhand dealers shall be paid for with a check issued by the business. No articles which are purchased by secondhand dealers shall be paid for with cash. 
(Ord. No. 12-020, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 16-653. - Records of transactions required. 
(a)  Every secondhand dealer shall keep a record, which record system guidelines shall be established in conjunction with the chief of police of the village for the purpose of promoting uniformity and accessibility to the police department with minimum inconvenience to both the dealer and the department. However, under no circumstances will a looseleaf system be considered to be a proper medium of record keeping. 
(b)  The record of all transactions shall be written in the English language and in a clear, legible manner. 
(c)  The record maintained by the secondhand dealer shall be made at the time of the transaction and shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  Name, age, sex, general description of the individual with whom the transaction is had, as well as the individual's residence, thumbprint and his or her signature on the receipt and permanent record kept by the dealer. 
(2)  Confirmation of identification, by also securing a driver's license/state ID number along with the state of issuance of such document, military identification card number and the account number of a major credit card account, is used for purchase. A photocopy of said identification document shall comply with the confirmation requirement. This number shall be recorded along with the information hereinabove designated; 
(3)  The price of consideration paid or received at the time of the transaction; 
(4)  A description of every article (except as to the sale of goods) by him or newspapers, magazines, or other wastepaper, rags and clothing) received, purchased, sold, or exchanged by the dealer giving the manufacturer's name and other marks of identification appearing on the article including, but not limited to, the serial number, if any, on the article; 
(5)  If the property is delivered by motor vehicle, the license number of the delivering vehicle and the issuing state of said license shall be recorded along with all other identification requirements enumerated hereinabove; 
(6)  All entries in the record shall be signed by the person making the entry; 
(7)  Such records shall be retained for a period of two years from the date of the transaction. 
(8)  The use of the electronic "leads online" service may be used in lieu of the above listed written requirements. 
(Ord. No. 12-020, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 16-654. - Report to the chief of police or his designated agent. 
    It shall be the duty of every secondhand dealer to make out and make available for the personal inspection of the chief of police or his designated agent before the hour of 12:00 noon, each and every business day, a copy of the records required to be kept under the terms of this article, reflecting the completed transactions of the previous day. The posting online of the information via the "leads online" database will meet this requirement. 
(Ord. No. 12-020, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 16-655. - Record inspection. 
    The record book, the goods, articles or things purchased, received or kept for sale or exchange, by every secondhand dealer, shall be open to inspection of any member of the police department at all reasonable business times, or any person duly authorized in writing for such purpose by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 12-020, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 16-656. - Goods to be kept without concealment for seven business/working days. 
    Every dealer in secondhand goods must keep without concealment for a period of seven working/business days, subject to the inspection by any police officer, all goods, wares and merchandise, purchased or received from any person, before selling, shipping or otherwise disposing of the same. 
    Except that any goods, wares, or merchandise purchased or received from any person may be sold, shipped, or otherwise disposed of prior to the expiration of the seven working/business day holding period if the goods, wares, or merchandise have been sooner inspected by the chief of police or his designated agent and received written clearance for such further disposition. 
(Ord. No. 12-020, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 16-657. - Melting, wrecking and remodeling. 
    No secondhand dealer shall melt any watch, watchcase, jewelry or other identifiable article composed or manufactured in whole or in part of gold, silver, platinum, or other precious metals until such dealer shall have made a record of his intention to do so along with all other data required to be recorded by the specific recordation provisions of this section and shall have reported the same to the chief of police or his/her designated agents within the criminal investigations division and unless and until he/she shall have kept such article intact in his/her licensed place of business, for inspection for seven working/business days after the report provided for in this article has been made available to the chief of police or his/her designated agent; unless the identifiable article proposed to be melted down, wrecked or remodeled has been sooner inspected by the chief of police or his designated agent and received written clearance for such melting, wrecking or remodeling from same. 
(Ord. No. 12-020, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 16-658. - Coin dealers, coin collection swap meets and conventions. 
(a)  Coin collectors and coin dealers shall not be subject to the extensive record keeping and goods retention requirements for secondhand goods or used personal property dealers to the extent of their actual dealings in coins. However, if any such coin establishment also purchases, trades, barters or exchanges any other type of secondhand personal property including gold, silver and/or other precious metals or jewelry in conjunction with its coin dealership, such establishment shall be subjected to the extensive record keeping, licensing and goods retention requirements as established in this division, as far as these other items of gold, silver and/or precious metals or jewelry are concerned; 
(b)  Coin collectors and coin dealers although not subject to the record keeping, licensing requirements, and goods retention provisions of this division as related to their coin dealings, nonetheless will be required to meet the conditions set forth in subsection (c) of this section as they relate to their coin business; 
(c)  Registration: 
(1)  All coin dealers and/or collectors who conduct a coin business and conduct no other precious metal business shall be required to register with the village clerk. 
(2)  All coin swap meets and conventions shall be required to register with the village clerk no later than three days before the scheduled date of the swap meet. The sponsor or sponsors of such a swap meet shall be required to submit the following information at the time of registration: 
a.  The type of swap meet to be conducted; 
b.  The location of the swap meet or convention; 
c.  The time and date of the swap meet or convention and its expected duration; 
d.  The approximate number of participants. 
(d)  The village clerk or designee will notify the chief of police in a timely manner of all such meets or events registered in the village. 
(Ord. No. 12-020, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Chapter 18 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Election Code, 10 ILCS 5/1-1; village elections, 10 ILCS 5/2A-30. 

Sec. 18-1. - Precincts-Established. 
    The village is, for the purpose of conducting municipal elections, including primaries, and for such other purposes as may be provided by law, divided into such precincts as shall be prescribed by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 9.102; Code 1982, § 10-1) 
Sec. 18-2. - Same-Boundaries. 
    Wherever a street is indicated as a precinct boundary, the centerline of such street shall be considered to be the boundary line of such precinct; provided, however, that if such street or some part thereof constitutes some portion or all of the boundaries of the village, that part of the street which is the village boundary shall also be the boundary of such precinct and; provided, further, that if any streets are not dedicated throughout the entire distance for which it is indicated as one of the boundary lines of any precinct, then the prolongation of the centerline of such street shall be considered to be such boundary line. 
(Code 1969, § 9.103; Code 1982, § 10-2) 
Chapter 20 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Disaster Relief Act, 15 ILCS 30/1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 20-1-20-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY 

Sec. 20-19. - Created; composition. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby created the emergency services and disaster agency to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or damage resulting from disaster caused by an enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or from natural or manmade disaster, in accordance with the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act, 20 ILCS 3305/8. 
(b)  Composition. This emergency services and disaster agency shall consist of the coordinator and such additional members as may be selected by the coordinator. 
(Code 1982, § 9-21; Ord. No. 84-002, § 1, 4-17-1984) 
Sec. 20-20. - Coordinator. 
(a)  Appointment. The coordinator of the village emergency services and disaster agency (hereinafter referred to as the "agency"), shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(b)  Noninterference. The coordinator shall do nothing which will interfere with or affect the village police department or village fire department or their respective activities or responsibilities. 
(c)  Duties. The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training, and operation of the agency, subject to the direction and control of the mayor as provided by statute. 
(d)  Absense, resignation, death or inability; mayor to act as interim coordinator. In the event of absence, resignation, death or inability to serve as the coordinator, the mayor, or any person designated by him, shall be and act as coordinator until a new appointment is made as provided in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 9-22; Ord. No. 84-002, § 2, 4-17-1984) 
Sec. 20-21. - Functions prescribed by state regulations and mutual aid agreements. 
    The agency shall perform such functions within the village as shall be prescribed in and by the state emergency operations plan and program prepared by the governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor, and in addition shall perform such duties outside the village corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality, or quasi-municipality entered into as provided by the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act, 20 ILCS 3305/8. 
(Code 1982, § 9-23; Ord. No. 84-002, § 3, 4-17-1984) 
Sec. 20-22. - Mobile support team created; compensation. 
(a)  Created. All or any members of the village agency organization may be designated as members of a mobile support team created by the director of the state agency as provided by law. 
(b)  Designation of leader. The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the coordinator of the village agency organization. 
(c)  Compensation. Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee or officer while serving on call to duty by the governor, or the state director, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights, and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a paid village officer or employee, while so serving, shall receive from the state reasonable compensation as provided by law. 
(Code 1982, § 9-24; Ord. No. 84-002, § 4, 4-17-1984) 
Sec. 20-23. - Mutual aid agreements; approval required. 
    The agency coordinator may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other cities or political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the mayor and by the director of the state emergency management agency. 
(Code 1982, § 9-25; Ord. No. 84-002, § 5, 4-17-1984) 
Sec. 20-24. - Full cooperation with state agencies and governor required during emergency situation. 
    If the governor proclaims that an emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state of a major disaster resulting from some enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from any manmade or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the village agency to cooperate fully with the state emergency management agency and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. 
(Code 1982, § 9-26; Ord. No. 84-002, § 6, 4-17-1984) 
Sec. 20-25. - Compensation. 
    Agency members who are paid village employees or officers, if called for training by the director of the state emergency management agency, shall receive for the time spent in such training the same rate of pay as if attached to the position held; members who are not such village employees or officers shall receive for such training and time such compensation as may be established by the village corporate authorities. 
(Code 1982, § 9-27; Ord. No. 84-002, § 7, 4-17-1984) 
Sec. 20-26. - Reimbursement by state. 
    The state treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund, any reimbursement by the state to the village for the following: 
(1)  Expenses incident to training members of the agency, as prescribed by the director of the state emergency management agency; 
(2)  Compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the village in response to a call by the governor or director of the state emergency management agency; and 
(3)  Any other reimbursement made by the state incident to the state emergency management agency activities which is prescribed by law. 
(Code 1982, § 9-28; Ord. No. 84-002, § 8, 4-17-1984) 
Sec. 20-27. - Advanced purchases and contracts permitted where public safety benefited. 
    The mayor may, on the recommendation of the coordinator of the village emergency management agency, authorize any purchase or contract necessary to place the village in a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any nuclear or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and safety, protect property, and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of such disaster, or from manmade or natural disaster. 
(Code 1982, § 9-29; Ord. No. 84-002, § 9, 4-17-1984) 
Sec. 20-28. - Sworn oath. 
    Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the village agency organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the following oath, which shall be filed with the coordinator: 
I, _______, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions, and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Lansing Emergency Services Agency, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence. 
(Code 1982, § 9-30; Ord. No. 84-002, § 10, 4-17-1984) 
Sec. 20-29. - Mayor authorized to designate office space. 
    The mayor is authorized to designate space in a village building, or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the mayor for the village agency as its office. 
(Code 1982, § 9-31; Ord. No. 84-002, § 11, 4-17-1984) 
Sec. 20-30. - Appropriations; additional levy on taxable property allowed. 
    The mayor may make an appropriation for emergency management purposes in the manner provided by law, and may levy in addition, for emergency management purposes only, a tax not to exceed $0.05 per $100.00 of the assessed value of all taxable property in addition to all other taxes, as provided by 65 ILCS 5/8-3-16; however, that amount collectable under such levy shall in no event exceed $0.25 per capita. 
(Code 1982, § 9-32; Ord. No. 84-002, § 12, 4-17-1984) 
Secs. 20-31-20-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Wireless Emergency Telephone Safety Act, 50 ILCS 751/1 et seq.; authority for continuation of local surcharges, 50 ILCS 751/45. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-50. - Imposition of surcharge on telecommunications carriers for emergency telephone system. 
(a)  The village shall impose a surcharge of up to $0.50 per month per network connection on telecommunications carriers, which surcharge expense will be added to the monthly bill received for telephone or telecommunications charges, for the purpose of installing (or improving) a 911 emergency telephone system. 
(b)  The utility company collecting said surcharge may deduct an amount equal to three percent of the surcharge to cover the cost of accounting. 
(Code 1982, § 9-51; Ord. No. 88-01, 1-12-1988; Ord. No. 88-023, § 1, 8-16-1988) 
Secs. 20-51-20-69. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM BOARD 

Sec. 20-70. - Created. 
    There is hereby created an emergency telephone system board. 
(Code 1982, § 9-71; Ord. No. 88-009, § 1, 5-17-1988) 
Sec. 20-71. - Composition. 
    The board shall consist of seven members, which shall be appointed on the basis of ability and experience. They shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual and necessary expenses. Three of the members shall be the village police chief, the village fire chief and the village treasurer. The remaining members shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the board of trustees and shall all be village residents. The mayor shall appoint a chairman and vice-chairman of said board. 
(Code 1982, § 9-72; Ord. No. 88-009, § 2, 5-17-1988) 
Sec. 20-72. - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the village emergency telephone system board shall be as follows: 
(1)  Planning a 911 system for the village. 
(2)  Coordinating and supervising the implementation, upgrading, or maintenance of the system, including the establishment of equipment specifications and coding systems. 
(3)  Receiving monies from the surcharge imposed under the Illinois Revised Statutes, and from any other source, for deposit into the emergency telephone system fund. 
(4)  Authorizing all disbursements from such fund, by means of resolutions adopted by a majority vote of the members of the emergency telephone service board, for purposes authorized by law and shall be approved by the village board. 
(5)  Hiring, on a temporary basis, any staff necessary for the implementation or upgrade of the system, and providing for the compensation of such staff. 
(6)  To adopt rules providing for its procedures and organization. 
(7)  To do all things related to the purposes for which it was created, not prohibited by law. 
(Code 1982, § 9-73; Ord. No. 88-009, § 3, 5-17-1988) 
Sec. 20-73. - Term. 
    The term of office of all persons appointed to the village emergency telephone system board shall be four years. The term of office of original appointees shall commence on June 1, 1988, and shall end at midnight, May 31, 1992. Successor appointees shall be appointed for terms of similar duration. There shall be no limit in the number of terms a member may serve. 
(Code 1982, § 9-74; Ord. No. 88-009, § 4, 5-17-1988) 
Sec. 20-74. - Filling of vacancies. 
    A vacancy on the village emergency telephone system board may be occasioned by the resignation, death, change of residence, physical or mental incapacity, or continual refusal to attend scheduled meetings of or by a member. The mayor shall have the power to determine the existence of a vacancy. All vacancies shall be filled within 60 days from the date the mayor determines a vacancy to exist. 
(Code 1982, § 9-75; Ord. No. 88-009, § 5, 5-17-1988) 
Secs. 20-75-20-93. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND FEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-94. - Ambulances-Requirements and operation. 
    No person shall operate an ambulance, which shall include any motor vehicle primarily designed and used for the conveyance of sick or injured persons, in a manner not in conformity with any motor vehicle law, state regulation or village ordinance, as such provision applies to motor vehicles in general, except in compliance with the following conditions: 
(1)  The person operating the ambulance shall be either responding to a bona fide emergency call or specifically directed by a licensed physician to disregard traffic laws in operating the ambulance during and for the purpose of the specific trip or journey that is involved; 
(2)  The ambulance shall be equipped with a siren producing an audible signal of an intensity of 100 decibels at a distance of 50 feet from said siren, and with a lamp emitting an oscillating, rotating or flashing red beam directed in part toward the front of the vehicle and containing a power rating of at least 100 amps; 
(3)  The aforesaid siren and lamp shall be in full operation at all times during such trip or journey; and 
(4)  Whenever the ambulance is operated at a speed in excess of 40 miles per hour, the ambulance shall be operated in complete conformity to every other motor vehicle law, state regulation and village ordinance. 
(Code 1969, § 23.210.1; Code 1982, § 14-2) 
Sec. 20-95. - Same-Penalty. 
    A person who operates an ambulance in violation of section 20-94 shall be liable for the general penalty prescribed by section 1-23, notwithstanding any provision of state law or this Code exempting therefrom the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle when responding to an emergency call. 
(Code 1969, § 23.210.2; Code 1982, § 14-3) 
Secs. 20-96-20-114. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MOBILE INTENSIVE CARE UNIT 

Sec. 20-115. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Advance life support/mobile intensive care services means the initiation of treatment of acute life threatening conditions under the direction of a physician authorized by law to practice medicine in the state or a person authorized by state law to act as a qualified registered professional nurse, who has satisfactorily completed a course of training in emergency care approved for purposes of this division by the state department of public health and where authorized by the project medical director, in a state department of public health approved advanced life support system. 
    Basic life support services means the rendering of basic emergency care, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Airway management; 
(2)  Cardiopulmonary resuscitation; and 
(3)  Control of bleeding and splinting of fractures. 
    Certified paramedic means a paramedic who is certified by both the resource hospital and the board of fire and police commissioners. 
    Emergency means any condition which, if not corrected, will cause death, permanent disability or deterioration of the individual's condition. 
    Emergency medical technician-ambulance (EMT-A) means a person who has successfully completed a course of instruction in basic life support services as required and is certified by the state department of public health. 
    Emergency medical technician-paramedic (EMT-P) means a person who has successfully completed a department-approved course of instruction in advanced life support/mobile intensive care services and is certified by the state department of public health. An EMT-P is qualified by training and education to perform advanced life support/mobile intensive care services under the provisions of the Emergency Medical Services (EMS) Systems Act, 210 ILCS 50/1 et seq. Advance life support/mobile intensive care services include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Mechanical resuscitation procedures; 
(2)  Fluid resuscitation procedures; and 
(3)  Electrical and pharmacological resuscitation procedures. 
    Prehospital emergency services means emergency care initiated by an advanced life support/mobile intensive care system prior to arrival at a hospital and the continuation of such emergency services by the advanced life support/mobile intensive care system personnel as may be necessary until the responsibility for the care of the patient is assumed by the medical personnel of a hospital emergency department or other facility within the hospital to which the patient is first delivered by the advanced life support/mobile intensive care system personnel. 
    Resource hospital means that which is designated as such by the area-wide hospital emergency services committee and the state department of public health (division of emergency medical services and highway safety). The term "resource hospital" means the hospital performs the following functions: 
(1)  Total responsibility for training of both hospital and field paramedic personnel; 
(2)  Monitors all medical direction transmission within the network; 
(3)  Nominates field personnel for state certification and recertification; 
(4)  Assumes medical control at both hospital and field levels; 
(5)  Maintains records and data pertaining to the program's function; and 
(6)  Ensures conformity with all local, state and federal rules, regulations and standards related to mobile intensive care operation. 
(Code 1982, § 14-49; Ord. No. 500, § 1, 12-11-1978) 
Sec. 20-116. - Created; composition. 
    There is hereby created for the village a mobile intensive care unit, whose membership shall consist of certified police/fire-emergency medical technicians-paramedics and emergency medical technicians-ambulance from the village police department, both regular and special, and from the village fire department, both regular and paid-on-call. 
(Code 1982, § 14-50; Ord. No. 500, § 1, 12-11-1978) 
Sec. 20-117. - Co-directors; appointed; qualifications. 
    The police chief and the fire chief, in their capacity as administrators of the village mobile intensive care unit (M.I.C.U.) program, shall appoint co-directors, one from each respective department, both individuals being certified paramedics within the village M.I.C.U. program who shall carry out the directives of the joint heads of the unit. 
(Code 1982, § 14-51; Ord. No. 500, § 1, 12-11-1978; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 20-118. - Fire department probationary status members to become state-certified paramedics. 
    All individuals who are appointed by the board of fire and police commissioners to a probationary status within the fire department must be advised that during their probationary period they are required to become state-certified paramedics through the then-established resource hospital with which the village is associated, and shall comply with such requirement prior to the termination of their probationary period. Advertisement for examination shall include this provision. 
(Code 1982, § 14-52; Ord. No. 500, § 1, 12-11-1978; Ord. No. 03-002, § 1, 1-21-2003) 
Sec. 20-119. - Probationary period may be extended upon fire chief's written request. 
    The probationary period of a firefighter/paramedic may be extended by the board of fire and police commissioners upon the fire chief's written recommendation. 
(Code 1982, § 14-53; Ord. No. 500, § 1, 12-11-1978; Ord. No. 03-002, § 2, 1-21-2003) 
Sec. 20-120. - Management and control jointly vested in police chief and fire chief. 
    The management, supervision and control of the village M.I.C.U. is vested in the police chief and fire chief, who shall be responsible for the government, efficiency and good conduct of the village M.I.C.U. members and shall be considered the joint heads of the unit. 
(Code 1982, § 14-54; Ord. No. 500, § 1, 12-11-1978) 
Sec. 20-121. - Personnel. 
    The police chief and fire chief shall have sole control and command over all persons connected with the village M.I.C.U. program. They shall have full power to prescribe and enforce rules and regulations for the government of M.I.C.U. members, which shall not be inconsistent with the charter and ordinances of the village, state laws or the rules and regulations set forth from the M.I.C.U. resource hospital. 
(Code 1982, § 14-55; Ord. No. 500, § 1, 12-11-1978; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 20-122. - Maintaining paramedic status. 
    Every police officer/paramedic who is currently a certified paramedic on the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived will be required to maintain his certified paramedic status for a period of five years from the effective date of the ordinance (Ord. No. 03-002) from which this division is derived, or at an earlier date, such persons, with the police chief's approval, will have the option of terminating participation in the paramedic program. 
(Code 1982, § 14-56; Ord. No. 500, § 1, 12-11-1978; Ord. No. 89-025, § 1, 12-19-1989; Ord. No. 03-002, § 3, 1-21-2003) 
Sec. 20-123. - Termination of employment. 
    A person's employment as a firefighter/paramedic may be terminated for the following reasons: 
(1)  In the event that a firefighter/paramedic who became a member of the fire department prior to January 21, 2003, is not certified during his probationary period or any extension thereof, he shall be terminated. 
(2)  In the event that a firefighter/paramedic who became a member of the fire department after December 19, 1989, is not certified as required by the resource hospital, he shall be terminated. 
(3)  In the event that a police officer/paramedic who became a member of the police department between the dates of December 19, 1989, and January 21, 2003, is not certified as required by the resource hospital, he shall be terminated. 
(4)  Police officer/paramedics hired after June 1, 2001, shall be offered the option of maintaining his status in the paramedic training program, or withdrawing from said program and changing their job description and title to the position of "police officer." Future eligibility lists for sworn positions within the police department will be for police officers only. 
(Code 1982, § 14-57; Ord. No. 500, § 1, 12-11-1978; Ord. No. 89-025, § 2, 12-19-1989; Ord. No. 03-002, § 4, 1-21-2003) 
Secs. 20-124-20-141. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SERVICE FEES 

Sec. 20-142. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Advanced life support-Level 1 (ALS1) means transportation by ground ambulance, medically necessary supplies and services and an ALS assessment by ALS personnel or the provision of at least one ALS intervention. 
    Advanced life support-Level 2 (ALS2) means transportation by ground ambulance, medically necessary supplies and services and an ALS assessment by ALS personnel or the provision of either: 
(1)  Three or more different administrations of medications by intravenous push/bolus or by continuous infusion excluding crystalloid, hypotonic, isotonic, and hypertonic solutions (Dextrose, Normal Saline, Ringer's Lactate); or 
(2)  The provision of at least one of the following ALS procedures: 
a.  Manual defibrilation/cardioversion; 
b.  Endotracheal intubation or the monitoring and maintenance of an endotracheaitube that was inserted prior to transport; 
c.  Central venous line; 
d.  Cardiac pacing; 
e.  Chest decompression; 
f.  Surgical airway; or 
g.  Intraosseous line. 
    Advanced life support assessment means an assessment performed by an ALS crew as part of an emergency response that was necessary because the patient's reported condition at the time of dispatch was such that only an ALS crew was qualified to perform the assessment. An ALS assessment does not necessarily result in a determination that the patient requires an ALS level of service. 
    Advanced life support intervention means a procedure that is, under state or local law or regulation, beyond the scope of authority an basic emergency medical technician (EMT-Basic). An unsuccessful attempt to perform an ALS Intervention may qualify the transport for billing at the appropriate ALS level; provided that the intervention would have been reasonable and necessary had if it had been successful. 
    Advanced life support personnel means an individual trained to the level of the intermediate emergency medical technician (EMT-intermediate) or paramedic. 
    Air ambulance services means either fixed wing (airplane) or rotary wing (helicopter) aircraft transport of a patient. 
    Ambulance services means any of seven categories of ground ambulance services and two categories of air ambulance services as provided in the fee schedule. 
    Basic life support (BLS) means transportation by ground ambulance vehicle and medically necessary supplies and services. 
    Closest appropriate facility means a facility capable of treating the patient's condition, as limited by the village's transportation policy set forth in this division. 
    Emergency response means responding immediately at the BLS or ALS level of services as a result of a 911 call or the equivalent. An immediate response is one in which the ambulance supplier begins as quickly as possible to take the steps necessary to respond to the call. The nature of the call at the time of dispatch is the determining factor. Regardless of the medium by which the call is made, if the call is of an emergency nature when, based on the information available to the dispatcher at the time of the call, it is reasonable for the dispatcher to issue an emergency dispatch in light of accepted, standard dispatch protocol. 
    EMT means a basic or intermediate emergency medical technician. 
    EMT-Basic means an individual who is qualified under state and local laws, rules, and regulations as a basic emergency medical technician. 
    EMT-Intermediate means an individual who is qualified under state and local laws, rules, and regulations as a EMT-Basic. The term "EMT___Intermediate" also means the individual is qualified to perform essential advanced techniques and to administer a limited number of medications. 
    EMT-Paramedic means an individual possessing the qualifications of the EMT-Intermediate and also, in accordance with state and local laws, rules, and regulations. The term "EMT-Paramedic" also means an individual having enhanced skills that include being able to administer additional interventions and medications. 
    Ground ambulance services refers to transportation over land or over water. 
    Miles means miles of transport with a patient on board rounded up to the nearest whole number. 
    Specialty care transport (SCT) means an inter-facility transport of a critically injured or ill patient by a ground ambulance vehicle, including the provision of medically necessary supplies and services, at a level of service beyond the scope of the EMT-Paramedic. SCT is necessary when a patient's condition requires ongoing care that must be provided by one or more health professionals in an appropriate specialty area (for example emergency, or critical care nursing, emergency medicine, respiratory care, cardiovascular care, or a paramedic with additional training.) The person providing care does not have to be an employee of the ambulance company for the service to be classified as SCT. 
Sec. 20-143. - Transportation policy. 
    It shall be the policy of the village and the emergency medical service of its fire department and police department to transport patients to either Community Hospital in Munster, Indiana, or St. Margaret-Mercy Health Care Center-North Campus in Hammond, Indiana or Franciscan Health Munster in Munster, Indiana, except as listed below: 
(1)  When ordered by the resource hospital, or as required by system policy. 
(2)  In accordance with state statutes pertaining to trauma or prisoner transport. 
(3)  For transportation of a psychiatric voluntary admission, which may be transported to St. Margaret-Mercy Health Care Center-South Campus in Dyer, Indiana. 
(4)  As directed by the incident commander when responding to a mutual-aid incident. 
(Code 1982, § 14-6; Ord. No. 02-030, § 1, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 16-033, § 1, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 20-144. - Categories of services; fees. 
    The categories of ambulance services are determined by the patient's condition and not by the type of vehicle used in transport. The fees for the ambulance services shall be as follows:

Sec. 20-145. - Fire department nonresident service fees. 
    Pursuant to the guidelines established by 60 ILCS 1/30-166 and 65 ILCS 5/11-6-1.1, emergency response fees for the village fire department, to be charged nonresidents, shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 06-030, § 1, 9-19-2006) 
Chapter 22 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 

Footnotes:
