(3)  The place in the village where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(6)  The applicant's fingerprints and the names of at least two reliable property owners of the county who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or, in lieu of the names of references, any other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will enable an investigator to properly evaluate such character and business responsibility; 
(7)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within 60 days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two inches by two inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(8)  The place, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant, where the applicant within the six months next preceding the date of said application conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted; 
(9)  A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the village in the following manner: 
a.  The invoice value and quality of such goods, wares and merchandise, whether the same are proposed to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in possession and by sample; 
b  At auction, by direct sale or by direct sale and by taking orders for future delivery; 
c.  Where the goods or property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced and where such goods or products are located at the time said application is filed; 
(10)  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers, and, if required by the village clerk, copies of all said advertising whether by handbills, circular, newspaper advertising, or otherwise, shall be attached to said application as exhibits thereto; 
(11)  Whether or not the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business has been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor; 
(12)  Credentials from the person for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative; 
(13)  No license shall be issued to the terms of this article, unless the applicant therefor shall produce evidence satisfactory to the village clerk that said applicant is complying with the state law relating to the tax imposed upon persons engaged in the business of selling tangible, personal property at retail; 
(14)  At the time of filing the application, a fee shall be paid to the village clerk to cover the cost of investigation in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk; 
(15)  The names and addresses of the applicant's suppliers; 
(16)  Such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of the person having the management or supervision of applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the village clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public good. 
(Code 1982, § 21-101; Ord. No. 621, § 18.103, 10-21-1980) 
Sec. 28-45. - Investigation; issuance; unsatisfactory finding. 
(a)  Police chief to conduct investigation. Upon the receipt of such application, the original shall be referred to the police chief who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. 
(b)  Disapproval. If as a result of such investigation the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the following shall occur: 
(1)  The police chief shall do the following: 
a.  Endorse on the application his disapproval and his reasons for the same; and 
b.  Return said application to the village clerk. 
(2)  The village clerk shall do the following: 
a.  Notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit and license will be issued. 
b.  The notice shall be given in writing setting forth the reasons for disapproval. 
c.  The notice shall be mailed postage prepaid to the applicant at the last known address. 
(c)  Approval; issuance. If a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the following shall occur: 
(1)  The police chief shall do the following: 
a.  Endorse on the application his approval; 
b.  Execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for; and 
c.  Return said permit, along with the application to the village clerk. 
(2)  The village clerk shall do the following: 
a.  Upon payment of the prescribed license fee, deliver to the applicant his permit and issue a license. 
b.  The license shall contain the following information: 
1.  Signature and seal of the issuing officer; 
2.  Name, address and photograph of the said licensee; 
3.  Class of license issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder; 
4.  Amount of fee paid; 
5.  Date of issuance; 
6.  Length of time the license shall be operative; 
7.  License number; and 
8.  Other identifying description of any vehicle used in such peddling. 
c.  Keep a permanent record of the license issued. 
(Code 1982, § 21-102; Ord. No. 621, § 18.104, 10-21-1980; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 28-46. - Bond required. 
    Before any license shall be issued for engaging in a transient or itinerant business in the village, such applicant shall file with the village clerk a bond running to the village in the sum of $5,000.00 executed by the applicant, as principal, and two sureties upon which service of process may be made in the state; said bond to be approved by the village attorney, conditioned that the said applicant shall comply fully with all the provisions of village ordinances and the state statutes, regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against said applicant for any violation of said ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with such applicant, whether said misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents, or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof. Action on the bond may be brought in the village's name to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond must be approved by the village attorney, both as to form, and as to the responsibility of the sureties thereon. 
(Code 1982, § 21-103; Ord. No. 621, § 18.105, 10-21-1980) 
Sec. 28-47. - Service of process; village clerk's authority to accept for applicant. 
    Before any license shall be issued for engaging in business as a transient or itinerant merchant in the village, such applicant shall file with the village clerk an instrument nominating and appointing the village clerk, or the person performing the duties of such position, his true and lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on behalf of said applicant in respect to any matters connected with or arising out of the business transacted under said license and the bond given as required by section 28-46, or for the performance of the conditions of said bond or for any breach thereof, which said instrument shall also contain recitals to the effect that said applicant for said license consents and agrees that service of any notice or process may be made upon said agent, and when so made shall be taken and held to be as valid as if personally served upon the person applying for the said license under this article, according to the law of this or any other state, and waiving all claim or right of error by reason of such acknowledgment of service or manner of service. Immediately upon service of process upon the village clerk, he shall send to the licensee at his last known address, by registered mail, a copy of said process. 
(Code 1982, § 21-104; Ord. No. 621, § 18.106, 10-21-1980) 
Sec. 28-48. - Posted conspicuously within business; separate license and posting required for each location. 
    The license issued under this article shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event that such person applying for said license shall desire to do business in more than one place within the village, separate licenses may be issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Code 1982, § 21-105; Ord. No. 621, § 18.107, 10-21-1980) 
Sec. 28-49. - Fees; village clerk's authority to inspect records and collect monies. 
(a)  Fee. A license issued under this article shall pay a fee based upon the gross amount of sales by such persons and shall be at the rate of five percent. 
(b)  Inspection; collection. Every person conducting a business licensed under this article shall, on the first business day of each week, and upon discontinuance of business in the village, present to the village clerk, at his office, a verified statement showing the total sales made during the preceding week and shall pay to the village clerk the amount of the license fee provided in subsection (a) of this section, for the sales made during the previous week. The village clerk and any other officer designated by him shall have the power and authority to enter any store, building, or any other place in which such temporary business may be conducted at anytime during business hours for ascertaining the amount of sales made and shall at all times have access to the books of such business. 
(Code 1982, § 21-106; Ord. No. 621, § 18.108, 10-21-1980) 
Sec. 28-50. - Nontransferable. 
    No license shall be transferred. 
(Code 1982, § 21-107; Ord. No. 621, § 18.109, 10-21-1980) 
Sec. 28-51. - Records. 
(a)  The village clerk shall deposit the license-fingerprint records, together with a license number, with the police chief. 
(b)  The police chief shall report to the village clerk any complaints against any person licensed under the provisions of this article and any conviction for any violation of this article. 
(c)  The village clerk shall keep a record of all such licenses, complaints and violations. 
(Code 1982, § 21-108; Ord. No. 621, § 18.112, 10-21-1980; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 28-52. - Revocation; notice. 
(a)  The permits and licenses issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the village mayor, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  A conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting the business licensed under this article in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of the license-revocation hearing shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee, at his last known address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Code 1982, § 21-109; Ord. No. 621, § 18.113, 10-21-1980) 
Sec. 28-53. - Appeal. 
(a)  Right of appeal. Any person aggrieved by action of the police chief or village clerk in the denial of an application for permit or license as provided in section 28-45, or in the decision with reference to the revocation of a license as provided in section 28-52, shall have the right to appeal to the village board of trustees. 
(b)  Notice. The appeal shall be taken by filing with the village clerk, within 14 days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. 
(c)  Board of trustee's action. The board of trustees shall set a time and place for a hearing on the appeal and notice of the hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided in section 28-52 for notice of hearing on revocation. 
(d)  Final decision. The decision and order of the board of trustees on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1982, § 21-110; Ord. No. 621, § 18.114, 10-21-1980; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 28-54. - Expiration. 
    All licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall expire 90 days after the date of issuance thereof, unless a prior date is fixed therein. 
(Code 1982, § 21-111; Ord. No. 621, § 18.115, 10-21-1980) 
Secs. 28-55-28-73. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PEDDLERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-74. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Peddler means: 
(1)  Any person, whether a village resident or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance, from place-to-place, from house-to-house, or from street-to-street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers. 
(2)  One who, without traveling from place-to-place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance. 
(3)  The term "peddler" includes one who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this article. 
(4)  The term "peddler" also includes the terms "hawker" and "huckster," but shall not include any religious, fraternal or charitable solicitations. 
    Person includes the singular and the plural and shall also mean and include any person, firm, or corporation, association, club, co-partnership or society, or any other organization. 
(Code 1982, § 21-16; Ord. No. 622, § 18.202, 11-4-1980) 
Sec. 28-75. - Loud noises and speaking devices prohibited for attracting business. 
    No peddler, nor any person on his behalf, shall shout, make any cryout, blow a horn, ring a bell or use any sound device, including any loud speaking radio or sound amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks or other public places of the village or upon any private premises in the said village where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom to be capable of being plainly heard upon the streets, avenues, alleys, parks, or other public places, for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares or merchandise which such license proposes to sell. 
(Code 1982, § 21-17; Ord. No. 622, § 18.208, 11-4-1980) 
Sec. 28-76. - Street usage. 
(a)  A peddler shall not be permitted to use public streets in the following ways: 
(1)  For his exclusive right to any location in the public streets; 
(2)  As a stationary location; 
(3)  To operate in any congested area where his operations might impede or inconvenience the public. 
(b)  For the purpose of this article, a police officer's judgment, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced. 
(Code 1982, § 21-18; Ord. No. 622, § 18.209, 11-4-1980) 
Sec. 28-77. - Police department's duty enforce. 
    It shall be any village police officer's duty to require any person seen peddling, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce his peddler's license and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Code 1982, § 21-19; Ord. No. 622, § 18.211, 11-4-1980) 
Secs. 28-78-28-96. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT AND LICENSE 

Sec. 28-97. - Permit and license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddler, as defined in section 28-74, within the village corporate limits without first obtaining a permit and license therefor. 
(Code 1982, § 21-26; Ord. No. 622, § 18.201, 11-4-1980) 
Sec. 28-98. - Application. 
    An applicant for permit and license under this article must file with the village clerk a sworn application in writing (in duplicate) on a form to be furnished by the village clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Applicant's name and description; 
(2)  Business' address (legal and local); 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold and in the case of products of farm or orchard, whether produced or grown by the applicant; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(6)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with license number or other means of identification; 
(7)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within 60 days immediately prior to the date of filing the application, which picture shall be two inches by two inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(8)  The applicant's fingerprints and the names of at least two reliable property owners of the county who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or, in lieu of the names of references, any other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will enable an investigator to properly evaluate such character and business responsibility; 
(9)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor, or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; 
(10)  The applicant shall file with his application a statement by a reputable physician of Cook County, Illinois or Lake County, Indiana dated no more than ten days prior to submission of the application, certifying the applicant to be free of infectious, contagious or communicable disease; 
(11)  At the time of filing the application, a fee shall be paid to the village clerk to cover the cost of investigation in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk; 
(12)  The names and addresses of the applicant's suppliers. 
(Code 1982, § 21-27; Ord. No. 622, § 18.203, 11-4-1980) 
Sec. 28-99. - Investigation and issuance. 
(a)  Police chief to conduct investigation. Upon receipt of the application, the original shall be referred to the police chief who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. 
(b)  Disapproval. If as a result of such investigation the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the following shall occur: 
(1)  The police chief shall do the following: 
a.  Endorse on such application his disapproval and his reasons for the same; and 
b.  Return the said application to the village clerk. 
(2)  The village clerk shall do the following: 
a.  Notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit and license will be issued. 
b.  The notice shall be given in writing setting forth reasons for disapproval. 
c.  The notice shall be mailed postage prepaid to the applicant at the last known address. 
(c)  Approved; issuance. If as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the following shall occur: 
(1)  The police chief shall do the following: 
a.  Endorse on the application his approval; 
b.  Execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for; and 
c.  Return said permit, along with the application to the village clerk. 
(2)  The village clerk shall do the following: 
a.  Upon payment of the prescribed license fee, deliver to the applicant his permit and issue a license. 
b.  The license shall contain the following information: 
1.  Signature and seal of the issuing officer; 
2.  Name, address and photograph of said licensee; 
3.  Class of license issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder; 
4.  Amount of fee paid; 
5.  Date of issuance; 
6.  Length of time the license shall be operative; 
7.  License number; and 
8.  Other identifying description of any vehicle used in such peddling. 
c.  Keep a permanent record of the licenses issued. 
(Code 1982, § 21-28; Ord. No. 622, § 18.204, 11-4-1980; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 28-100. - Fees. 
(a)  Computation. Fees shall be computed as follows: 
(1)  The fees in this section shall be in an amount as determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(2)  No fee shall be required of one selling products of the farm or orchard actually produced by the seller. 
(b)  Basis. For the purpose of this article, the following applies: 
(1)  Any period of seven-calendar days or less shall be considered one week; 
(2)  Any period of more than seven-calendar days, and no more than 30-calendar days shall be considered one month; 
(3)  Any period of more than 30-calendar days, and no more than one calendar year shall be treated as a year; and 
(4)  The annual fees shall be assessed on a calendar-year basis and on and after July 1 the amount of the fee for such annual licenses shall be one-half the amount stipulated for the remainder of the year. 
(Code 1982, § 21-29; Ord. No. 622, § 18.205, 11-4-1980) 
Sec. 28-101. - License plates and credentials. 
(a)  The village clerk shall issue to each licensee at the time of license delivery two license plates for each vehicle to be used, plus credentials for each individual licensed under this article. 
(b)  The license plates and credentials shall bear the following information: 
(1)  The words "Licensed Peddler"; 
(2)  Period for which the license is issued; and 
(3)  Number of the license in letters and figures plainly discernable. 
(c)  License plates shall be attached to the vehicle used by the licensee, either on both sides or on the front and rear of the vehicle so used. 
(d)  The credentials shall be carried constantly by the licensee during such time as the licensee is engaged in peddling. 
(Code 1982, § 21-30; Ord. No. 622, § 18.206, 11-4-1980) 
Sec. 28-102. - Nontransferable. 
    No license or credentials issued under the provisions of this article shall be used or carried at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(Code 1982, § 21-31; Ord. No. 622, § 18.207, 11-4-1980) 
Sec. 28-103. - Must display upon request. 
    Peddlers are required to exhibit their licenses at the request of any citizen. 
(Code 1982, § 21-32; Ord. No. 622, § 18.210, 11-4-1980) 
Sec. 28-104. - Records. 
(a)  The village clerk shall deposit the license-fingerprint records, together with a license number, with the police chief. 
(b)  The police chief shall report to the village clerk any complaints against any person licensed under the provisions of this article and any conviction for violation of this article. 
(c)  The village clerk shall keep a record of all such licenses, complaints and violations. 
(Code 1982, § 21-33; Ord. No. 622, § 18.212, 11-4-1980; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 28-105. - Revocation; notice. 
(a)  Permits and licenses issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the mayor of the village after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for license; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business as a peddler; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  A conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
(5)  Conducting the business of peddling in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of the license-revocation hearing shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at his last known address at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Code 1982, § 21-34; Ord. No. 622, § 18.213, 11-4-1980) 
Sec. 28-106. - Appeal. 
(a)  Right of appeal. Any person aggrieved by the action of the police chief or village clerk in the denial of any application for permit or license as provided in section 28-99, or in the decision with reference to the revocation of a license as provided in section 28-105, shall have the right to appeal to the village board of trustees. 
(b)  Notice. The appeal shall be taken by filing with the village clerk, within 14 days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. 
(c)  Board of trustee's action. The board of trustees shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of the hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided in section 28-105 for notice of hearing on revocation. 
(d)  Final decision. The decision and order of the board of trustees on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1982, § 21-35; Ord. No. 622, § 18.214, 11-4-1980; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 28-107. - Expiration. 
    All annual licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall expire on December 31 in the year when issued. Other than annual licenses shall expire on the date specified on the license. 
(Code 1982, § 21-36; Ord. No. 622, § 18.215, 11-4-1980) 
Secs. 28-108-28-126. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HOME SOLICITATION SALES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, adopted July 20, 2010, repealed former Art. IV, Divs. 1-3, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. IV pertained to canvassing and derived from the Code of 1982 and the following: Ord. No. 467, § 2, 2-7-1978; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000. 

Sec. 28-127. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, and the interpretation and application thereof, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein, unless the context in which they are used shall indicate otherwise. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the singular number include the plural number and words in the plural number include the singular number. Words or phrases not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    Business shall mean any Village-licensed business located in any zoning district. 
    Chief of police shall mean the chief of police of the Lansing Police Department or such other designee. 
    Residence shall mean every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure. 
    Soliciting or solicitation shall mean one (1) or more of the following activities: 
(1)  Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or description whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever. 
(2)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character. 
(3)  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of publication. 
(4)  Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Sec. 28-128. - License required: exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in solicitation activities within the village without first obtaining a license issued by the village clerk in cooperation with the village police department. 
(b)  No person engaging in the mere act of expressing ideas for charitable, benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, not-for-profit, religious or political purposes shall be required to obtain a solicitation permit from the Village unless such activities are coupled with a request for donations or the offering of property for sale. 
(c)  The terms and provisions of this article shall not be applicable to any person under the age of 18 years who is engaged in solicitation activities on behalf of a youth organization such as Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, Little League, church youth organizations or other such youth groups. The village clerk, in cooperation with the chief of the police department shall make the final determination of the application of this exemption. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Sec. 28-129. - Application required. 
(a)  Application for a solicitation license shall be made upon a form provided by the village clerk and shall be forwarded to the police department. The applicant shall, under oath, truthfully state in full the information requested on the application, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  The applicant's name and residential address and the length of residence at said address. 
(2)  The applicant's business address, if other than a residential address; 
(3)  Proof of the applicant's age and address, as identified on a state-issued form of identification; 
(4)  A complete physical description of the applicant; 
(5)  The name, address and telephone number of the applicants employer or, if acting as an agent or representative, the name, address and telephone number of the principal who is being represented, with credentials in written form to establish the relationship and the authority of the employee or agent to act for the employer or principal, as the case may be; 
(6)  The length of time of employment or relationship, as the case may be; 
(7)  A description sufficient for identification of the subject matter of the solicitation activity the applicant will engage in; 
(8)  The dates and hours in which the solicitation is proposed to begin, the expected duration of the proposed soliciting, and the geographic area within the village wherein such solicitation shall occur; 
(9)  If using a vehicle while soliciting, proof of insurance for and the complete description and license number of the vehicle to be used by the applicant; 
(10)  The approximate date of any previous application for a license under this article and indication if any license issued to the applicant by the village under this article has been revoked; Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony under the laws of the State of Illinois or any other state or federal law; 
(12)  Execution of a statement indicating that, if a license is granted, it shall not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement by the village or any of its departments or employees thereof; and 
(13)  Any such additional information as the chief of police deems necessary to process the application. 
(b)  A criminal background check shall be required before a solicitation license is issued to the applicant. Accordingly, the chief of police shall require the applicant, in addition to the completion of the application form, to submit the applicant's fingerprints, along with all other necessary identifying information, in order to allow the chief of police to obtain such a background criminal record check on the applicant. Applicant shall pay a non-refundable $50.00 processing fee to reimburse the village for the cost of the background check at the time the application is submitted. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010; Ord. No. 17-021, § 2, 10-17-2017) 
Sec. 28-130. - License fee; duration. 
    At the time the application is filed with the village clerk, the applicant shall pay a fee for the license of $10.00 per day for a license permitting solicitation for one 24-hour period, or $50.00 per 30-day period, up to a maximum of three such consecutive periods, or 90 days. After 90 days, the applicant must reapply. The license shall be nontransferable and shall be valid for a period of either 24 hours or the applicable number of 30-day periods applied for (up to 90 days) from the date of issuance, respectively. 
    If a license is denied, the license fees deposited with the village pursuant to this subsection shall be promptly returned to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010; Ord. No. 17-021, § 3, 10-17-2017) 
Sec. 28-131. - Application, review, denial of license; appeal. 
(a)  Review. Upon the police department's review of the application, the chief of police may refuse to issue a license to the applicant for any of the following reasons, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  The location and time of solicitation would endanger the safety and welfare of the applicant or their customers; 
(2)  An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application; 
(3)  The applicant has been convicted of a violation of any provision of this article or the ordinance of any other unit of government regulating soliciting; 
(4)  The applicant has been convicted of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or federal law; 
(5)  There is no proof as to the authority of the applicant to serve as an agent or representative to the principal or employee to the employer, as the case may be; 
(6)  The applicant has been denied a license under this article, unless the applicant demonstrates to the satisfaction of the chief of police that the reasons the earlier denial no longer exists; or 
(7)  The application or proposed solicitation is not in compliance with the provisions of this article or other applicable requirements of law. 
(b)  Denial. Any denial by the chief of police and the reasons for denial shall be noted on the application and the applicant shall be notified that the application is denied and that no license shall be issued. Notice shall be mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant at the address shown on the application. 
(c)  Appeal. An appeal may be filed by the applicant. An appeal must be filed in the office of the village clerk within 21 days after the date of the written notice notifying the applicant of the denial of the application. Notice and time and place of the hearing shall be given to the applicant in the same manner as provided for the mailing of notice in subsection 28-131(b). A hearing shall be set no later than twenty (20) days from receipt of the applicant's appeal with the village clerk. The applicant shall have the burden of proof to show, by a preponderance of the evidence, the denial is not justified. The decision of the mayor or such other designee, who shall preside over and decide such matter shall be binding and final and reviewable in a manner provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Sec. 28-132. - Records; application and license. 
    The village clerk shall cause to be kept in her office an accurate record of every application received and processed with all other information and data pertaining thereto. Every application shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed and every license issued shall be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Sec. 28-133. - Display of license. 
    Every license shall be carried at all times by the applicant to whom the license was issued, when soliciting in the Village, and shall be exhibited by such licensee whenever requested to do so by any prospective customer or police officer. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Sec. 28-134. - Temporary identification; display. 
    At the time of the issuance of a license, the village clerk shall issue to each licensee temporary identification, which shall be worn by the licensee in such a way as to be conspicuous at all times while soliciting in the village. The information included on the temporary identification shall include, but not be limited to, the name of the licensee, the picture of the licensee and the expiration date of the license. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Sec. 28-135. - Assignment; transfer of license or temporary identification. 
    No license or temporary identification shall be assigned or transferred nor shall it be used by any person other than the person to whom it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Sec. 28-136. - Time limit on soliciting. 
    Solicitation at a business or residence shall be permitted only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. Solicitation at any other time shall be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance. No soliciting is permitted on a Sunday or any state or federal holiday. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Sec. 28-137. - Uninvited soliciting. 
(a)  No person shall engage in soliciting from persons in residences or businesses where a notice is displayed upon or near the main entrance door stating that solicitation is uninvited. Such notice shall consist of a weatherproof card, approximately three inches by four inches in size with letters at least one-third of an inch in height and may be obtained from the village clerk's office, at the cost thereof. Any solicitation in disregard of a posted notice shall be unlawful and constitute a nuisance. 
(b)  No person shall engage in soliciting, whether invited or not, in a business or residence, when requested to do so by any occupant. Every such person shall be required to immediately and peacefully depart the business or residence. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Sec. 28-138. - False personation: representation. 
(a)  No person shall falsely represent to be an employee, agent or representative of any organization or charitable organization or when any person exhibits or uses in any manner any decal, badge or insignia of any organization or charitable organization when not authorized to do so by any organization or charitable organization. 
(b)  No person shall claim or represent that they are acting on behalf of the village, or any of its departments or employees thereof, unless the village has first entered into a written agreement with the person or the person's employer authorizing solicitation. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Sec. 28-139. - Revocation; appeal. 
(a)  Revocation. The chief of police shall revoke a license for a violation of any regulation listed in this article. Upon such revocation, written notice shall be mailed by the village clerk to the holder of the license, to the address shown on the application, by certified mail, return receipt requested, and all solicitation shall promptly cease. 
(b)  Appeal. An appeal may be filed by the licensee. An appeal must be filed in the office of the village clerk within 21 days after the date of the written notice notifying the licensee of the revocation along with a written statement under oath setting forth the grounds for the appeal. Notice and time and place of the hearing shall be given to the licensee in the same manner as provided for the mailing of notice in subsection 28-139(a). A hearing shall be set no later than twenty (20) days from receipt of the licensee's written statement. The licensee shall have the burden of proof to show, by a preponderance of the evidence, the revocation is not justified. The decision of the mayor or such other designee shall be binding and final and reviewable in a manner provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Sec. 28-140. - Violation; penalty. 
(a)  Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $750.00 for each offense. Every day that a violation exists constitutes a separate offense. 
(b)  Proceedings to enforce violations of this article may be initiated and conducted in accordance with and pursuant to the provisions of the Municipal Code of the Village providing for administrative adjudication of code violations or by any other means provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 10-015, § 2, 7-20-2010) 
Chapter 30 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal contracts for disposal of refuse, garbage and ashes, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ashes means residue from fires used for cooking and for heating buildings. 
    Garbage waste means wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food; wastes from the handling, storage and sale of produce and such paper as may necessarily be used for wrapping. 
    Refuse. 
(1)  The term "refuse" means: 
a.  Combustible trash including, but not limited to, the following: 
1.  Paper; 
2.  Cartons; 
3.  Boxes; 
4.  Barrels; 
5.  Wood; 
6.  Excelsior; 
7.  Tree branches; 
8.  Yard trimmings; and 
9.  Wood furniture and bedding. 
b.  Noncombustible trash including, but not limited to, the following: 
1.  Metals; 
2.  Tin cans; 
3.  Metal furniture; 
4.  Dirt; 
5.  Small quantities of rock; and 
6.  Pieces of concrete, glass, crockery and other mineral waste. 
c.  Street rubbish including, but not limited to, the following: 
1.  Street sweepings; 
2.  Dirt; 
3.  Leaves; 
4.  Catchbasin dirt; and 
5.  Contents of litter receptacles. 
(2)  The term "refuse" does not include the following: 
a.  Earth and wastes from building operations; and 
b.  Solid wastes resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing operations such as: 
1.  Food processing wastes; and 
2.  Boiler-house cinders, lumber, scraps and shavings. 
(Code 1969, § 11.101; Code 1982, § 25-1) 
State Law reference- Definitions relating to the disposal of refuse, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-2. 
Secs. 30-2-30-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GARBAGE AND REFUSE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-21. - Littering; prohibited, declared nuisance. 
    No person shall throw or drop any litter or refuse upon a sidewalk, crosswalk, roadway or any part of any public street, and such act is hereby declared to be a nuisance and unlawful. 
(Code 1969, § 17.115; Code 1982, § 25-11) 
State Law reference- Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq. 
Sec. 30-22. - Accumulation. 
    The owner, occupant or lessee of any premises in the village shall cause to be removed from said premises all garbage, refuse and ashes, and shall keep said premises at all times free and clean from any accumulation thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 11.102; Code 1982, § 25-12) 
Sec. 30-23. - Unlawful to put debris in windblown state. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or leave any refuse or material in such a place or condition that it can be blown by the wind so as to be scattered or cause clouds of dust or particles; and it shall be unlawful for any person to permit the escape of soot, ashes or other solid products or result of combustion so as to be windblown or scattered. 
(Code 1969, § 17.139; Code 1982, § 25-13) 
Sec. 30-24. - Disposal. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of, place or deposit, or permit to be deposited, any grass, leaves, branches, human or animal excrement, garbage or refuse in any street, gutter or any other public place within the village. 
(b)  No person shall dispose of or place any garbage or refuse on private property, whether owned by such person or not, within the village limits, or any area under village jurisdiction, unless the same shall be enclosed in a suitable container or bundled as provided in sections 30-25 and 30-26; provided, however, that any person who immediately disposes of any refuse upon his own premises in a properly constructed, enclosed incinerator, or disposes of garbage through home garbage grinders into sewers, shall not be required to place such refuse in any such container. 
(Code 1969, §§ 11.103, 17.136, 24.304; Code 1982, § 25-14) 
Sec. 30-25. - Household waste requirements. 
    All household garbage and refuse shall be drained and stored for collection in the following manner: 
(1)  In a container with a capacity not to exceed 35 gallons, equipped with a tight-fitting cover or lid and handles. 
(2)  In a container furnished by or rented from Homewood Disposal Service, Inc., or acceptable to said firm, or its successors and assigns. 
(3)  The loaded weight for each container shall not exceed 50 pounds. 
(4)  The use of plastic bags, paper bags, oil drums, cardboard drums or other similar containers is prohibited. 
(5)  Bulky refuse, if not otherwise stored, shall be bundled and tied securely. 
(Code 1969, § 11.104; Code 1982, § 25-16; Ord. No. 667, § 1, 11-17-1981; Ord. No. 11-023, § 1, 7-19-2011) 
Sec. 30-26. - Food establishments and food multiple-family dwelling waste containers. 
    All garbage and refuse of any restaurants, coffee shop or establishment where food is served and all garbage and refuse of all multiple-family dwellings of three units or more shall be stored in a refuse container that meets the following specifications: 
(1)  Length: 77 3/8 inches; 
(2)  Width: 30 inches; 
(3)  Height: 463/4 inches at the back edge; tapers down to 41 inches at the leading edge; capacity one cubic yard; 
(4)  Gauge: 14 steel; 
(5)  Weight: 290 pounds; 
(6)  Paint: Two primer coats followed by baked on enamel finish; 
(7)  Wheels: Six inches diameter and two inches thick, total of four rubber roller bearing casters, two stationary and two free wheeling; and 
(8)  Cover: A tight-fitting slip cover type that will attach for unloading to the garbage trucks now operating in the village. 
(Code 1969, § 11.105; Code 1982, § 25-17) 
Sec. 30-27. - Owner's duty to maintain containers. 
    Containers for garbage, refuse and ashes shall be provided by and kept clean and in good repair by the owner, occupant or lessee of any premises in the village. 
(Code 1969, § 11.106; Code 1982, § 25-18) 
Secs. 30-28-30-46. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COLLECTION BY VILLAGE 

Sec. 30-47. - Superintendent's authority to collect. 
    The public works superintendent shall have charge of the collection of garbage, refuse and ashes in the village. The collection shall be made from all premises at least once each week; provided that the material is properly stored for collection in the container complying with the provisions of this chapter. 
    The village has the sole and exclusive authority to contract for the removal of solid waste and recycling material from all single-family residences and multi-family residences with less than three units within the village. 
(Code 1969, § 11.109.3; Code 1982, § 25-26; Ord. No. 16-018, § 1, 5-3-2016) 
Sec. 30-48. - Compliance. 
    No owner, occupant or lessee of any premises in the village shall be entitled to solid waste collection service from the village who has not complied fully with all the provisions of this chapter and with the village rules and regulations as established and approved by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 11.109.2; Code 1982, § 25-27) 
Sec. 30-49. - Service rates. 
    The village shall collect and dispose of all garbage, refuse and ashes in accordance with such rules and regulations as to service rates of charge as may be approved by the president and board of trustees from time to time. 
(Code 1969, § 11.109.1; Code 1982, § 25-28) 
Sec. 30-50. - Fees. 
    The fees for collection in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk shall be paid in advance for the following: 
(1)  Per month; for all single-family dwellings; 
(2)  Per month; for all single-family dwellings owned and occupied by a senior citizen, conditioned upon proof of age (65 years and older) and property ownership; 
(3)  Per month; per unit, for all duplexes and townhouses. 
(Code 1969, § 11.109.3; Code 1982, § 25-29; Ord. No. 362, § 1, 1-7-1975; Ord. No. 446, § 1, 7-19-1977; Ord. No. 628, § 7, 12-30-1980; Ord. No. 95-025, § 1, 8-15-1995; Ord. No. 95-034, § 1, 10-17-1995; Ord. No. 99-032, § 1, 12-21-1999) 
Sec. 30-51. - Quarterly billing. 
    Billing for village solid waste collections shall be on a quarterly basis. Charges will be made for a half month if service is started after the 15th of the month. 
(Code 1969, § 11.109.03; Code 1982, § 25-31; Ord. No. 95-025, § 1, 8-15-1995; Ord. No. 95-034, § 1, 10-17-1995) 
Sec. 30-52. - Request for change in service. 
    Where a user desires a change in pick-up service, he shall make a change request to the superintendent of public works or the public works committee. 
(Code 1969, § 11.109.4; Code 1982, § 25-33) 
Secs. 30-53-30-71. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RECYCLING 

Sec. 30-72. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Recyclables means material having an economic value in the secondary materials market. The following materials have such economic value: 
(1)  Aluminum cans and articles; 
(2)  Bi-metal cans; 
(3)  Glass containers; 
(4)  Corrugated paper (cardboard and paper boxes); 
(5)  Magazines; 
(6)  Computer printout paper; 
(7)  Computer tab cards; 
(8)  Office paper; 
(9)  Steel cans; 
(10)  Newspaper; 
(11)  Paper products not chemically coated; 
(12)  Grass clippings and leaves. 
(Code 1982, § 25-151; Ord. No. 89-023, § 1, 12-19-1989) 
Sec. 30-73. - Program established. 
(a)  Mandatory. There is hereby established a recycling program for the mandatory separating of recyclables from garbage and rubbish in the village. The village shall adopt such rules and regulations for the collection of the recyclable material, post such rules and regulations in prominent places within the village to make them available to all village residents, and provide a copy to each household located within the village. 
(b)  Containers provided. Further, the village shall provide containers for said recyclable material as are reasonably necessary for an average household. Additional containers may be purchased from the village. 
(Code 1982, § 25-152; Ord. No. 89-023, § 2, 12-19-1989) 
Sec. 30-74. - Separation from other refuse; curbside placement or transport to a facility. 
    Recyclables shall be prepared and separated from other refuse as required, and shall be collected by the village, or its agent. Recyclables shall be placed either at the curbside to be collected at times designated by the village or taken to a recycling facility. 
(Code 1982, § 25-153; Ord. No. 89-023, § 3, 12-19-1989) 
Sec. 30-75. - Village property; collection by unauthorized person prohibited. 
(a)  From the time of placement of the recyclable at the curb or in recycling shelters for collection in accordance with the terms hereof, items shall be and become the property of the village or its authorized agent. It shall be a violation of this article for any person unauthorized by the village to collect or pick up or cause to be collected or picked up any such items. Any and each such collection in violation hereof from one or more locations shall constitute a separate and distinct offense punishable under this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a person to allow recyclable materials to be commingled with other forms of solid waste. 
(Code 1982, § 25-154; Ord. No. 89-023, § 4, 12-19-1989) 
Sec. 30-76. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates or neglects to comply with any provision of this article or any regulation promulgated pursuant thereto, shall, be subject to the general penalty contained in section 1-23. 
(Code 1982, § 25-155; Ord. No. 89-023, § 5, 12-19-1989) 
Sec. 30-77. - Donation or resale permitted. 
    Any person may donate or sell recyclables to any other person whether operating for profit or not for profit. 
(Code 1982, § 25-156; Ord. No. 89-023, § 6, 12-19-1989) 
Chapter 32 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal administration of streets and limitations thereon, 605 ILCS 5/7-101; general power of municipalities over streets, alleys, and sidewalks, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cement contractor includes any person engaged in the business of the construction or repair of footings, foundations, sidewalks, streets, vaults, sewer headwalls, manholes or other like work requiring the use of Portland cement. 
    Excavating contractor includes any person engaged in the business of excavating or removing dirt, rock, sand or any other substance in preparation for the construction of streets, sidewalks, parking lots or other hard surface areas, or for the construction of the basement or foundation of any building or other structure requiring such basement or foundation to be constructed below the street or ground level, or for the construction of any sewer, vault or other like work requiring such excavation or removal. 
    Lot includes a portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land with or without building development. 
    Sidewalk means an area within the street right-of-way which provides pedestrian access to adjacent areas. 
    Street means any roadway accessible to the public for vehicular traffic including, but not limited to, private streets or access lanes, as well as all public streets and highways within the village boundaries. 
(Code 1969, § 29.102; Code 1982, § 27-1) 
Sec. 32-2. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all existing and proposed streets, sidewalks, crosswalks, driveways, curbs and curb cuts within the village. 
(Code 1969, § 20.101; Code 1982, § 27-2) 
Sec. 32-3. - Work to be done under superintendent's direction. 
    All construction, repair and maintenance of existing and proposed streets, sidewalks, crosswalks, driveways, curbs and curb cuts within the village for which a permit is granted under the provisions of this chapter shall be under the direction and supervision of the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1969, § 20.103; Code 1982, § 27-3) 
Sec. 32-4. - Conflict of laws. 
    In the event of a conflict between the provisions of this chapter and any other provision of this Code, village ordinance, state law, or federal law, the more stringent regulation shall prevail, if permitted by state law, and the specific shall control over the general regulation. 
Sec. 32-5. - Erection or maintenance of poles, wires, pipes on or over public areas requires superintendent's prior approval. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any poles or wires on or over any public street, alley or other public way or to install any pipes or conduits in or under such place, without having first secured permission from the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1969, § 20.112; Code 1982, § 27-4) 
Sec. 32-6. - Barricades required. 
    Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or other public place, or making or maintaining any excavation or opening in any such place, shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury to any person or property by reason of the work; such barricades shall be protected by a light at night. 
(Code 1969, § 20.106.1; Code 1982, § 27-5) 
Sec. 32-7. - Disturbing or interfering with barricades or lights prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb or interfere with any barricade or light lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement, excavation or opening in or obstruction on any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Code 1969, § 20.106.2; Code 1982, § 27-6) 
Sec. 32-8. - Security deposit required; additional to any bond or other monies necessary for the protection of public streets and sidewalks. 
(a)  Any person obtaining a permit to erect any building or structure where the erection of such structure requires the transportation of materials across the street, sidewalk, curb, parkway or public way, shall adequately protect such street, sidewalk, curb, parkway or public way, and shall deposit with the village clerk an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk to ensure replacement or repair of the aforementioned areas to a like-new condition, the terms and conditions of such deposit are as follows: 
(1)  The village retains the cost of repairing any damage done to sidewalks, curbs, parkways, public ways or any trees on parkways. 
(2)  The balance of such deposit shall be returned to the person making the deposit when the structure has been completed and all damages repaired. 
(b)  In the event that no damage is done to any sidewalk, curb, parkway, public way or trees, then all of said deposit shall be returned to the person depositing same. 
(c)  The deposit provided in this section is distinct from any in addition to any bond or security deposit required under this chapter for construction of streets or sidewalks or for the excavation and restoration of streets and sidewalks within the village. The deposit required pursuant to this section is to indemnify the village for damage that may result from use of village streets and sidewalks as set forth in this section. 
(Code 1969, § 20.114; Code 1982, § 27-7) 
Sec. 32-9. - Bond, instead of cash deposit, acceptable to indemnify the village. 
(a)  In lieu of depositing cash to cover any damage to surfaces, a surety bond, executed by an acceptable surety company regularly doing business in the state, conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss or damage to sidewalk, curb, parkway, public way or trees, in the amount of 11/2 times the amount of the cash deposit may be furnished. 
(b)  The bond permitted in lieu of a cash deposit is distinct from any in addition to any bond or security deposit required under this chapter for the construction of streets or sidewalks or for the excavation and restoration of streets and sidewalks within the village. The bond permitted in lieu of a cash deposit is to indemnify the village for damage that may result from use of village streets and sidewalks. 
(Code 1969, § 20.114; Code 1982, § 27-8) 
Sec. 32-10. - Scaffolds and ladders must be safely constructed and maintained; tools and articles must be properly fastened. 
(a)  Any scaffolds or ladders placed in a position where they overhang or can fall onto any public street or other public way in the village shall be firmly and properly constructed and safeguarded. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or leave any tools or articles on any such place in a manner that the same can fall onto such street, sidewalk or other public way from a greater height than four feet. 
(Code 1969, § 20.116; Code 1982, § 27-9) 
Sec. 32-11. - Unlawful to place articles above streets, sidewalks or other public places in a dangerous manner. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place any moveable article on any window ledge, or other place abutting a public street, sidewalk or other public place at a height above four feet from the ground in such a manner that the same can be or is in danger of falling onto such street, sidewalk or other public place. 
(Code 1969, § 20.113; Code 1982, § 27-10) 
Sec. 32-12. - Obstructions prohibited. 
    A person shall not cause, create, erect, construct, place or maintain any bumps, fences, gates, chains, bars, pipes, wood or metal horses or any other type of obstruction in or on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way within the village boundaries, unless approved by the village or the state. 
(Code 1969, § 20.111; Code 1982, § 27-11; Ord. No. 567, § 2, 11-6-1979) 
Sec. 32-13. - Unlawful to obstruct public drains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any drain in any public street, public place, easement or alley. 
(Code 1969, § 20.110; Code 1982, § 27-12) 
Sec. 32-14. - Encroachments prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any building or structure which encroaches upon any public street, sidewalk, crosswalk, alleyway or public property. 
(Code 1969, § 20.109; Code 1982, § 27-13) 
Sec. 32-15. - Pumps and tanks prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or erect any pump or tank or similar structure on any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Code 1969, § 20.115; Code 1982, § 27-14) 
Sec. 32-16. - Unlawful to injure pavement. 
(a)  New pavement. It shall be unlawful for any person to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon, or injure any newly laid street or sidewalk pavement while the same is guarded by a warning sign or barricade, or knowingly to injure any soft or newly laid pavement. 
(b)  Any public pavement. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully injure any pavement in any public place. 
(Code 1969, § 20.105; Code 1982, § 27-14.1) 
Sec. 32-17. - Deposit of injurious material. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit on any street or sidewalk in the village any material which may be harmful to the pavements thereof or any waste material, or any glass, or other substance or articles which may do injury to any person, animal, property or such street or sidewalk. 
(b)  Material or coal may be deposited on streets preparatory to delivery or use under the following conditions: 
(1)  The deposit does not reduce the usable width of the roadway at that point to less than 17 feet; and 
(2)  Such material or coal, other than the material to be used in the street building construction shall not remain on such street for more than three hours. 
Any such material or coal shall be guarded by lights if the same remains upon any such street after dark. 
(c)  Merchandise or other articles may be deposited on sidewalks preparatory to delivery or removal under the following conditions: 
(1)  The usable width of the walk is not reduced to less than four feet; and 
(2)  No such articles shall remain on the walk for more than one-half hour. 
(Code 1969, § 20.108; Code 1982, § 27-15) 
Sec. 32-18. - Defects; duty to report. 
    It shall be the duty of every village officer or employee becoming cognizant of any defect in any street, alley or sidewalk, or any obstruction thereof, to report the same to the superintendent of public works as soon as possible. Dangerous defects shall be barricaded by the superintendent of public works to prevent injury. 
(Code 1969, § 20.107; Code 1982, § 27-16) 
Sec. 32-19. - Unlawful to place signs, words or figures on any public street, property or place without superintendent's prior approval. 
    It shall be unlawful, except as the president and board of trustees may provide by ordinance or resolution, for any person to use any street, sidewalk, telephone pole, power pole, street light pole, tree, public place or public property as space for the display of any signs, placards or any printed, painted or written matter for any purpose, or to write, print or mark any sign, words or figures on any street, sidewalk, telephone pole, power pole, street light pole, tree, public place or public property. 
(Code 1969, § 20.118; Code 1982, § 27-17) 
Sec. 32-20. - Trimming and cutting back. 
    Every owner of property shall maintain his or her property and the adjacent parkway and alley so as to prevent the growth of: vegetation, alternative vegetation, trees or shrubs which prevent the free and unobstructed travel of pedestrians upon sidewalks, or vehicles on streets and alleys, or which otherwise negatively affect traffic or pedestrians' safety by impairing the visibility or passage of pedestrians or vehicles. Owners shall trim vegetation, trees, and shrubs so as to maintain a minimum overhead clearance of eight feet over sidewalks and 14 feet over streets and alleys at all times. 
(Ord. No. 14-034, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Secs. 32-21-32-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMITS 

Sec. 32-39. - Required. 
    No person shall begin to build, construct, lay, reconstruct, rebuild, remove, repair, alter, grade or disturb in any manner any portion of any street, sidewalk, alley, crosswalk, curb or curb cut without first obtaining a permit from the village clerk, except in all cases where sidewalks are to be constructed, laid or rebuilt in accordance with the provisions of the Special Assessment Act or by special taxation ordinances. 
(Code 1969, §§ 20.104.1, 20.301, 20.401; Code 1982, § 27-26) 
Sec. 32-40. - Application. 
    An applicant for a permit required by section 32-39 shall file with the village clerk an application showing all required data, including but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Name and address of the owner, or agent in charge of the property abutting the proposed work area; 
(2)  Name and address of the party doing the work; 
(3)  Name and address of the person who prepared the plans; 
(4)  Location of the work area by township, section, town or range, or by other legal description; 
(5)  Description of work and the owner's or his agent's estimate of its cost; 
(6)  Date of application and signature of applicant; 
(7)  Attached plans showing the following information: 
a.  The scale (not less than one inch to 100 feet); 
b.  Date of plans; 
c.  North point; and 
d.  The details of the proposed construction as outlined in this article; 
(8)  Evidence of insurance coverage, conditioned to save harmless the village against all loss, damage or expense which the village might become liable for on account of an injury to persons or property arising out of the execution of the proposed work. The insurance coverage shall contain the following limits: 
a.  The liability for bodily injury to be no less than $100,000.00/$300,000.00 for each accident; and 
b.  The general property damage to be no less than $50,000.00 for each accident. 
(Code 1969, § 20.104.2; Code 1982, § 27-27) 
Sec. 32-41. - Guarantee of performance required; cash, check or bond; default. 
(a)  Required. For all work performed in accordance with a permit as required by this article where in the estimate of the superintendent of public works the cost of the work will exceed $500.00. 
(b)  Cash, check or bond. The permittee shall provide as a guarantee of performance, either cash or a certified check, in the estimated cost of the work or shall provide a maintenance and construction bond, executed by an acceptable surety company regularly doing business in the state to be filed in an amount equal to 150 percent of the estimated cost of the work and conditioned that such work shall be done in accordance with the village's standard specifications and guaranteeing the same for a period of two years. 
(c)  Default. In any case where a permittee hereunder shall be in default or shall fail to comply with the requirements of this article, the superintendent of public works shall order the completion of the work by the village and shall recover the cost from the permittee as required by law of all costs and expenses including legal fees. 
(Code 1969, § 20.104.3; Code 1982, § 27-28) 
Sec. 32-42. - Work costing more than $1,000.00; additional information required. 
    All applications for improvements or changes in or to the streets, cul-de-sacs, alleys, sidewalks or other public ways which, in the opinion of the superintendent of public works, are estimated to cost more than $1,000.00 shall include the following: 
(1)  Delineation of existing conditions: 
a.  Boundary line of the proposed improvement or change indicated by solid heavy line. 
b.  Location, widths and names of all existing or prior platted streets or other public ways, railroad and utility rights-of-way, all permanent easements for rights-of-way provided for public services or utilities, parks and other public open spaces, permanent buildings, structures and houses and section and corporation lines, within or adjacent to the improvement or change. 
c.  Existing sewers, water mains, culverts or other underground facilities within the improvement or change indicating pipe sizes, grades and exact location; radii, internal angles, points or curvature, tangent bearings and lengths of arcs. 
d.  Boundary lines of any adjacent tracts, showing owners where possible. 
e.  Contours at two-foot intervals, except where topography requires one-foot intervals. 
(2)  Delineation of proposed conditions: 
a.  Layout of streets, sidewalks, curb cuts and widths and also the widths and easements. 
b.  Building setback lines, showing dimensions. 
(Code 1969, § 20.204.1; Code 1982, § 27-29) 
Sec. 32-43. - Conditions of issuance. 
    The village clerk shall issue the permit required by this article when he finds the following: 
(1)  The plans for the proposed work have been approved by the superintendent of public works, to whom they shall be forwarded within a reasonable time after receipt thereof; 
(2)  The work shall be done according to the village standard specifications for public work of like character; 
(3)  The work will not unreasonably interfere with vehicular and pedestrian traffic, the demand and necessity for parking spaces and the means of egress to and from the property affected and adjacent properties; and 
(4)  The health, welfare and safety of the public will not be unreasonably impaired. 
(Code 1969, § 20.104.4; Code 1982, § 27-30) 
Sec. 32-44. - Temporary private use permitted for storage of building materials. 
    The superintendent of public works may issue a permit for the temporary use of streets and parkways within the limits of the building site lot line extended, for the storage of building materials, if the following can be demonstrated: 
(1)  A continuous roadway shall be maintained with a minimum width of no less than three-fourths of the total width of the roadway, nor less than 17 feet; and 
(2)  The view at street intersections shall not be obstructed. 
(Code 1969, § 20.117; Code 1982, § 27-31) 
Secs. 32-45-32-63. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Sidewalk construction and repair, 65 ILCS 5/11-84-1 et seq.; general municipal power over sidewalks, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-13. 

Sec. 32-64. - Fees. 
(a)  The permit fee for the construction or rebuilding of a sidewalk shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(b)  Any charge by the village engineer in addition to his daily rate is to be paid for by the permittee. 
(Code 1969, § 20.402; Code 1982, § 27-41; Ord. No. 628, § 27, 12-30-1980; Ord. No. 93-053, § 2, 12-21-1993; Ord. No. 00-001, § 2, 1-18-2000) 
Sec. 32-65. - Location. 
    Sidewalks shall be constructed in the street right-of-way and no more than one foot from the abutting property line. 
(Code 1969, § 20.403; Code 1982, § 27-42) 
Sec. 32-66. - Grade. 
    Sidewalks must be constructed to the grade established by the village engineer. 
(Code 1969, § 20.404.2; Code 1982, § 27-43) 
Sec. 32-67. - Width. 
    All sidewalks in the village shall be five feet in width and shall slope from the inside toward the center of the street at a rate of one-quarter inch per foot. 
(Code 1969, § 20.404.1; Code 1982, § 27-44) 
Sec. 32-68. - Base. 
    The subgrade foundation of sidewalks shall first be prepared by cutting down or filling the natural surface of the ground to the proper grade, and all spongy material or inferior vegetable matter in the subgrade shall be removed. The base shall consist of six inches of sand which shall be clean, sharp and free from all dirt, and the sand shall be thoroughly flooded and rammed. 
(Code 1969, § 20.404.3; Code 1982, § 27-45) 
Sec. 32-69. - Construction. 
(a)  All sidewalks in the village shall be constructed of Portland cement and shall be a minimum thickness of five inches; said cement shall be of a quality that will successfully pass the standard tests specified by the American Standards Association for testing materials. 
(b)  The superintendent of public works may require such standard tests to be made and certified copies of the results thereof to be furnished to him for examination. 
(c)  The proportion of the sidewalk cement shall be by volume: one part Portland cement, two parts clean sand and four parts of stone or gravel. The water used in mixing the cement shall be clean and free from oil, acid, alkalis or vegetable matter. 
(d)  Coarse aggregate for concrete in sidewalks and curbs shall conform to the requirements for coarse aggregate in Class X concrete as set forth in the standard specifications for road and bridge construction issued by the state department of transportation, division of highways, as amended. 
(e)  The stone shall be sound gravel or broken stone with a specific gravity of no less than 2.6. 
(Code 1969, § 20.404.4; Code 1982, § 27-46) 
Sec. 32-70. - Level. 
    The walk level shall be set so that the slope to the curb is one-quarter inch per linear foot, except as modified by action of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 20.404.1; Code 1982, § 27-47) 
Sec. 32-71. - Joints. 
    The transverse joints shall be made through the top every five feet, and an expansion joint one inch in thickness shall be placed at intervals of 50 feet. 
(Code 1969, § 20.404.5; Code 1982, § 27-48) 
Sec. 32-72. - Acceptance of work; superintendent's approval. 
    All work done or performed with respect to sidewalks in the village shall be subject to the approval and acceptance of the superintendent of public works or such other officer as the president and board of trustees may designate. 
(Code 1969, § 20.405; Code 1982, § 27-49) 
Sec. 32-73. - Grade elevation fee. 
    Fees for establishing sidewalk grades shall be the same as those charged under section 32-100. 
Secs. 32-74-32-92. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STREETS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 32-93. - Purpose. 
    All proposed streets shall promote the realization of the official plan and provide for the health, safety, comfort and convenience of the village residents and contiguous territory by the protection of residential, industrial and commercial properties and the separation of through and local traffic. 
(Code 1969, § 20.201; Code 1982, § 27-61) 
Sec. 32-94. - Conforming to existing street pattern and comprehensive plan. 
    All streets shall conform to the existing village street pattern or adjacent areas under its jurisdiction and shall constitute reasonable extensions of these, and shall not violate any part of the village official comprehensive plan. 
(Code 1969, § 20.202; Code 1982, § 27-62) 
Sec. 32-95. - President and board approval required; public's best interest to be demonstrated. 
    The village clerk shall issue no permits for unplatted streets until the location of a proposed street has been approved by the president and board of trustees. It shall be the duty of the owner or contractor to furnish evidence that any proposed street is in the best interest of the public. 
(Code 1969, § 20.203; Code 1982, § 27-63) 
Sec. 32-96. - Village engineer's approval also required. 
    No street construction, alteration or improvement shall be made, installed or constructed, unless and until all required plans, profiles and specifications shall have been submitted to and approved by the village engineer. 
(Code 1969, § 20.204.3; Code 1982, § 27-64) 
Sec. 32-97. - Profiles required prior to approval. 
    The president and board of trustees, prior to approving any street construction or alteration, shall require profiles showing the following information: 
(1)  Existing ground surface and proposed street grades, including extensions for a reasonable distance beyond the limits of the improvement or change; 
(2)  Typical cross sections of proposed grading; 
(3)  The preliminary plan of proposed storm sewers, if any, for street drainage, with grades and sizes indicated; and 
(4)  Such other plans, specifications and information as may reasonably be necessary. 
(Code 1969, § 20.204.2; Code 1982, § 27-65) 
Sec. 32-98. - Permit authorization. 
    The president and board of trustees may authorize the village clerk to issue a permit for street construction, alteration or improvement upon receiving the village engineer's approval that all required plans, profiles and specifications for the proposed work submitted by the applicant comply with the minimum standards of this chapter and with all other applicable provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1969, § 20.204.4; Code 1982, § 27-66) 
Sec. 32-99. - Stormwater drainage. 
(a)  A system of stormwater drainage for any proposed street shall be constructed and installed, consisting of pipes, tiles, manholes, inlets and other necessary facilities which will drain the street and protect roadway pavements. 
(b)  The design capacity shall be such that this drainage system will provide for the removal of stormwater resulting from rainfall with a rate equal to the receiving rate of each part of the system based on a rainfall with an intensity rate of two inches per hour and its concentration time equivalent. 
(c)  Materials and methods of construction shall conform to the standard specifications for road and bridge construction, adopted by the state department of transportation, division of highways. 
(Code 1969, § 20.206; Code 1982, § 27-67) 
Sec. 32-100. - Finished floor grade elevation fee. 
    In addition to any other fees charged for excavation, there will be a fee of $50.00 payable to the village engineer for establishing grade for the finished floor elevation on all construction. 
(Code 1982, § 27-68; Ord. No. 595, § 1, 3-4-1980) 
Sec. 32-101. - Lighting required.
