All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this article shall be official traffic control devices. 
(Code 1969, § 23.204; Code 1982, § 18-157) 
Sec. 38-117. - Conformity to state department of transportation regulations required. 
    All traffic control signs, signals and devices used within the village shall conform to the manual and specifications adopted by the state department of transportation, pursuant to law. 
(Code 1969, §§ 23.204, 23.301.3; Code 1982, § 18-158) 
State Law reference- State sign manual, 625 ILCS 5/11-301 and 5/11-304. 
Sec. 38-118. - Installation, operation and maintenance controlled by superintendent. 
    The superintendent of public works shall place and maintain traffic control signs, signals and devices when and as required or authorized under the village traffic ordinances, to make effective the provisions of said ordinances, and may place and maintain such additional traffic control devices as he may deem necessary to regulate traffic under the traffic ordinances of the village or state law, or to guard or warn traffic. 
(Code 1969, §§ 23.204, 23.301.2; Code 1982, § 18-159) 
Sec. 38-119. - Police chief authorized to regulate timing of signals. 
    The police chief is authorized to regulate the timing of traffic signals so as to permit the movement of traffic in an orderly and safe manner at speeds slightly at variance from the speeds otherwise applicable within the district or at intersections. 
(Code 1969, § 23.205; Code 1982, § 18-160; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-120. - Driver's duty to obey. 
    No driver of a vehicle shall disobey the instructions of any traffic control device placed in view by the authority of the president and board of trustees, or in accordance with state laws, except on the direction of a police officer or as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Code 1969, § 23.302.1; Code 1982, § 18-161) 
Sec. 38-121. - Avoidance prohibited. 
    No driver of a vehicle shall drive upon or across any private property, including, but not limited to, a private drive, automobile service station or parking lot, for the purpose of avoiding an official traffic control device. 
(Code 1969, § 23.302.2; Code 1982, § 18-162) 
Sec. 38-122. - Police officer's authority to direct traffic during congested hours and emergencies. 
    A police officer, for the purpose of relieving traffic congestion or of controlling traffic during congested hours or in the case of emergency, may undertake the control of traffic within or at an intersection at which traffic or control signals are installed. The orders and direction of such police officer shall supersede, for the period of time he is so controlling and directing traffic, the directions of such traffic control signals. 
(Code 1969, § 23.306; Code 1982, § 18-167) 
Secs. 38-123-38-141. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PARADES AND PROCESSIONS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Power of village to regulate or prohibit processions or assemblages on the highways, 625 ILCS 5/11-208. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-142. - Funeral procession; escort and flashing light required. 
    No funeral procession shall proceed upon the village streets, unless preceded and led either by a police escort or by a privately owned authorized emergency vehicle under the direction of a funeral director licensed by the village, which private vehicle shall be equipped with a flashing yellow warning light in actual operation on the front of such vehicle, during the time of leading such procession and at no other time. 
(Code 1969, §§ 23.213, 23.537; Code 1982, § 18-397) 
State Law reference- Power of village to regulate or prohibit processions or assemblages on the highways, 625 ILCS 5/11-208; funeral processions, 235 ILCS 5/11-1420. 
Secs. 38-143-38-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARADES AND OPEN AIR MEETINGS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 38-146. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Open air meeting means any congregation of citizens held outdoors and upon any public property for the purpose of hearing speakers or discussing some matter of common interest where the number of participants expected may reasonably be assumed to exceed 50. 
    Parade means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other public place in the village. 
    Parade permit means a permit as required by this division. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212-1; Code 1982, § 18-366) 
Sec. 38-147. - Exceptions. 
    This division shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Funeral processions. 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities; provided such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities. 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.2; Code 1982, § 18-367) 
Sec. 38-148. - Interference prohibited. 
    No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade or open air meeting. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.12; Code 1982, § 18-368) 
Sec. 38-149. - Police chief's authority to restrict parking along parade route. 
    The police chief shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The police chief shall post signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.12; Code 1982, § 18-369; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-150. - Unlawful to drive through parade. 
    No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.12; Code 1982, § 18-370) 
Sec. 38-151. - Limited to 500 persons; unreasonable obstruction of traffic prohibited. 
    Parades and open air meetings shall be limited to such numbers as will not obstruct traffic, either vehicular or pedestrian, in an unreasonable manner, and in any event, no such parade or open air meeting shall consist of more than 500 persons. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.5; Code 1982, § 18-381) 
Sec. 38-152. - Events to be held during nonpeak traffic hours. 
(a)  All parades shall be held during daylight hours at times other than peak traffic periods (7:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m.) and (4:30 p.m. to 6:00 p.m.) Monday through Saturday, and not before noon on Sundays. 
(b)  All open air meetings shall conclude by midnight and shall not be held before noon on Sunday. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.4; Code 1982, § 18-382) 
Secs. 38-153-38-160. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Permit 

Sec. 38-161. - Required. 
    No person shall participate in a parade or open air meeting held on any public way or on any public property, unless a written permit therefor shall first be obtained from the village. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.2; Code 1982, § 18-371) 
Sec. 38-162. - Application-Time limit. 
    An application to conduct a parade or open air meeting shall be made in writing to the village at least 72 hours prior to the event, by a representative of the group seeking the permit. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.3; Code 1982, § 18-372) 
Sec. 38-163. - Same-Contents. 
    The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade or open air meeting; 
(2)  If the parade or open air meeting is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of or by an organization the following information is required: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization; and 
b.  The name, address and telephone number of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization; 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman or chairman of the open air meeting; 
(4)  The date when the parade or open air meeting is to be conducted; 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point, the termination point and the location of speakers' platforms; 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade or open air meeting; the type of animals, and description of the vehicles; 
(7)  The hours when such parade or open air meeting will start and terminate; 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed; 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade or open air meeting; 
(10)  The time at which parade units will begin to assemble at any such assembly area; 
(11)  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade; 
(12)  If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf of, or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the police chief a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf; 
(13)  Any additional information which the police chief shall find reasonably necessary to make a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.3; Code 1982, § 18-373; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-164. - Issuance; corrected applications. 
(a)  Following the receipt of an application or reapplication, the police chief shall either, within 24 hours, issue a permit for the holding of a parade or open air meeting or reject the application. 
(b)  Permits may be rejected on the basis of improper or incomplete application, and reasons for the rejection shall be made known to the applicant, in writing, at the time of the rejection. The applicant shall be allowed to correct or complete said improper application and resubmit it to the police chief, the original 72-hour required advance notification time being still valid if a corrected application is resubmitted within 24 hours prior to the time of the event. 
(c)  If a corrected application is not received by the police chief within 24 hours prior to the time of the event, a new period of 48 hours will be imposed prior to which the event may not be held. Such 48-hour period shall commence upon receipt of the corrected application. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.6; Code 1982, § 18-374; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-165. - Multiple permits for same time and place-Precedence based on first-come-first-served; limited duration. 
(a)  First in time. If the village shall receive more than one application for a parade or open air meeting at the same time and the same place, or on the same day, the applications filed first in time shall take precedence. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    At the same time means an event is scheduled to commence within two hours before or after the holding of the other event. 
    At the same place means the requested parade route comes at any point within six blocks or any equivalent distance from the route of another parade or if the open air meeting is conducted within one-half mile of another open air meeting. 
(c)  Three-hour limit. If the village receives an application for more than one parade or open air meeting in a single day, it may set a time for the duration of each parade or open air meeting, which time shall not, without the consent of the group seeking the permit, be less than three hours. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.7; Code 1982, § 18-375) 
Sec. 38-166. - Same-Issuance; public protection considered. 
    The village shall issue permits for more than a single parade during one day, in accordance with the requirements of sections 38-170 and 38-171; provided, however, that it will not issue multiple permits beyond the point at which the issuance of an additional permit would require the continuing diversion of so great a number of police officers or other village personnel so as to prevent normal police protection or other services to the village. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.8; Code 1982, § 18-376) 
Sec. 38-167. - Contents. 
    Each permit issued under this division shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time; 
(2)  Minimum speed; 
(3)  Maximum speed; 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the parade units; 
(5)  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade; 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof; 
(7)  Such other information as the police chief shall find necessary to the enforcement of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.10; Code 1982, § 18-377; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-168. - Notice. 
    Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit, the police chief shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
(1)  The village president; 
(2)  The village attorney; 
(3)  The fire chief; 
(4)  The superintendent of public works; 
(5)  The general manager or responsible head of each public transportation utility, the regular routes of whose vehicles will be affected by the route of the proposed parade. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.9; Code 1982, § 18-378; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-169. - Compliance required. 
    A permittee under this division shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.11; Code 1982, § 18-379) 
Sec. 38-170. - Chairman shall have in his possession at all times. 
    The parade or open air meeting chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade or of the open air meeting. 
(Code 1969, § 23.212.11; Code 1982, § 18-380) 
Secs. 38-171-38-198. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Power of village to regulate the standing or parking of vehicles, 65 ILCS 5/11-208; stopping, standing and parking generally, 65 ILCS 5/11-1301 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-199. - Presumption that owner was in control. 
    It shall be presumed, prima facie, that an illegally parked automobile was under the control of its registered owner when parked. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1119; Code 1982, § 18-416) 
Sec. 38-200. - Parking sign regulations; police chief's duty to erect, install and maintain. 
    The president and board of trustees may, by ordinance, from time to time, designate areas in which parking is prohibited, or prohibited during certain hours, or limited in time, or otherwise regulated or restricted. It shall be the police chief's duty to erect or cause to be erected, installed and maintained suitable signs or markings, giving notice of such regulations and restrictions. Such designation shall be evidenced by the physical presence of such signs, legends or notices on or near the parking lane of the streets or portions thereof, where such restriction is to be effective. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any such sign or marking. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1102; Code 1982, § 18-417) 
State Law reference- Signs giving notice of parking regulations to be posted, 625 ILCS 5/11-208. 
Sec. 38-201. - Restrictions on parking in residential zones and on private property. 
(a)  Commercial vehicles; parking and storage. 
(1)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial vehicle means any vehicle used for commercial or business purposes, with or without lettering, with a gross weight of 10,000 pounds, or more, any bus or vehicle designed to transport more than nine passengers, including the driver. 
    Commercial trailer and/or construction trailer means any trailer with or without lettering, flat or enclosed, used for commercial or business purposes, represented by a "TA" or greater license plate designation. 
(2)  Parking; including overnight parking and storage. 
a.  Semitruck tractor units, with or without attached trailers and buses, as defined in subsection (a)(1) of this section, are not permitted to be stored or parked in any residential or commercial zoning district. Semitrucks and buses shall be allowed to be parked in residential or commercial zoning districts for the limited purpose of loading and unloading. 
b.  Only standard sized passenger vehicles including, but not limited to, automobiles, vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks are permitted to be stored or parked outdoors on residentially zoned property. All other commercial vehicles in excess of 10,000 pounds maximum gross weight, all commercial trailers represented by "TA" license plates or above, commercial trailers, box trucks, tow trucks, construction vehicles or trailers or other vehicles of a similar nature are not permitted to be stored or parked outside residentially zoned property or on any street, parkway or alley, adjacent thereto, unless kept in an enclosed building that complies with all village building codes, a garage, or upon a driveway, and in no event shall more than one such commercial vehicle be parked or stored on any residential lot or parcel. 
c.  Any commercial vehicle engaged in loading, unloading or engaged in current work being done on the premises adjacent to where said vehicle is located shall be exempt from the application of subsections (a)(2)a and (a)(2)b of this setion, during the time of the loading, unloading or performance of said work operations. 
(3)  Limousines. No more than one limousine shall be parked or stored on a residential lot or parcel, and then only if it is parked or stored in a driveway, garage or otherwise enclosed building or is situated on a residential zoning lot or parcel in such a manner so as not to be intrusive or encroaching on adjoining properties or to create a safety hazard and in no event shall any limousines be permitted to park or be stored upon any street, parkway or alley within the village. 
(4)  Habitation. No stored or parked vehicles shall be used or occupied for human habitation. 
(5)  Safety. No commercial vehicle shall be parked on private property in such a manner as to impair the safety of pedestrians or the access to sidewalks or vehicular traffic, including the safe entrance and exit of any vehicle from and upon adjacent properties. No commercial vehicle or equipment shall be stored or parked in a side or front yard. 
(6)  Commercial vehicles otherwise permissible. If any vehicle, even though it otherwise complies with the technical requirements of this article, is parked in such a manner as to create a legitimate safety hazard or is intrusive or encroaching upon the neighboring premises, it shall not be permitted. 
(b)  Recreational vehicles; parking and storage. 
(1)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Recreational vehicle means every camping trailer, motor home, minimotor home, travel trailer, truck, camper or van camper, and any boat, snowmobile, jet ski or personal water craft, all terrain vehicle, including trailers used to transport any such recreational vehicle and any similar vehicle used for recreational purposes. 
(2)  Parking and storage on public property. No recreational vehicle shall be parked or stored on any public street, alley, parkway or right-of-way in a district zoned for residential purposes. Exception: a recreational vehicle may be parked on the street or in a driveway in front of the home for loading and unloading purposes for a period not to exceed 48 hours. 
(3)  Parking and storage on private property. All recreational vehicles parked or stored on private property which is residentially zoned, shall be parked in either a garage or enclosed building or upon a driveway or upon a rear yard of said residential lot or parcel, not less than five feet from the rear and side lot lines. The storage of the recreational vehicle must be to the rear of the front wall of the principal dwelling. When a recreational vehicle is parked upon a driveway, it must be located behind the front wall of the principal dwelling. No recreational vehicle may be parked upon a driveway that is located in front of the front wall of the principal dwelling. Where the recreational vehicle is stored outside, the vehicle must be screened from neighboring properties by the erection of an opaque fence and/or bushes or shrubs to a height of six feet above average grade. Each dwelling unit is allowed to have one recreational vehicle. Each recreational vehicle must be owned by the property owner or tenant. 
(4)  Safety. No recreational vehicles shall be parked on private property in such a manner as to impair the safety of pedestrians or the access to sidewalks or vehicular traffic, including the safe entrance and exit of any vehicle from and upon adjacent properties. No recreational vehicle or equipment shall be stored or parked in a side or front yard. 
(5)  Habitation. No recreational vehicle shall be used for living, sleeping or housekeeping purposes in any zoning district. 
(6)  Recreational vehicles otherwise permissible. If any vehicle, even though it otherwise complies with the technical requirements of this article, is parked in such a manner as to create a legitimate safety hazard or is intrusive or encroaching upon the neighboring premises, it shall not be permitted. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1103.2; Code 1982, § 18-421; Ord. No. 82-009, § 1, 4-20-1982; Ord. No. 90-008, § 1, 6-5-1990; Ord. No. 02-003, § 1, 3-19-2002; Ord. No. 02-007, § 1, 4-16-2002; Ord. No. 14-036, § 1, 9-16-2014; Ord. No. 14-045, § 1, 12-16-2014; Ord. No. 18-007, § 2, 3-6-2018) 
Sec. 38-202. - Signs posted with times for parking. 
    No vehicle shall be parked for any period of time in excess of the time posted on the officially erected sign or legend or notice effective for the parking space for which it is erected during the effective time thereof, and no vehicle, within one hour of the time of leaving a restricted parking space, shall be again parked in any portion of either side of the same street between the immediate intersecting streets where parking is also restricted during the effective time thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1104; Code 1982, § 18-422) 
Sec. 38-203. - No parking sign along driveway; property owner responsible for costs of installation. 
    Any person owning any real estate abutting upon one of the village streets who desires to have a no parking sign installed along the driveway of such abutting property shall, after the approval of such no parking sign installation by the president and board of trustees, pay to the village clerk a fee equal to the cost of materials and installations for each no parking sign. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1122; Code 1982, § 18-428; Ord. No. 318, § 3, 2-5-1974) 
Sec. 38-204. - Moving another's vehicle unlawful; police exception. 
    No person other than a police officer shall move a vehicle into any prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful or start or cause to be started the motor of any motor vehicle, or shift, change or move the levers, brake, starting device, gears or other mechanism of a parked motor vehicle to a position other than that in which it was left by the owner or driver thereof, or attempt to do so. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1118; Code 1982, § 18-433) 
Sec. 38-205. - Loading zone restrictions. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the loading or unloading of passengers, not to exceed three minutes, and for the driver to stand any freight-carrying vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials, not to exceed 30 minutes, in any place designated by the president and board of trustees as a loading zone and marked as such, or in any of the following designated places: 
(1)  In any public alley, during any hour of the day or night; 
(2)  At any place not to exceed 75 feet along the curb before the entrance to any hospital or hotel at anytime; 
(3)  At any place not to exceed 75 feet along the curb before the entrance to a public building between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., except on Sunday; 
(4)  Directly in front of the entrance to any theater at anytime the theater is open for business; 
(5)  In any public street, alley or public way no person shall stand any freight-carrying vehicle for the purpose of transferring freight from one vehicle to another, except in case of a disabled vehicle, and then not to exceed one hour. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1110; Code 1982, § 18-434) 
Sec. 38-206. - Unlawful to leave motor running. 
    No vehicle shall be left unattended while the motor of such vehicle is running. 
(Code 1969, § 23-532; Code 1982, § 18-435) 
Sec. 38-207. - Police authority to remove unattended vehicle causing obstruction. 
    Whenever any police officer finds a vehicle unattended while the motor is running or unattended upon any street or highway, as defined in this chapter, where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic, such officer is hereby authorized to provide for the removal of such vehicle to one of the same locations as authorized in section 38-249. 
(Code 1969, § 23.532; Code 1982, § 18-436) 
Sec. 38-208. - Leaving ignition key in prohibited; police authority to remove. 
(a)  The registered owner of a vehicle found in violation of section 38-209 shall be held prima facie responsible for any such violation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave a vehicle unattended with the key in the ignition. 
(c)  Whenever any police officer shall find a motor vehicle standing unattended with the ignition key in the vehicle, in violation of this section, such police officer is authorized to remove the key from such vehicle and to deliver the key to the police officer in charge of the nearest police station. 
(Code 1969, §§ 23.533.2, 23.533.3; Code 1982, §§ 18-437-18-439) 
Sec. 38-209. - Alley parking prohibited; exceptions. 
    Within public alleys, no vehicle shall be parked at anytime, except for the purposes of loading or unloading merchandise, or of making deposits in, or withdrawals from, any state or national banking association, commonly known as a bank, which may be situated adjacent to any alley and which may have constructed facilities for the purpose of handling deposits and withdrawals made from a motor vehicle while parked in any such alley; provided, that, any such vehicle must be so parked as to leave available at least ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no such vehicle shall be stopped, parked or allowed to stand within any public alley in such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1111; Code 1982, § 18-440) 
Sec. 38-210. - Parking in designated taxicab and bus areas prohibited. 
    No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area designated by ordinance as a taxicab stand; and no vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated by ordinance as a bus loading zone. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1112; Code 1982, § 18-441) 
Sec. 38-211. - Stopping for passengers in traffic lane. 
    A private vehicle may be momentarily stopped within a traffic lane to permit a passenger to alight therefrom or to permit a passenger waiting at the curb opposite the place where such vehicle is stopped to enter or board such vehicle. Any vehicle stopped within a traffic lane for such purpose shall not be permitted to remain standing in such traffic lane after such passenger has alighted from, or has entered or boarded, such vehicle. No such vehicle shall be parked or permitted to stand within a traffic lane, while awaiting for a passenger or other occupant to return thereto, or while waiting for some person to appear who is not at the curb opposite the place where such vehicle is parked or stopped, or while waiting for some person to leave a building or to perform an errand or to transact business. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1113; Code 1982, § 18-442) 
Sec. 38-212. - Police authority to designate no parking areas adjacent to schools. 
    The police chief is hereby authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon either or both sides of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking would, in his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous condition. When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon either side of a street adjacent to any school property as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1114; Code 1982, § 18-443; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-213. - Parking vehicle on street for purpose of sale or peddling prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business street from which vehicle merchandise is peddled. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1109; Code 1982, § 18-444) 
State Law reference- Power of municipalities to regulate or prohibit peddlers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 
Sec. 38-214. - Standing vehicle on street for purpose of repairing or racing engine prohibited; exception. 
    No person shall adjust or repair any automobile or motorcycle or race the motor of same while standing on the village public streets or alleys, excepting in case of breakdown or other emergency requiring same, and no person or employee connected with a garage or repair shop shall use streets or alleys in the vicinity of such garage or shop for the purpose of working on or upon automobiles or motor-driven vehicles of any description. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1115; Code 1982, § 18-445) 
Sec. 38-215. - Unlawful to parking in private driveway without owner's consent. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stand a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading, in a private drive or driveway or on private property without the express or implied consent of the owner or person in lawful possession of such driveway or property. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1116; Code 1982, § 18-446) 
Sec. 38-216. - Leased vehicle violations; lessor's duty to provide police and court with information. 
    Every person in whose name a vehicle is registered pursuant to the motor vehicle law and who leases such vehicle to others, after receiving written notice of a violation of this article or any other parking ordinance or village regulation involving such vehicles, shall upon request provide such police officers as have authority of the offenses, and the court having jurisdiction thereof, with a written statement of the name and address of the lessee at the time of such offense and the identifying number upon the registration plates of such vehicle. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1117; Code 1982, § 18-447) 
Sec. 38-217. - Public parking lots-Time restriction. 
    No motor vehicle shall be parked on village owned, leased or controlled parking lots in excess of four consecutive hours between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
(Code 1982, § 18-448; Ord. No. 330, § 1, 4-16-1974; Ord. No. 82-033, § 1, 10-19-1982) 
Sec. 38-218. - Same-Violations. 
    Any motor vehicle parked in violation of section 38-217 shall be towed away and removed from such parking lot to the nearest available storage area. The owner of such vehicle, if the owner can be determined, shall be notified that his vehicle has been removed from a village parking lot and informed as to the place of storage of said vehicle. Upon application to the police department, said vehicle may be released upon payment to the towing operator, designated by the village board, the sum equal to the cost of towing and daily storage charges. 
(Code 1982, § 18-449; Ord. No. 330, § 1, 4-16-1974; Ord. No. 82-033, § 1, 10-19-1982) 
Sec. 38-219. - Snow removal-Restricted parking. 
    It is the responsibility of the owner, lessee, or other person having charge of a motor vehicle as defined by state law, to be aware of weather conditions creating a snow removal occurrence. A snow removal occurrence is defined as a snowfall of two or more inches of snowfall. Thus every owner, lessee, or other person having charge of any motor vehicle or trailer in the village that is parked on any street within the village corporate limits following a snowfall of two inches or more shall remove the motor vehicle or trailer at or before 8:00 a.m. as follows: 
(1)  To the even-numbered side of the street on days when snowfall occurs on even-numbered days of the month. 
(2)  To the odd-numbered side of the street on days when snowfall occurs on odd-numbered days of the month. 
(3)  Where parking is permitted on one side of the street only, that restriction will be suspended until those village streets have been cleared of snow. 
(4)  Where no parking is permitted on either side of the street, the no parking restriction shall apply. 
(5)  In the event a residence has a driveway that intersects the public street, parking shall be in the driveway so as not to obstruct the sidewalk. 
(6)  The restricted parking shall remain in effect until all of the snow has been cleared in your area. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1123.1; Code 1982, § 18-450; Ord. No. 318, § 1, 2-5-1974; Ord. No. 320, § 1, 2-19-1974; Ord. No. 565, § 1, 10-16-1979; Ord. No. 14-031, § 1, 8-5-2014) 
State Law reference- Power of village to prohibit parking during snow removal operation, 625 ILCS 5/11-208. 
Sec. 38-220. - Same-Ticket and towing. 
    The police department is authorized to remove and tow away any motor vehicle or trailer found parked on any public street in violation of section 38-219. Such tows shall be towed by an authorized commercial towing service. All towing and storage costs associated with the tow, as well as the fine associated for the violation shall be paid by the owner or operator of the towed vehicle. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1123.2; Code 1982, § 18-451; Ord. No. 318, § 2, 2-5-1974; Ord. No. 565, § 1, 10-16-1979; Ord. No. 620, § 1, 10-7-1980; Ord. No. 14-031, § 2, 8-5-2014) 
Sec. 38-221. - Same-Towing operator's designation, insurance and bond. 
(a)  The village president and board of trustees shall designate reputable, qualified towing operators to provide the towing services required under the provisions of the preceding section. Such towing operators shall carry liability insurance with an insurance company to be approved by the president and board of trustees with minimum limits as follows: 
(1)  Bodily injury liability: 
a.  For each person: $50,000.00. 
b.  For each accident: $100,000.00. 
(2)  Property damage: For each accident: $10,000.00. 
(b)  The towing operators shall carry insurance or a bond which by its provisions shall save and hold harmless the village from any acts of the towing operator causing any injury to persons or property. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1123.3; Code 1982, § 18-452; Ord. No. 565, § 1, 10-16-1979) 
Sec. 38-222. - Same-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of sections 38-219 through 38-221 shall be subject to the general penalty provisions contained in section 1-23. 
(Code 1982, § 18-453; Ord. No. 620, § 1, 10-7-1980; Ord. No. 82-011, § 2, 5-18-1982) 
Sec. 38-223. - Parking of motor vehicles in front yards and porches prohibited. 
    No person shall stand or park any motor vehicle as defined by Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 951/2, entitled Illinois Vehicle Code, on any area of residential property other than the designated driveways and parking areas. No motor vehicle shall be parked on porches, or landscaped or grass areas. No such vehicles shall be parked on parkways, unless the parkway contains a paved area of sufficient size to permit the parking of a motor vehicle or vehicles thereon. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the general penalty provisions contained in section 1-23 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 11-018, § 1, 6-21-2011) 
Sec. 38-224. - Enforcement of traffic and ordinance regulations in private parking lots. 
    Owners of private parking lots are authorized to enter into a private parking agreement with the Lansing Police Department to have the Lansing Police Department enforce traffic and ordinance regulations in the private lots pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-209. The form of the agreement shall be as stated in 625 ILCS 5/11-209. The owner of the parking lot shall be required to pay a fee of $75.00 to the Village of Lansing for the village's cost and expense in having the agreement recorded with the Cook County Recorder of Deeds. 
(Ord. No. 14-041, § 1, 12-16-2014) 
Secs. 38-225-38-241. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ABANDONMENT 

Sec. 38-242. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Police chief means the police chief of the village or his authorized representative. 
    Property means any real property within the village or any village property within or without the corporate limits which is not a street or highway. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1120.1; Code 1982, § 18-461; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-243. - Prohibited. 
    No person shall abandon any vehicle within the village or on village property within or without the corporate limits, and no person shall leave any vehicle at any place within the village or on village property within or without the corporate limits for such time and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle reasonably to appear to have been abandoned. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1120.2; Code 1982, § 18-462) 
Sec. 38-244. - Nonoperating vehicle-Abandonment prohibited; village authority to dump. 
    No person shall leave any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked or junked vehicle on any street or highway within the village or on village property within or without the corporate limits; provided, such vehicle may be left at a place authorized by the village for the dumping and disposal of garbage and rubbish in accordance with the ordinances of the village and the rules and regulations governing such dumping ground. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1120.3; Code 1982, § 18-463) 
Sec. 38-245. - Same-Time restrictions; exceptions. 
    No person in charge of or control of any property other than village property within the village, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or otherwise, shall allow any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked, junked or discarded vehicle to remain on such property longer than ten days, and no person shall leave any such vehicle on any property other than village property within the village longer than ten days or on village property within or without the corporate limits for a longer time than 48 hours; except that this section shall not apply to the following vehicles: 
(1)  In an enclosed building; 
(2)  On the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner, when necessary to the lawful operation of such business enterprise; 
(3)  A historic vehicle over 25 years of age; or 
(4)  In an appropriate storage place or depositary maintained in a lawful place and manner by the village. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1120.4; Code 1982, § 18-464) 
Sec. 38-246. - Parking on private property. 
(a)  Without owner's consent prohibited. No person shall drive, stop, stand or park a vehicle onto or upon privately owned property, or an area developed as an off-street parking facility, without the consent of the owner, lessee or a person in charge of such privately owned property or facility. 
(b)  Violation. A violation of subsection (a) of this section shall place the vehicle involved in the status of an illegally-parked vehicle and upon complaint of the owner, lessee or person in charge of the privately owned property or facility, said vehicle may be dealt with as described in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Police authority to remove. The police chief is hereby authorized to remove or have removed any vehicle left at any place within the village or on any village property within or without the corporate limits which reasonably appears to be in violation of this section or which reasonably appears to be lost, stolen or unclaimed. 
(d)  Impoundment; notice. A vehicle described in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall be impounded in one of the garages of the village, or in a privately owned garage as designated by the police chief, until lawfully claimed or disposed of; provided, that, any vehicle left at any place, other than on village property or on private property without consent, shall not be removed and impounded as provided herein until the police chief shall have given written notice to remove said vehicle within 72 hours of the mailing of such notice and of the intention of the police chief to remove and impound such vehicle if it has not been removed at the end of such time. Such notice shall be given by: 
(1)  Affixing notice on such vehicle; 
(2)  Sending notice by mail to the owner of such vehicle, at his last known address if the owner is reasonably ascertainable; and 
(3)  By sending notice by mail to the person owning or controlling the property on which such vehicle is located. 
(e)  Right of entry. The police chief may enter upon private property at all reasonable hours for the purpose of inspecting a vehicle, posting notice thereon and removing and impounding such vehicle under this section, and it shall be unlawful for any person to prevent the police chief from entering on private property for purposes of carrying out his duties hereunder or to interfere with him in the lawful performance of his duties under the provisions of this section. 
(f)  Multiple violations; vehicle impounded; owner arrested. Any motor vehicle found upon the streets or highways of the village, having charged against the state license registration number of said vehicle an accumulation of four or more offenses, may be removed for impoundment in the manner described in this section. Should the owner of said vehicle appear to claim same, he will be booked for appearance in the circuit court of the county on all outstanding offenses. 
(Code 1969, §§ 23.1120.6-23.1120.8; Code 1982, §§ 18-465-18-470; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-247. - Semi-tractor and trailers prohibited regulations for parking in limited manufacturing districts. 
    Semi-tractors and trailers shall be allowed to park in limited manufacturing districts provided that the parking space is a bituminous surface, the owner of the property allows the semi-tractor/trailer to be parked on his/her property, the parking does not hinder access to emergency vehicles and the owner of the semi-tractor and trailer secures a permit from the village clerk. 
    A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to $750.00 per occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 14-045, § 2, 12-16-2014) 
Secs. 38-248-38-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MOTORCYCLES AND MOTOR-DRIVEN CYCLES 

Sec. 38-271. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Area means the geographical boundaries within which an operating motorcycle or operating motor-driven cycle can be heard. 
    Motor-driven cycle means every motorcycle and every motor scooter with less than 150 cubic centimeter piston displacement, including motorized pedalcycles (moped). 
    Motor vehicle or vehicle means a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle. 
    Nonresident means every person who is not a resident of the state. 
    Nonresident's operating privilege means the privilege conferred upon a nonresident by state laws pertaining to the operation by such person of a motor vehicle, or the use of a vehicle owned by such person, in the state. 
    Operator means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a motor vehicle upon a street or who is exercising control of or steering a vehicle being towed by a motor vehicle. 
    Racing of motor means the sudden acceleration or deceleration of the motor of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle. 
    Safety helmet. 
(1)  The term "safety helmet" means protective headgear designated for wear by riders and occupants of vehicles for the purpose of mitigating the effects of a blow on the head. The term "safety helmet" includes motorcycle and motorcycle crash helmets designed in accordance with the specifications contained in this article, or in accordance with specifications of equal quality. 
(2)  The term "safety helmet" does not include the following items: 
a.  Construction hard hats; 
b.  Baseball, football or other athletic headgear; or 
c.  Other helmets designed for a purpose other than protective headgear for riders and occupants of vehicles. 
    Stunting means operating a vehicle in a manner causing it to weave or suddenly change course, or the loss of body contact with the seat by a driver or passenger, and not for the purpose of safe operation of such vehicle. 
    Touring means any repetitious driving in the same area which causes a disturbance or is done with the intent of calling attention to an operator of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1001; Code 1982, § 18-501) 
State Law reference- Motor-driven cycle defined, 625 ILCS 5/1-148. 
Sec. 38-272. - Police authority to inspect. 
    Any member of the police department is authorized to inspect any motorcycle, at any reasonable time, for the purpose of making a checkup for the license plate and license number, serial number and for the purpose of determining the mechanical condition of the motorcycle. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1007; Code 1982, § 18-503) 
Sec. 38-273. - Removal of serial number or license plate prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, willfully or maliciously, to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the serial number of any motorcycle licensed under this article; or to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any license plate or registration card during the time in which the license plate or registration card is in force. The police chief is hereby authorized to stamp numbers on the frame of a motorcycle in a legible manner for identification purposes, upon which no serial number can be found, or upon which the serial number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1008; Code 1982, § 18-506; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-274. - Unlawful to purchase, trade, etc., any motor-driven cycle with the serial number altered without first reporting to the police chief. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person residing in the village, or any dealer in motorcycles or motor-driven cycles operating in the village, to purchase, receive in trade, or otherwise acquire any motorcycle or motor-driven cycle from which the serial number on the frame has been removed, destroyed, mutilated or altered, without first reporting the same to the police chief. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1010; Code 1982, § 18-507; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-275. - Mudguards or fenders required. 
    Each motorcycle shall be equipped with mudguards or fenders which will reduce effectively the wheel spray or splash of water from the roadway to the rear. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1003.2; Code 1982, § 18-515) 
Sec. 38-276. - Manner of operation. 
(a)  All motorcycles, motor scooters and motorbikes, when operated on the village streets, shall proceed in single file and in the center of the driving lane in which they are driving, except that on four-lane traffic ways within the village, no more than two vehicles shall drive side by side and will at all times remain in the single lane, and at all times said operators shall drive said vehicle in the same direction as all other motorized traffic. 
(b)  The provisions of this section will not preclude the possibility of one vehicle overtaking and passing another, but is intended to prevent the operation of two or more vehicles in an abreast fashion on the village streets. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1004.4; Code 1982, § 18-520) 
State Law reference- Driving on roadways laned for traffic, 625 ILCS 5/11-709. 
Sec. 38-277. - Designated quiet zones. 
    Touring, stunting or racing of motors is prohibited in any hospital or nursing home area, and in residential areas. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1004-7; Code 1982, § 18-524) 
Sec. 38-278. - Reckless driving prohibited. 
    No operator of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall engage in maneuvers, stunting or other operations dangerous to himself or his passenger or to the persons or property of others, except when done for the better control of a vehicle, in emergencies or to maneuver rough passages of a street, an operator must at all times keep body contact with the saddle or seat of such vehicle. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1004.8; Code 1982, § 18-525) 
State Law reference- Reckless driving, 625 ILCS 5/11-503. 
Sec. 38-279. - Disturbances prohibited. 
    No motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall be operated in any manner so as to cause a disturbance in any village area. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1004.7; Code 1982, § 18-526) 
Secs. 38-280-38-298. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - BICYCLES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Power of village to regulate the operation of bicycles and to require their registration and licensing and a registration fee, 625 ILCS 5/11-208; bicycles generally, 625 ILCS 5/11-1501 et seq. 

Sec. 38-299. - Penalty. 
    Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be punished by the general penalty provisions contained in section 1-23. 
(Code 1969, § 23.819; Code 1982, § 18-556; Ord. No. 300, § 1, 10-2-1973) 
Sec. 38-300. - Safety equipment required. 
    Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will adequately control movement of and stop and hold such bicycle, and such other safety equipment as is required to meet the standards specified by the police chief. 
(Code 1969, § 23.813; Code 1982, § 18-559; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
State Law reference- Bicycle equipment, 625 ILCS 5/11-1507) 
Sec. 38-301. - Riding prohibited where signs indicate. 
    The police chief is authorized to erect signs on any sidewalk or roadway prohibiting the riding of bicycles thereon by any person, and when such signs are in place, no person shall disobey the same. 
(Code 1969, § 23.806.2; Code 1982, § 18-573; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-302. - Must use hand signals for turning. 
    Bicycle operators shall signify their intentions of turning by using the same hand signals specified for operators of motor vehicles. 
(Code 1969, § 23.804; Code 1982, § 18-582) 
Sec. 38-303. - Riding on sidewalk-Pedestrians have right-of-way. 
    Pedestrians shall have the right-of-way, at all times, over bicycles, and a person riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk or sidewalk crossing shall either turn off the sidewalk when meeting or passing pedestrians or shall dismount until the pedestrians have passed. 
(Code 1969, § 23.806.3; Code 1982, § 18-583) 
Sec. 38-304. - Same-Prohibited in business district and where heavy pedestrian traffic present. 
    No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district, or on any other sidewalk where and when there is heavy pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1969, § 23.806.1; Code 1982, § 18-584) 
Sec. 38-305. - Parking requirements. 
    No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a supporting rack or against a building, except glass sections, in such manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. Parking racks must be used when provided. 
(Code 1969, § 23.811; Code 1982, § 18-588) 
Sec. 38-306. - Parental responsibility for compliance with article provisions. 
    The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any provisions of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 18-589; Ord. No. 273, § 3, 1-9-1972; Ord. No. 276, § 3, 2-6-1973) 
Secs. 38-307-38-325. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SNOWMOBILES 

Sec. 38-326. - Operation within village limits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a snowmobile on the following areas: 
(1)  Publicly owned or leased property; 
(2)  Owned or leased public school district property; 
(3)  Any roadway, parkway, highway, street, alley, sidewalk; or 
(4)  Any other type of public thoroughfare within the village jurisdictional boundaries. 
(Code 1982, § 18-631; Ord. No. 631, § 2(23.1400), 1-20-1981) 
Sec. 38-327. - Enforcement and arrest. 
    It is the duty of all village police officers to arrest or cause the arrest of any person detected in violation of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 18-632; Ord. No. 631, § 2(23.1401), 1-20-1981) 
Sec. 38-328. - Police authority to stop and inspect. 
(a)  Any authorized police officer shall stop and inspect any snowmobile in order that he may determine if a violation exists in its operation. 
(b)  Inspection shall be made of all snowmobiles operating within the village corporate limits. 
(Code 1982, § 18-633; Ord. No. 631, § 2(23.1402), 1-20-1981) 
Sec. 38-329. - Operation on private property; owner's/lessee's permission required. 
    The operation of snowmobiles will be permitted on private property; provided the operator of the snowmobile has written permission from the owner or lessee of the land on which the operation is being conducted. 
(Code 1982, § 18-634; Ord. No. 631, § 2(23.1403), 1-20-1981) 
Sec. 38-330. - Operational permit required; contents. 
    The operator of a snowmobile must produce a permit on the demand of an investigating officer which shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name of the operator; 
(2)  Name of the landowner or lessee; 
(3)  Date approved by the landowner or lessee on which to operate a snowmobile; and 
(4)  General description of the property on which the snowmobile operation may be conducted. 
(Code 1982, § 18-635; Ord. No. 631, § 2(23.1404), 1-20-1981) 
Sec. 38-331. - Nuisance violation. 
    It shall be the police department's duty to respond to any calls of snowmobile operation on private property. The investigating officer will determine if the operation of the snowmobile disrupts the normal serenity and calmness of the area involved and, if a violation is found, the violator will be charged with creating a nuisance. 
(Code 1982, § 18-636; Ord. No. 631, § 2(23.1405), 1-20-1981) 
Sec. 38-332. - Exceptions; use by village departments. 
(a)  Police department/fire department. The operation of a snowmobile within the village limits shall be allowed by the police department and fire department in the normal execution of their duty. 
(b)  Emergency. In extreme emergencies the police chief may allow the operation of other snowmobiles as the situation warrants and subject to the rules established by the police chief. 
(Code 1982, § 18-637; Ord. No. 631, § 2(23.1406), 1-20-1981; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-333. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction of such violations, be subject to the general penalty provisions contained in section 1-23. 
(Code 1982, § 18-638; Ord. No. 631, § 2(23.1407), 1-20-1981) 
Secs. 38-334-38-352. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - TOWING 

Sec. 38-353. - Applicability. 
    This article shall apply only to towing arising from violations that are not subject to administrative adjudication pursuant to article XIII of this chapter. 
Sec. 38-354. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Any term not defined herein shall have the meaning ascribed to it in the other ordinances of this municipality, and if not defined in any other municipal ordinances, it shall have the meaning ascribed in the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq. 
    Abandoned vehicle means: 
(1)  A vehicle parked or otherwise located on the public way and: 
a.  Is in such a state of disrepair that it is incapable of being driven; or 
b.  Has been unmoved for a period of at least 24 hours and from its condition, the period during which it has not been moved or some other circumstance appears to have been, and will be presumed to have been, abandoned by its owner; or 
(2)  Vehicles parked in a public parking lot or on private property without the consent of the lot owner, proprietor or agent of the property, which person has requested that the vehicle be towed; or 
(3)  A vehicle defined as abandoned under subsections (1) and (2) of this section, or capable of being towed, by any other municipal ordinance, and which does not fall into the categories of hazardous or unlawful vehicles, and therefore is not subject to an immediate tow. 
    Hazardous vehicle means: 
(1)  A vehicle that has been involved in an accident and is disabled or cannot be immediately moved by the owner or operator of the vehicle; 
(2)  A vehicle that presents an immediate danger to the health or welfare of members of the public; 
(3)  A vehicle abandoned or disabled on a public street, way or alley that is impeding the orderly flow of traffic or poses a potential danger to pedestrians and other operators of vehicles; or 
(4)  A vehicle that must be moved to allow for proper municipal snow removal from a public street, way or alley. 
    Owner means a person who holds legal title to the vehicle, or the right of possession of the vehicle. 
    Unlawful vehicle means: 
(1)  A vehicle that has been reported stolen or is the subject of a search and seizure by the police department; or 
(2)  A vehicle parked in violation of state statutes or municipal ordinances which prohibit parking at the location in question or for the period of time for which the vehicle has been parked, and where either the statute or ordinance authorizing the vehicle to be towed and signs to be posted as to the general location note that fact. 
    Vehicle. 
(1)  The term "vehicle" means any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street, highway or any public way. 
(2)  The term "vehicle" does not include the following: 
a.  Devices moved by human power; 
b.  Devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks; and 
c.  Snowmobiles. 
(Code 1982, § 18-642; Ord. No. 85-014, § 2, 5-21-1985) 
Sec. 38-355. - Authorization. 
    The towing of vehicles by the municipality or by its approved towing service operators on the municipality's behalf shall be authorized only by the police department and only under the circumstances herein provided. Towed vehicles shall be impounded at facilities designated by the police department until lawfully claimed or disposed of pursuant to state law. 
(1)  Towing without notice; immediate tows. Hazardous or unlawful vehicles may be towed without prior notice, except that, when an unlawful vehicle is also one that has been reported as stolen or is not towable for some other specific reason, the owner should be, when practicable, notified by telephone or other means and given the opportunity to claim or move the vehicle, if he so wishes, to avoid incurring the expenses of a police-ordered tow. Provided, however, that the vehicle may be towed if the owner permitted the tow to be made when the vehicle was reported stolen or at any time thereafter, in the form provided in section 38-359. Within 24 hours after towing a vehicle pursuant to this article, a notice shall be sent to or personally delivered to the owner of the vehicle affording the opportunity for a hearing as provided in sections 38-356 and 38-358. 
(2)  Towing with prior notice; abandoned vehicles. Abandoned vehicles may be towed after the mailing or delivery of prior notice and the affording of an opportunity for a hearing as provided in subsection (1) of this section and section 38-356. 
(Code 1982, § 18-643; Ord. No. 85-014, § 3, 5-21-1985) 
Sec. 38-356. - Pre-tow notice for abandoned vehicles. 
(a)  Notice pursuant to this section shall be personally delivered to the owner or shall be forwarded by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the owner of the vehicle as indicated in the most current registration list of the secretary of state. The notice shall be in the form provided in section 38-359. 
(b)  In the event that an out-of-state vehicle is proposed to be towed, inquiry by computer, telephone or letter shall be made of the secretary of state of the particular jurisdiction for the furnishing of the most current registered name and address of the vehicle's owner, and notice shall be mailed as provided herein to the address furnished, though in no case will the municipality be required to delay towing more than seven days after the date of the mailing or personal delivery of the notice if no request for a hearing has been received within that seven-day period. 
(c)  A notice of intent to tow sticker with the earliest date upon which the tow may take place and the address and phone number of the police department shall be placed on the vehicle. 
(Code 1982, § 18-644; Ord. No. 85-014, § 4, 5-21-1985) 
Sec. 38-357. - Pre-tow hearing procedures. 
(a)  Opportunity for hearing. The owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle to be towed as an abandoned vehicle shall have seven days after the date of mailing or personal delivery of the notice to request, in writing, a pre-tow hearing. Subsequent to this seven-day period, the vehicle may be towed, if the owner has not filed a written hearing request within the seven-day period, and any hearing rights under the provisions of this article will be deemed waived. 
(b)  Scheduling. The pre-tow hearing shall be scheduled for a date within 14 days of the mailing or personal delivery of the pretow notice. The municipality shall not be required to delay towing longer than such a 14-day period. 
(c)  Request for hearing. Requests for a pre-tow hearing are to be made in person to the office indicated on the notice. Requests for hearing by persons who reside more than 50 miles from the municipality may be made by mail. Forms for such requests shall be made available at the police department. At the time of making the request, the owner will be provided a hearing date and time by mail or in person, as the circumstances require. 
(d)  Hearing officer appointed. The municipality shall choose an officer or employee of the municipality to serve as hearing officer. In no case shall that hearing officer be an individual who was involved in the initial decision to tow the vehicle. The hearing officer shall have the authority to require the presence of the enforcement officer who initiated the proposed tow or any other municipal personnel. 
(e)  Nature of hearing; preponderance of the evidence standard used. The hearing shall be informal in nature, and the rules of evidence shall not apply. The hearing will not be determinative of, or adjudicate, any citation relative to any vehicle. After receiving all relevant evidence, the hearing officer shall make a written decision based upon a preponderance of the evidence as to whether towing the vehicle is authorized by state laws or municipal ordinances, with a specific statutory or ordinance section cited in the decision. The owner shall be provided a copy of such pre-tow hearing decision. 
(f)  Decision to remove; fees. If the preponderance of the evidence supports towing and compliance with the provisions of this article, the hearing officer shall direct that the vehicle be towed, with any towing and storage costs to then be imposed upon the owner thereof. The fees to be charged for towing and storage services shall be no more than the maximum rates set by the police chief, pursuant to the provisions of this section. The owner of said vehicle having had such a hearing may avoid the towing by immediately removing the vehicle from the improper location to a proper, lawful location and correcting any unlawful condition of the vehicle. 
(g)  Decision not to remove. If the preponderance of the evidence fails to support towing of the vehicle, the hearing officer shall direct that the vehicle shall not be towed. The municipality shall furnish a copy of such decision to the owner, who may place it inside the vehicle in a location plainly visible from the outside, such as the dashboard or rear window. No vehicle about which such a decision has been rendered shall be towed by the municipality, unless the circumstances under which the decision was rendered have changed. If at some subsequent time the municipality should wish to tow the vehicle from the same location, it shall follow the same procedures required for the towing of any other similarly situated vehicle. 
(h)  Reports and documents to be retained; appeal. Originals or copies of all notices, pre-tow hearing decisions, towing reports, and any associated police reports or documents shall be retained by the police department for a period of at least five years after each hearing, or after each tow if no hearing was requested or held. The municipality or the owner may contest the decision of the hearing officer in any manner provided by law. 
(Code 1982, § 18-645; Ord. No. 85-014, § 5, 5-21-1985; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-358. - Post-tow notice for hazardous and unlawful vehicles. 
(a)  Mailing or delivery of notice. Notice pursuant to this section shall be forwarded by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the owner of the vehicle as indicated in the most current registration list of the secretary of state, unless the notice is personally delivered to the owner, in which case, the date and time of the delivery and the name of the police officer making the delivery shall be noted in the police department records or reports. The notice shall be in the form provided for in sections 38-359, and shall be mailed or delivered within 24 hours of the tow, as provided in section 38-355(1). In the event that the municipality has towed an out-of state hazardous or unlawful vehicle, inquiry by computer, telephone or letter shall be made of the secretary of state of the particular jurisdiction for the furnishing of the most current registered name and address of the owner of the vehicle, and notice shall be mailed as provided herein to the address furnished. 
(b)  Posting of signs showing hearing rights. All approved towing service operators shall prominently post at least one sign, with dimensions of at least 12 inches by 18 inches, indicating the opportunity and procedures for a hearing to contest the validity of a towed vehicle. The sign, the form for which is referenced in section 38-359, shall be placed in locations readily visible to the public transacting business at any towing facility. If a towing service operator performs services for more than one municipality, the information for contacting the various appropriate municipal offices can be listed in one such sign, the format for which shall be substantially similar to the form referenced in section 38-359. 
(c)  Requests for post-tow hearings. Requests for hearing may be made in person at the office indicated on the notice within 15 days of the mailing or personal delivery of the notification of tow, or release of the vehicle, whichever occurs first; otherwise, the right to a hearing shall be deemed waived. Requests for hearings by persons who reside more than 50 miles from the municipality may be made in person or by mail received by the municipality with the 15-day period. 
(d)  Releasing vehicles. Before the owner or person entitled to possession of any impounded vehicle shall be permitted to remove same, the owner or other person entitled to possession shall furnish evidence of his identity, ownership of the vehicle, or his right to possession, sign a receipt for the vehicle, and pay the amount currently owed for towing and storage fees to the towing service operator. The police chief is authorized to promulgate regulations as to the documents or other proof necessary to establish these facts. 
(e)  Establishment of maximum towing and storage rates. 
(1)  The owner shall pay fees to the towing service operator for towing and storage on police-ordered tows at rates that do not exceed maximum amounts to be administratively established by the police chief and which may be revised from time to time. The basic rates for such fees shall be shown in the form and sign concerning vehicle release requirements set forth in section 38-359. However, nothing in this article is intended to prevent a competitive towing service operator from charging less than the established maximum rates for police-ordered or any other tows. 
(2)  In arriving at the maximum rates for various services, the police chief shall consider such matters as the prevalent market rates in the area for the different types of vehicles, the types of storage and area requirements for categories such as large trucks and commercial vehicles, and the relative difficulties and amount of work required to perform various types of towing operations. 
(3)  For particularly difficult or unusual towing jobs, such as large or serious accidents, the police chief is authorized to allow towing operators to charge rates above those established for normal situations, which special charges must be based upon the cost of service provided, taking into account such matters as the man-hours and equipment time required for the job. 
(4)  A towing service operator must fully itemize in writing the details of such a billing at special rates for a particularly difficult or unusual tow, and supply a copy of the itemized bill to the owner and to the police department. Any such special rates charged must be customary in the towing industry in the area for the nature and extent of the services provided. Every towing service operator and the police department shall have available a copy of the complete current rate schedule and any special rate policy established by the police chief, for vehicle owners to view upon request. 
(Code 1982, § 18-646; Ord. No. 85-014, § 6, 5-21-1985; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 38-359. - Board's authority to establish and amend the forms used for post-tow notice, signs and reports. 
    The wording for notice signs and forms for a pre-tow notice, post-tow incident report, permission to tow stolen vehicle as established and amended from time to time by the village board, are available from the village police department. 
Secs. 38-360-38-379. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - TRANSPORTATION OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS 

Sec. 38-380. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish hazardous material transportation routes within the village which will enable those who transport hazardous materials to and from locations within the village to do so in compliance with federal requirements, as they may from time to time be amended, which are hereby incorporated herein as if enacted by the village president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 18-701; Ord. No. 88-011, § 1, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-381. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Discharge means leakage, seepage, or other release. 
    Hazardous materials means a substance or material in a quantity and form which has been determined by the U.S. Department of Transportation to be capable of posing an unreasonable risk to health, safety or property when transported in commerce. 
    Hazardous materials access route means any street which has been designated pursuant to this article for the purpose of providing vehicular access from the primary hazardous material route to locations within the village where hazardous materials are used, produced, or stored. 
    Hazardous materials placard means the placard which a motor vehicle transporting hazardous materials is required to display under regulations enacted by either the United States Department of Transportation or state department of transportation pursuant to the Hazardous Materials Transportation Act, 49 USC 1801 et seq. 
    Primary hazardous materials route means when signs are posted giving notice thereof, the system of streets composed of the following: 
Street From/To Torrence Avenue Through village I-80, I-94 Through village  
    Toxic substance means any substance, mixture, or compound containing a substance which is listed in: 
(1)  The Code of Federal Regulations, 29 CFR 1910.1000 through 29 CFR 1910.1500, inclusive. 
(2)  The Uniform Hazardous Substances Act, 430 ILCS 35/1 et seq. 
(3)  The United States Department of Health and Human Services, Public Health Service National Toxicology Program, Second Annual Report on Carcinogens-December 1981, and its periodic updates. 
(4)  A list of toxic substances promulgated by the director of the state department of labor, pursuant to 430 ILCS 35/15a. 
(Code 1982, § 18-702; Ord. No. 88-011, § 2, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-382. - Operator required to know route. 
(a)  Every person who uses, produces, or stores hazardous materials at a location within the village, shall request from the fire department a hazardous materials access route to and from such location. 
(b)  Every motor vehicle which displays or is required to display a hazardous materials placard, shall be operated within the village only on the primary hazardous material route or upon a hazardous material access route established pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Every operator of a motor vehicle which displays or is required to display a hazardous material placard, who does not know the village's primary hazardous material route or the hazardous material access route to and from the location in the village from which he is coming or to which he is destined, shall request directions concerning said routes from the village fire department, before operating said vehicle in the village. 
(d)  No motor vehicle which displays or is required to display a hazardous material placard shall be operated on any street within the village other than I-80 and I-94, unless such vehicle is coming from or destined for a location within the village. 
(Code 1982, § 18-703; Ord. No. 88-011, § 3, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-383. - Exceptions. 
    The following types of vehicles are exempt from the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Placarded vehicles making residential deliveries of home heating fuel. 
(2)  Placarded vehicles making residential deliveries of medical supplies. 
(3)  For purposes of picking up or delivering nonhazardous materials at a location within the village which is not required under the provisions of this article to request a hazardous materials access route, placarded vehicle may use the most direct route to and close as possible to said location on the primary hazardous materials transportation route or a hazardous materials access route assigned to a business in the vicinity of said location. 
(Code 1982, § 18-704; Ord. No. 88-011, § 4, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-384. - Procedure for assigning hazardous materials access route. 
    Any person who uses, produces, or stores hazardous materials at a location within the village shall be assigned a hazardous materials transportation route after he had submitted a request for such a report to the village fire department on a form provided by the fire department. Upon receipt of such a request, the fire department shall assign to such person, a route which in the judgment of the fire department and all other interested departments, is consistent with and implements the purpose of this article. Said route shall be valid for a period as specified by the fire department and may be changed or amended by the fire department with notice. If there is any change in the frequency or materials being transported, a new request for a route must be submitted. 
(Code 1982, § 18-705; Ord. No. 88-011, § 5, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-385. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article shall upon conviction be subject to the general penalty provisions contained in section 1-23. 
(Code 1982, § 18-706; Ord. No. 88-011, § 6, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-386. - Actual or threatened discharge of hazardous materials-Declared nuisance. 
    The actual or threatened discharge of hazardous materials within the village is hereby declared a nuisance. 
(Code 1982, § 18-707; Ord. No. 88-011, § 7, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-387. - Same-Owner, lessee, etc., liable for abatement costs. 
    Any person who owns, leases, operates or controls any facility, equipment, or vehicles from which a discharge of hazardous materials has occurred or is threatened to occur, shall be liable to the village for any expenses incurred by the village in connection with preventing, cleaning up, or disposing of or attempting to prevent, clean up, or dispose of any such discharge or threatened discharge. 
(Code 1982, § 18-708; Ord. No. 88-011, § 8, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-388. - Compliance with state and federal regulations for disposal. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of hazardous materials within the village, unless such disposal is conducted in accordance with applicable state and federal rules and regulations pertaining to the disposal of such materials. 
(Code 1982, § 18-709; Ord. No. 88-011, § 9, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-389. - Unlawful disposal of hazardous materials-Declared nuisance. 
    The unlawful disposal of hazardous materials within the village is hereby declared a nuisance. 
(Code 1982, § 18-710; Ord. No. 88-011, § 10, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-390. - Same-Violator liable for abatement costs. 
    Any person who engages in the unlawful disposal of hazardous materials shall be liable to the village for any and all expenses incurred by the village in connection with cleaning up and lawfully disposing of said materials. 
(Code 1982, § 18-711; Ord. No. 88-011, § 11, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-391. - Same-Penalty. 
    In addition to the liability imposed by section 38-390, any person who unlawfully disposes of hazardous materials within the village shall upon conviction, be subject to the general penalty provisions of section 1-23. 
(Code 1982, § 18-712; Ord. No. 88-011, § 12, 6-7-1988) 
Sec. 38-392. - Disclosure requirements.
