The owner shall report the results of measurements and laboratory analyses to the village and MWRDGC at such times and in such manner as prescribed by the village. The owner shall bear the expense of all measurements, analyses, and reporting required by the village and/or MWRDGC. At such times as deemed necessary, the village and/or MWRDGC reserve the right to take measurements and samples for analysis by an outside laboratory service. 
(j)  All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of the "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. (The particular analyses involved will determine whether a 24-hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from 24-hour composites of all outfalls, whereas pH's are determined from periodic grab samples.) 
(k)  No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the village, MWRDGC, and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the village for transmission, and MWRDGC for treatment, subject to payment therefor, in accordance with section 40-148 hereof, by the industrial concern; provided such payments are in accordance with federal and state guidelines for user charge system. 
(Code 1982, § 30-84; Ord. No. 86-017, § 2-4, 7-1-1986; Ord. No. 07-017, § 1, 5-15-2007) 
Sec. 40-125. - Malicious, willful or negligent damage to sewerage works prohibited. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break damage, destroy, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the sewerage works. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct. 
(Code 1982, § 30-85; Ord. No. 86-017, § 2-5, 7-1-1986) 
Sec. 40-126. - Inspections. 
(a)  Duly authorized village employees, the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago, the state environmental protection agency, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, bearing proper credentials and identification, may request permission to enter all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. Said representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper or other industries, beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterway or facilities for waste treatment. 
(b)  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the duly authorized village employees, the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago, the state environmental protection agency, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company and the company shall be held harmless for the injury or death the village employees and the village shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation. 
(c)  Duly authorized village employees bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties in which the village holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewerage works lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly-negotiated easement pertaining to the property involved. 
(Code 1982, § 30-86; Ord. No. 86-017, § 2-6, 7-1-1986) 
Sec. 40-127. - Penalty; notice. 
(a)  Any person found in violation of any provision of this article, except section 40-125, shall be served by the village with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. The village may revoke any permit for sewage disposal as a result of any violation of any provision of this article. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof, shall be subject to the general penalty provisions of section 1-23. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the village by reason of such violation. 
(Code 1982, § 30-87; Ord. No. 86-017, § 2-7, 7-1-1986) 
Sec. 40-128. - Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago ordinances adopted by reference. 
    The village is located within the boundaries of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago (MWRDGC). The Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago, therefore, has jurisdiction over certain activities within the village that relate to construction, operation and maintenance of sanitary and stormwater infrastructure elements. This jurisdiction requires parties within the village to comply with MWRDGC ordinances, including the "Sewer Permit Ordinance," "Manual of Procedures for the Administration of the Sewer Permit Ordinance," and "Sewage and Waste Control Ordinance." Therefore, the most current editions of the aforesaid ordinances or any other applicable MWRDGC ordinances are hereby adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-017, § 2, 5-15-2007) 
Secs. 40-129-40-147. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - USER CHARGES 

Sec. 40-148. - Wastewater service. 
(a)  Basis for charges. The wastewater service charge for the use of and for service supplied by the village wastewater collection system shall consist of a user charge for operation and maintenance, plus replacement and a capital outlay charge. The basic user charge shall be based on water usage as recorded by water meters. It shall consist of operation and maintenance costs, plus replacement and shall be computed as follows: 
(1)  Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and maintain the wastewater collection system, including a replacement fund for the year, for all works categories. Compute a basic user rate per 1,000 gallons of billable flow. 
(2)  The adequacy of the wastewater service charge shall be reviewed annually by certified public accountants for the village in their annual audit report. The wastewater service charge shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in debt service or a change in operation and maintenance costs, including replacement costs. 
(b)  Measurement of flow. The volume of flow used for computing basic user charges shall be the metered water consumption read to the lowest even increments of 100 gallons. 
(1)  If the person discharging wastes into the public sewers procures any part, or all, of his water from sources other than the public waterworks system, all or a part of which is discharged into the public sewers, the person shall install and maintain, at his expense, water meters of a type approved by the village for the purpose of determining the volume of water obtained from these other sources. 
(2)  Devices for measuring the volume of waste discharged may be required by the village if these volumes cannot otherwise be determined from the metered water consumption records. 
(3)  Metering devices for determining the volume of waste shall be installed, owned, and maintained by the person. Following approval and installation, such meters may not be removed, unless service is cancelled, without the village's consent. 
(c)  Capital outlay charge. A capital outlay charge effective September 1, 1986, to each user of the village wastewater collection system is established in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk for the following: 
(1)  Residents per quarter. 
(2)  Business and apartments up to eight units per quarter. 
(3)  Industry and apartments over eight units per quarter. 
(d)  Basic user charge. There shall be and there is hereby established a basic user rate for the use and service supplied by the village wastewater collection system in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk for the following: 
(1)  A basic user rate applied to all users of the wastewater collection system. 
(2)  In any case where the user of the wastewater collection system is a nonresident who is not connected to the village water supply system and who, therefor, does not use village water, such user of the wastewater collection system shall pay per quarter, which includes an additional 50 percent of the customary quarterly charge, which would be imposed upon a village resident, in accordance with the formula used to bill nonresidents for the use of village water. 
(3)  In any case where the user of the wastewater collection system is a resident, but not connected to the village water supply system. 
(4)  Any user of the wastewater collection system who is a nonresident shall also be required to annex any property being served by the village wastewater collection system to the village as soon as such annexation is legally practicable, and to pay the customary costs of such annexation, and, further, to execute any written documents which may be required by the village to memorialize such condition. 
(5)  The afore described user charges shall be increased annually at a rate of three percent per annum commencing on January 1, 2011 and continuing on the first day of January of each year thereafter. 
(e)  Surcharges. All surcharges for wastes exceeding a BOD of 25 pounds per day or suspended solids of 35 pounds per day are covered in the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago user charge ordinance adopted October 4, 1979, as amended. No additional surcharges shall be assessed by the village to users of the wastewater collection system. 
(f)  Computation of charge. The wastewater service charge shall be computed by the following formula: 
CW - CR(V) + CC. 
Where: 
CW = Wastewater service charge per month. 
V = Number of gallons of water used per quarter. 
CR = Basic user rate. 
= Total 0, M & R costs per year. 
Annual billable flow. 
CC = Capital outlay charge. 
= Projected capital costs per year. 
Total users. 
(g)  Sprinkler systems. There shall be no special wastewater service rate for use generated by the operation of sprinkler systems. 
(Code 1982, § 30-91; Ord. No. 86-017, § 3-1, 7-1-1986; Ord. No. 95-021, § 2, 7-18-1995; Ord. No. 96-026, § 1, 9-17-1996; Ord. No. 10-003, § 1, 3-16-2010) 
Sec. 40-149. - Billing, enforcement and collection requirements; penalty; public records. 
(a)  Bills. The rates or charges for service shall be payable quarterly. The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service to such premises and the service is furnished to the premises by the village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant and user of the services are jointly and severally liable therefor to the village. 
(1)  Bills for sewer service shall be sent out by the village the first day of the month succeeding the period for which the service is billed. 
(2)  All sewer bills are due and payable by the 15th day of the month following said billing. 
(b)  Delinquent bills. If the charges for such services are not paid by the 15th day of the month following the billing, a penalty of five percent of the unpaid balance shall be assessed. 
(c)  Lien; notice of delinquency. Whenever a bill for sewer service remains unpaid for 120 days for quarterly service after it has been rendered, the village shall file with the county recorder of deeds a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges subsequent to the period covered by the bill. 
(1)  If the user whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises and the village has notice of this, notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises if his address be known to the village whenever such bill remains unpaid for the period of 120 days for a quarterly bill after it has been rendered. 
(2)  The failure of the village to record such lien or to make such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid bills as mentioned in the foregoing section. 
(d)  Foreclosure. Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by fill-in-equity in the name of the village. The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the village's name in any court having jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which the bill has remained unpaid 120 days in the case of a quarterly bill after it has been rendered. 
(e)  Revenues. All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the wastewater collection system shall be deposited in the waterworks and sewerage system enterprise fund. Such fund shall be administered in every respect in the manner required by state law. 
(f)  Account. The village shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records, and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the sewerage system, and at regular annual intervals shall cause to be made an audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipt and disbursements of the wastewater collection system. In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the wastewater collection system, including a replacement cost, to indicate that sewer service charges under the waste cost recovery system do in fact meet these regulations. In this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit report shall also include the following: 
(1)  Billing data to show the total number of gallons billed. 
(2)  Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year. 
(3)  Number of users connected to the system. 
(4)  Number of nonmetered users. 
(g)  Notice of rates. Each user will be notified, at least annually, in conjunction with a regular bill, of the rate and that portion of the user charges which are attributable to the wastewater collection system. A copy of this article properly certified by the village shall be filed in the office of the county recorder of deeds and shall also be deemed notice to all property owners of the charges of the village wastewater collection system on their properties. 
(h)  Penalty. Any person violating any provisions of this article shall be subject to the general penalty provisions of section 1-23. 
(i)  Access to records. The state environmental protection agency or authorized representative shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of the village which are applicable to the village system of user charges for the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance with the terms of the special and general conditions to any state grant. 
(Code 1982, § 30-92; Ord. No. 86-017, § 3-2, 7-1-1986) 
Sec. 40-150. - Appeals. 
    The method for computation of rates and service charges established for user charges in section 40-148 shall be made available to a user within five days of receipt of a written request for such. A formal written appeal may be filed with the village outlining any discrepancies regarding service charges. A resolution of such discrepancies shall be made by the village within seven days after receipt of a written appeal. 
(Code 1982, § 30-94; Ord. No. 86-017, § 3-4, 7-1-1986) 
Secs. 40-151-40-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - OVERHEAD SEWER COST PROGRAM 

Sec. 40-161. - Establishment of cost reimbursement program. 
    The village hereby establishes a cost reimbursement program for the installation of overhead sewers in residences located in the village; which reimbursement shall cover 50 percent of the cost of any such installation, but in no event, shall it exceed $2,500.00, per eligible residence. 
(Ord. No. 09-001, § 1, 1-20-2009) 
Sec. 40-162. - Eligibility. 
    The program shall apply to all residential buildings consisting of not more than two units, located in the village. 
(Ord. No. 09-042, § 2, 12-15-09) 
Sec. 40-163. - Financial participation. 
    Financial participation of the village is limited to funds budgeted for the program. Such funding may be changed or eliminated on the village's annual review of the program. 
(Ord. No. 09-042, § 2, 12-15-09) 
Sec. 40-164. - Priority. 
    Applications will be classified into the following groups for purposes of determining funding eligibility: 
(1)  First priority shall be given to residential buildings consisting of not more than two units where one or more sanitary back ups have occurred and have been reported to the Village. The owner must provide documentation of previous sanitary sewer backup, either by telephone or a written notice to the village at the time of the backup. 
(2)  Second priority shall be given to the owner of any residential building consisting of not more than two units which has the potential to experience sanitary sewer backups. This would cover situations where there has not been previous backups, but the owner is desirous of installing overhead sewers as a preventative measure. 
(Ord. No. 09-042, § 2, 12-15-09) 
Sec. 40-165. - Administration. 
    The building department with the assistance of the public works department is hereby authorized and directed to establish and publish a detailed outline of all program requirements, including an application and a form of agreement to be executed by eligible participants, and all other necessary documents and to take all necessary actions required for the implementation of said program in the village. 
(Ord. No. 09-042, § 2, 12-15-09) 
Secs. 40-166-40-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BUILDING SEWER 

Sec. 40-171. - Permit-Required. 
    No person shall uncover, excavate under or around, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the village engineer. 
(Code 1969, § 24.401.1; Code 1982, § 30-101) 
Sec. 40-172. - Same-Classification. 
(a)  There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  For residential and commercial service, and 
(2)  For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
(b)  In either case, the owner or his agent shall make an application at least 24 hours (exclusive of Sundays and holidays) before any work is to be done, on a special form furnished by the village. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the village engineer's judgment. 
(Code 1969, § 24.401.2; Code 1982, § 30-102) 
Sec. 40-173. - Same-Fees. 
    A permit and inspection fee in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk for property which has been annexed to the village after service was already available shall be paid at the time that an application is filed for a permit under this article. 
(Code 1969, § 24.402; Code 1982, § 30-103; Ord. No. 361, § 6, 1-7-1975) 
Sec. 40-174. - Owner responsible for installation costs and damage. 
    All costs and expenses incident to the installation, connection and maintenance of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner or his agent shall indemnify the village from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Code 1969, § 24.403; Code 1982, § 30-104) 
Sec. 40-175. - Size; slope. 
    The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the village engineer's approval, but in no event shall the diameter be less than six inches. The slope of such six-inch pipe shall be no less than one-eighth inch per foot. 
(Code 1969, § 24.407; Code 1982, § 30-105; Ord. No. 84-018, § 3, 8-7-1984) 
Sec. 40-176. - Street openings-Application of sections 32-170 through 32-203. 
    The provisions of sections 32-170 through 32-203 shall apply to any street openings or excavations made in connection with sewer work. 
(Code 1969, § 24.413.1; Code 1982, § 30-106) 
Sec. 40-177. - Same-Excavation, pipe laying and backfill specifications. 
    All excavations required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trench work, unless otherwise approved by the village engineer. Pipe laying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with A.S.T.M. specification C-12-19, except that no backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected. 
(Code 1969, § 24.413.2; Code 1982, § 30-107) 
Sec. 40-178. - Same-Restoration to previous condition. 
    Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of work under this article shall be restored to their previous condition. 
(Code 1969, § 24.413.3; Code 1982, § 30-108) 
Sec. 40-179. - Old building sewers to comply with article provisions. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and testing by the village engineer, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 24.404; Code 1982, § 30-110) 
Sec. 40-180. - Installation format. 
    No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet of any bearing wall, which might thereby be weakened. The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost. The building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction or grade shall be made only by means of a manhole. 
(Code 1969, § 24.408; Code 1982, § 30-111) 
Sec. 40-181. - Stone bedding required for all construction. 
    Stone bedding shall be provided for all sewer construction, including building service sewer and house connections. 
(Code 1982, § 30-112; Ord. No. 366, § 1, 2-18-1975) 
Sec. 40-182. - Overhead plumbing required for new construction below ground level. 
    All new buildings with basements, floors, rooms or occupancy areas below ground level at the building site and served by a public or private sewer system shall have overhead plumbing. No building permit application will be accepted, nor any permits issued for construction of any structure, unless plans and specifications therefor provide for overhead plumbing as called for in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 30-113; Ord. No. 366, § 1, 2-18-1975) 
Sec. 40-183. - Gravity flow lifters. 
    In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Code 1969, § 24.409; Code 1982, § 30-114) 
Sec. 40-184. - Unstable ground to be replaced by compacted, granular backfill. 
    If unstable ground is encountered during construction of a building sewer, the unstable soil shall be removed and replaced with compacted, granular backfill. 
(Code 1969, § 24.406; Code 1982, § 30-115) 
Sec. 40-185. - Footing drains to be connected to sump pumps, not sewer system. 
    Footing drains shall be connected to sump pumps for further discharge into storm sewer or drainage ditches. No footing drain or drainage tile shall be connected to the sanitary sewer system. 
(Code 1982, § 30-116; Ord. No. 366, § 1, 2-18-1975) 
Sec. 40-186. - Joint and connection specifications. 
(a)  All building sewer joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. 
(b)  Cast iron pipe joints shall be firmly packed with oakum or hemp and filled with molten lead, Federal Specification QQ-L-156, not less than one inch deep. 
(c)  Lead shall be run in on pouring and caulked tight. 
(d)  No paint, varnish or other coatings shall be permitted on the jointing material until after the joint has been tested and approved. 
(e)  All joints in vitrified clay pipe shall consist of factory-made resilient compression joints, meeting or exceeding the A.S.T.M. specification designation, C-245. 
(f)  All joints between vitrified clay pipe and metals shall be made with approved bituminous jointing material. 
(g)  Other jointing materials and methods may be used only by the village engineer's approval. 
(Code 1969, § 24.410; Code 1982, § 30-117) 
Sec. 40-187. - Connection requirements. 
(a)  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the "Y" branch, if such branch is available at a suitable location. 
(b)  If the public sewer is 12 inches in diameter or less, and no properly located "Y" branch is available, a neat hole may be cut into the public sewer and a properly sized "T' saddle-fitted and cemented in place so as not to project into the public sewer. 
(c)  The invert elevation of the building sewer above the invert of the public sewer at the point of connection shall be no less than one-third of the diameter of the public sewer. 
(d)  A smooth, neat joint shall be made and the connection made secure and watertight by encasement in concrete. 
(e)  Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by the village engineer. 
(Code 1969, § 24.411; Code 1982, § 30-118) 
Sec. 40-188. - Inspections; notice. 
    The owner shall notify the village engineer when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the village engineer or his representative. 
(Code 1969, § 24.412; Code 1982, § 30-119) 
Secs. 40-189-40-207. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WATER CONSERVATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 40-208-40-226. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SPRINKLING OR IRRIGATION OF LAWNS AND GARDENS 

Sec. 40-227. - Water use limitations-Traditional hose fed sprinkler irrigation systems. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use water for hose-fed sprinkling or irrigation of lawns or gardens on any day of the week, except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and noon or 6:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m.; provided, however, in emergency conditions sprinkling or irrigation shall be permitted only on an odd/even basis (on odd-numbered calendar days if the last digit in the street address is odd or on the even-numbered calendar days if the last digit in the street address is even) between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and noon or 6:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m. 
(Code 1982, § 30-141; Ord. No. 91-001, § 1(1), 4-16-1991) 
Sec. 40-228. - Same-Fully automated underground sprinkler irrigation systems. 
    Fully automated irrigation and sprinkler systems that are piped underground and electronically controlled may operate any day of the week, but only between the hours of midnight and 7:00 a.m.; provided, however, in emergency conditions sprinkling or irrigation shall be permitted only on an odd/even basis (on odd-numbered calendar days if the last digit in the street address is odd or on the even-numbered calendar days if the last digit in the street address is even). 
(Code 1982, § 30-142; Ord. No. 91-001, § 1(2), 4-16-1991) 
Sec. 40-229. - Village authority to impose further limitations or suspension under certain conditions. 
    The village reserves the right to further limit or suspend the use of water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or for any other special purposes whenever the president and board of trustees shall determine that the public exigencies and emergencies require such action. If public exigencies and emergencies so require, due to the possibility that the water supply will not meet demand, the president may unilaterally declare and take such action prior to the next regularly scheduled or specially scheduled meeting of the president and board of trustees. At the next meeting of the president and board of trustees after the village president's action the emergency conservation action shall be abated, continued, or made more stringent by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 30-143; Ord. No. 91-001, § 1(3), 4-16-1991) 
Sec. 40-230. - Notice of limitation or suspension required. 
    Whenever the president/president and board of trustees limit or suspend the use of water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or for any other special purpose, it shall be unlawful for any person to use water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or for any other special purpose designated, other than during the times allowed for such use of water; provided that said person has been given notice of said limitation on, or the suspension of, the use of water, from the village, by telephone, U.S. Mail or personal service. 
(Code 1982, § 30-144; Ord. No. 91-001, § 1(4), 4-16-1991) 
Sec. 40-231. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating this article shall be subject to the general penalty provisions of section 1-23. 
(Code 1982, § 30-145; Ord. No. 91-001, § 2, 4-16-1991) 
Chapter 42 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1]

ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power of municipalities to license, tax and regulate cabmen, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-6; regulation of runners for cabs, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-4; Taxicab Safety Act of 2007, 625 ILCS 55/1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-20. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Driver means any person actually driving a taxicab. 
    Identification data includes: 
(1)  When applied to a taxicab, the following items of information: 
a.  Make, model and year of manufacture; 
b.  Engine number; 
c.  Serial number; 
d.  State certificate of title number and license number; 
e.  Number of passengers capable of being accommodated therein at one time. 
(2)  When applied to a driver, the following items of information: 
a.  Full name; 
b.  Present residence address; 
c.  Residence for three years past; 
d.  Age, color, height, weight, color of eyes and hair; 
e.  Citizenship and marital status; 
f.  Date and place of convictions of felonies or misdemeanors, if any, and a statement of the nature of the offenses for which convicted; 
g.  Whether he has ever been previously licensed as a chauffeur, if so, when, and by what authority; 
h.  Whether his license has ever been revoked or suspended; if so, for what cause; and 
i.  State motor vehicle chauffeur's license number. 
    Licensed driver means any person who shall have been properly identified by a licensee and authorized to drive licensee's taxicabs under a certificate of public convenience and necessity, in accordance with the terms of this article. 
    Licensee means any owner, operator, firm, association or corporation in whose name a certificate of public convenience and necessity shall have been issued by the village for the operation of taxicabs. 
    Standard number of taxicabs means the next whole number larger than the quotient obtained after dividing by 1,000 the village population as determined from time to time by the United States Bureau of the Census. 
    Taxicab. 
(1)  The term "taxicab" means all vehicles transporting passengers for remuneration for which patronage is solicited publicly. 
(2)  The term "taxicab" does not include the following: 
a.  Vehicles operating on established routes which are regulated by the state Commerce Commission; 
b.  Vehicles rented to be driven by the renter or his agent, commonly known as rent-a-cars; 
c.  Vehicles operated solely as funeral cars or ambulances; or 
d.  Vehicles owned and/or operated by any unit or agency of federal, state or local government. 
(Code 1969, § 25.101; Code 1982, § 31-11) 
Sec. 42-21. - Drinking; obscenity; disturbing the peace prohibited while on duty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensed driver of a taxicab, while on duty, to drink any intoxicating liquor, use any profane or obscene language, shout or call to prospective passengers or disturb the peace in any way. 
(Code 1969, § 25.110.3; Code 1982, § 31-12) 
Sec. 42-22. - Soliciting by mouth or gesture prohibited. 
    No taxicab driver shall at anytime solicit the patronage of a person by word of mouth or by gesture, within the village limits. 
(Code 1969, § 25.110.2; Code 1982, § 31-13) 
Sec. 42-23. - Unlawful to use in crime. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensed driver of a taxicab to knowingly permit any taxicab to be used in perpetration of a crime or misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 25.110.1; Code 1982, § 31-14) 
Sec. 42-24. - Identification, contact, and fare information to be posted. 
(a)  The taxi driver's picture, the taxi driver's license or registration number, and the taxicab medallion number or an exterior identification number must be posted in a visible location in each cab, as required by the Taxicab Safety Act of 2007, 625 ILCS 55/1. 
(b)  There must be posted in a visible location in each taxicab a telephone number for a passenger to call if the taxi driver is operating the taxicab in a reckless manner, as required by the Taxicab Safety Act of 2007, 625 ILCS 55/1. 
(c)  There shall be affixed on the inside of each taxicab in a conspicuous place and in such a manner that the same may be conveniently and easily read by a person riding in such taxicab a copy of the map and fee schedule. 
(Code 1969, § 25.105; Code 1982, § 31-15) 
Sec. 42-25. - Equipment maintenance; inspection; repairs at licensee's expense. 
(a)  Each taxicab licensee, for all taxicabs licensed under his name, shall maintain or cause all of the following to be maintained in a satisfactory condition to ensure safe operation: 
(1)  Brakes; 
(2)  Horns; 
(3)  Lights; 
(4)  Tires; 
(5)  Steering gear; 
(6)  Speedometers; and 
(7)  Windshield wipers. 
(b)  All mechanical equipment, including any taximeter, installed in or as part of any such taxicab, may be inspected by the police chief or his authorized representative at anytime. 
(c)  Whenever the police chief finds any such equipment to be in unsatisfactory condition, he may, by written notice to the licensee, require specific adjustment or repairs to be made at the licensee's expense. 
(Code 1969, § 25.104.2; Code 1982, § 31-17) 
Sec. 42-26. - Daily manifest; contents; required to keep for six months. 
(a)  Contents. Each taxicab licensee shall require each driver to maintain a daily manifest upon which are recorded the following information: 
(1)  Serial number of the taxicab; 
(2)  The speedometer total mileage reading at the beginning and end of the driver's tour of duty; and 
(3)  For each revenue trip made: 
a.  The date, time and place of origin; 
b.  Place of destination; 
c.  Speedometer total mileage reading at both origin and destination; 
d.  Number of passengers; and 
e.  Amount of fare collected. 
(b)  Required to keep for six months. Manifest forms shall be furnished to the driver by the licensee and shall, upon completion of the driver's tour of duty, be returned to the licensee, who shall retain every manifest as part of his records, available for inspection by village officers on request, for at least six months. 
(Code 1969, § 25.111; Code 1982, § 31-18) 
Sec. 42-27. - Passengers-Duty to accept person acting appropriately. 
    It shall be the duty of every licensed driver of any taxicab to accept as a passenger any person who seeks to so use the taxicab; provided such person conducts himself in an orderly manner and is not intoxicated. No person shall be admitted to a taxicab occupied by a passenger, if the passenger objects to sharing the cab with said person. 
(Code 1969, § 25.109.2; Code 1982, § 31-19) 
Sec. 42-28. - Same-Duty to reach destination by most direct route. 
    The taxicab driver shall take his passenger to his destination by the most direct available route from the place where the passenger enters the taxicab. 
(Code 1969, § 25.109.2; Code 1982, § 31-20) 
Sec. 42-29. - Charge requirements. 
(a)  The charges for taxicab service shall be in accordance with the map and fee schedule attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived. The hourly rate shall be no more than an amount approved by the village corporate authorities. 
(b)  No extra charge shall be made for baggage or parcels the size of which permits them to be carried on the lap or directly in front of the passenger. 
(Code 1969, § 25.105; Code 1982, § 31-21) 
Sec. 42-30. - Failure to pay prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for a taxicab passenger to fail or refuse to pay the lawful fare at the termination of a trip. 
(Code 1969, § 25.105; Code 1982, § 31-23) 
Sec. 42-31. - Receipt upon requested. 
    Upon paying his fare, each taxicab passenger, if he so requests, shall be given a receipt showing the amount so paid and the name of the company or person operating the taxicab, together with the number of the taxicab if such company or person operates more than one taxicab in the village. 
(Code 1969, § 25.105; Code 1982, § 31-24) 
Sec. 42-32. - Maximum 12-hour driving period; definitions. 
(a)  Maximum driving period. It shall be unlawful for any licensed driver to engage in driving a taxicab more than 12 hours out of every 24 hours. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Driving a taxicab means whenever a person is in charge of a taxicab and holding himself in readiness to convey passengers. 
(Code 1969, § 25.112; Code 1982, § 31-25) 
Sec. 42-33. - Duty to report involvement in accidents. 
    It shall be the duty of every licensed taxicab driver, if no police officer is present, to report to the police department, by the fastest available means of communication, any accident reportable under the traffic regulations of this Code wherein a taxicab driven by him was involved. 
(Code 1969, § 25.109.3; Code 1982, § 31-26) 
Sec. 42-34. - Drug and alcohol testing required following pedestrian accident. 
    If a taxi driver collides with a pedestrian while operating a taxicab, resulting in bodily injury, then any responding law enforcement officers must test the taxi driver for drug and alcohol use, as required by the Taxicab Safety Act of 2007, 625 ILCS 55/1. 
Secs. 42-35-42-53. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE 

Sec. 42-54. - Public vehicles commission-Established. 
    There is hereby established a public vehicles commission, which shall consist of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.1; Code 1982, § 31-36) 
Sec. 42-55. - Same-President is chairman. 
    The village president shall be the chairman of the public vehicles commission. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.1; Code 1982, § 31-37) 
Sec. 42-56. - Same-Meetings. 
    The public vehicles commission shall meet on the call of the chairman or of two members thereof, at such times as may be necessary to transact its business. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.1; Code 1982, § 31-38) 
Sec. 42-57. - Required; exception. 
    No person shall operate a taxicab within the village, unless and until the public vehicles commission shall have certified the taxicab under a certificate of public convenience and necessity, except that a taxicab may enter the village for the purpose of discharging a passenger therein upon the immediate request of such passenger. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.2; Code 1982, § 31-39) 
Sec. 42-58. - Application. 
    Any application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity to operate taxicabs in the village shall be made in writing, signed by the applicant, sworn before the village clerk, or other officer authorized to administer oaths, and shall set forth the following information pertaining to the prospective licensee: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; and if a corporation, the name and address of the chief executive official of the corporation; and if a firm or association, the names and addresses of all shareholders or partners; 
(2)  Identification data of all vehicles which applicant proposes to operate as taxicabs; 
(3)  Whether there are any liens, mortgages or encumbrances on such taxicabs, and if so, the amount and character thereof; 
(4)  The applicant's statement as to where and for what period of time he has previously engaged in the taxicab business; 
(5)  A schedule of all rates of fare which the applicant proposes to charge for hire of taxicabs. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.3; Code 1982, § 31-40) 
Sec. 42-59. - Insurance; limits; termination; revocation. 
(a)  No certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be issued until the applicant deposits with the village clerk a policy of liability insurance covering all vehicles to be operated under the certificate, or evidence satisfactory to the village attorney that such a policy is in full force and effect. 
(b)  Such policy shall be issued by a company licensed to do business in the state and shall insure the licensee against loss from liability to the amount of $100,000.00 for the injury or death of one person in any one accident and to the amount of $300,000.00 for the injury or death of more than one person in any accident; and to the amount of $10,000.00 for the damage to the property of others for any one accident due to the negligent operation of such vehicle. 
(c)  The policy of insurance shall be approved by the village attorney as to conformity with the terms of this article and shall contain a provision that the same may not be cancelled before the expiration of its term, except upon ten days written notice to the village. 
(d)  The cancellation or other termination of any insurance policy issued in compliance with this section shall automatically revoke and terminate the validity of the certificate of public convenience and necessity under which the vehicles covered by such insurance policy were operated, unless another policy shall have been filed and approved pursuant to this section, and shall be in effect at the time of such cancellation or termination. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.4; Code 1982, § 31-41) 
Sec. 42-60. - Approval based on public convenience and necessity. 
(a)  The village clerk shall present each application under this division to the public vehicles commission at its next regular meeting. 
(b)  The public vehicles commission shall approve such application by resolution authorizing the issuance of a certificate of public convenience and necessity, unless after a public hearing it finds that the public convenience and necessity would not be served by the proposed operation of taxicabs. 
(c)  In deciding the question of public convenience and necessity, the commission shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  Need of the public for taxicab service; 
(2)  Number of taxicabs in operation; and 
(3)  Anticipated future demands. 
(d)  The resolution shall state the name of the licensee and the number of vehicles authorized to be licensed under the certificate; and said number of vehicles authorized in the resolution shall not be different from the number set forth in the application; provided, however, that the number of taxicabs authorized by such resolution may be reduced below the number applied for insofar as necessary to avoid the licensing, at any one time, under all certificates of public convenience and necessity, of a total number of taxicabs in excess of the standard number of taxicabs. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.5; Code 1982, § 31-42) 
Sec. 42-61. - Issuance. 
    The village clerk shall issue a certificate of public convenience and necessity for the operation of taxicabs only after the following occurs: 
(1)  Payment of the fees; 
(2)  Proper authorization by the public vehicles commission; and 
(3)  When the required insurance policies or evidence thereof have been deposited. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.5; Code 1982, § 31-43) 
Sec. 42-62. - Contents. 
    A certificate issued under this division shall set forth all of the information on the application therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.5; Code 1982, § 31-44) 
Sec. 42-63. - Expiration; renewal. 
    Certificates of public convenience and necessity shall expire on December 31 of each year, except that any such certificate shall be automatically renewed upon payment of the annual fees provided in this division; however, the village clerk shall determine that the certificate is valid and in force in accordance with all provisions of this article, before such renewal fees may be accepted by the clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.5; Code 1982, § 31-45) 
Sec. 42-64. - Amendments; fee. 
(a)  The village clerk is authorized to alter, by endorsement on a certificate of public convenience and necessity, the identification data of licensed vehicles, at anytime on the written request of the licensee; provided that the number of vehicles licensed under one certificate is thereby neither increased nor decreased, and to add or delete the name of any of the licensed drivers; provided that in the case of new names being added, each such name shall be followed in the endorsement by the identification data for the new licensed driver. 
(b)  Identification cards for new licensed drivers shall be provided, and identification cards for drivers deleted shall be returned to the village clerk by the licensee. 
(c)  Any other amendment of a certificate of public convenience and necessity may be made only by written application for an amended certificate, made by the licensee to the village clerk for presentation to the public vehicles commission. 
(d)  The additional fee shall be payable by the licensee to the village clerk in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk, after approval of such amendment by the public vehicles commission, before endorsement thereof on the certificate shall be made. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.6; Code 1982, § 31-46) 
Sec. 42-65. - Revocation. 
    The public vehicles commission may at anytime by resolution revoke and terminate the validity of any certificate of public convenience and necessity for the following reasons: 
(1)  Any conduct by the licensee or by any licensed driver, which is prejudicial to the public safety, welfare, morals or good order of the community; or 
(2)  Repeated violation of any provision of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.7; Code 1982, § 31-47) 
Sec. 42-66. - Abandonment; commission's authority to modify. 
    If any licensee on whose behalf a certificate has been issued under this division shall fail to operate all or any of the taxicabs covered by such certificate for a period of 14 days, consecutively, the certificate may be revoked or modified by the public vehicles commission so as to cover and authorize only the number of taxicabs actually operated. 
(Code 1969, § 25.102.8; Code 1982, § 31-48) 
Secs. 42-67-42-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSE OF OWNER 

Sec. 42-86. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating a taxicab in the village without first having secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 25.103.1; Code 1982, § 31-56) 
Sec. 42-87. - Driving unlicensed cab prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of a taxicab not licensed by the village to pick up passengers within the village limits. 
(Code 1969, § 25.103.2; Code 1982, § 31-57) 
Sec. 42-88. - Fee; tags or stickers. 
(a)  The annual fee, payable in advance, for licenses under this division shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk for each taxicab operated. Whenever the number of taxicabs so operated shall be increased during the license year, the licensee shall notify the village clerk of such change and shall pay the additional fee. 
(b)  Such fee shall be in addition to any other vehicle fee required by ordinance, and the village clerk shall issue suitable tags or stickers for the number of taxicabs covered by each license. Such tag or sticker shall be displayed in a prominent place on each taxicab while it is in use, and may be transferred to any taxicab put into service to replace one withdrawn from service. 
(c)  The licensee shall notify the village clerk of the motor number and state license number of each taxicab operated and of the corresponding municipal tag or sticker number. 
(Code 1969, § 25.103.4; Code 1982, § 31-58; Ord. No. 628, § 32, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 42-89. - Application; contents. 
    Applications for licenses under this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall state thereon the following information: 
(1)  Applicant's name; 
(2)  Intended place of business; 
(3)  Number of taxicabs to be operated; and 
(4)  If the applicant is a corporation, the names and addresses of the president and secretary thereof shall be given. 
(Code 1969, § 25.103.1; Code 1982, § 31-59) 
Sec. 42-90. - Character of applicant. 
    No license under this division shall be issued to or held by any of the following persons: 
(1)  A person not of good character; 
(2)  A person convicted of a felony; or 
(3)  Any corporation, if any officer thereof would be ineligible for a license under subsections (1) and (2) of this section. 
(Code 1969, § 25.103.3; Code 1982, § 31-60) 
Sec. 42-91. - State license required. 
    No taxicab shall be operated, unless it bears a state license duly issued. 
(Code 1969, § 25.104.1; Code 1982, § 31-61) 
Secs. 42-92-42-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - LICENSE OF DRIVER 

Sec. 42-111. - Required. 
    No person shall drive or otherwise operate any taxicab within the village without first having obtained a license so to do. 
(Code 1969, § 25.107.1; Code 1982, § 31-71) 
Sec. 42-112. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for a taxicab driver's license shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 25.107.4; Code 1982, § 31-72; Ord. No. 628, § 33, 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 42-113. - Application; photos and fingerprints required. 
    No license to drive a taxicab within the village shall be issued to any applicant, unless the application therefor is signed by a taxicab operator, duly licensed under the provisions of this article, and contains identification data concerning the applicant and is sworn to by him. Such application shall be accompanied by three copies of a photograph of the applicant suitable for mounting on identification cards. The fingerprints of the applicant shall be taken and recorded by the police chief. 
(Code 1969, § 25.107.2; Code 1982, § 31-73; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 42-114. - Issuance. 
    All licenses authorizing persons to drive taxicabs within the village shall be issued by the village clerk upon receipt of a certificate of fitness issued by the police chief and upon payment of the license fee. 
(Code 1969, § 25.107.5; Code 1982, § 31-74; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 42-115. - Identification cards. 
(a)  Upon the issuance of a license to drive or operate a taxicab within the village, the applicant shall be furnished with an identification card bearing his name, photograph and the words "Taxicab Driver, Village of Lansing." 
(b)  Every licensed driver, while actually engaged in driving a taxicab, shall at all times wear conspicuously, on his person, his identification card. 
(c)  The village clerk shall also furnish the police chief with a copy of all such cards issued, together with the identification data for the licensed drivers. 
(Code 1969, § 25.108; Code 1982, § 31-75; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 42-116. - Police chief's authority to deny, suspend or revoke; appeals. 
(a)  The police chief shall have the power to grant, deny, suspend or revoke a taxicab driver's licenses whenever, in his opinion, the circumstances warrant such action. 
(b)  In case of a denial or revocation, an appeal may be made by the driver to the village board of trustees for hearing thereon. 
(c)  The village board may, after the hearing, affirm or reverse the action of the police chief. 
(d)  If no appeal has been taken within 20 days after notice given to driver and licensee of action to deny or revoke a taxicab driver's license, the action of the police chief shall be final. 
(Code 1969, § 25.107.6; Code 1982, § 31-76; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 42-117. - Renewal. 
    The license to drive a taxicab within the village shall be renewable annually on January 1. 
(Code 1969, § 25.107.7; Code 1982, § 31-77) 
Sec. 42-118. - Certificate of fitness-Required. 
(a)  No licensee under this article, nor any person employed by such licensee, shall operate any taxicab in the village who has not first applied for and received from the police chief a certificate of fitness to drive a public passenger vehicle. 
(b)  Such certificate shall be issued by the police chief to any person of good moral character who shall satisfy the police chief that he has the necessary physical faculties and the ability to drive a motor vehicle on the village streets in a safe and efficient manner. Such certificate shall be in force and effect only until December 31 of the year in which it was issued. 
(Code 1969, § 25.107.3; Code 1982, § 31-78; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 42-119. - Same-Conviction of felony; exception. 
    No certificate shall be issued under this division by the police chief to any person who has been convicted of a felony; provided, however, that upon the written recommendation of the police chief, the village president and the village board of trustees, such certificate may be granted. 
(Code 1969, § 25.107.3; Code 1982, § 31-79; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 42-120. - Same-Application; contents. 
    Any person desiring to secure a taxicab driver's certificate shall make application in writing to the police chief, and such application shall give the following information: 
(1)  Applicant's name and address; 
(2)  Name of, and the length of service with, his present employer; 
(3)  Information as to previous employment; and 
(4)  Names of at least two responsible village citizens as references. 
(Code 1969, § 25.107.3; Code 1982, § 31-80; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 42-121. - Same-Revocation. 
    Any certificate issued under this division may be revoked by the police chief for a violation by the holder thereof of any village ordinances or state law, or whenever the holder of such certificate shall cease to possess the character and qualifications provided for in this article as requisite to the issuance of such certificate. 
(Code 1969, § 25.107.3; Code 1982, § 31-81) 
Secs. 42-122-42-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - VEHICLE RENTING, LEASING AND LENDING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 42-141-42-159. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MOTOR VEHICLES 

Sec. 42-160. - Requirements for engaging in business. 
    Any person engaging in the business of renting, leasing or lending motor vehicles shall do the following: 
(1)  First obtain a license as provided in this article; 
(2)  Not conduct such business within any zoned residential district or within 200 feet thereof; 
(3)  Be 21 years of age, if any individual or manager for corporation, and shall possess any license required by state law; 
(4)  Make application for a license on forms provided by the village clerk and containing the following: 
a.  If an individual: the name and address of the individual; 
b.  If a partnership: the name, residence and business of each partner; 
c.  If a corporation: 
1.  Name, date and state under whose laws such corporation was organized; and 
2.  If a foreign corporation: 
i.  Whether authorized to do business in the state; 
ii.  Names of the principal officers, directors and local representatives, their residences and business addresses. 
d.  The location where the business of renting motor vehicles will be conducted, and the number of motor vehicles that will be maintained on the premises for rental purposes; 
(5)  Maintain precise records of vehicle rentals indicating the following information: 
a.  Name and address of the person to whom the rental was made; 
b.  The registered motor number of the vehicle rented or leased; 
c.  Other identifying data; 
d.  Parent or guardian's written approval of a minor's application and his agreement to be responsible for the action of such minor in the use of the vehicle; 
e.  Date and hour of its rental; and 
f.  Time of its return to the possession of the licensee; 
(6)  Not rent to anyone under 18 years of age until he has on file in his possession an acknowledgment in writing, signed by either parent of the applicant or the applicant's legal guardian, in the presence of and witnessed by the licensee, or his duly authorized agent, to the effect that permission is granted for such child to rent, lease, lend or borrow a motor vehicle from such renter, lessor, lender or borrower, and that such parent or guardian consents to the renting, leasing, lending or borrowing of a motor vehicle to such child, and assumes full legal responsibility for acts or actions of such child in the operation of any such motor vehicle then or thereafter rented, leased, lent or borrowed to such child and such renter, lessor, lender or borrower may reply upon such written consent, as compliance with this section, until it is revoked in writing, signed by either of such parents or by such guardian and delivered to such renter, lessor, lender or borrower; 
(7)  Rent vehicles only to persons who have and can show a valid motor vehicle operator's license and who can first demonstrate that he is sufficiently proficient to operate such vehicle upon a public street without unreasonable danger to others; 
(8)  Maintain all motor vehicles in a safe manner and provide each with all equipment required by law; 
(9)  Operate the business between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. There shall be no rental after 10:00 p.m. or the returning of motor vehicles between the hours of midnight and 8:00 a.m.; 
(10)  Provide proof of financial responsibility by compliance with all pertinent provisions of 625 ILCS 5/8-101; 
(11)  Have only the number of rental motor vehicles on the premises as provided for in his application; 
(12)  Comply with all village ordinances and regulations, including any reasonable regulations set by the police chief to effectuate this section; and 
(13)  Comply with all applicable state law. 
(Code 1982, § 31-91; Ord. No. 629, § 1(23.1401), 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 42-161. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for a person engaged in the business of renting, leasing or lending motor vehicles shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1982, § 31-92; Ord. No. 629, § 1(23.1402), 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 42-162. - Police authority to inspect. 
    Any member of the police department is authorized to inspect any motor vehicle, at any reasonable time, for the purpose of checking the following information: 
(1)  The license plate, license number and serial number; and 
(2)  The mechanical condition of the motor vehicle. 
(Code 1982, § 31-93; Ord. No. 629, § 1(23.1403), 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 42-163. - Removal or alteration of license plate or registration card prohibited; police authority to stamp numbers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, willfully or maliciously, to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the serial number of any motor vehicle licensed hereunder; or to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any license plate or registration card during the time in which the license plate or registration card is in force. The police chief is hereby authorized to stamp numbers on the frame of a motor vehicle in a legible manner for identification purposes, upon which no serial number can be found, or upon which the serial number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. 
(Code 1982, § 31-94; Ord. No. 629, § 1(23.1404), 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 42-164. - Unlawful to use motor vehicle without owner's consent. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate any motor vehicle within the village without the consent of the owner. 
(Code 1982, § 31-95; Ord. No. 629, § 1(23.1405), 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 42-165. - Unlawful to purchase, trade, etc., a motor vehicle without a valid serial number. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person residing in the village, or any dealer in motor vehicles operating in the village, to purchase, receive in trade, or otherwise acquire any motor vehicle from which the serial number on the frame has been removed, destroyed, mutilated or altered, without first reporting the same to the chief of police. 
(Code 1982, § 31-96; Ord. No. 629, § 1(23.1406), 12-30-1980) 
Sec. 42-166. - Police chief to enforce provisions of article. 
    The police chief shall enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 31-97; Ord. No. 629, § 1(23.1407), 12-30-1980) 
Secs. 42-167-42-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MOTORCYCLES OR MOTOR-DRIVEN CYCLES 

Sec. 42-186. - Requirements for engaging in business. 
    Any person engaging in the business of renting, leasing or lending motorcycles or motor-driven cycles shall do the following: 
(1)  First obtain a license as provided in this article. 
(2)  Not conduct such business within any zoned residential district or within 200 feet thereof. 
(3)  Be 21 years of age, if any individual or manager for a corporation, and shall possess any license required by state law. 
(4)  Make application for a license on forms provided by the village clerk and containing the following: 
a.  If an individual: the name and address of the individual; 
b.  If a partnership: the name, residence and business address of each partner; 
c.  If a corporation: 
1.  Name, date and state under whose laws such corporation was organized; and 
2.  If a foreign corporation: 
i.  Whether authorized to do business in the state; and 
ii.  Names of the principal officers, directors and local representatives and their residences and business addresses; 
d.  The location where the business of renting motorcycles will be conducted, and the number of motorcycles that will be maintained on the premises for rental purposes. 
(5)  Maintain precise records of vehicle rental indicating the following information: 
a.  Name and address of the person to whom the rental was made; 
b.  Registered motor number of the vehicle rented or leased; 
c.  Other identifying data; 
d.  Parent or guardian's written approval of a minor's application and his agreement to be responsible for the action of such minor in the use of the vehicle; 
e.  Date and hour of its rental; and 
f.  Time of its return to the possession of the licensee. 
(6)  Not rent to anyone under 18 years of age until he has on file in his possession an acknowledgment in writing, signed by either parent of the applicant or the applicant's legal guardian, in the presence of and witnessed by the licensee, or his duly authorized agent, to the effect that permission is granted for such child to rent, lease or borrow a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle from such renter, lessor or lender, and that such parent or guardian consents to the renting, leasing or lending of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle to such child, and assumes full legal responsibility for acts or actions of such child in the operation of any such motorcycle or motor-driven cycle then or thereafter rented, leased or lent to such child and such renter, lessor or lender may reply upon such written consent, as compliance with this section, until it is revoked in writing by written revocation, signed by either of such parents or by such guardian and delivered to such renter, lessor or lender. 
(7)  Rent vehicles only to persons who have and can show a valid motor vehicle operator's license and who can first demonstrate that they are sufficiently proficient to operate such vehicle upon a public street without unreasonable danger to others. 
(8)  Maintain all motorcycles in a safe manner and provide each with all equipment required by law. 
(9)  Operate the business between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. There shall be no rental after 10:00 p.m. or the returning of motorcycles between the hours of midnight and 8:00 a.m. 
(10)  Provide proof of financial responsibility by compliance with all pertinent provisions of 625 ILCS 5/9-101. 
(11)  Have only the number of rental motorcycles on the premises as provided for in his application. 
(12)  Comply with all village ordinances and regulations, including any reasonable regulations set by the police chief to effectuate this section. 
(13)  Comply with all applicable state law. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1005; Code 1982, § 31-111) 
Sec. 42-187. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for a person engaged in the business of renting, leasing or lending motorcycles or motor-driven cycles shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 23.1006; Code 1982, § 31-112; Ord. No. 628, § 30, 12-30-1980)

PART II - LAND USE, FIRE, BUILDING AND RELATED REGULATIONS 
Chapter 44 - COMMISSIONS, CODES AND PROCEDURES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 44-1-44-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONTRACTOR REGISTRATION 

Sec. 44-19. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of contractor, without being registered as a contractor in the manner hereinafter set forth. Contractors shall include, but not be limited to, the classifications described in section 44-21. 
(Code 1969, § 308.4-A) 
Sec. 44-20. - Application. 
(a)  Any person desiring to engage in the business of contractor shall apply for registration to the building department. Upon the filing of such application in proper form and the providing of all necessary bonds and insurance certificates, along with the payment of the registration fee set out in section 44-21, the building commissioner shall register the applicant as a contractor and classify the applicant into the proper category as outlined in section 44-21. 
(b)  Upon verification of the applicant's application, references, bond and insurance, the building commissioner shall issue a certificate of registration which will authorize the applicant to engage in such business for the fiscal year in which it is issued. 
(Code 1969, § 308.4-B) 
Sec. 44-21. - Fees, classifications; expiration date. 
    The fees for registration as a contractor shall be an annual fee in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk which shall be paid by the applicant to the village in advance upon filing the application. The certificate of registration issued thereunder shall expire on April 13 of the then current fiscal year. 
(Code 1969, §§ 308.4-C, 308.4-C(a)) 
Sec. 44-22. - Surety bonds required. 
    Every person desiring to engage in the business of construction, alteration, repair and conversion of buildings in the village shall execute and file with the building department a bond payable to the village in the sum as outlined in section 44-21 with sureties to be approved by the president and the board of trustees and filed with the village clerk conditioned that the applicant shall well and faithfully observe all of the provisions of this Code and other village ordinances and regulations relating to such construction, alteration, repair and conversion of buildings, and conditioned further to indemnify, save and keep harmless the village from loss, cost, damage, expense or liability of any kind whatsoever which the village may suffer or which may occur against it, be charged to or recovered by the village from or by reason of anything by such person or by any servant, agent or employee thereof in the construction, alteration or repair of any building or structure. 
(Code 1969, § 308.4-D) 
Sec. 44-23. - Insurance required. 
    Every person registered as a contractor in the village shall show proof of insurance to the building department in the following amounts: 
(1)  General liability shall be $1,000,000.00 per occurrence; $3,000,000.00 in the aggregate. 
(2)  Worker's compensation shall be in amounts conforming to the state statutory limits. Employer liability limits shall be $500,000.00. 
(3)  Business auto liability shall be $1,000,000.00 per occurrence. 
(Code 1969, § 308.4-E) 
Sec. 44-24. - Revocation; notice. 
    The building commissioner may revoke a contractor's registration if the contractor violates the village building codes. The contractor must be notified by certified mail of the intent to revoke the contractor registration and of the alleged violations, and the contractor will have seven days from the date notice is given to correct said violations, or to show cause why there is no violation. Notice shall be given by any of the following manners: 
(1)  Certified mail at the address provided on the contractor's license. 
(2)  Personal delivery. 
(3)  Posting on the site in which the contractor is working. 
(Code, 1969, § 308.4-F; Ord. No. 473, § 1, 4-18-1978; Ord. No. 87-018, § 1, 8-18-1987; Ord. No. 93-053, § 2, 12-21-1993; Ord. No. 00-001, § 2, 1-18-2000; Ord. No. 06-040, § 1, 11-7-2006; Ord. No. 06-045, § 1, 12-19-2006) 
Secs. 44-25-44-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICAL COMMISSION 

Sec. 44-44. - Composition; terms; qualifications. 
(a)  There is hereby established a commission to be known as the village electrical commission, which shall consist of six members, as follows: 
(1)  The electrical inspector shall be a member and the ex officio chairman of the commission; 
(2)  One registered professional engineer; 
(3)  One electrical contractor; 
(4)  One journeyman electrician; 
(5)  One representative of an inspection bureau maintained by the fire underwriters, if such a representative resides in the village, or if no such representative resides in the village, then the fire chief; and 
(6)  One representative of an electrical supply company, who shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees; provided that, if in the village, there is no person qualified under any of the descriptions contained in subsections (1) through (5) of this section to act, the president and board of trustees may appoint some other person, to fill such position. 
(b)  Such members shall be appointed for a three-year term by the president and board of trustees. 
(c)  The president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint the first members of the electrical commission. Two of the members shall be appointed to serve for a period of two years and three of the members shall be appointed to serve for three years. But every member shall serve until his successor is appointed and has qualified. 
(Ord. No. 07-028, § 201.1, 9-18-2007) 
Sec. 44-45. - Duties. 
    The electrical commission shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  Recommend safe and practical standards and specifications for the installations, alteration and use of electrical equipment designed to meet the necessities and conditions that prevail in the village; 
(2)  Recommend reasonable rules and regulations governing the issuance of permits by and for electrical installations; and 
(3)  Recommend reasonable fees to be paid therefor and for inspections by the electrical inspector of all electrical equipment installed or altered within the village; provided that such standards and rules and regulations shall not be effective, unless the same have been adopted by ordinance. 
(Code 1982, § 30-35; Ord. No. 88-002, § 1, 2-16-1988; Ord. No. 07-028, § 204.201.2, 9-18-2007) 
Secs. 44-46-44-64. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL INSPECTION DIVISION 

Sec. 44-65. - Established. 
    The village has established a subdivision within the building department known as the electrical inspection division. 
(Code 1982, § 30-33; Ord. No. 492, § 1, 7-11-1978; Ord. No. 88-002, § 1, 2-16-1988; Ord. No. 90-031, § 7, 10-16-1990; Ord. No. 93-029, § 7, 6-15-1993; Ord. No. 07-028, § 202.1, 9-18-2007) 
State Law reference- Municipal inspection of electrical equipment, 65 ILCS 5/11-37-1 et seq. 
Sec. 44-66. - Composition; terms; electrical inspector. 
(a)  The electrical inspection division shall consist of an electrical inspector and such other employees as may from time to time be appointed by the president and approved by the board of trustees. The electrical inspector shall report directly to the building commissioner. 
(b)  The president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint the first members of the electrical inspection division. Two members shall be appointed to serve for a period of two years and three of the members shall be appointed to serve for three years. But every member shall serve until his successor is appointed and has qualified. 
(Code 1982, § 30-34; Ord. No. 492, § 1, 7-11-1978; Ord. No. 88-002, § 1, 2-16-1988; Ord. No. 07-028, § 202.1, 9-18-2007) 
Sec. 44-67. - Certain activity by inspector prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the electrical inspector, except in the performance of his duties, to engage in the business of installation, alteration, maintenance or sale of electric wiring, electric devices or electrical material, either directly or indirectly, and he shall have no financial interest in any concern or be engaged in any such business in the village. This section shall not apply to a parttime, on-call inspector. 
(Code 1982, § 30-36; Ord. No. 88-002, § 1, 2-16-1988; Ord. No. 07-028, § 202.2, 9-18-2007) 
Sec. 44-68. - Electrical inspector's powers. 
(a)  Inspection and enforcement. The electrical inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building in the village in the discharge of his official duties, or for the purpose of making an inspection or test of the electrical equipment therein; and he shall have the duty and authority to enforce all the ordinance provisions relating to electric signs, electrical wiring and electrically operated equipment. He shall have the power to cause the current in any wire or conduit to be turned off whenever this is necessary in an emergency for the protection of life or property. The electrical inspector shall make all inspections necessary to the enforcement of the Village Code as may be required from time to time by the board of trustees. 
(b)  Stop work order. Whenever the electrical inspector shall find electrical work being done in violation of the village ordinances he shall have the power to order the work stopped until the ordinances are complied with. It shall be unlawful to continue any such work after such as stop order has been issued, except upon written permission of the president and board of trustees; provided that where such stop order is made orally, it shall be followed by a written stop order within an hour. 
(d)  Certificate of approval. The electrical inspector shall give the certificate of approval to the owner or person in charge of the premises that he has inspected where he finds that the electrical apparatus and wiring therein fully comply with village ordinances. 
(Code 1982, § 30-37; Ord. No. 88-002, § 1, 2-16-1988; Ord. No. 07-028, §§ 202.3-202.6, 9-18-2007) 
Secs. 44-69-44-87. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PLUMBING-MECHANICAL COMMISSION 

Sec. 44-88. - Established; composition. 
(a)  Created; membership. There is hereby established a commission, to be known as the village plumbing-mechanical commission, which shall consist of eight members, as follows: 
(1)  The plumbing inspector shall be a member and the ex officio chairman of the commission; 
(2)  One plumbing contractor representative; 
(3)  One licensed journeyman plumber; 
(4)  The heating inspector; 
(5)  One representative of the fire department; 
(6)  Two heating contractors; and 
(7)  One representative of the gas company. 
(b)  Term. Such members shall be appointed for three-year terms by the mayor and board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-51; Ord. No. 93-038, § 1, 8-17-1993) 
Sec. 44-89. - Appointments. 
    The mayor, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint the first members of the plumbing-mechanical commission. Three the members shall be appointed to serve for a period of two years and four members shall be appointed to serve for three years, but every member shall serve until his successor is appointed and has qualified. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-52; Ord. No. 93-038, § 2, 8-17-1993) 
Sec. 44-90. - Duties. 
    The plumbing-mechanical commission shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  Recommend safe and practical standards and specifications for the installation, alteration and use of plumbing and mechanical equipment designed to meet the necessities and conditions that prevail in the village; 
(2)  Recommend reasonable rules and regulations governing the issuance of permits by and for plumbing and mechanical installations; and 
(3)  Recommend reasonable fees to be paid therefor and for inspections by the plumbing-mechanical inspector of all plumbing and mechanical equipment installed or altered within the village; provided that such standards and rules and regulations shall not be effective, unless the same have been adopted by ordinance. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-53; Ord. No. 93-038, § 3, 8-17-1993) 
Sec. 44-91. - Permit required.
