    Upon the adoption by ordinance of such standards, specifications, rules and regulations specified in section 44-72, the same shall at once become operative and no plumbing and mechanical equipment shall be installed or altered, except upon a permit first being issued. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-54; Ord. No. 93-038, § 4, 8-17-1993) 
Secs. 44-92-44-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING PROCEDURE 

Sec. 44-211. - State statute adopted. 
    The provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., as it may be amended from time to time are adopted as permitted by statute. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-81; Ord. No. 97-022, § 1, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-212. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building inspector means a municipal employee whose duties include the inspection or examination of structures or property in the village to determine if zoning or other code violations exists. 
    Code means any municipal ordinance, law, housing, building code or zoning ordinance that establishes construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire prevention, sanitation or other health and safety standards that are applicable to structures in the village. 
    Hearing officer means a municipal employee or a village officer or agent, other than a property inspector or law enforcement officer, whose duty it is to: 
(1)  Preside at an administrative hearing called to determine whether or not a code violation exists; 
(2)  Hear testimony and accept evidence from the property inspector, the building owner and all interested parties relevant to the existence of a code violation; 
(3)  Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; 
(4)  Issue and sign a written finding, decision and order stating whether a code violation exists. 
    Property owner means the legal or beneficial owner of a structure. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-82; Ord. No. 97-022, § 2, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-213. - Code hearing department established. 
(a)  There is hereby established a code hearing department the function of which is to expedite the presentation and correction of code violations in the manner set out in 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1 et seq., and this article. 
(b)  The adoption of this article does not preclude the village from using other lawful methods to enforce the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-83; Ord. No. 97-022, § 3, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-214. - Hearing procedure. 
(a)  Violation notice and report form; contents. When a building inspector finds a code violation while inspecting a property, he shall note the violation on a multiple copy violation notice and report form, indicating the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the property owner; 
(2)  Type and nature of the violation; 
(3)  Date and time the violation was observed; 
(4)  Names of witnesses to the violation; and 
(5)  Address of the property where the violation was observed. 
(b)  Notice of hearing. The violation report form shall be forwarded by the building inspector to the code hearing department where a docket number shall be stamped on all copies of the report and a hearing date noted in the blank spaces provided for that purpose on the form. The hearing date shall be no less than ten days, nor more than 40 days after the violation is reported by the building inspector. 
(c)  Copies. One copy of the violation report form shall be maintained in the files of the code hearing department and shall be part of the record of hearing, one copy of the report form shall be returned to the building inspector so that he may prepare evidence of the code violation for presentation at the hearing on the date indicated, and one copy of the report form shall be served by first class mail on the property owner along with a summons commanding the property owner to appear at the hearing. If the name of the property owner cannot be ascertained or if service on the property owner cannot be made by mail, service may be made on the property owner by posting or mailing a copy of the violation report form on the front door of the structure where the violation is found, no less than 20 days before the hearing is scheduled. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-84; Ord. No. 97-022, § 4, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-215. - Hearing officer's authority to issue subpoenas. 
    At any time prior to the hearing date the hearing officer assigned to the case may, at the request of the building inspector, village attorney or the property owner or his attorney, issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give testimony at the hearing. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-85; Ord. No. 97-022, § 5, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-216. - Default judgment allowed. 
    If on the date set for hearing the property owner or his attorney fail to appear, the hearing officer may find the property owner in default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relative to the existence of a code violation. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-86; Ord. No. 97-022, § 6, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-217. - Continuances and representation at hearings. 
(a)  No continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer in proceedings under this article, except in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the owner. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. 
(b)  Any continuance authorized by a hearing officer under this article shall not exceed 45 days. 
(c)  The case for the village may be presented by the building inspector, by any other village employee or by an attorney designated by the village. However, in no event shall the case for the village be presented by an employee of the code hearing department. 
(d)  The case for the property owner may be presented by the owner, his attorney, or any other agent or representative. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-87; Ord. No. 97-022, § 7, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-218. - Strict rules of evidence not applicable at hearing. 
    At the hearing, a hearing officer shall preside and shall hear testimony and accept the evidence relevant to the existence or nonexistence of a code violation relating to a property or structure indicated. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply to hearings authorized by this article. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-88; Ord. No. 97-022, § 8, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-219. - Retaliatory action against occupants prohibited. 
    No action for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and detainer or other similar proceeding shall be threatened or instituted against an occupant of a dwelling solely because such occupant agrees to testify or testifies at a code violation hearing. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-89; Ord. No. 97-022, § 9, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-220. - Defenses. 
    It shall be a defense to a code violation charge under this article if the property owner, his attorney or any other agent or representative proves to the hearing officer's satisfaction that: 
(1)  The code violation alleged in the notice does not in fact exist, or at the time of the hearing the violation has been remedied or removed; 
(2)  The code violation has been caused by the current property occupants and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the property owner to maintain the dwelling free of such violations, the current occupants continue to cause the violations; 
(3)  An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the property owner or his agent to all or a part of the dwelling for the purpose of correcting the code violation. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-90; Ord. No. 97-022, § 10, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-221. - Hearing officer's findings, decision and order. 
(a)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing whether or not a code violation exists. The determination shall be in writing and shall be designated as findings, decision and order. The findings, decision and order shall include the hearing officer's finding of fact, a decision whether or not a code violation exists based upon the findings of fact, and an order ordering the property owner to correct the violation or dismissing the case in the event a violation is not proved. 
(b)  If a code violation is proved, the order may also impose the sanctions that are provided in the Code for the violation proved. A copy of the findings, decision and order shall be served on the property owner within five days after they are issued; service shall be in the same manner as the report form and summons and shall be served pursuant to section 44-77(c). Payment of any penalty or fine and the disposition of fine money shall be in the same manner as set forth in the Code, unless otherwise provided. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-91; Ord. No. 97-022, § 11, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-222. - State statutes concerning fines and sanctions adopted. 
    The village adopts by reference all current and future local ordinances, and those provisions of Illinois Compiled Statutes 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq. governing property or zoning codes applicable to structures or properties relative to construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire prevention, sanitation and other health and safety standards in the village, for its enforcement and adjudication within the village geographical boundaries. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-92; Ord. No. 97-022, § 12, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-223. - County circuit court to apply Administrative Review Law. 
    The hearing officer's findings, decision and order shall be subject to review in the county circuit court, and the provisions of the state Administrative Review Law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.), and all amendments and modifications thereto, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto are adopted and shall apply to and govern every action for the judicial review of the final findings, decision and order of a hearing officer under this article. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-93; Ord. No. 97-022, § 13, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-224. - Procedure for obtaining judgment. 
(a)  Debt owed village. Any fine, other sanction or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other sanction or costs imposed remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures under the Administrative Review Law shall be a debt due and owing the village, and, as such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law. 
(b)  Circuit court procedure. After expiration of the period within judicial review under the Administrative Review Law may be sought for a final determination of the code violation, the village may commence a proceeding in the circuit court for purposes of obtaining a judgment on the findings, decision and order. Nothing in this section shall prevent the village from consolidating multiple findings, decisions and orders against a person in such a proceeding. Upon commencement of the action, the village shall file a certified copy of the findings, decision and order, which shall be accompanied by a certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the findings, decision and order was issued in accordance with this article and applicable state law. Service of the summons and a copy of the petition may be by any method provided by section 2-203 of the Code of Civil Procedures (735 ILCS 5/2-203) or by certified mail, return receipt requested; provided that the total amounts of fines, other sanctions and costs imposed by the findings, decision and order does not exceed $2,500.00. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-94; Ord. No. 97-022, § 14, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-225. - Findings and sanctions attach to property. 
    The order to correct a code violation and the sanctions imposed by the village as a result of a finding of a code violation under this article shall attach to the property as well as to the property owner so that a finding of a code violation against one owner cannot be avoided by conveying or transferring the property to another owner. Any subsequent transferee or owner of property takes subject to the findings, decision and order of a hearing officer under this article. 
(Code 1982, § 8.3-95; Ord. No. 97-022, § 15, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 44-226. - Appeals made to planning and zoning board; procedure. 
    Unless otherwise provided by ordinance, any appeal from an adverse ruling of the building commissioner will be heard by the planning and zoning board of appeals in accordance with the following rules and the existing zoning rules of chapter 56: 
(1)  Petition; contents. A petition shall be filed with the secretary of the planning and zoning board of appeals that shall include the following information: 
a.  The type of building or construction proposed to be performed by the petitioner. 
b.  The village ordinance that prohibits the building or construction for which a variance is requested. 
c.  The relief requested by the petitioner. 
d.  Petitioner's reasons why such relief should be granted. 
(2)  Fees; notice. Upon the payment of the prescribed filing fee and cost for publication of the hearing, the secretary of the planning and zoning board of appeals shall schedule a hearing date for the petitioner and publish notice pursuant to applicable ordinances in effect. 
(3)  Representation. The petitioner may appear individually, or with counsel, at all hearings before the planning and zoning board of appeals. 
(4)  Finding of fact. At the conclusion of the hearing, or no later than 15 days after such hearing, the planning and zoning board of appeals shall issue its decision, based on its findings of fact, which may sustain or overrule the building commissioner or vary or modify the ordinance in question. 
(5)  Voting. A decision shall require the concurrence of four members of the planning and zoning board of appeals, at which the chairman also votes, and a member of the planning and zoning board of appeals who was absent from the hearing who has reviewed the transcript and other evidence presented at the hearing, if any, may also vote. 
(6)  Subject to Administrative Review Law. Appeals taken from the planning and zoning board of appeals shall be subject to the Administrative Review Law provisions of 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq. 
(Code 1982, § 1-27; Ord. No. 83-029, § 1, 11-1-1983; Ord. No. 86-033, § 6, 12-2-1986) 
Sec. 44-227. - Recordation of zoning hearings. 
    A tape-recorded record shall be made of all zoning hearings. A written transcript of said tape recording will only be made in the following situations: 
(1)  At the request of the mayor or the board of trustees; 
(2)  At the request of the petitioner, so long as the petitioner reimburses the village for a reasonable transcribing charge; 
(3)  In the event of an appeal of a decision of the planning and zoning board of appeals or as may otherwise be provided by statute; or 
(4)  By a majority vote of the planning and zoning board of appeals as may be required in order to satisfy their duties and obligations. 
(Code 1982, § 1-28) 
Sec. 44-228. - Penalty. 
    Unless otherwise specified, any failure to comply with the Code provisions contained in volume II shall result in a violation subject to the general penalty provisions of section 1-23. 
(Code 1982, § 16-238; Ord. No. 95-026, § 2, 8-15-1995) 
Chapter 46 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Illinois Building Commission Act, 20 ILCS 3918/1 et seq.; Public Building Commission Act, 50 ILCS 20/1 et seq.; Municipal Adoption of Codes and Records Act, 50 ILCS 220/1 et seq.; adoption of building codes by local ordinance, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-3.1; incorporation by reference of certain construction regulations by municipalities, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1; identification of local building codes, 20 ILCS 3918/55. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Conflicts. 
    When the provisions herein specified for structural, fire and sanitary safety are more restrictive than the zoning law, the provision of this chapter shall control the erection or alteration of buildings in respect to location, use, peripheral area, and height; but in any case, the most rigid requirements of either this chapter or the village's zoning law (chapter 56) shall apply whenever they may be in conflict. In addition, if two provisions of this Code are applicable, one general and one specific, the specific shall prevail over the general. 
Sec. 46-2. - Official or employee not personally liable for damages resulting from the proper performance of his duties; village to pay defense costs and assume any financial responsibility. 
    Any official or employee charged with the administration or enforcement of this chapter and acting for the governmental authority in the discharge of such duties, shall not thereby be rendered liable personally, and is hereby relieved of all personal liability for any and all damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted under the provisions of this chapter, and any suit or legal action brought against any official or employee because of any act performed in the administration or enforcement of the provisions of this chapter shall be defended by the village legal department until a final termination of the proceedings, and the village shall assume any and all financial liability thereof. 
(Code 1969, app. B, § 311; Code 1982, § 30-2; Ord. No. 88-002, § 1, 2-16-1988) 
Sec. 46-3. - Violation; penalty. 
(a)  Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter shall, unless otherwise specifically provided herein, be subject to the general penalty set forth in section 1-23. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The penalties set forth in this section shall be in lieu of any penalty provisions provided in any technical code adopted by the village in this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 30-3; Ord. No. 88-002, § 1, 2-16-1988) 
State Law reference- Adoption of penalty provisions by reference prohibited, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-4. 
Sec. 46-4. - Clerk to keep copies of adopted technical codes. 
    Pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/1-2-4 and 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1 through 5/1-3-6 three copies of all technical codes adopted herein are on file in the village clerk's office, in addition to such other copies as may be available in the village's departments as appropriate, for use and examination by the public. 
(Code 1982, § 30-4) 
Secs. 46-5-46-23. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-24. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to ensure proper safety, health and welfare insofar as they are affected by building construction through structural strength, adequate egress facilities, sanitary equipment, light and ventilation, and fire safety, and in general to provide certain minimum standards, provisions and requirements for safe and stable design, methods of construction, and uses of materials in buildings hereinafter erected, constructed, enlarged, altered, repaired, moved, converted to other uses or demolished, in order to ensure to a fuller extent the health and safety of the public. 
(Code 1969, app. A, § 102) 
Sec. 46-25. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall control all matters concerning the construction, alteration, addition, repair, removal, demolition, use, location, the occupancy and maintenance of all buildings and structures and their service equipment and shall apply to existing or proposed buildings and structures in the village; except where such matters are otherwise provided for in the local, municipal charter or other ordinance or statutes. 
(Code 1969, app. A, § 103) 
Sec. 46-26. - Applicability. 
(a)  Generally. The provisions of this article shall apply to all buildings and structures and their appurtenant construction and accessory additions; and shall apply with equal force to municipal, county, state and private buildings; except where such buildings are specifically provided for by statute. 
(b)  Exceptions. No building or structure shall be constructed, extended, repaired, removed or altered in violation of these provisions, except for the following situations: 
(1)  Ordinary repairs. Ordinary repairs to buildings may be made without application or notice to the building official. Such ordinary repairs shall not include the following: 
a.  Cutting away of any wall, partition or portion thereof; 
b.  Removal or cutting of any structural beam or bearing support; 
c.  Removal or change of any required means of egress; 
d.  Rearrangement of parts of a structure affecting the exit requirements; 
e.  Addition to, alteration of, replacement or relocation of any standpipe, water supply, sewer, drainage, drain leader, gas, soil, waste, vent or similar piping, electric wiring or mechanical or other work affecting public health or general safety. 
(2)  Raising and lowering of buildings or structures. The raising and lowering or removing of a building or structure as a unit necessitated by a change in legal grade or widening of a street shall be permitted, provided the building or structure is not otherwise altered and/or the building's use or occupancy has not been changed. 
(c)  Relation with zoning restrictions. When the provisions herein specified for structural, fire and sanitary safety are more restrictive than the zoning law (chapter 56), this article shall control the erection or alteration of buildings in respect to the location, use, permissible area and height, but in any case, the most rigid requirements of either this article or chapter 56 shall apply whenever they may be in conflict. 
(Code 1969, app. A, §§ 104-104.3) 
Sec. 46-27. - Existing buildings; conformance with this article. 
(a)  Major alterations and repairs. Existing buildings when altered or repaired as follows shall be made to conform to the full requirements of this article for new buildings: 
(1)  Alterations exceeding 50 percent. If the alterations or repairs are made within any period of 12 months costing in excess of 50 percent of the physical value of the building; or 
(2)  Damages exceeding 50 percent. If the building is damaged by fire or any other cause to the extent in excess of 50 percent of the physical value of the building before the damage was incurred. 
(b)  Changed use. Existing buildings shall be made to conform with the requirements for new buildings, if the existing use or occupancy of the building is changed to a use or occupancy which would not be permitted in a similar building hereafter erected; provided, however, if the use or occupancy of only a portion of an existing building is changed in occupancy or to a new use group and that portion is separated from the remainder of the building with required vertical and horizontal fire divisions complying with the fire grading as specified in this Code, the construction involved in the change shall be made to conform to the requirements for the new use and occupancy and the existing portion shall be made to comply with the existing requirements of this article. 
(c)  Increase in size. Any existing building increased in floor area or number of stories shall be made to conform with the requirements of this article in respect to means of egress, fire safety, light and ventilation; provided that no existing building shall have its floor area or its number of stories increased beyond the limits which would be allowed for new buildings under similar conditions. 
(d)  Minor repairs. Every alteration or repair to any structural part or portion of any existing building shall, when determined necessary in the opinion of the building commissioner, be made to conform to the requirements of this article for new buildings. Minor alterations, repairs and changes shall be made as follows: 
(1)  Alterations under 50 percent. If the cost of alterations or repairs is between 25 percent and 50 percent of the physical value of the building or structure, the building commissioner shall determine to what degree the portions so altered or repaired shall be made to conform to this article for new buildings. 
(2)  Alterations of 25 percent. If the cost of alterations or repairs is 25 percent or less than the physical value of the building, the building commissioner shall permit the restoration of the building to its condition previous to damage or deterioration with the same kind of materials as those of which the building was constructed; provided, however, that said construction does not endanger the general safety and public welfare, and that no more than 25 percent of the roof covering of the existing building shall be replaced in any period of 12 months, unless the entire roof covering is made to conform with requirements of this article for new construction. 
(e)  Physical value. In applying the provisions of this section the building commissioner shall determine the physical value of the building based on current replacement costs. 
(Code 1969, app. A, §§ 105-105.5) 
Sec. 46-28. - Property owner responsible for maintenance. 
(a)  All buildings and structures and all parts thereof, both existing and new, shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition. All service equipment, means of egress, devices and safeguards which are required by this article in a building, or which were required by a previous statute in a building when erected, altered or repaired, shall be maintained in good working order. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed as permitting the removal or nonmaintenance of any existing devices or safeguards unless authorized in writing by the building commissioner. 
(c)  The owner or his designated agent shall be responsible for the safe and sanitary maintenance of the building or structure and its exit facilities at all times. 
(Code 1969, app. A, § 106) 
Secs. 46-29-46-47. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 46-48. - International Building Code adopted. 
    The village adopts the International Building Code, 2015 Edition, published by the International Code Council, for the control of building and structures as provided herein. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions, and terms of the adopted code are made a part hereof as if fully set forth herein, unless otherwise specifically provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 13-028, § 1, 5-21-2013; Ord. No. 16-011, § 1, 3-1-2016) 
Sec. 46-49. - Revisions and exceptions to adopted code. 
    The following revisions and exceptions to the building code adopted pursuant to this article shall apply in the village: 
(1)  Section 101.1. Title -Insert "The Village of Lansing, Illinois". 
(2)  Section 105.2. Work exempt from permit: 
Building-Items 1 through 6, inclusive, are hereby deleted; and item 9 is hereby deleted. 
(3)  Section 903.2. Where required -Add to the end of the section "all structures erected or added to, after the adoption of this Code, in which the outer building perimeter walls encompass over 15,000 square feet, regardless of fire walls or separations, and regardless of use or occupancy, shall be provided with an automatic sprinkler system through the entire structure according with section 903.3." 
(4)  Section 906.6. Monitoring -Add to the end of the section "Approved supervising stations are the village communications center or a UL listed central station." 
(5)  Section 1010.1.4.4. Security Grilles -Add to the end of the section 
Security gates or grilles on storefronts or other buildings or structures used for commercial purposes. 
All such security grilles or gates shall be located on the interior of the building and shall not be visible during the period of occupancy. All such interior security grilles shall be retractable and shall recess completely into pockets that conceal the grille when it is retracted. Such pocket shall be integrated into the design of the building. Exterior security grilles, roll-down security grilles that conceal storefront windows or permanently affixed security bars are prohibited. 
(6)  All new structures or substantially rebuilt existing structures or building additions, other than single-family residences, shall be constructed with all exterior walls being face brick or natural stone. Trash enclosures for the above structures shall also be constructed of the same face brick or natural stone. In addition, the exterior of all such structures must provide a sufficient level of architectural interest. The plans for all structures containing exterior walls of face brick or natural stone must be submitted to and approved by the village. There shall be an exception for the requirement for exterior walls to be of face brick or natural stone where an exterior wall is beyond the public view. In such case, the wall may be constructed of masonry after village approval. For structures exceeding 50,000 square feet, upon application by the developer, the village may consider and approve the use of a Quick Brick or similar masonry product. 
(Code 1982, § 30-21; Ord. No. 83-010, § 1, 4-5-1983; Ord. No. 85-024, § 1, 8-20-1985; Ord. No. 88-030, § 1, 11-1-1988; Ord. No. 90-011, § 1, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 95-004, § 1, 2-21-1995; Ord. No. 01-042, § 1, 11-6-2001; Ord. No. 06-034, § 1, 10-17-2006; Ord. No. 08-026, 10-21-2008; Ord. No. 13-028, § 1, 5-21-2013; Ord. No. 13-050, § 1, 9-17-2013; Ord. No. 16-011, § 1, 3-1-2016) 
Secs. 46-50-46-68. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 46-69. - Building department established; building commissioner. 
    The village building department is hereby created and the executive official in charge shall be known as the building commissioner: 
(1)  Appointment. The building commissioner shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees for a term of one year, subject to removal at their pleasure. 
(2)  Qualifications. To be eligible for appointment, the building commissioner shall be generally informed on the following subjects: 
a.  Good engineering practice in respect to the design and construction of buildings; 
b.  Basic principles of fire prevention; and 
c.  The accepted requirements for means of egress and the installation of elevators and other service equipment necessary for the health, safety and general welfare of the occupants. 
(3)  Bond. Before any building inspector shall enter upon his duties he shall take and subscribe an oath of office upon the back of his certificate of appointment. Said certificate of appointment, along with the oath of office, shall thereupon be filed with the village clerk-collector. 
(4)  Duties and powers. The building commissioner shall enforce all the provisions of this article and shall act on any question relative to the mode or manner of construction and the materials to be used in the erection, addition to, alteration, repair, removal, demolition, installation of service equipment, and the location, use, occupancy, and maintenance of all buildings and structures, except as may otherwise be specifically provided for by statutory requirements or as herein provided: 
a.  Applications and permits. The building commissioner shall receive applications and issue permits for the erection and alteration of buildings and structures, and examine the premises for which such permits have been issued and enforce compliance with the building code provisions; 
b.  Notices and orders. The building commissioner shall issue all necessary notices or orders to remove illegal or unsafe conditions, to require the necessary safeguards during construction, to require adequate exit facilities in existing buildings and structures, and to ensure compliance with all the Code requirements for the safety, health and general welfare of the public; 
c.  Inspections. The building commissioner shall make all the required inspections, or he may accept reports of inspection of authoritative and recognized services or individuals; and all reports of such inspections shall be in writing and certified by a responsible officer of such authoritative service or by the responsible individual; or he may engage such expert opinion as he may deem necessary to report upon unusual technical issues that may arise, subject to the approval of the appointing authority; 
d.  Records. The building commissioner shall keep official records of applications received, permits and certificates issued, reports of inspections, and notices and orders issued. File copies of all papers in connection with building operations shall be retained in the official records for a period of five years; 
e.  Annual report. At least annually, the building commissioner shall submit to the chief authority of the municipality a written statement of all permits and certificates issued, orders promulgated and materials approved. 
(5)  Relief from personal liability. 
a.  The building commissioner, officer or employee charged with the enforcement of this article, while acting for the municipality, shall not thereby render himself liable personally, and he is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his official duties. Any suit instituted against any officer or employer because of an act performed by him in the lawful discharge of his duties and under the provisions of the building code shall be defended by the legal representative of the municipality until the final termination of the proceedings. 
b.  In no case shall the building commissioner or any of his subordinates be liable for costs in any action, suit or proceeding that may be instituted in pursuance of the provisions of this article; and any officer of the department of building inspection, acting in good faith and without malice, shall be free from liability for acts performed under any of its provisions or by reason of any act or omission in the performance of his official duties in connection therewith. 
(6)  Restrictions on outside employment. No official or employee connected with the department of building inspection, shall be engaged in or directly or indirectly connected with the furnishing of labor, materials or appliances for the construction, alteration or maintenance of a building, or the preparation of plans or of specifications therefor, unless he is the owner of the building; nor shall such officer or employee engage in any work which conflicts with his official duties or with departmental interests. 
(Code 1969, app. A, §§ 301-301.6; Ord. No. 84-018, § 1, 8-7-1984; Ord. No. 90-031, § 6, 10-16-1990; Ord. No. 93-029, § 6, 6-15-1993) 
Secs. 46-70-46-88. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 46-89. - Requirements. 
(a)  Preliminary. Before issuing a permit, the building commissioner shall examine or cause to be examined all buildings, structures and sites for which an application has been filed for a permit to construct, enlarge, alter, repair, remove, demolish or change the use thereof. 
(b)  Construction phase. The building commissioner shall examine all buildings in the course of erection a minimum of three times: 
(1)  Foundation. A foundation inspection shall be made by the building commissioner when the foundation is completed and the title around footings is installed and before any backfilling has been started; provided that before the inspection is made, the building commissioner has received notification from the village engineer that he has set the grade for the finished floor elevation on the foundation to be inspected. 
(2)  Frame. The building commissioner shall make the second inspection when the framing and all mechanical roughing is completed and installed. 
(3)  Final. The building commissioner shall make the third inspection when the building is ready for occupancy, at which time particular attention shall be paid to the location of walks, driveways, grading of the lot around the building and all outside improvements. 
(c)  Notice. The builder, whether a contractor or owner, shall be responsible for notifying the building commissioner when the building is ready for the foundation, frame and final inspections. 
(d)  Inspection reports. No work shall be done on any part of the building and/or structure beyond the point indicated in each successive inspection without first obtaining the building commissioner's written approval. Such written approval shall be given only after an inspection has been made of each successive step in the construction as indicated by subsection (b) of this section. 
(Code 1969, app. A, §§ 302-302.4; Ord. No. 595, § 2, 3-4-1980) 
Sec. 46-90. - Right of entry; identification badge; assistance from other village departments. 
    In the discharge of his duties, the building commissioner shall have the authority to enter at any reasonable hour any building, structure or premises in the municipality to enforce the provisions of the building code. 
(1)  Official badge. The building commissioner may adopt a badge of office for himself and his assistants which shall be displayed for the purpose of identification. 
(2)  Municipal cooperation. The assistance and cooperation of the police, fire, and health departments and all other municipal officials shall be available to him as required in the performance of his duties. 
(Code 1969, app. A, §§ 303-303.2) 
Secs. 46-91-46-109. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - PERMITS 

Sec. 46-110. - Application. 
(a)  Permit required; exception. 
(1)  Unless otherwise provided herein, it shall be unlawful to do any of the following: 
a.  Construct, enlarge, alter, remove or demolish, or change the occupancy of a building from one use group to another requiring greater strength, exit or sanitary provisions; 
b.  Change to a prohibited use; or 
c.  Install or alter any equipment for which provision is made or the installation of which is regulated by this article, without first filing an application with the building commissioner in writing and obtaining the required permit therefor. 
(2)  No permit shall be required for detached accessory buildings not exceeding 40 square feet in area, ten feet in the greatest horizontal dimensions, wall heights not to exceed six feet, overall height not to exceed seven feet. 
(b)  Commencement of work without permit. In the event any work is commenced prior to issuance of a required permit, the owner or applicant may be required to pay a permit fee of twice the amount normally applicable. 
(c)  Form of application. The application for a permit shall be submitted in such form as the building commissioner may prescribe and shall be accompanied by the required fee as established from time to time by the board of trustees, the village maintains a fee schedule, a copy of the fee schedule can be obtained from the village clerk's office. 
(d)  Persons authorized to make an application. An application for a permit shall be made by the owner or lessee of the building or structure, or agent of either, or by the licensed engineer, architect or contractor employed in connection with the proposed work, or by a contractor who owns the fee and is building a structure or building for a purchasing party. If the application is made by a person other than the owner in fee, it shall be accompanied by a duly verified affidavit of the owner or the qualified person making the application that the proposed work is authorized by the owner in fee and that the applicant is authorized to make such application. The full names and addresses of the owner, lessee, applicant and of the responsible officers, if the owner or lessee is a corporate body, shall be stated in the application. 
(e)  Description of work. The application shall contain a general description of the following: 
(1)  The proposed work; 
(2)  Its location; 
(3)  The use and occupancy of all parts of the building or structure and of all portions of the site or lot not covered by the building; and 
(4)  Such additional information as may be required by the building commissioner. 
(f)  Plans and specifications. The application shall contain specific plans and dimensions of the following type: 
(1)  Copies; waiver. The application for the permit shall be accompanied by no less than two copies of specifications and of plans drawn to scale, with sufficient clarity and detailed dimensions to show the nature and character of the work to be performed. When the quality of materials is essential for conformity to this article, specific information shall be given to establish such quality; and in no case shall the Code be cited or the term "legal" or its equivalent be used as a substitute for specific information. The building commissioner may waive the requirement for filing plans when the work involved is of a minor nature. 
(2)  Grading plans. A grading plan prepared by a licensed engineer is to be submitted to the building department, together with the other required plans and specifications for construction in the village. Prior to occupancy, a licensed engineer shall certify to the village the final landscaping grade for the lot to be in conformity with village requirements. 
(g)  Plot diagram. The application shall contain specific plot and plat descriptions providing the following information: 
(1)  Plot plan; accurate scale required. There shall also be filed a plot plan showing to scale the size and location of all the new construction and all existing structures on the site, distances from lot lines and the established street grades; and it shall be drawn in accordance with an accurate boundary line survey. In the case of demolition, the plot plan shall show all construction to be demolished and the location and size of all existing buildings and construction that are to remain on the site or plot. 
(2)  Plat of property. There shall be filed with each application sufficient information that the building commissioner can determine that the subdivision regulations, as provided for by state statutes and in village ordinances, as amended, have been complied with or the application shall be denied. 
(h)  Engineering details; signature required. The building commissioners may require adequate details of structural, mechanical and electrical work including computations, stress diagrams and other essential technical data to be filed. All engineering plans and computations shall bear the signature of the engineer or architect responsible for the design. 
(i)  Amendments. Subject to the limitations of subsection (j) of this section, amendments to a plan, application or other records accompanying the same may be filed at anytime before completion of the work for which the permit is sought or issued, and such amendments shall be deemed part of the original application and shall be filed therewith. 
(j)  Time constraints; extensions; fees. An application for a permit for any proposed work shall be deemed to have been abandoned six months after the date of filing, unless such application has been diligently prosecuted or a permit shall have been issued, except that for reasonable cause, the building commissioner may grant one or more extensions of time for additional periods not exceeding 90 days each. An additional fee in the amount of 25 percent of the original permit fee shall be paid by the applicant for each such extension of time. 
(Code 1969, app. A, §§ 304-304.9; Ord. No. 595, § 3, 3-4-1980; Ord. No. 93-039, § 1, 8-17-1993; Ord. No. 97-031, §§ 1, 2, 10-21-1997) 
Sec. 46-111. - Requirements. 
(a)  Action on application. The building commissioner shall examine or cause to be examined all applications for permits and amendments thereto within a reasonable time after filing. The building commissioner shall cause the records of the village to be examined to determine if the applicant owes any fees, fines or judgments to the village (debt due and owing) and if it is determined there is such a debt, the permit shall not be issued until such debt is paid in full. If the application or the plans do not conform to the requirements of all pertinent laws, he shall reject such application in writing stating the reasons therefor. If he is satisfied that the proposed work conforms to the requirements of this article and all laws and ordinances applicable thereto, he shall issue a permit therefor as soon as practicable. 
(b)  Suspension of permit. Any permit issued shall become invalid if the authorized work is suspended or abandoned for a period of six months after the time of commencing the work. 
(c)  Previous approvals. Nothing in this article shall require changes in the plans, instructions or designated use of a building for which a lawful permit has been heretofore issued or otherwise lawfully authorized, and the construction of which shall have been actively prosecuted within 90 days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. A single building permit for a valuation of less than $50,000.00 shall be valid for a period of six months. A single building permit for a valuation of $50,000.00 or more shall be valid for a period of one year. However, a permit may be renewed for a period of six months after an application and the payment of fees has been made. A permit for any structure creating a public nuisance shall not be renewed until the violation is corrected. 
(d)  Signature required. The building commissioner shall attach his signature to every permit; or he may authorize a subordinate to affix such signature thereto. 
(e)  Approved plans. The building commissioner shall stamp or endorse in writing both sets of corrected plans "Approved," and one set of such approved plans shall be retained by him and the other set shall be kept at the building site, open to inspection of the building commissioner or his authorized representative at all reasonable times. Approved plans of temporary structures where required and approved plans of single-family dwellings may be destroyed two years after the permit is granted or voided. 
(f)  Revocation. The building commissioner may revoke a permit or approval issued under the provisions of this article in the case of any false statement or misrepresentation of fact in the application or on the plans on which the permit or approval was based. 
(g)  Approval in part. The building commissioner may issue a permit for the construction of foundations or any other part of a building or structure before the entire plans and specifications for the whole building have been submitted; provided adequate information and detailed statements have been filed complying with all the pertinent requirements of this article. The holder of such permit for the foundations or other part of a building or structure shall proceed at his own risk with the building operation and without assurance that a permit for the entire structure will be granted. 
(h)  Posting of permit and site plans. A true copy of the building permit shall be kept on the site of operations open to public inspection during the entire time of prosecution of the work and until the completion of the same. 
(Code 1969, app. A, §§ 305-305.8; Ord. No. 96-008, § 1, 3-5-1996; Ord. No. 13-045, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 46-112. - Prerequisites. 
(a)  Fees. No permit shall be issued until the fees in an amount as established from time to time by the village board and placed on the fee schedule, a copy of the fee schedule may be obtained from the village clerk's office, have been paid. 
(b)  Compliance with Code. The permit shall be a license to proceed with the work and shall not be construed as authority to violate, cancel or set aside any of the provisions of this article, except as specifically stipulated by a modification or legally granted variation as described in the application. 
(c)  Compliance with permit. All work shall conform to the approved application and plans for which the permit has been issued and any approved amendments thereto. 
(d)  Compliance with plot plan. All new work shall be located strictly in accordance with the approved plot plan. 
(e)  Reducing or diminishing lot. No lot or plot shall be changed, increased or diminished in area from that shown on the official plot plan, unless a revised diagram showing such changes accompanied by the necessary affidavit of owner or applicant shall have been filed and approved; except that such revised plot plan will not be required if the change is caused by reason of an official street opening, street widening or other public improvements. 
(Code 1969, app. A, §§ 306-306.5) 
Sec. 46-113. - Building removal or demolition requirements. 
(a)  Service connections. Before a building can be demolished or removed, the owner or agent shall notify all utilities having service connections within the building such as water, electric, gas, sewer and other connections. A permit to demolish or remove a building shall not be issued until a release is obtained from the utilities, stating that their respective service connections and appurtenant equipment, such as meters and regulators, have been removed or sealed and plugged in a safe manner. 
(b)  Notice to adjoining owners. Only when written notice has been given by the applicant to the owners of adjoining lots and to the owners of wired or other facilities, of which the temporary removal may be necessitated by the proposed work, shall a permit be granted for the removal of a building or structure. 
(c)  Lot regulation. Whenever a building is demolished or removed, the premises shall be maintained free from all unsafe or hazardous conditions by the proper regulation of the lot, restoration of established grade and the erection of the necessary retaining walls and fences. 
(Code 1969, §§ 307-307.3) 
Secs. 46-114-46-132. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - CERTIFICATES OF USE AND OCCUPANCY 

Sec. 46-133. - Required. 
    No building or structure shall be occupied or used, in whole or in part, until a certificate of occupancy shall have been issued by the building commissioner. 
(Code 1969, § 309.1) 
Sec. 46-134. - New certificate required for buildings added to or altered; exception. 
    No building hereafter enlarged, extended or altered to change from one use group to another, in whole or in part, and no building hereafter altered for which a certificate of use and occupancy has not been heretofore issued, shall be occupied or used, in whole or in part, until the certificate shall have been issued by the building commissioner, certifying that the work has been completed in accordance with the provisions of the approved permit, except that any use or occupancy, which was not discontinued during the work of alteration, shall be discontinued within 30 days after the completion of the alteration, unless the required certificate is secured from the building commissioner. 
(Code 1969, § 309.2) 
Sec. 46-135. - Existing buildings; issued at owner's request after inspection. 
    Upon written request from the owner of an existing building, the building commissioner shall issue a certificate of use and occupancy; provided there are no violations of law or orders of the building commissioner pending, and it is established after inspection and investigation that the alleged use of the building has heretofore existed. Nothing in this article shall require the removal, alteration or abandonment of, or prevent the continuance of the use and occupancy of a lawfully existing building, unless such use is deemed to endanger public safety and welfare. 
(Code 1969, § 309.3) 
Sec. 46-136. - New certificate required for change of occupancy and use. 
(a)  Required. No change of occupancy shall be made in a building or structure that is not consistent with the last issued certificate of occupancy for such building or structure, unless a new certificate of occupancy is secured. 
(b)  Exception; prohibitions. The occupancy of a building or structure shall not be deemed to have changed because of a temporary vacancy or change of ownership or tenancy. The reestablishment in a building or structure, after a change of occupancy has been made, of a prior use that is not permitted in a new building or structure of the same type of construction is prohibited. The change from a specifically prohibited use to another specifically prohibited use shall not be made. 
(c)  Certificate of occupancy; fee. Any building or structure which has been vacant for a period of 120 days or more must be inspected and the owner or his designee obtain a new certificate of occupancy. A fee to be determined by the village clerk will be required. 
(Code 1969, §§ 309.4-309.4.2) 
Sec. 46-137. - Temporary certificate issuance. 
    Upon the request of a holder of a permit, or owner of the building, the building commissioner may issue a temporary certificate of occupancy for a building or structure, or part thereof, before the entire work covered by the permit shall have been completed; provided such portion may be occupied safely prior to the full completion of the building without endangering life or public welfare. 
(Code 1969, § 309.5) 
Sec. 46-138. - Issuance. 
    A certificate of occupancy shall be issued within seven days after written application therefor, if the building or structure at the time of such application shall be entitled thereto. Copies of the certificate of occupancy shall be furnished, on request, to persons having a proprietary interest in the building or structure. 
(Code 1969, § 309.6) 
Sec. 46-139. - Contents. 
    The certificate shall certify compliance with the provisions of this article and the purpose for which the building or structure may be used in its several parts. The certificate of use and occupancy shall specify the following information: 
(1)  The use group; 
(2)  The fire grading and maximum live load on all floors; 
(3)  The occupancy load in the building and all parts thereof; and 
(4)  Any special stipulations and conditions of the building permit. 
(Code 1969, § 309.7) 
Sec. 46-140. - Required for completed installations, extensions or alterations of equipment or appliances. 
    When a certificate is specifically required by a provision of this Code for an installation, extension or alteration of equipment or appliances, it shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of such equipment or appliances to which such provision applies, until the appropriate certificate has been issued. 
(Code 1969, § 309.8) 
Secs. 46-141-46-159. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 46-160. - Notice required. 
    Whenever the building commissioner is satisfied that a building or structure, or any work in connection therewith, the erection, construction, addition or alteration, execution of which is regulated, permitted or forbidden by this Code, is being erected, constructed, added to or altered, in violation of the provisions or requirements of this Code, or in violation of a detailed statement or plan submitted and approved thereunder, or of a permit or certificate issued thereunder, he shall serve a written notice or order upon the person responsible therefor directing the discontinuance of such illegal action and the remedying of the condition that is in violation of the provisions or requirements of this Code. 
(Code 1969, § 310.1) 
Sec. 46-161. - Enforcement of Code. 
    In case a violation notice or order is not properly complied with, the building commissioner shall notify the village attorney of such noncompliance, and the village attorney upon such notice shall institute an appropriate action or proceeding at law or in equity, to restrain, correct or remove such violation, or the execution of work thereon, or to restrain or correct the erection or alteration of, or to require the removal of, or to prevent the occupancy or use of, the building or structure erected, constructed, added to or altered, in violation of, or in noncompliance with the provisions of this Code or with respect to which the requirements thereof, or of any order or direction made pursuant to provisions contained therein, shall not have been complied with. 
(Code 1969, § 310.2) 
Sec. 46-162. - Penalty; abatement. 
(a)  Misdemeanor; fine; imprisonment. Any person who shall violate a provision of this Code or fail to comply therewith or with any of the requirements thereof, or who shall erect, construct, add to or alter, move or demolish, or has erected, constructed, added to or altered, moved or demolished a building or structure or portion thereof, in violation of a detailed statement or plan submitted and approved thereunder, or of a permit or certificate issued thereunder, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any provision of this Code is committed or continued and upon conviction of such violation each person shall be punished by the general penalty provisions of section 1-23. 
(b)  Abatement. The imposition of the penalties herein prescribed shall not preclude the village attorney from instituting any of the following actions or proceedings: 
(1)  To prevent an unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, addition, alteration, conversion, removal, demolition, maintenance or use; 
(2)  To restrain, correct or abate a violation; 
(3)  To prevent the occupancy of a building or structure or portion thereof, or of the premises; or 
(4)  To prevent an illegal act, conduct, business or use in or about any premises. 
(Code 1969, §§ 310.3-310.3.2) 
Sec. 46-163. - Stop work order. 
    Upon notice from the building commissioner that work on any building or structure is being prosecuted contrary to the provisions of this article or in an unsafe and dangerous manner, or that the contractors are not licensed as required, such work shall be immediately stopped. The stop work order shall be in writing and given to the owner of the property involved, the owner's agent or to the person doing the work; and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. 
(Code 1969, § 310.4) 
Secs. 46-164-46-182. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICAL CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-183. - Purpose and intent; minimum standard. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is the practical safeguarding of human life and property from electrical hazards arising from the use of electricity. 
(b)  The regulations of this article constitute a minimum standard. Strict compliance with the regulations of this article and proper maintenance will result in an installation free from hazard. 
(c)  This article is not intended as a design specification or an instruction manual for untrained persons. 
(Code 1982, § 30-30; Ord. No. 88-002, § 101.2, 2-16-1988; Ord. No. 07-028, § 101.2, 9-18-2007) 
Sec. 46-184. - Village immunity. 
    The electrical regulations of this article shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility of any person owning, operating or installing any electrical wires, appliances, apparatus, construction or equipment, for damages to anyone injured by any defect therein by reason of the inspection authorized herein or the certificate of inspection issued by the electrical inspector; nor shall the village be liable for any damages resulting from the enforcement of the regulations of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 30-31; Ord. No. 88-002, § 101.3, 2-16-1988; Ord. No. 07-028, § 101.3, 9-18-2007) 
Sec. 46-185. - Interpretation, purpose and conflict. 
    In interpreting and applying the provisions of this article they shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public safety, health, convenience, comfort, morals, prosperity and general welfare. It is not intended by this Code to interfere with or abrogate or annul any ordinances, rules, regulations or permits previously adopted or issued, and not in conflict with any of the provisions of this Code, or which shall be adopted or issued pursuant to a law relating to the use of buildings or premises, and likewise not in conflict with this Code; except that if this Code imposes a greater restriction, this Code shall control. 
(Ord. No. 07-028, § 307, 9-18-2007) 
Sec. 46-186. - Official or employee not liable for damage occurring during the proper performance of his duty; village to pay defense costs and financial liability. 
    Any official or employee of the electrical inspection division charged with the administration or enforcement of this Code and acting for the governmental authority in the discharge of such duties, shall not thereby be rendered liable personally, and is hereby relieved of all personal liability for any and all damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted under the provisions of this Code, and any suit or legal action brought against any official or employee because of any act performed in the administration or enforcement of the provisions of this Code shall be defended by the village legal department until a final termination of the proceedings, and the village shall assume any and all financial liability thereof. 
(Ord. No. 07-028, § 311, 9-18-2007) 
Sec. 46-187. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Electrical contractor means any person engaged in the contracting business of installing or altering electrical equipment for the utilization of electricity supplied for light, heat or power, not including radio apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sounds and signals, conductors and other equipment installed for or by public utilities, including common carriers which are under the jurisdiction of the state commerce commission, for use in their operation as public utilities. The term "electrical contractor" does not include employees employed by an electrical contractor to do or supervise his work. 
    Electrical equipment means conductors and equipment installed for the utilization of electricity supplied for light, heat or power, not including radio apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sounds and signals and does not include apparatus, conductors and other equipment installed for or by public utilities, including common carriers, which are under the jurisdiction of the state commerce commission, for use in their operation as public utilities. 
(Ord. No. 07-028, § 102.2, 9-18-2007) 
Secs. 46-188-46-207. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - QUALIFICATION FOR ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS AND PROPERTY OWNERS 

Sec. 46-208. - Examination; license. 
    Any person applying for an electrical contractors license who does not have proof of completing, with a passing grade, an approved state electrical test shall be required to submit to such examination and obtain a passing grade before an electrical license will be issued. 
(1)  General electrical license exam. The following requirements pertain to the general electrical exam: 
a.  The test shall be based on the 2005 National Electrical Code and the Lansing Electrical Code. 
b.  The test shall be open book and shall contain 100 questions either true or false, multiple choice, or fill-in-the-blank, or any combination. 
c.  The test shall have a three hour time limit. 
d.  A passing grade shall be 70 percent correct. 
e.  Tests shall be given monthly at the building department. 
f.  The fee for the test and a retest shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk charged for any further attempt to pass this test within one year of the original test. 
g.  The building commissioner or electrical inspector shall grade all tests. 
(2)  Exam for property owners. The following requirements pertain to the property owners exam: 
a.  This exam shall be open book and consist of 20 questions concerning basic electric and only be taken once every year, allowing for one calendar year between test dates. The test may only be taken to perform work on a home where the homeowner currently resides. 
b.  A passing grade for this exam shall be 16 or more correct. 
c.  No fee shall be charged for this exam. 
d.  Compliance by homeowners: All building permits issued to homeowners to build and/or install systems themselves shall comply with all codes. If an inspection reveals code violations have been created because an owner lacks the required expertise to properly build and/or install to code specifications, the homeowner will be required to have a contractor, who is licensed and bonded with the village, properly alter any construction and/or installation which is in violation of the code. The homeowner shall indemnify and hold harmless the village and its officers, employees and agents from all accidents and damages. 
(Ord. No. 07-028, § 302.5, 9-18-2007) 
Secs. 46-209-46-228. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ELECTRICAL CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 13-041, adopted Aug. 20, 2013, repealed div. 3, §§ 46-229-46-239, and enacted a new div. 3 as set out herein. The former div. 3 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for a complete derivation. 

Sec. 46-229. - Adoption of electrical code. 
    The rules and regulations as contained in the 2014 National Electrical Code, NFPA 70 and the rules and regulations regarding the installation, alteration, and use of electrical equipment as adopted by the Fifth Edition of Commonwealth Edison Company Residential Electrical Service Installation, also known as the "Red Book," are hereby adopted by reference as the safe and practical standards for the installation, alteration and use of electrical equipment in the village. Both the 2014 National Electrical Code and the Fifth Edition of Commonwealth Edison Company Residential Electrical Service Installation are adopted, to the extent that the two codes conflict, the Fifth Edition of Commonwealth Edison Company Residential Electrical Service Installation will control. 
(Ord. No. 13-041, § 1, 8-20-2013; Ord. No. 18-027, § 3, 8-21-2018) 
Sec. 46-230. - Residential units-Ampere requirements. 
(a)  Each residential unit shall be provided with a minimum of 100 ampere service with provision for 16 sub circuits with a minimum of eight working circuits. Circuit breaker equipment shall have a minimum of 100 ampere main breaker with 16 branch circuits. Each unit containing 2,000 square feet or more, including garages, shall require 200 ampere main breaker with a minimum of 30 branch circuits. The use of mini breakers is not allowed, unless approved by the electrical inspector. 
(b)  A fixed lighting fixture of approved type shall be installed over the sump or ejector pumps, heating plant, air conditioning unit or similar unit when located in a crawl space. 
(c)  A weatherproof receptacle shall be provided on the front and rear of each single-family, two-family and multiple-family dwelling. Additionally, there must also be ground-fault interrupters. 
(d)  Permanent lighting fixtures, wall-switch controlled shall be installed in kitchens, dining rooms, bathrooms, powder rooms, halls and other applicable areas. Where there is more than one entrance to the rooms and halls indicated in this subsection, permanent lighting fixtures shall be multiple-switch controlled at both entrances. Each bedroom shall be provided with a permanent ceiling or wall fixture, wall switch controlled, or switch all receptacles with one-half of the receptacles alive at all times. 
(e)  A permanent lighting fixture shall be installed to illuminate properly all basement stairs and such fixture shall be switch-controlled from the head of the stairs. Multiple switch controls shall be installed at both elevations when the basement is provided with other exit doorways. 
(f)  In bathrooms and powder rooms, a grounded receptacle outlet shall be installed adjacent to the mirror. Additionally, there must also be ground fault interrupters. 
(g)  All toilet rooms, other than residential, must have exhaust fans switched with the light. 
(h)  All exterior lighting fixture feeds must terminate in a junction box. 
(i)  Only lighting circuit conduit shall be allowed to be attached to suspended ceiling grid work. 
(j)  All receptacles on 15 and 20 amp circuits shall be a grounded type. 
(k)  All ceiling lights shall have a bar hanger to support the possible use for a paddle fan (in locations where possible usage). All such installations shall include an approved paddle fan box of the 8-B type. 
(l)  All garages attached to the house must have a heat detector interlocked with house smoke detectors. 
(m)  Each smoke, carbon monoxide, and heat detector shall be powered by 110 volts and, if interrupted, the detectors shall receive power from a battery source. 
(Ord. No. 13-041, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 46-231. - Service conductor specifications. 
    Service conductors extending along the exterior of or entering buildings shall be copper and thermoplastic covered in rigid metal conduit. Aluminum wire is not permitted within any building. 
(Ord. No. 13-041, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 46-232. - Raceway or conduit requirements. 
(a)  For all work, wiring shall be installed in rigid conduit, electrical metallic tubing, or surface metal raceways, except that it shall be permissible to use a section of flexible Greenfield metal conduit, where flexible connections are necessary, not exceeding six feet in length. 
(b)  The use of armored flexible cable (BX) is prohibited on all work. All types of BX including but not limited to: AC, FC, FCC, NM, MNC, MS, SE, FMT. 
(c)  Ridged nonmetallic conduit may be used for outside underground wiring only. 
(d)  No PVC conduit shall be used above grade level, unless it is encased in concrete. 
(Ord. No. 13-041, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 46-233. - Main disconnection control. 
    There shall be only one main disconnection control on any buildings or improvements to be used for commercial purposes on any property which is zoned B-1 through B-4. 
(Ord. No. 13-041, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 46-234. - Interpretation, purpose and conflict. 
    In interpreting and applying the provisions of this Code they shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public safety, health, convenience, comfort, morals, prosperity and general welfare. It is not intended by this Code to interfere with or abrogate or annul any ordinances, rules, regulations or permits previously adopted or issued, and not in conflict with any of the provisions of this Code, or which shall be adopted or issued pursuant to a law relating to the use of buildings or premises, and likewise not in conflict with this Code; except that if this Code imposes a greater restriction, this Code shall control. 
(Ord. No. 13-041, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Secs. 46-235-46-258. - Reserved.

Each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions, and terms of the adopted code are made a part hereof as if fully set forth herein, unless otherwise specifically provided herein.
