ARTICLE V. - HEATING AND AIR CONDITIONING CODE 

Sec. 46-376. - Board of heating and air conditioning. 
(a)  Established; duties. There is hereby created a board of heating and air conditioning. The board shall issue all certificates of registration for heating and air conditioning. The board shall also act as appeal board of heating and air conditioning. 
(b)  Appeal procedure. Any person directly interested who is aggrieved by any decision of the heating and air conditioning inspector or from any requirement resulting from any enforcement of the heating and air conditioning code, may appeal from such decision to the appeal board of heating and air conditioning. To serve as such an appeal board, the board of heating and air conditioning may sit in hearing either as a full board or as appointed parts thereof. The appeal shall be made by the person aggrieved giving written notice of such appeal to the village clerk within 48 hours after such decision is made. Said appeal board shall meet within 48 hours after the giving of such notice; and shall render a decision within five days thereafter. Any interested party, including the heating and air conditioning inspector, shall have the right to present the case to such appeal board, whose decision shall be final. 
(c)  Membership. Such board shall consist of five members, as follows: 
(1)  The electrical inspector shall be a member and the ex officio chairman of the board; 
(2)  The assistant fire chief; 
(3)  The fire inspector; 
(4)  A licensed wet heating contractor; and 
(5)  A licensed forced air and air conditioning contractor. 
(d)  Appointment. Board members shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees, voting jointly. 
(e)  Term. Initially, two board members shall be appointed for a term of one year, and the balance of the board and all future appointments shall be for a term of two years. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2600-2600.5; Ord. No. 491, § 2, 7-11-1978) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 46-377. - Duties. 
(a)  Rules and procedures. The board of heating and air conditioning shall make such rules and prescribe such procedures as may be necessary for its operation in conformity with this article. 
(b)  Decisions. Board decisions shall be concurred in by at least three board members. 
(c)  Suspension or revocation of certificate of registration. The board shall have the authority to suspend or revoke any heating or air conditioning certificate of registration granted under this article for violations enumerated following, after due hearing as hereinafter specified: 
(1)  Misrepresentation of a material fact in obtaining such certificate of registration or renewal thereof. 
(2)  Use of a certificate of registration in obtaining a permit for another. 
(3)  Failure to secure the permits, inspections and approvals required by the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(4)  Workmanship or work not in conformity with the provisions of this article or not in conformity with the permit issued therefor. 
(5)  Repeated violation of this article or failure or refusal to promptly correct an installation or part thereof made in an incompetent or improper manner or in violation of any provision of this article. 
(6)  Conviction of a felony involving the moral character of the registrant; provided such revocation or suspension is deemed necessary in the public interest. 
(7)  Whenever a certificate of registration has been suspended three times, any subsequent action because of any reason listed under subsections (c)(1) through (c)(10) of this section shall include the revocation of such certificate of registration. 
(8)  No certificate of registration shall be revoked until a public hearing has been held, at which hearing the registrant may appear in person or be represented by council. Public hearings relative to certificates of registration shall be held by the board of heating and air conditioning. 
(9)  A certificate of registration may be suspended for a prescribed period not exceeding six months, and the notice of suspension may require the person whose registration is suspended to correct work improperly installed, or to correct any other condition because of which such registration was suspended before such registration is reinstated. At the expiration of a suspension period, the registration shall be automatically reinstated, unless a new period of suspension is imposed for cause or registration is revoked. 
(10)  Whenever the board revokes or suspends a certificate of registration, it must notify the registrant by registered mail sent to the last known address and no work authorized by such certificate of registration holder can be performed by the registrant, except work necessary to correct a violation of this Code by the registrant and specified in the notice of suspension, until notice of reinstatement of certificate of registration is given by the board, or the period of suspension has expired; provided, however, that an appeal may be taken. 
(d)  Approval of materials, methods, equipment not covered by article. The board shall have the authority to approve any materials, devices, fixtures, methods of assemblage, appliances or types of installations not covered specifically by this article, but which are deemed to be at least as efficient and durable as those which are covered by the provisions of this article and article II of this chapter. 
(e)  Revisions of this article. It shall be the duty of the board to receive and consider suggestions for revision and/or improvements of this article, and if, in the board's judgment, such suggestions will contribute to the objectives of this article, the board shall submit such suggestions to the village standards commission for appropriate action. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2700-2700.5) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 46-378. - Heating and air conditioning inspector. 
(a)  Office created; title; conflicts of interest prohibited. 
(1)  There is hereby created the office of inspector for gravity and mechanical heating and air conditioning, stoker, natural and artificial gas burner, and oil burning installations. 
(2)  Such inspector shall be known as "inspector of heating and air conditioning;" and shall not, during his term of office, be employed or engaged, directly or indirectly, in any manner, with any person eligible for certificate of registration provided herein, or enter into any contract for work for others, covered by this article, or for furnishing materials, plans or specifications for others. 
(b)  Oath. The inspector of heating and air conditioning and/or his assistants shall, before entering upon his duties, take the oath required by law for city, state or county officials. 
(c)  Qualifications. The inspector of heating and air conditioning shall have had experience in engineering, planning, supervising and installation of heating and air conditioning systems, oil burners, gas burners, stokers; or shall have at least two years of practical training and, in addition, have satisfactorily completed a course of study in heating and air conditioning given by a recognized school. His work shall be coordinated with that of the building department. 
(d)  Term. The term of office of the inspector of heating and air conditioning and/or assistants, shall be in accordance with local regulations. 
(e)  Duties. The duties of the inspector of heating and air conditioning shall include the following: 
(1)  Issue all permits in accordance with article III of this chapter; 
(2)  Examine and approve when correct, all plans and specifications for the performance of any work governed by this article; 
(3)  Point out in what respect such plans or specifications are deficient or in violation of this article; 
(4)  Inspect all work in the area covered by this article for which permits are required under this article, and to see that all such work is performed in accordance with the provisions hereof; 
(5)  Stop any work being done in violation of this article and to post "stop work" signs therefor; 
(6)  Order any such work removed or corrected to conform with this article; 
(7)  Issue certificates of approval on satisfactory completion of projects; provided, however, that no "stop work" order so posted shall affect work not governed by this article, except where the progress of any such work would interfere with the inspection of work governed by this article; 
(8)  The properly accredited inspector of heating and air conditioning shall, by permission of the owner or occupant, or by due process of law, make an inspection where he has reasonable cause to believe work is being done, or has been performed in violation of this article, which violation might be a menace to life or health. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2800-2800.5) 
State Law reference- Oath of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25; power of president or clerk to administer oaths, 5 ILCS 255/1. 
Sec. 46-379. - Inspections. 
(a)  Notice; time and number of inspections. 
(1)  In any new building or addition, immediately upon completion of those portions of the installation which are thereafter to be concealed or covered, the heating and air conditioning contractor shall notify the village clerk, giving the location of the work, that said portions of the installations are ready for inspection; and it shall be unlawful for any person to lath over, plaster or cover up any heating work before such work has been inspected and the building permit card stamped approved by the inspector of heating and air conditioning. The inspector of heating and air conditioning shall have the right and authority to order the removal of all such lath, plaster or other covering which may have been placed over such work before same has been inspected. The inspector of heating and air conditioning must make inspection within two working days after notice, excepting Sundays and holidays. 
(2)  Final inspection, on new installations, to be made upon completion of such work. 
(3)  Inspection of repair, replacement or conversion work to be made upon completion of such work. 
(b)  Stop work order; notice; posting. Wherever any work or project governed by the provisions of this article and for which a permit has been issued, is being performed or carried on in violation of any of the provisions of this article, it shall be the duty of the inspector of heating and air conditioning to post a printed notice to "stop work" signed by the inspector of heating and air conditioning, on the premises where such work is in progress; and to notify anyone in charge of such work on the premises of such stop order. After the posting of such notice, it shall be unlawful for any person to do any further work on such project until such time as the defects or violations of this article have been eliminated to the approval of the inspector of heating and air conditioning and said "stop work" sign has been removed by him; provided, however, that no "stop work" order so posted shall affect work not governed by this article, except where the progress of any such work would interfere with inspection of work governed by this article. 
(c)  Violations. To fail or neglect to comply with the provisions of the heating and air conditioning code and of the permit issued under this article shall be considered a violation of this article. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2900-2900.3) 
Sec. 46-380. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article and who shall be found guilty thereof, shall be subject to the penalty provision provided in article I of this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 3000) 
Secs. 46-381-46-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MECHANICAL CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-401. - International Mechanical Code adopted. 
    The village adopts the International Mechanical Code, 2015 Edition, published by the International Code Council, for the control of building and structures as provided herein. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions, and terms of the adopted code are made a part hereof as if fully set forth herein, unless otherwise specifically provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 13-039, § 2, 8-20-2013; Ord. No. 16-011, § 3, 3-1-2016) 
Sec. 46-402. - Revisions and exceptions to adopted code. 
    The following sections are hereby revised: 
Section 101.1. Insert: VILLAGE OF LANSING. 
Section 106.5.2. Insert: Village of Lansing Fee Schedule. 
Section 106.5.3. Remove this section. 
Section 108.4. Remove this section and insert: Any person who violates this code or allows known violations to remain may receive a citation with fines up to $750 per violation. 
Section 108.5. Insert: $0, $750. 
(Ord. No. 13-039, § 2, 8-20-2013; Ord. No. 16-011, § 3, 3-1-2016) 
Secs. 46-403-46-420. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELEVATOR REGULATIONS 

Sec. 46-421. - Adoption of regulations and standards. 
    The following publications are adopted by the village as if fully set forth in this Code, as the regulations and standards applicable to elevators within the village: 
(1)  American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME): 
a.  Safety Code for Elevators and Escalators, ASME A17.1 et seq.-2005; ASME A17.1(a)-2005; ASME A17.1(s)-2005. 
b.  Guide for Inspection of Elevators, Escalators, and Moving Walks, ASME 17.2-2004. 
c.  Safety Code for Existing Elevators and Escalators, ASME 17.3-2005. 
d.  Safety Standard for Platform Lifts and Stairway Chairlifts, ASME A18.1-2005. 
e.  Standard for the Qualification of Elevator Inspectors, ASME QEI-1-2004. 
(2)  American National Standards (ANSI): Safety Requirements for Personal Hoists and Employee Elevators, ANSI A10.4-2004. 
(3)  American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE): Automated People Mover Standards, ASCE 21-2000. 
(Ord. No. 08-001, 1-15-2008) 
Sec. 46-422. - Amendments. 
    Should the village amend any of the standards set forth in this division, the village shall submit to the state fire marshal's office a copy of the amendment and the reason for the change. 
(Ord. No. 08-001, 1-15-2008) 
Sec. 46-423. - Required upgrades. 
    Upgrades required by ASME A17.34-2005, Safety Code for Existing Elevators, shall be completed no later than January 1, 2009, except that upgrades to the hydraulic cylinder system and firefighter control system shall be completed by January 1, 2011. 
(Ord. No. 08-001, 1-15-2008) 
Sec. 46-424. - Conflicts; this division controls. 
    If any provision of this division conflicts with any other provision of this Code, this division shall control and shall be applied as the village law. 
(Ord. No. 08-001, 1-15-2008) 
Secs. 46-425-46-434. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MINIMUM HOUSING STANDARDS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Development of safe and decent housing, 20 ILCS 605/605-945; State Housing Act, 310 ILCS 5/1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-435. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Administrative official means the president or department head designated by him to enforce this article or portion thereof. 
    Basement means a portion of the building partly underground, but having less than half its clear height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    Cellar means the portion of the building partly underground, having half or more than half of its clear height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    Dwelling means: 
(1)  One-family means a building containing one dwelling unit occupied by a family unit and with no more than three lodgers or boarders, all occupants of which live as a family unit. 
(2)  Multifamily means a building containing more than two dwelling units. 
(3)  Two-family means a building containing two dwelling units. 
    Dwelling unit means one or more rooms arranged for the use of one or more individuals living together as a single housekeeping unit, with cooking, living, sanitary and sleeping facilities. 
    Extermination means the control and elimination of insects, rodents or other pests by doing the following: 
(1)  Eliminating their harborage places; 
(2)  Removing or making inaccessible materials that may serve as their food; 
(3)  Poisoning, spraying, fumigating or trapping; or 
(4)  Any other recognized and legal pest elimination methods approved by the administrative official. 
    Family unit means one or more persons living, sleeping and cooking together as a single housekeeping unit. 
    Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking or consumption of food. 
    Habitable room means a room or enclosed floor space arranged for living, eating and sleeping purposes. The term "habitable room" does not include the following: 
(1)  Bathrooms; 
(2)  Water closet compartments; 
(3)  Laundries; 
(4)  Utility rooms; 
(5)  Pantries; 
(6)  Foyers; 
(7)  Hallways; and 
(8)  Other accessory floor space. 
    Infestation means the presence, within or around a dwelling, of any insects, rodents or other pests. 
    Occupant means any person over one year of age living, sleeping, cooking or eating in or having actual possession of a dwelling unit or rooming unit. 
    Operator means any person who has charge, care or control of a building or part thereof in which dwelling units or rooming units are let. 
    Owner means any person who alone, jointly or severally with others shall have the following: 
(1)  Title to any dwelling or dwelling unit with or without accompanying actual possession thereof; or 
(2)  Charge, care or control of any dwelling or dwelling unit as owner or agent of the owner, or as executor, administrator, trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner. Any such person thus representing the actual owner shall be bound to comply with the provisions of this article and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto to the same extent as if he were the owner. 
    Part of premises, etc., means whenever the words dwelling, dwelling unit, roominghouse, rooming unit or premises are used in this article, they shall be construed as though they were followed by the words or any part thereof. 
    Plumbing means all the following supplied facilities and equipment with connections to water, sewer or gas lines: 
(1)  Gas pipes; 
(2)  Gas-burning equipment; 
(3)  Water pipes; 
(4)  Garbage disposal units; 
(5)  Waste pipes; 
(6)  Water closets; 
(7)  Sinks; 
(8)  Installed dishwashers, lavatories, bathtubs and shower baths; 
(9)  Installed clothes-washing machines; 
(10)  Catchbasins, drains and vents; and 
(11)  Any other similar supplied fixtures. 
    Premises means the lot, plot or parcel of land, including the buildings and structures thereon. 
    Rubbish means combustible and noncombustible waste materials, except garbage, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Paper; 
(2)  Rags; 
(3)  Cartons, boxes and wood; 
(4)  Excelsior; 
(5)  Rubber; 
(6)  Leather; 
(7)  Tree branches and yard trimmings; 
(8)  Tin cans and metals; 
(9)  Mineral matter; 
(10)  Glass; 
(11)  Crockery; 
(12)  Dust; and 
(13)  Residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other combustible materials. 
    Supplied means paid for, furnished or provided by or under the control of the owner or operator, their agents or representatives. 
(Code 1969, § 13.102; Code 1982, § 15-1) 
Sec. 46-436. - Compliance required for occupancy. 
    No person shall occupy as owner-occupant or let to another for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking or eating therein which does not comply with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 13.101.2; Code 1982, § 15-2) 
Sec. 46-437. - Scope. 
    Every building used in whole or in part as a dwelling unit or as two or more dwelling units shall conform to the requirements of this article irrespective of the class to which such buildings may otherwise belong, and irrespective of when such buildings may have been constructed, altered or repaired. 
(Code 1969, § 13.101.1; Code 1982, § 15-3) 
Sec. 46-438. - Forms, rules and regulations adopted must conform to this article. 
    The administrative official is hereby authorized to adopt such forms, written rules and regulations as may be necessary for the proper enforcement of the provisions of this article; provided that such forms, written rules and regulations shall not be in conflict with the provisions of this article. The administrative official shall keep available for public inspection and use at the village hall copies of all forms, rules and regulations that may be adopted. 
(Code 1969, § 13.104; Code 1982, § 15-4) 
Sec. 46-439. - Inspections. 
    The administrative official or his authorized representative is hereby authorized and directed to make inspections to determine the condition of dwellings, dwelling units, rooming units and premises located within the village in order that he may perform his duty of safeguarding the health and safety of the occupants of dwellings and of the general public. 
(Code 1969, § 13.103.1; Code 1982, § 15-5) 
Sec. 46-440. - Offical's right of entry. 
    For the purpose of making inspections under this article, the administrative official or his authorized representative is hereby authorized to enter, examine and survey at all reasonable times all dwellings, dwelling units, rooming units and premises. 
(Code 1969, § 13.103.2; Code 1982, § 15-6) 
Sec. 46-441. - Owner's duty to permit access for inspection. 
    The owner or occupant of every dwelling, dwelling unit and rooming unit, or the person in charge thereof, shall give the administrative official or his authorized representative free access to such dwelling, dwelling unit or rooming unit and its premises at all reasonable times for the purpose of inspection, examination and survey under this article. 
(Code 1969, § 13.103.3; Code 1982, § 15-7) 
Sec. 46-442. - Owner's duty to permit access for repairs or alterations. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall give the owner thereof or his agent or employee access to any part of such dwelling or dwelling unit or its premises at all reasonable times for the purpose of making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with the provisions of this article or with any lawful rule or regulation adopted or order issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 13.103.4; Code 1982, § 15-8) 
Secs. 46-443-46-451. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONDEMNATION OF DWELLINGS 

Sec. 46-452. - Compliance required. 
    The designation of dwellings or dwelling units as unfit for human habitation and the procedure for the condemnation and placarding of such unfit dwellings or dwelling units shall be carried out in compliance with the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 13.111; Code 1982, § 15-21) 
Sec. 46-453. - Defects making premises unfit for human habitation. 
    Any dwelling or dwelling unit which shall be found to have any of the following defects shall be condemned as unfit for human habitation and the owner so notified as provided for in this article, after which it shall be so designated and placarded by the administrative official: 
(1)  One that is so damaged, decayed, dilapidated, unsanitary, unsafe or vermin-infested that it creates a serious hazard to the health or safety of the occupants or of the public. 
(2)  One that lacks illumination, ventilation or sanitation facilities adequate to protect the health or safety of the occupants or of the public. 
(3)  One that, because of its general condition or location, is unsanitary or otherwise dangerous to the health or safety of the occupants or of the public. 
(Code 1969, § 13.111; Code 1982, § 15-22) 
Sec. 46-454. - Vacating the premises. 
    Any dwelling or dwelling unit which is condemned as unfit for human habitation and is so designated and placarded by the administrative official shall be vacated within a reasonable time as ordered by such official. 
(Code 1969, § 13.111; Code 1982, § 15-23) 
Sec. 46-455. - Fit for human habitation with written approval and placard removal. 
    No dwelling or dwelling unit which has been condemned and placarded as unfit for human habitation shall again be used for human habitation until written approval is secured from and such placard is removed by the administrative official. Such official shall remove such placard whenever the defect upon which the condemnation and placarding action were based have been eliminated. 
(Code 1969, § 13.111; Code 1982, § 15-24) 
Sec. 46-456. - Defacing or removing placard prohibited. 
    No person shall deface or remove the placard from any dwelling or dwelling unit that has been condemned as unfit for human habitation and placarded as such, except as provided in section 46-455. 
(Code 1969, § 13.111; Code 1982, § 15-25) 
Sec. 46-457. - Hearing. 
    Any person affected by any notice or order relating to the condemning and placarding of a dwelling or dwelling unit as unfit for human habitation may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the president, under the procedure set forth in this article. 
(Code 1969, § 13.111; Code 1982, § 15-26) 
Secs. 46-458-46-476. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 46-477. - Notice; service. 
(a)  Whenever the administrative official determines there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provision of this article or of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto, he shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person responsible therefor. 
(b)  The notice shall be in writing; include a statement of the reasons why it is being issued; allow a reasonable time for the performance of any act it requires; and be served upon the owner or his agent, or the occupant, as the case may require; provided, however, that such notice shall be deemed to be properly served upon such owner, agent or occupant if any of the following occurs: 
(1)  A copy thereof is served upon him personally; 
(2)  If a copy thereof is sent by certified mail to his last known address; 
(3)  If a copy thereof is posted in a conspicuous place in or about the dwelling affected by the notice; or 
(4)  If he is served with such notice by any other method authorized or required under state law. 
(c)  The notice may contain an outline of remedial action that, if taken, will effect compliance with the provisions of this article and with rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 13.105; Code 1982, § 15-36) 
Sec. 46-478. - Notice becomes order if petition for hearing not filed. 
    Any notice served pursuant to section 46-477 shall automatically become an order if a written petition for a hearing is not filed in the village clerk's office within ten days after such notice is served. 
(Code 1969, § 13.107; Code 1982, § 15-37) 
Sec. 46-479. - Filing petition required for hearing. 
    Any person affected by any notice that has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this article or of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto may request, and shall be granted, a hearing on the matter before the president or his duly authorized representative; provided that such person shall file in the office of the village clerk a written petition requesting such hearing and setting forth a brief statement of the grounds therefor within ten days after the day the notice was served. Upon receipt of such petition, the president shall set a time and place for such hearing and shall give the petitioner written notice thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 13.106; Code 1982, § 15-38) 
Sec. 46-480. - Hearing procedure. 
(a)  At a hearing under this article, the petitioner and the administrative official shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show why the notice as to enforcement should be modified, withdrawn or sustained. 
(b)  The hearing shall commence no later than ten days after the day on which the petition was filed; provided that upon application of the petitioner, the president may postpone the date of the hearing for a reasonable time beyond such ten day period if, in his judgment, the petitioner has submitted a good and sufficient reason for such postponement. 
(c)  All hearings requested by any petitioner shall be open to the public. 
(Code 1969, § 13.106; Code 1982, § 15-39) 
Sec. 46-481. - Findings; order. 
    After a hearing under this division, the president, or his duly authorized representative shall sustain, modify or withdraw the notice, depending upon his findings as to whether the provisions of this article and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto have been complied with. If the president or his duly authorized representative sustains or modifies such notice, it shall be deemed to be an order. 
(Code 1969, § 13.107; Code 1982, § 15-40) 
Sec. 46-482. - Record of proceedings. 
    The proceedings at the hearing authorized by section 46-479, including the findings and decision of the president or his duly authorized representative, shall be summarized in writing and filed as a matter of public record with the village clerk. Such record shall also include a copy of every notice or order issued in connection with the matter. 
(Code 1969, § 13.108; Code 1982, § 15-41) 
Sec. 46-483. - Emergency procedure. 
(a)  Order without notice. Whenever the administrative official finds that an emergency under his jurisdiction exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, he may, without notice or hearing, issue an order reciting the existence of such an emergency and requiring that such action be taken as he deems necessary to meet the emergency. 
(b)  Order effective immediately; request for hearing. Notwithstanding the other provisions of this article, such order shall be effective immediately. Any person to whom such order is directed shall comply therewith immediately, but upon request to the president or his duly authorized representative, shall be afforded an immediate hearing to determine whether or not such an emergency exists. 
(c)  Hearing; findings. If at such a hearing it is determined that such emergency does exist, the order shall continue in effect. If it is found that such an emergency does not exist, the order shall be revoked and proceedings instituted as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Code 1969, § 13.109; Code 1982, § 15-42) 
Sec. 46-484. - Noncompliance with order; enforcement; owner liable for costs. 
    Should an emergency order under this division not be complied with, the administrative official shall take all necessary steps to ensure compliance with the order as expeditiously as possible. All costs of such action shall be paid by the village, and the village shall be entitled to recover all costs involved in such action from the owner of the premises. 
(Code 1969, § 13.109; Code 1982, § 15-43) 
Sec. 46-485. - Appeal. 
    Any person aggrieved by an order issued under the provisions of section 46-483 may seek relief therefrom in any court of competent jurisdiction, as provided by state law. 
(Code 1969, § 13.110; Code 1982, § 15-44) 
Secs. 46-486-46-504. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BASIC STANDARDS 

Sec. 46-505. - Compliance required. 
    No person shall occupy as owner-occupant, or let to another for occupancy; any dwelling or dwelling unit for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking or eating therein which does not comply with the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 13.201; Code 1982, § 15-56) 
Sec. 46-506. - Safe, unobstructed egress. 
    Every dwelling and dwelling unit shall have safe, unobstructed means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level. 
(Code 1969, § 13.201; Code 1982, § 15-57) 
Sec. 46-507. - Properly connected hot/cold water lines. 
    Every required kitchen sink, lavatory basin and bathtub or shower shall be properly connected with both hot and cold water lines. 
(Code 1969, § 13.201; Code 1982, § 15-58) 
Sec. 46-508. - Properly installed and maintained water-heating facilities. 
    Every dwelling shall have in operation water-heating facilities which are properly installed, are maintained in safe and good working condition, are properly connected with the required hot water lines and are capable of heating water to such a temperature as to permit an adequate amount of water to be drawn at every required kitchen sink, lavatory basin, bathtub or shower at a temperature of no less than 120 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Code 1969, § 13.201; Code 1982, § 15-59) 
Sec. 46-509. - Private bathroom connected to approved water and sewer system. 
    Every dwelling unit shall contain a room which affords privacy to a person within said room, and which is equipped with a flush water closet, a lavatory basin and a bathtub or shower, in good working condition and properly connected to an approved water and sewer system. 
(Code 1969, § 13.201; Code 1982, § 15-60) 
Sec. 46-510. - Kitchen sink in good working condition. 
    Every dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen sink in good working condition and properly connected to an approved water and sewer system. 
(Code 1969, § 13.201; Code 1982, § 15-61) 
Sec. 46-511. - Adequate garbage disposal facilities. 
    Every dwelling and dwelling unit shall have adequate garbage disposal facilities or garbage storage containers, type and location of which conform with applicable provisions of this Code and village ordinances. 
(Code 1969, § 13.201; Code 1982, § 15-62) 
Sec. 46-512. - Adequate rubbish storage facilities. 
    Every dwelling and dwelling unit shall have adequate rubbish storage facilities, type and location of which conform to applicable provisions of this Code and village ordinances. 
(Code 1969, § 13.201; Code 1982, § 15-63) 
Secs. 46-513-46-531. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - DUTIES OF OWNERS AND OCCUPANTS 

Sec. 46-532. - Keep dwelling unit in clean, sanitary condition. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall keep in a clean and sanitary condition that part of the dwelling, dwelling unit and premises thereof that he occupies and controls. 
(Code 1969, § 13.205.2; Code 1982, § 15-71) 
Sec. 46-533. - Keep plumbing fixtures in clean, sanitary condition; reasonable care required. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling unit shall keep all plumbing fixtures therein in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be responsible for the exercise of reasonable care in the proper use and operation thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 13.205.7; Code 1982, § 15-72) 
Sec. 46-534. - Install screens when required by law. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall be responsible for installing all screens whenever the same are required under the provisions of this article or of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 13.205.5; Code 1982, § 15-73) 
Sec. 46-535. - Dispose of garbage properly. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall dispose of all garbage and any other organic waste which might provide food for rodents in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in the garbage disposal facilities or garbage storage containers required by applicable sections of this Code and village ordinances. 
(Code 1969, § 13.205.4; Code 1982, § 15-74) 
Sec. 46-536. - Use appropriate rubbish containers. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall dispose of all rubbish in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in the rubbish containers required by applicable sections of this Code and village ordinances. 
(Code 1969, § 13.205.3; Code 1982, § 15-75) 
Sec. 46-537. - Keep shared or public areas in clean, sanitary condition. 
    Every owner of a dwelling containing two or more dwelling units shall be responsible for maintaining in a clean and sanitary condition the shared or public areas of the dwelling and premises thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 13.205.1; Code 1982, § 15-76) 
Sec. 46-538. - Exterminate pests. 
    Every occupant of a single dwelling unit shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests therein or on the premises. Whenever infestation exists in any dwelling unit in any two-family or multifamily dwelling, or in the shared or public parts of any dwelling containing two or more dwelling units, extermination thereof shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
(Code 1969, §§ 13.204, 13.205.6; Code 1982, § 15-77) 
Sec. 46-539. - Erection and take down of holiday decorations. 
    Holiday decorations, displayed for holidays scheduled between the dates of March 16 and November 14, including, but not limited to, holiday lights on houses or in the yard or shrubbery, yard ornaments or decorations, and the like, shall not be installed or placed more than 30 days before the date of the holiday for which said decorations are intended and shall be removed within a reasonable amount of time, not to exceed 30 days, following the date of the holiday for which said decorations were intended. Holiday decorations, displayed for holidays scheduled between the dates of November 15 and March 15 shall not be installed or placed more than 45 days before the date of the holiday for which said decorations are intended and shall be removed within a reasonable amount of time, not to exceed 45 days following the date of the holiday for which said decorations were intended. Holiday lights, even if not illuminated, are not permitted to remain on any house or structure year-round. Weather conditions, such as extreme cold or excessive rainfall, may result in the allowance of an additional time period, to be determined by the code official, for removal of lights and decorations. Also, in the event that residents have a loved one serving in the military who will be home after the required time for removal, a request may be made for a waiver to allow for the decorations to remain until the person serving in the military has a chance to enjoy them. 
(Ord. No. 14-035, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Secs. 46-540-46-557. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - SPACE USE AND LOCATION 

Sec. 46-558. - Compliance required. 
    No person shall occupy or let to another for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit for the purpose of living therein which does not comply with the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 13.203; Code 1982, § 15-96) 
Sec. 46-559. - Total floor space computations. 
    Every dwelling unit shall contain at least 150 square feet of floor space for the first occupant thereof and at least 100 additional square feet of floor space for every additional occupant thereof, the floor space to be calculated on the basis of total habitable room area. Persons over one year of age, who have not attained their 11th birthday, shall be counted as a half-occupant. 
(Code 1969, § 13.203; Code 1982, § 15-97) 
Sec. 46-560. - Cellars not to be used for sleeping or dwelling. 
    No cellar space shall be used as a sleeping room or dwelling unit. 
(Code 1969, § 13.203; Code 1982, § 15-98) 
Sec. 46-561. - Basement requirements. 
    No basement space shall be used as a habitable room or dwelling unit, unless: 
(1)  The floor and walls are impervious to leakage of underground and surface runoff water and are insulated against dampness; 
(2)  The total of window area in each room is equal to at least the minimum window area sizes, as required herein; 
(3)  Such required minimum window area is located entirely above the grade of the ground adjoining such window area; and 
(4)  The total of openable window area in each room is equal to at least the minimum as required herein, except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate ventilation and approved by the administrative official. 
(Code 1969, § 13.203; Code 1982, § 15-99) 
Sec. 46-562. - Ceiling height specifications. 
    At least one-half of the floor area of every habitable room shall have a ceiling height of at least 71/2 feet; and the floor area of that part of any room where the ceiling height is less than five feet shall not be considered as part of the floor area in computing the total floor area of the room for the purpose of determining the maximum permissible occupancy thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 13.203; Code 1982, § 15-100) 
Sec. 46-563. - Bedroom requirements; exception. 
    In every dwelling unit of two or more rooms, every bedroom shall contain at least 50 square feet of floor space for each occupant thereof who has attained his 11th birthday, and 25 square feet for each occupant who has attained his first birthday, but not his 11th birthday, except that two occupants may use a bedroom containing 80 square feet or more of floor space; but in no case shall the number of occupants exceed four per bedroom. 
(Code 1969, § 13.203; Code 1982, § 15-101) 
Sec. 46-564. - Additional rooms available for sleeping purposes; exceptions. 
    The remaining habitable area, except kitchens, utility rooms and cellars, may be occupied for sleeping purposes by one occupant for each 150 square feet. 
(Code 1969, § 13.203; Code 1982, § 15-102) 
Sec. 46-565. - Access to bathrooms and sleeping rooms. 
    Access to a bathroom or water closet compartment from a sleeping room shall not be through another sleeping room; nor shall access to a sleeping room be through another sleeping room or a bathroom or water closet compartment. 
(Code 1969, § 13.203; Code 1982, § 15-103) 
Secs. 46-566-46-584. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - LIGHT, VENTILATION AND HEATING 

Sec. 46-585. - Compliance required. 
    No person shall occupy as owner-occupant, or let to another for occupancy, any dwelling or dwelling unit for the purpose of living therein that does not comply with the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 13.202; Code 1982, § 15-116) 
Sec. 46-586. - Lighting public halls and stairways. 
    Every public hall and stairway in every multiple dwelling containing five or more dwelling units shall be adequately lighted at all times. Every public hall and stairway in structures devoted solely to dwelling occupancy and containing no more than four dwelling units, may be supplied with conveniently located light switches controlling an adequate lighting system which may be turned on when needed, instead of fulltime lighting. 
(Code 1969, § 13.202; Code 1982, § 15-117) 
Sec. 46-587. - Screen protection against insects; self-closing devices. 
    During that portion of each year when the administrative official deems it necessary for protection against mosquitoes, flies and other insects, every exterior door shall have screens, which protect against the entry of such insects, and be equipped with a self-closing device, wherever applicable and available; and every window or other device with openings to outdoor space used or intended to be used for ventilation shall likewise have screens which protect against the entry of such insects. 
(Code 1969, § 13.202; Code 1982, § 15-118) 
Sec. 46-588. - Securing basement entries against rodents. 
    Every basement or cellar window used or intended to be used for ventilation, and every other opening to a basement which might provide entry for rodents, shall be supplied with a screen or such other device as will effectively prevent their entrance. 
(Code 1969, § 13.202; Code 1982, § 15-119) 
Sec. 46-589. - Ventilation; one window or skylight per habitable room. 
    Habitable rooms, but not including bedrooms or kitchens, shall have at least one unobstructed window or skylight which can easily be opened, or such other device as will adequately ventilate the room. The total of openable window area in every habitable room shall be equal to at least 50 percent of the minimum window area size or minimum skylight-type window size, as required in this division, except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate ventilation and approved by the administrative official. 
(Code 1969, § 13.202; Code 1982, § 15-120) 
Sec. 46-590. - Exceptions to lighting and ventilation requirements. 
    Every kitchen, bathroom and water closet compartment shall comply with the light and ventilation requirements for habitable rooms contained in sections 46-589 and 46-591, except that no window or skylight shall be required in adequately lighted and ventilated kitchens, bathrooms and water closet compartments equipped with an electrical and ventilation system approved by the administrative official. 
(Code 1969, § 13.202; Code 1982, § 15-121) 
Sec. 46-591. - Window and skylight specifications-Habitable rooms. 
    Habitable rooms, but not including bedrooms or kitchens, shall have at least one unobstructed window or skylight facing directly to the outdoors. The minimum total window area, measured between stops, for every habitable room, shall be ten percent of the floor area of such room. Whenever the only window in a room is a skylight-type window in the top of such room, the total window area of such skylight shall equal at least 15 percent of the total floor area of such room. 
(Code 1969, § 13.202; Code 1982, § 15-122) 
Sec. 46-592. - Same-Bedrooms. 
    Every bedroom shall have at least one unobstructed window facing directly to the outside that can easily be opened. The minimum total window area measured between stops shall be ten percent of the floor area of such bedroom. The total of openable window area in every bedroom shall be equal to at least 50 percent of the minimum window area size. 
(Code 1969, § 13.202; Code 1982, § 15-123) 
Sec. 46-593. - Heating. 
    Every dwelling shall have heating facilities which are properly installed, are maintained in safe and good working condition and are capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms, bathrooms and water closet compartments in every dwelling unit located therein to a temperature of at least 70 degrees Fahrenheit, at a distance three feet above floor level, when the outside temperature is ten degrees below zero, Fahrenheit. 
(Code 1969, § 13.202; Code 1982, § 15-124) 
Sec. 46-594. - Electricity. 
    Every habitable room of each dwelling shall conform to the village electrical code (article III of this chapter). Every such outlet and fixture shall be properly installed and maintained in a good, safe working condition and shall be connected to the source of electric power in a safe manner. 
(Code 1969, § 13.202; Code 1982, § 15-125) 
Secs. 46-595-46-613. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 46-614. - Compliance required. 
    No person shall occupy as owner-occupant, or let to another for occupancy, any dwelling unit or portion thereof for the purpose of living therein, which does not comply with the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-136) 
Sec. 46-615. - Shared or public areas must be maintained in a safe, sanitary condition. 
    Every owner of a dwelling containing two or more dwelling units, and every owner of a premises where two or more dwelling units share the same premises, shall be responsible for maintaining in a clean and sanitary condition all communal, shared or public areas of the dwelling and premises thereof which are used or shared by the occupants of two or more dwelling units. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-137) 
Sec. 46-616. - Vacant unit cannot be occupied until in a safe, sanitary condition and conforms to all regulations of this article. 
    No owner shall occupy or let to any other person for occupancy or allow any other person to occupy any vacant dwelling unit, unless it is reasonably clean and sanitary and complies with all provisions of this article and all rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-138) 
Sec. 46-617. - Proper drainage required. 
    All rainwater shall be so drained and conveyed from every lot so as not to cause dampness in the walls, ceiling or floors of any residence. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-139) 
Sec. 46-618. - Building must be in good repair. 
    Every foundation, exterior wall and room shall be reasonably weathertight, watertight, rodentproof and insectproof and shall be kept in a good state of maintenance and repair. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-140) 
Sec. 46-619. - Interior partitions, walls, floors and ceilings. 
    Every interior partition, wall, floor and ceiling shall be capable of affording privacy and shall be kept in a good state of repair and maintained so as to permit them to be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-141) 
Sec. 46-620. - Gutters, trim, etc. 
    Where gutters, downspouts or metal trim are provided, such items shall be kept in a good state of maintenance and repair. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-142) 
Sec. 46-621. - Exterior wood surfaces shall be reasonably protected from the weather. 
    All exterior wood surfaces shall be reasonably protected from the elements and against decay by paint or other approved protective coating applied in a workmanlike fashion. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-143) 
Sec. 46-622. - Windows and exterior doors must be weatherproof and rodentproof. 
    Every window and exterior door shall be reasonably weathertight and rodentproof and shall be kept in good working condition and in a good state of maintenance and repair. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-144) 
Sec. 46-623. - Stairways and porches. 
    Every inside and outside stairway, every porch and every appurtenance thereto shall be kept in sound condition and in a good state of maintenance and repair. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-145) 
Sec. 46-624. - Plumbing fixtures. 
    Every plumbing fixture and water and waste pipe shall be maintained in a good sanitary working condition. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-146) 
Sec. 46-625. - Ducts, chimneys and smoke pipes. 
    Every duct, chimney and smoke pipe shall be adequately supported, reasonably clean and maintained in a good state of repair. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-147) 
Sec. 46-626. - Bathroom floors must be protected from water, clean and sanitary. 
    Every toilet room floor surface and bathroom floor surface shall be maintained so as to be reasonably impervious to water so as to permit such floor to be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-148) 
Sec. 46-627. - Appliances, utility connections, etc. 
    Every facility, appliance, piece of equipment or utility connection thereto shall be so installed that it will function properly and shall be maintained in good working condition. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-149) 
Sec. 46-628. - Discontinuance of services prohibited; exception. 
    No owner, lessor or operator shall cause any service, facility, equipment or utility, which is required to be supplied under the provisions of this article, to be removed from or shut off from or discontinued for any occupied dwelling or dwelling unit let or occupied by him, except for such temporary interruption as may be necessary while actual repairs, replacements or alterations are in the process of being made. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-150) 
Sec. 46-629. - Exterminate pests. 
    Every owner of a dwelling shall be responsible for the extermination of insects, rodents or other pests on the premises. 
(Code 1969, § 13.204; Code 1982, § 15-151) 
Secs. 46-630-46-648. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PLUMBING CODE[9] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Authority for municipalities to regulation plumbing systems, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-5; requirement for local regulation and inspection of plumbing systems, 225 ILCS 320/18; minimum code of plumbing standards, 225 ILCS 320/35; authority for municipal adoption of minimum plumbing standards code, 225 ILCS 320/36; authority for enforcement of plumbing ordinances and resolutions, 225 ILCS 320/37. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-649. - State plumbing code adopted. 
    The village adopts the Illinois Plumbing Code, 77 Ill. Admin. Code 890, including all applicable appendix chapters thereof, for regulating the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of plumbing systems in the village and providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions, and terms of the adopted code are made a part hereof as if fully set forth herein, unless otherwise specifically provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 05-001, § 1, 1-18-2005)

Secs. 46-651-46-669. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONTROL OF BACKFLOW AND CROSS CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 46-670. - Plumbing inspector's authority; inspection. 
(a)  Responsibility of the building department; plumbing inspector. The building department shall inspect the plumbing in every building or premises in the village as frequently as in its judgment may be necessary to ensure that such plumbing has been installed in such a manner as to prevent the possibility of pollution of the village water supply. The plumbing inspector shall notify or cause to be notified in writing the owner or authorized agent of the owner of any such building or premises, to correct, within a reasonable time set by the plumbing inspector, any plumbing installed or existing contrary to or in violation of this division, and which in his judgment, may, therefore, permit the pollution of the village water supply, or otherwise adversely affect the public health. This plumbing inspector shall report directly to the building commissioner. 
(b)  Inspection; right of entry. The plumbing inspector shall have the right of entry into any building, during reasonable hours, for the purpose of making inspections of the plumbing systems in such building or premises; provided that with respect to the inspection of any single-family dwelling, consent to such inspection shall first be obtained from a person of suitable age and discretion therein or in control thereof. 
(Ord. No. 82-006, §§ 1-1.3, 2-16-1982; Ord. No. 90-031, § 8, 10-16-1990; Ord. No. 93-029, § 8, 6-15-1993) 
Sec. 46-671. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agency means the department of the municipal government invested with the authority and responsibility for the enactment and enforcement of this article. 
    Airgap means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture, or other device and the flood-level rim of the receptacle. 
    Approved means accepted by the agency as meeting an applicable specification stated or cited in this article, or as suitable for the proposed use. 
    Auxiliary supply means any water source or system other than the potable water supply that may be available in the building or premises. 
    Backflow means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures, or substances into the distributing pipes of a potable supply of water from any source other than its intended source. Backsiphonage is one type of backflow. 
    Backflow preventer means a device to prevent backflow. 
    Backsiphonage means backflow resulting from negative pressures in the distributing pipes of a potable water supply. 
    Check valve means a self-closing device which is designed to permit the flow of fluids in one direction and to close if there is a reversal of flow. 
    Contamination. See Pollution. 
    Cross connection means any physical connection between a potable water supply and any waste pipe, soil pipe, sewer, drain, or any unapproved source or system. Furthermore, it is any potable water supply outlet which is submerged or can be submerged in waste water and/or any other source of contamination. See Backflow and Siphonage. 
    Drain means any pipe that carries wastewater or waterborne wastes in a building drainage system. 
    Fixture, plumbing, means installed receptacles, devices, or appliances supplied with water or that receive or discharge liquids or liquid-borne wastes. 
    Flood-level rim means the edge of the receptacle from which water overflows. 
    Hazard, health, means any conditions, devices, or practices in the water supply system and its operation which create, or, in the judgment of the superintendent, may create, a danger to the health and well-being of the water consumer. The term "health hazard" includes a structural defect in the water supply system, whether of location, design, or construction, that regularly or occasionally may prevent satisfactory purification of the water supply or cause it to be polluted from extraneous sources. 
    Hazard, plumbing, means any arrangement of plumbing, including piping and fixtures whereby a cross connection is created. 
    Hydropneumatic tank means a pressure vessel in which air pressure acts upon the surface of the water contained within the vessel, pressurizing the water distribution piping connected to the vessel. 
    Inlet means the open end of the water supply pipe through which the water is discharged into the plumbing fixture. 
    Plumbing system includes the water supply and distribution pipes, plumbing fixtures, and traps; soil, waste, and vent pipes; building drains and building sewers including their respective connections, devices, and appurtenances within the property lines of the premises; and water-treating or water-using equipment. 
    Pollution means the presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological, or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water. 
    Reduced pressure principle backflow preventer means an assembly of differential valves and check valves, including an automatically opened spillage port to the atmosphere designed to prevent backflow. 
    Surge tank means the receiving, nonpressure vessel forming part of the airgap separation between a potable and an auxiliary supply. 
    Vacuum means any pressure less than that exerted by the atmosphere. 
    Vacuum breaker, nonpressure type, means a vacuum breaker designed so as not to be subjected to static line pressure. 
    Vacuum breaker, pressure type, means a vacuum breaker designed to operate under conditions of static line pressure. 
    Water, nonpotable, means water that is not safe for human consumption or that is of questionable potability. 
    Water, potable, means water free from impurities in amounts sufficient to cause disease or harmful physiological effects. Its bacteriological and chemical quality shall conform to the requirements of the Federal Drinking Water Standards or to the regulations of the public health authority having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 82-006, §§ 2-2.26, 2-16-1982) 
Sec. 46-672. - Requirements. 
(a)  Potable water supply system. A potable water supply system shall be designed, installed, and maintained in such manner as to prevent contamination from nonpotable liquids, solids, or gases from being introduced into the potable water supply through cross connections or any other piping connections to the system. 
(b)  Cross connections prohibited. Cross connections between potable water systems and other systems or equipment containing water or other substances of unknown or questionable safety are prohibited, except when and where, as approved by the authority having jurisdiction, suitable protective devices such as the reduced pressure zone backflow preventer or equal are installed, tested, and maintained to ensure proper operation on a continuing basis. 
(c)  Interconnections; approval. Interconnection between two or more public water supplies shall be permitted only with the approval of the health authority having jurisdiction. 
(d)  Individual water supplies. Cross connections between an individual water supply and a potable public supply shall not be made, unless specifically approved by the health authority having jurisdiction. 
(e)  Connections to boilers. Potable water connections to boilers shall be made through an airgap or provided with an approved backflow preventer. 
(f)  Prohibited connections to fixtures and equipment. Connection to the potable water supply system for the following is prohibited, unless protected against backflow in accordance with subsection (g) of this section. 
(1)  Bidets. 
(2)  Pumps for nonpotable water, chemicals, or other substances: priming connections may be made only through an airgap. 
(3)  Building drainage, sewer, or vent systems. 
(4)  Any other fixture of similar hazard. 
(g)  Protection against backflow and backsiphonage. The following shall be used to prevent against backflow and backsiphonage: 
(1)  Water outlets. A potable water system shall be protected against backflow and backsiphonage by providing and maintaining at each outlet: 
a.  An airgap, as specified in subsection (g)(2) of this section, between the potable water outlet and the flood level rim of the fixture it supplies or between the outlet and any other source of contamination; or 
b.  A backflow preventer. 
(2)  Minimum required airgap. A potable water system shall be protected against backflow and backsiphonage by providing and maintaining airgaps as follows: 
a.  How measured. The minimum required airgap shall be measured vertically from the lowest end of a potable water outlet to the flood rim or line of the fixture or receptacle into which it discharges. 
b.  Size. The minimum required airgap shall be twice the effective opening of a potable water outlet, unless the outlet is a distance less than three times the effective opening away from a wall or similar vertical surface, in which cases the minimum required airgap shall be three times the effective opening of the outlet. 
(3)  Approval of devices. Before any device for the prevention of backflow or backsiphonage is installed, it shall have first been certified by a recognized testing laboratory acceptable to the agency. Devices installed in a building potable water supply distribution system for protection against backflow shall be maintained in a good working condition by the person responsible for the maintenance of the system. The superintendent of public works or his designee shall inspect routinely such devices and if found to be defective or inoperative shall require the replacement thereof. 
(4)  Installation of devices. A potable water system shall be protected against backflow and backsiphonage by providing and maintaining the following devices: 
a.  Vacuum breakers. Vacuum breakers shall be installed with the critical level at least six inches above the flood level rim of the fixture they serve and on the discharge side of the last control valve to the fixture. No shutoff valve or faucet shall be installed beyond the vacuum breaker. For closed equipment or vessels such as pressure sterilizers, the top of the vessel shall be treated as the flood level rim, but a check valve shall be installed on the discharge side of the vacuum breaker. 
b.  Reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. A reduced pressure principle type backflow preventer may be installed subject to full static pressure. 
c.  Devices of all types. Backflow and backsiphonage preventing devices shall be accessibly located, preferably in the same room with the fixture they serve. Installation in utility or service spaces; provided they are readily accessible, is also permitted. 
(5)  Tanks and vats below rim supply. A potable water system shall be protected against backflow and backsiphonage by providing and maintaining tanks and vats below the rim as follows: 
a.  Where a potable water outlet terminates below the rim of a tank or vat and the tank or vat has an overflow of a diameter that is in compliance with state statute or the village's technical codes, whichever is stricter. 
b.  The potable water outlet to the tank or vat shall terminate at a distance no less than 11/2 times the height to which water can rise in the tank above the top of the overflow. This level shall be established at the maximum flow rate of the supply to the tank or vat and with all outlets, except the airgap overflow outlet closed. 
c.  The distance from the outlet to the high water level shall be measured from the critical point of the potable water supply outlet. 
(6)  Protective devices required. Approved devices to protect against backflow and backsiphonage shall be installed at all fixtures and equipment where backflow and/or backsiphonage may occur and where a minimum airgap cannot be provided between the water outlet to the fixture or equipment and its flood-level rim. 
a.  Connections not subject to backpressure. Where a water connection is not subject to backpressure, a vacuum breaker shall be installed on the discharge side of the last valve on the line serving the fixture or equipment. 
b.  Connections subject to backpressure. Where a potable water connection is made to a line, fixture, tank, vat, pump, or other equipment with a hazard of backflow or backsiphonage where the water connection is subject to backpressure, and an airgap cannot be installed, the superintendent may require the use of an approved reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. 
(7)  Double check-double gate valves. The superintendent may authorize installation of approved, double check-double gate valve assemblies with test cocks as protective devices against backflow in connections between a potable water system and other fluid systems which present no significant health hazard in the judgment of the superintendent. 
(8)  Low pressure cutoff required on booster pumps. When a booster pump is used on a water pressure booster system and the possibility exists that a positive pressure of ten psi or less may occur on the suction side of the pump, there shall be installed a low-pressure cutoff on the booster pump to prevent the creation of a vacuum or negative pressure on the suction side of the pump, thus cutting off water to other outlets. 
(Ord. No. 82-006, §§ 3-3.7.8, 2-16-1982) 
Sec. 46-673. - Maintenance requirements. 
(a)  Owner's responsibility. It shall be the responsibility of building and premises owners to maintain all backflow preventers and vacuum breakers within the building or on the premises in good working order and to make no piping or other arrangements for the purpose of bypassing backflow devices. 
(b)  Backflow preventers; testing and inspection. Periodic testing and inspection schedules shall be established by the superintendent for all backflow preventers and the interval between such testing and inspections and overhauls of each device shall be established in accordance with the age and condition of the device. Inspection intervals should not exceed one year, and overhaul intervals should not exceed five years. These devices should be inspected frequently after the initial installation to ensure that they have been installed properly and that debris resulting from the installation has not interfered with the functioning of the device. The testing procedures shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions when approved by the superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 82-006, §§ 4-4.2, 2-16-1982) 
Sec. 46-674. - Indemnification. 
(a)  Agreement required; owner liable for damage. The owner at the time of securing a permit to tap into the municipal water supply who maintains a separate source of water through an individual well shall execute an indemnity agreement with the village, in a form approved by the village attorney, to indemnify and hold harmless the village from all costs, claims, or expense which it may incur as a result of backflow into the municipal system caused by any defect or deterioration in the cross connection system installed by the owner. 
(b)  Recording; runs with property. The indemnity agreement is to be recorded or registered as a covenant that will run with the real estate so as to bind executors, heirs, administrators, and assigns. 
(c)  Enforcement. The superintendent may cut off the municipal water supply to any owner until the indemnity agreement is executed. 
(Ord. No. 82-006, §§ 5-5.3, 2-16-1982) 
Sec. 46-675. - Penalty. 
(a)  Notice. The superintendent shall notify the owner, or authorized agent of the owner, of the building or premises in which there is found a violation of this article, of such violation. The superintendent shall set a reasonable time for the owner to have the violation removed or corrected. Upon failure of the owner to have the defect corrected by the end of the specified time interval the superintendent may, if in his judgment an imminent health hazard exists, cause the water service to the building or premises to be terminated, and/or recommend such additional fines or penalties to be invoked as herein may be provided. 
(b)  Fines. The owner or authorized agent of the owner responsible for the maintenance of the plumbing systems in the building who knowingly permits a violation to remain uncorrected after the expiration of time set by the superintendent shall, upon conviction thereof by the court, be required to pay a fine of no more than $100.00 for each violation. Each day of failure to comply with the requirements of this article, after the specified time provided under subsection (a) of this section, shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 82-006, §§ 6-6.2, 2-16-1982) 
Secs. 46-676-46-694. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XI. - DANGEROUS BUILDINGS 

Sec. 46-737. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dangerous building includes: 
(1)  Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which is dangerous to the public health because of its construction or condition, or which may cause or aid in the spread of disease or cause injury to the health of the occupants of it or of neighboring structures; 
(2)  Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which, because of faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is especially liable to fire and constitutes or creates a fire hazard; 
(3)  Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which, by reason of faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is liable to cause injury or damage by collapsing or by a collapse or all of any part of such a structure; and 
(4)  Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which, because of its condition or because of lack of doors or windows, is available to be frequented by malefactors or disorderly persons who are not lawful occupants of such structure. 
(Code 1982, § 30-431) 
Sec. 46-738. - Declared nuisance. 
    Any dangerous building in the village is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1982, § 30-432) 
Sec. 46-739. - Prohibition. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain or permit the existence of any dangerous building in the village; and it shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or person in custody of any dangerous building to permit the same to remain in a dangerous condition, or to occupy such building or permit it to be occupied while it is or remains in a dangerous condition. 
(Code 1982, § 30-433) 
Sec. 46-740. - Abatement; notice. 
(a)  Whenever the building commissioner, fire chief, health commissioner or any other officer or employee of the village shall be of the opinion that any building or structure in the village is a dangerous building, he shall file a written statement to this effect with the village clerk. The clerk shall thereupon cause written notice to be served upon the owner thereof, and upon the occupant thereof, if any, by registered mail or by personal service. Such notice shall state that the building has been declared to be in a dangerous condition, and that such dangerous condition must be removed or remedied by repairing or altering the building or by demolishing it; and that the condition must be remedied at once. Such notice may be in the following terms: 
    "To ___________ (owner-occupant of premises) of the premises known and described as: ___________. 
    "You are hereby notified that ___________ (describe building) on the premises above mentioned has been condemned as a nuisance and a dangerous building after inspection by ___________. 
    "The causes for this decision are ___________ (here insert the facts as to the dangerous condition). 
    "You must remedy this condition or demolish the building immediately, or the Village of Lansing will proceed to do so." 
(b)  If the person receiving the notice has not complied therewith or taken an appeal from the determination of the officer or employee finding that a dangerous building exists, within ten days from the time when this notice is served upon such person by personal service or registered mail, the building commissioner may, upon orders of the president and board of trustees, proceed to remedy the condition or demolish the dangerous building. 
(Code 1982, § 30-434) 
Sec. 46-741. - Buildings or structures substantially damaged by fire; notice. 
(a)  Any frame building or structure within the village fire limits that has been or may be damaged by fire, decay or other causes to the extent of 50 percent of its value, shall be torn down and removed, or rebuilt with nonflammable walls. 
(b)  Upon written notice by the building commissioner, health officer, fire chief or any other officer or employee to the effect that such building has been so damaged, filed with the clerk, the said clerk shall notify the president and board of trustees of the receipt of such notice. 
(Code 1982, § 30-435) 
Sec. 46-742. - Emergency measures. 
(a)  Vacating buildings. When, in the opinion of the building commissioner, there is actual and immediate danger of failure or collapse of a building or structure or any part thereof which would endanger life, or when any structure or part of a structure has fallen and life is endangered by the occupation of the building, the building commissioner is hereby authorized and empowered to order and require the occupants to vacate the same forthwith. He shall cause to be posted at each entrance to such building a notice reading as follows: 
"THIS BUILDING IS UNSAFE AND ITS USE OR 
OCCUPANCY HAS BEEN PROHIBITED BY THE 
BUILDING COMMISSIONER" 
And it shall be unlawful for any person to enter such building or structure, except for the purpose of making the required repairs or of demolishing the same. 
(b)  Temporary safeguards. When, in the opinion of the building commissioner, there is an actual and immediate danger of collapse or failure of a building or structure or any part thereof which would endanger life, he shall cause the necessary work to be done to render such building or structure or part thereof temporarily safe, whether or not the legal procedure herein described has been instituted. 
(c)  Closing streets. When necessary for the public safety, the building commissioner may temporarily close sidewalks, streets, buildings and structures and places adjacent to such unsafe buildings, and prohibit the same from being used. 
(d)  Repairs. For the purpose of this section the building commissioner shall employ the necessary labor and materials to perform the required work as expeditiously as possible. 
(e)  Costs of repairs; owner liable. Costs incurred in the performance of emergency work shall be paid from the municipal treasury on certificate of the building commissioner; and the legal authority of the municipality shall institute appropriate action against the owner of the premises where the unsafe building or structure was located for the recovery of such costs. 
(Code 1982, § 30-436) 
Secs. 46-743-46-761. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - FEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-762. - Permits. 
(a)  No permit to begin work for new construction, alteration, removal, demolition or other building operation shall be issued until the owner or his agent shall have paid the fees in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(b)  In applying the provisions of this chapter in respect to new construction, existing buildings, alterations and repairs, removals, demolitions and other building operations, the physical value of the work shall be determined by the building commissioner, who may accept an estimate of the total cost furnished by the owner or his agent or require a certificate from a licensed architect or an affidavit from the owner or his agent of the total cost of the proposed work; or the building commissioner may make an estimate of the total cost. The building commissioner shall not require both the architect's certificate and the owner's affidavit. 
(c)  A penalty in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk or ten percent of the original fee, whichever is greater, shall be assessed on any permit which is not paid for within two weeks after issuance. 
(d)  No additional permits will be issued to contractors who have existing permits issued, but unpaid. 
(e)  No fee shall be returned if an issued permit is lapsed or voided which occurs six months after issuance. 
(f)  Requirements of satellite receiving antenna: The permit fee shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 84-018, § 2, 8-7-1984; Ord. No. 85-016, § 6, 5-21-1985; Ord. No. 93-053, § 2, 12-21-1993; Ord. No. 00-001, § 2, 1-18-2000) 
Sec. 46-763. - Building permit security deposit. 
(a)  Established; applicability. The village hereby establishes a permit security deposit. All permits issued by the planning and development department for construction, renovation, installation or any other improvements upon property located within the village shall not be issued, unless and until a security deposit is paid by the person to whom the permit is issued. The security deposit shall be applied in the following manner: 
(1)  The security deposit shall be an amount as provided in the following schedule. 
(2)  The security deposit shall be refunded by the village in a reasonable time after the construction is completed and inspected by the village. 
(3)  Any amounts for damage to village property or clean up performed by the village which was necessitated by the construction, or additional inspection fees shall be deducted from the security deposit prior to its return. 
(b)  The planning and development department shall charge, in addition to the normal building permit fee, an amount of five percent of the job value for any permit that is issued after work is performed. 
(c)  Once a job is stopped by the village for any reason, an additional fee for residential property and commercial property shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk and collected prior to restarting construction.
