All other security deposits shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. Persons shall not be required to deposit more than one deposit so long as the deposit or any portion thereof has not been used for damage to village property, cleanup provided by the village, or additional inspection fees. At the completion and final inspection of any construction project, the person may elect to have said deposit returned in accordance with this section, or may leave said deposit as a permanent security deposit for future permits. 
(Ord. No. 91-009, §§ 1-3, 6-4-1991; Ord. No. 91-022, § 1, 11-19-1991) 
Sec. 46-764. - Additional building related fees. 
    Additional building related fees shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 00-001, § 1, 1-18-2000) 
Sec. 46-765. - Special fees may apply. 
    The fee payment for the construction, alteration, removal or demolition and for all work done in connection with or concurrently with the work contemplated by a building permit shall not relieve the applicant or holder of the permit from the payment of other fees that may be prescribed by law or ordinance for water taps, sewer connections, electrical permits, erection of signs and display structures, marquees or other appurtenant structures, or fees for inspections, certificates of use and occupancy or other privileges or requirements, both within and without the jurisdiction of the department of building inspection. 
(Code 1969, § 308.2) 
Sec. 46-766. - Disposition of payments. 
    Such amounts so required for each permit shall be paid by the party contemplating such erection, construction repair, changes or additions, to the village clerk-collector's office. All such fees so charged for such permits and collected by the village clerk-collector shall be reported to the board of trustees after having been paid into the village clerk-collector's office, and shall be and become a part of the village general fund. 
Sec. 46-767. - Plumbing fees. 
    At the time of issuance of a permit for plumbing work, fees shall be paid in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 308.3) 
Sec. 46-768. - Inspection fees. 
    At the time of issuance of a permit for plumbing work, inspection fees shall be paid in accordance with the amounts established from time to time by resolution or ordinance, as required by law, of the board of trustees as set forth in a separate fee schedule and adopted and maintained by the village. A copy of the fee schedule is available for inspection and copying in the village clerk's office. 
Sec. 46-769. - Additional water and sewerage. 
    In addition to the permit fees required in this article, there shall be such charges for water used in connection with building operations as are fixed by the schedule of water rates in this village and such other charges as may be fixed for the installation of sanitary sewer or as required under any other village ordinance or as required by law, of the board of trustees as set forth in a separate fee schedule and adopted and maintained by the village. A copy of the fee schedule is available for inspection and copying in the village clerk's office. 
Secs. 46-770-46-788. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LAND DEVELOPMENT AND OBSERVATION 

Sec. 46-789. - Review and construction fees. 
    The village shall charge developers administration, review and construction observation service fees. These fees shall be based upon the fixed fee schedule set forth in this division and shall be paid in advance by means of United States currency, or certified check/money order payable to the village treasurer and delivered to the village clerk. No plan, or plat, for a proposed planned development or subdivision, preliminary or otherwise, shall be considered without the receipt from the village treasurer indicating that the requisite fees have been paid. Fees so paid are nonrefundable regardless of whether the proposed development is approved or disapproved. 
(1)  Administrative fees (to village). Review and construction fees in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk shall be paid in the following order: 
a.  Fifty percent upon the submittal of the conceptual plan; and 
b.  Fifty percent upon the submittal of the preliminary plan. 
(2)  Conceptual plan engineering review fees. Fees in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk shall be paid upon the submittal of the conceptual plan, but shall be credited toward the engineering review fees upon the submittal of the preliminary plan, after such fees shall have been determined in accordance with subsection (3) of this section. 
(3)  Engineering review fees. 
a.  All single-phased developments which contemplate, or which may otherwise require, the construction of and/or dedication of public improvements, shall be submitted to the village for review by the village engineer. The fee for such review shall be determined based upon the cost of the public improvements required by the village and approved by the village engineer shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. 
b.  The engineering review fees shall be paid upon the submittal of the preliminary plan. Should the actual infrastructure improvement costs be unavailable at the time of submittal of the preliminary plan, the developer shall submit, as a viable substitute, an engineer's opinion of the probable construction costs for the proposed public improvements. The village engineer shall review the sufficiency of the tendered improvement costs and either: 
1.  Approve them as submitted; or 
2.  Require that they be revised and resubmitted. 
Improvement costs, actual or estimated, as approved by the village engineer, shall be utilized as the basis for calculating the engineering review fees. Such fees, if based upon estimated amounts, shall be eligible for adjustment in accordance with the infrastructure improvement costs amount when finally determined. Any additional engineering review fees required due to upward revisions in the infrastructure improvement costs shall be paid prior to final plan approval. If the final infrastructure improvement costs amount is less than the initial estimate as submitted by the developer, the initial estimate shall be utilized, unless the difference between the initial estimate and the final infrastructure improvement costs amount is greater than 25 percent, in which case the village shall refund that amount of the difference in excess of 25 percent. 
(4)  Multiphase developments. Multiphased developments which contemplate or which may otherwise require the construction and/or dedication of public improvements and which would require phased engineering review of the final plan submittals shall be submitted to the village for review by the village engineer. The engineering review fees shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk and paid as follows: 
a.  Twenty percent of the engineering review fee, as determined by applying the fee table set forth in subsection (3)a of this section to the infrastructure improvement costs for all phases of the development, shall be paid upon the submittal of the preliminary plan. 
b.  Subsequently, as each phase of the multiphased development is submitted for final plan approval, a percentage of the total engineering review fee shall be due and paid prior to final plan approval for that phase. The amount due for each phase shall be calculated by applying the percentage of infrastructure improvements proposed for that phase (infrastructure improvement cost for phase divided by infrastructure improvement costs for all phases) to the engineering review fees remaining after deducting fees provided in subsection (3) of this section. 
c.  Example. The infrastructure improvement costs amount for the public improvements for the entire (all phases) development: $1,000,000.00. 
d.  Should the actual infrastructure improvement costs be unavailable at the time of the submittal of the preliminary plan, for each phase of the development, the developer shall submit, as a viable substitute, an engineer's opinion of probable construction costs for the proposed public improvements. The village engineer shall review the sufficiency of the tendered improvement costs and either: 
1.  Approve them as submitted; or 
2.  Require that they be revised and resubmitted. 
Improvement costs, actual or estimated, as approved by the village engineer, shall be utilized as the basis for calculating the engineering review fees. Such fees, if based upon estimated amounts, shall be eligible for adjustment in accordance with the infrastructure improvement costs amount when finally determined. Any additional engineering review fees required due to upward revisions in the infrastructure improvement costs shall be paid prior to final plan approval. If the final infrastructure improvement costs amount is less than the initial estimate as submitted by the developer, the initial estimate shall be utilized, unless the difference between the initial estimate and the final infrastructure improvement costs amount is greater than 25 percent, in which case the village shall refund that amount of the difference in excess of 25 percent. 
(5)  Construction observation fees. The village engineer, or his representative, shall observe the construction of the public improvements or utilities for single-phased and multiphased developments that contemplate the construction and/or dedication of public improvements. The fee for the construction observation services shall be determined based upon the cost of the public improvements required by the village and approved by the village engineer, in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk. The construction observation fees shall be paid prior to final plat approval. 
(6)  Development not including public improvements and redevelopment projects. For developments that do not contemplate the construction and/or dedication of public improvements, review and construction observation fees shall be charged to the developer as follows: 
a.  Administrative fees shall be charged in amounts and in the same manner as set forth in subsection (1) of this section. 
b.  Engineering review and construction observation fees shall be charged at the hourly rate specified by the village and in effect at the time such fees are charged. When performed by a consultant acting as village engineer the hourly fee for this work shall be as provided in the consultant engineering contract between the village and the village engineer. When performed by village personnel the hourly fee shall be as established by the village. 
c.  A base fee shall be charged and will be used by the village to cover the initial cost for this work. The base fee shall be in an amount determined by the board from time to time, as set forth in the fee schedule maintained by the village and available in the office of the village clerk which amount shall be adjusted by the village when the project is approved. The base fee shall be paid prior to approval of the site or development plan. 
d.  Any deficiency in the engineering review or construction observation fees shall be due and payable by the developer within 30 day of written notice of said deficiency by the village. 
(Ord. No. 00-007, § 1(exh. A), 4-18-2000) 
Secs. 46-780-46-800. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - VACANT BUILDINGS 

Sec. 46-801. - Declaration of policy. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety and welfare by enactment of this article which: 
(1)  Establishes a program for identification, registration and regulation of buildings which are or become vacant on and after the effective date of this article. 
(2)  Determines the responsibilities of owners of vacant buildings. 
(3)  Provides for administration, enforcement, including abatement of public nuisances, and imposition of penalties. 
(b)  This article shall be construed liberally to affect its purposes. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 46-802. - Other ordinances. 
    This article shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other applicable ordinances, codes, legislation and regulations which prescribe standards other than are provided herein, and in the event of conflict, the most restrictive standard shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 46-803. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, and the interpretation and enforcement thereof, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein, unless the context in which they are used shall indicate otherwise. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the singular number include the plural number, and words in the plural number include the singular number. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory and "may" is permissive. Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning. 
    Building means any structure occupied or intended for supporting or sheltering any occupancy. 
    Building commissioner means the building commissioner as defined in this chapter or the building commissioner's designee. Owner means any person, agent, operator, firm or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in a building; or recorded in the official records of the state, county or village as holding title to the building or the premises upon which a building sits; or otherwise having charge, care or control of a building or premises, including the guardian of the estate of any such person, the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of real property by a court; or any person or agent maintaining, operating or collecting rent for any vacant building. 
    Person means an individual, corporation, partnership or other entity or group acting as a unit. 
    Premises means a lot, plot, parcel of land, easement or public way, including any structure or building thereon. 
    Public nuisance includes the following: 
(1)  The physical condition, or uses of any building regarded as a public nuisance at common law, under the Illinois Compiled Statutes, or this Code; or 
(2)  Any physical condition, use or occupancy or any building or its appurtenances considered an attractive nuisance to children, including, but not limited to, abandoned wells, shafts, basements, excavations, and unsafe fences or structures; or 
(3)  Any building which has unsanitary sewerage or plumbing facilities; or 
(4)  Any building designed by the building commissioner as unsafe for human habitation or use; or 
(5)  Any building which is manifestly capable of being a fire hazard, or manifestly unsafe or insecure as to endanger life, limb or property; or 
(6)  Any building which is unsanitary, or which is littered with rubbish or garbage, or which has an uncontrolled growth of weeds; or 
(7)  Any building that is dangerous, in a state of dilapidation, deterioration or decay; faulty construction; open or vacant and the doors, windows or other openings are secured by any means other than conventional methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new construction of similar type; damaged by fire to the extent as not to provide shelter, in danger of collapse or failure and dangerous to anyone on or near the premises. 
    Secured building means a building which has had, in a manner intended to be temporary or permanent, any or all openings, which openings are windows or doors which were present for the purpose of light, ventilation or egress, material permitted pursuant to this Code affixed to such openings, from the interior or exterior of the building, for the purpose of securing or preventing access or damage to the building or its components. 
    Unoccupied building means an abandoned building or portion thereof which lacks the habitual presence of human beings who have a legal right to be on the premises, including buildings ordered vacated by the building commissioner pursuant to authority granted to the building commissioner by this Code. 
    Unmaintained building means to not take care of the property and the building which would cause violation with our property maintenance ordinances. This would include, but is not exclusive to: 
 Securing the building; 
 Keeping the property in clean, safe and sanitary condition; 
 Property shall be kept free from rodent harborage and infestation; 
 Cutting the grass regularly; and 
 Ensuring that the building and the property are not a hazard to the safety or health of the public. 
    Vacant building means a building or portion of a building which is: 
(1)  Unoccupied and unmaintained; or 
(2)  Unoccupied and a dangerous structure; or 
(3)  Unoccupied and condemned by the building commissioner pursuant to applicable law; or 
(4)  Unoccupied and has multiple code violations; or 
(5)  A multifamily residential property containing five (5) or more building units shall be considered vacant when substantially all of the building units are unoccupied. 
Exceptions: 
 A vacant building shall not include unoccupied buildings which are undergoing construction, renovation or rehabilitation and which are in compliance with all applicable village ordinances, codes and regulations, and for which construction, renovation or rehabilitation is proceeding diligently to completion. 
 A building that has been used as a residence by a person entitled to possession for a period of at least three months within a previous nine-month period and a person entitled to possession intends to resume residing at the property. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 13-16, §§ 1, 2, 3-19-2013) 
Sec. 46-804. - Determination. 
(a)  The building commissioner may determine, at his or her discretion, that a building is a "vacant" building within the definition of section 46-803 of this article. For buildings the building commissioner determines to be "vacant buildings", the building commissioner may, within seven days of making that determination, send notice of the written determination with the factual findings to the last taxpayer of record listed on the most recent Cook County tax roll. Said notice of determination shall be sent first class United States Mail, with proper postage prepaid. Failure of delivery shall not excuse a person from complying with this article. The building commissioner may personally serve or cause personal service of the notice of determination. Any person making such service shall execute an affidavit attesting to the facts of service. The building commissioner shall maintain an affidavit of such mailing for each notice of determination sent pursuant to this section. 
(b)  The notice served pursuant to this section may specify a date and time on which the owner shall allow for an inspection of the interior of the vacant building to determine the extent of water, sewer, fire, building and safety concerns. The village shall provide any inspection report to the owner within 30 days. 
(c)  If a notice is served pursuant to this section shall contain a statement of the obligations of the owner of a building determined to be a vacant building, a copy of the registration form the owner is required to file pursuant to section 46-806 of this article, and a notice of the owner's right to appeal the building commissioner's determination. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 13-16, § 3, 3-19-2013) 
Sec. 46-805. - Appeal of determination. 
(a)  An owner of a building determined by the building commissioner to be a vacant building as defined in section 46-803 of this article, may appeal that determination to the planning and zoning board of appeals. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the board within 15 days of the date of mailing of the notice of determination. The filing of an appeal stays the owner's obligations to register a building as required by this article. The appeal shall contain a complete statement of the reasons the owner disputes the building commissioner's determination, shall set forth specific facts in support thereof, and shall include all evidence the owner relies upon to support the appeal. The zoning board of appeals shall decide the appeal on the basis of facts presented by the owner in the written appeal and the building commissioner's written determination. 
(b)  The burden is upon the owner to present sufficient evidence to show that had the evidence been known to the building commissioner at the time the building commissioner made the determination, the building commissioner would more likely than not have determined that the subject building was not a "vacant building" within the meaning of section 46-803. 
(c)  The zoning board of appeals shall send written notice of its decision to the owner within 30 days of its receipt of the appeal. The village board may, but is not required to, seek additional information from the owner. The zoning board of appeals may, upon written notice thereof to the owner, take no more than 15 additional days to decide the appeal if the owner determines that such additional time is required for consideration of the appeal. 
(d)  An owner who wishes to challenge the applicability of this article to a vacant building without the building commissioner's determination having been made shall set forth specific facts to support no applicability in writing to the building commissioner. In the event the building commissioner determines that the subject building is a "vacant building" as defined in section 46-803, the owner shall have the right to appeal the building commissioner's determination to the village board as provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 13-16, §§ 4, 5, 3-19-2013) 
Sec. 46-806. - Obligation to register vacant buildings. 
(a)  The owner of a building who knows, or from all the facts and circumstances should know, that the owner's building is or has become a "vacant building" as defined in section 46-803 after the effective date of this article or the owner of a building, which the building commissioner determines at any time to be a "vacant building" as defined in section 46-803, or the owner of a building whose appeal from the building commissioner's determination has been denied by the village board shall register the building pursuant to section 15-306 within 60 days after either the date of the building commissioner's notice of determination or occurrence of the facts which would cause a reasonable person to believe that the building was a "vacant building," or denial of the appeal, whichever is applicable. Registration does not exonerate the owner from compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances, including this article, nor does it preclude any of the actions the village is authorized to take pursuant to this article or elsewhere in this Code. 
(b)  Each vacant building shall be registered pursuant to an executed and completed form provided by the building commissioner and filed with the building commissioner. 
(c)  A registration for a vacant building shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of registration. 
(d)  An annual, nonprorated registration fee of $200.00 shall be required to register each vacant building. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 46-807. - Registration requirements. 
    The registration form required by this article shall include the name, street address and telephone number of a natural person 21 years of age or older, designated by the owner, as the authorized agent for receiving notices of code violations and for receiving process in any court proceeding or administrative enforcement proceeding on behalf of such owner in connection with the enforcement of this Code. Said person must maintain an office in Cook County, or must actually reside within Cook County. A street address is required; a post office box is not an acceptable address. An owner who is a natural person and who meets the requirements of this section as to location of residence or office may designate himself or herself as agent. By designating an authorized agent pursuant to this section, the owner consents to receive any and all notices of code violations concerning the registered building and all process in any court proceeding or administrative enforcement proceeding brought to enforce this Code concerning the registered building by service of the notice or process on the authorized agent. Any owner who fails to register a vacant building under the provisions of this section shall further be deemed to consent to receive, by posting at the building, any and all notices of code violations and all process in an administrative proceeding brought to enforce code provisions concerning the building. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 46-808. - Changes in registration information. 
    An owner shall notify the building commissioner within 15 days of any change in the registration information by filing an amended registration on a form provided by the building commissioner. A new registration is required for any change in ownership whatsoever. The registration shall be deemed prima facie proof of the statements therein contained in any administrative enforcement proceeding or court proceeding instituted by the village against the owner of the building. A processing fee in the amount of $25.00 shall be submitted with any amended registration application. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 11-022, § 2, 7-19-2011) 
Sec. 46-809. - Renewal of registration. 
    An owner shall be required to annually renew on the anniversary date of the first filing registration as long as the building remains vacant and shall pay the annual registration fee of $200.00 for each vacant building. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 46-810. - Posting of notices. 
    Service of notices sent or required to be sent pursuant to this article may be posted on an applicable building if the owner fails to renew the registration if required, or maintain with the building commissioner the information required regarding the person designated to accept notice and service of process pursuant to section 46-807 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 46-811. - Liability insurance. 
    An owner of any vacant building must obtain liability insurance and maintain such insurance for as long as the building is vacant, and file evidence of such insurance with the building commissioner as follows: For a vacant residential building of one to three units, $500,000.00 in coverage; for a vacant residential building of four (4) to 11 units, $750,000.00 in coverage; for a vacant residential building of 12 to 48 units, $1,000,000.00 in coverage; for a vacant residential building of more than 48 units, $2,000,000.00 in coverage; and for a vacant manufacturing, industrial, storage or nonresidential commercial building, $2,000,000.00 in coverage. Written notice shall be supplied to the building commissioner within 30 days of any lapse, cancellation or change in the coverage required by this section. An owner shall supply evidence of the insurance required by this section at any time upon the request of the building commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 46-812. - Vacant building plan. 
    At the time a building is registered as required herein, the owner shall submit a vacant building plan. The building commissioner may prescribe a form for the plan. If the owner fails to submit the plan as provided for by this section, the building commissioner may determine the plan. At a minimum, the plan shall contain the following: 
(1)  A plan of action to repair any doors, windows or other openings which are secured by any means other than conventional methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new construction or similar type. The proposed repair shall result in openings being secured by conventional methods used in the design of the building or by methods permitted for new construction of similar type with board removed. Securing a building shall be accomplished with materials and methods permitted pursuant to this Code. The owner shall maintain the building in an enclosed and secure state so that it is a secured building as defined pursuant to this article until the building is reoccupied or made available for immediate occupancy. If the owner demonstrates that securing of the building will provide adequate protection to the public, the building commissioner may waive the requirement of an enclosure. 
(2)  For buildings and premises thereof which are determined by the building commissioner as being or containing public nuisances, as defined in section 46-803 of this article, then the vacant building plan shall contain a plan of action to remedy such public nuisance(s). 
(3)  A time schedule identifying a date of commencement of repair and date of completion of repair for each improperly secured opening and nuisance identified by the building commissioner. 
(4)  When the owner proposes to demolish the vacant building, then the owner shall submit a plan and time schedule for such demolition. 
(5)  A plan of action to maintain the building and premises thereof in conformance with this article. 
(6)  A plan of action, with a time schedule, identifying the date the building will be habitable and occupied or offered for occupancy or sale. The time schedule shall include date(s) of commencement and completion of all actions required to achieve habitability. No plan which provides for compliance with this article or, which will not, as determined by the building commissioner, achieve such compliance, within six months, in the case of a vacant and secured building, and two years, in the case of a vacant and unsecured building will be approved. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 46-813. - Approval of plan. 
(a)  Review of building plan. The building commissioner shall review the proposed vacant building plan required by section 46-812 in accordance with the standards below. The building commissioner shall send notice to the owner of the vacant building of the building commissioner's determination. 
(b)  Standards for plan approval. In considering the appropriateness of a vacant building plan, the building commissioner shall include the following in the building commissioner's considerations: 
(1)  The purposes of this section 46-813 and intent of the village to minimize the time a building is secured or otherwise vacant. 
(2)  The effect of the building and the proposed plan on adjoining property. 
(3)  The length of time the building has been vacant. 
(4)  The presence of any public nuisances on the premises. 
(5)  The likelihood that the plan or portion(s) thereof will prevent or ameliorate the condition it is designed to address. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 13-16, § 6, 3-19-2013) 
Sec. 46-814. - Authority to modify plan. 
    The building commissioner shall, upon notice to the vacant building owner, have the right to modify the vacant building plan by modifying the dates of performance, the proposed methods of action, or by imposing additional requirements consistent with this article that the building commissioner deems necessary to protect the public health, safety or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 46-815. - Failure to comply with plan. 
    Failure to have an approved vacant building plan as required by section 46-812 within 30 days of filing the registration form or failure to comply with the approved plan shall constitute a violation of this article subjecting the owner of the building to penalties as provided in this article and to any remedies the village may avail itself of as provided for herein and elsewhere in this Code, including, but limited to an action to compel correction of property maintenance violations. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 46-816. - Owner responsibility to secure a vacant building; signage. 
(a)  Enclosure of vacant building. An owner of any vacant building shall within ten days of the building becoming vacant enclose and secure the building as defined pursuant to this article and maintain the building in a secured and closed condition until the building is no longer a vacant building as defined herein. Any board up material used must be painted with exterior grade paint that closely matches the color of the exterior of the building. 
(b)  Security guard service. On written notice of the building commissioner, an owner of any vacant building shall provide bonded, licenses and insured security guard service at the building between the hours of 3:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. Such service shall remain in place until the building commissioner gives written notice that the service is no longer required. Such service shall be required when the building commissioner makes a written determination that the vacant building constitutes a fire hazard, is otherwise dangerous to human life or the public welfare, involves illegal or improper use, occupancy, or maintenance, under such conditions that securing the building are insufficient to prevent the actual or threatened harm. 
(c)  Signage. An owner of any vacant building must affix a sign to the building that provides the name, address and telephone number of the owner and the owner's authorized agent for the purpose of service of process. The name, address and telephone number of a person responsible for day-to-day supervision and management of the building, if such person is different from the owner holding title or authorized agent, shall also be set forth on the sign. The sign shall be of a size and placed in such a location so as to be legible from the nearest public street or sidewalk, whichever is nearer. The sign shall be in compliance with the village's sign regulations, with the exception that no permit shall be required for the sign. 
(d)  Nuisances. In the event the building commissioner determines that any such vacant building constitutes a public nuisance as that term is defined herein, the commissioner may require the owner to secure the building immediately, or, in the alternative, the building commissioner may take appropriate action to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 11-022, § 3(a), (b), 7-19-2011) 
Sec. 46-817. - Owner to maintain alarm and sprinkler systems. 
    Whenever pursuant to this Code an owner is required to maintain an alarm and/or sprinkler system, the owner shall continue to be required to maintain said alarm and/or sprinkler system during all times that a building is vacant. This shall include any and all necessary systems and appurtenances incident thereto to keep said alarm and/or sprinkler operable, including, but not limited to, source(s) of water, heat and/or electricity. 
    The owner shall otherwise maintain the premises in accordance with the following specific maintenance requirements: 
(1)  All such property shall be kept free of weeds, dry brush, dead vegetation, trash, junk, debris, building materials, any accumulation of any newspapers, circulars, flyers, notices, except those required by federal, state or local law, discarded personal items including but not limited to furniture, clothing, large and small appliances, printed material or any other items that give the appearance that the property is abandoned. 
(2)  The property shall be maintained free of graffiti, tagging or similar markings by removal or painting over with an exterior grade paint that matches the color of the exterior of the structure. 
(3)  Visible side and front yard shall be landscaped and maintained in accordance with the neighborhood standard at the time registration was required. 
(4)  Landscaping shall include, but is not limited to grass, ground covers, bushes, scrubs, hedges or similar plantings, decorative rock or bark or artificial turf/sod designed specifically for residential installation. 
(5)  Landscaping does not include weeds, gravel, broken concrete, asphalt, decomposed granite, plastic sheeting, indoor-outdoor carpeting or any other similar material. 
(6)  Maintenance includes, but is not limited to regular watering, irrigation, cutting, pruning and mowing of required landscaping and removal of all trimmings. 
(7)  Pools, spas and pounds shall be kept in working order so the water remains clear and free of pollutants and debris, or drained and kept dry. In either case, properties with pools and/or spas must comply with the minimum fencing requirements of the Village of Lansing or be removed from the premises. If upon inspection by the village it is found that any pool, spa or pond is holding stagnant water or is unsecure and a hazard, the building commissioner shall act to remove the hazard. This may include removal of the pool, pond or spa at the expense of the property owner. 
(8)  Properties shall be maintained in a secure manner so as not to be accessible to unauthorized persons. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 11-022, § 4, 7-19-2011) 
Sec. 46-818. - Other enforcement. 
    The registration of a vacant building shall not preclude action by the village to demolish or to take other action against the building pursuant to other provisions of this article, this Code or other applicable laws or regulations. All premises upon which unoccupied or vacant buildings are located and the exteriors shall at all times, be maintained in compliance with this Code. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Sec. 46-819. - Certification. 
    A certificate of occupancy inspection for vacant buildings may be issued by the village and payment in full of all fees imposed pursuant to this article are required prior to any occupancy of a vacant building. 
    Any building or structure which has been vacant for a period of 120 days or more, except for those situations described in section 46-803 hereof, which are exceptions, must be inspected and the owner or his designee shall be required to obtain a new certificate of occupancy, the fee for which shall be $50.00 to cover the cost of the required inspections. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 11-022, § 5, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 13-16, § 7, 3-19-2013) 
Sec. 46-820. - Securing of buildings. 
(a)  A vacant building may not remain secured longer than six (6) months unless an extension of that time is part of a plan approved by the building commissioner. 
(b)  A vacant building which is not secured and code compliant and for which securing is determined by the building commissioner on the basis of police reports, citizen complaints and other information of other type considered reliable by reasonable persons, to not require securing to prevent unauthorized entry may not remain vacant for more than two years without an approved plan for occupancy, sale, demolition or other disposition of the building. 
(c)  Failure of owner to secure. Upon failure of an owner to secure a vacant building, the building commissioner may secure the building in accordance with Section 108.2 of the 2006 International Property Maintenance Code as adopted by the Village of Lansing. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 11-022, § 6, 7-19-2011) 
Sec. 46-821. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  Any person found to have violated any provision of this article shall be subject to a minimum fine of $100.00 per day per violation to a maximum of $750.00 per day per violation, in addition to any other legal or equitable remedies available to the village. Such other remedies include, but are not limited to, injunctive relief, application to a court of competent jurisdiction for a receiver, demolition or condemnation, contracting for the repair or purchase of the premises, or foreclosure of any lien the village may have thereon. 
(b)  A separate and distinct offense shall be committed each day on which such person or persons shall violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The village may enforce this article in its administrative adjudication system, or through the circuit court. 
(d)  Nothing herein contained shall prohibit the village form immediately condemning as provided for in this Code or applicable law a building or taking other immediate action upon a determination that the building is a public nuisance or poses an imminent danger to the occupants of the building, or the public, health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 10-020, § 2, 9-21-2010) 
Secs. 46-822-46-829. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - CERTIFICATE OF PAYMENT 

Sec. 46-830. - Required upon real estate transfer. 
(a)  No real estate in the Village of Lansing shall be sold, quit claimed, traded or otherwise transferred unless it has been determined that the village's water charges, grass cutting charges, ambulance charges, property maintenance charges and unpaid judgments related to the parcel, as of the most recent billing, have been paid in full, and that the owner of the real estate is otherwise not in debt to the village, as evidenced by a transfer certificate issued by the treasurer's office. 
(b)  The requirement of obtaining a transfer certificate shall be mandatory on all transfers of ownership of or beneficial interest in real estate located within the village. The requirement shall further be reflected on all real estate title insurance reports conducted precedent to the transfer of ownership to give public notice of the mandatory requirement of the transfer certificate. A certified copy of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be recorded with the Cook County Recorder of Deeds, and copies shall be sent to all title insurance companies with notice that a transfer certificate is required on any transfer of ownership of real estate in the village. 
(c)  An application for a transfer certificate can be secured from the treasurer's office by any person owning real estate located within the village or his agent or nominee. The application for a transfer certificate must be submitted to the treasurer's office during regular business hours not less than three business days prior to any proposed sale, assignment or other transfer for any legal or beneficial interest of such real estate. A certificate of payment shall be prepared within three business days from receipt of the application. 
(1)  If the treasurer or his/her designee determines that the applicant has paid in full all water charges, grass cutting charges, ambulance charges, property maintenance charges and unpaid judgments as of the most recent billing, and that the owner is not otherwise in debt to the village, the treasurer shall issue a certificate of payment which must be submitted with the original deed or document of transfer in order to transfer property within the village. The certificate of payment shall indicate that as of the date of the most recent billing, all water charges, grass cutting charges, ambulance charges, property maintenance charges and unpaid judgments have been paid in full and that the owner is not otherwise in debt to the village. Any unbilled assessments as of the date of closing shall remain the responsibility of the owner of the real estate. The certificate of payment shall be valid for a period of 30 days from the date of issuance. The treasurer's office shall keep a record of all certificate of payments on file in the treasurer's office and copies shall be furnished, upon request, to any person having a tenancy interest in the property. 
(2)  If the treasurer or his/her designee determines that the applicant has not paid in full all water charges, grass cutting charges, ambulance charges, property maintenance charges and unpaid judgments or that the owner is otherwise in debt to the village, no certificate of payment shall be issued. The applicant will be given a report in a form adopted by the treasurer's office which indicates any water charges, grass cutting charges, ambulance charges, property maintenance charges and unpaid judgments and/or debts owed by the owner to the village. When, and if, the applicant has paid the debt noted on the report, he shall reapply for a certificate of payment. 
(Ord. No. 13-032, § 2, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 46-831. - Appeal of refusal to issue. 
(a)  Any person whose application for a certificate of payment has been denied may appeal to the village administrator and contest the findings contained on the report or request that the requirements of this chapter be waived in his or her particular circumstances. 
(b)  An appeal to the village administrator must be perfected by filing a notice of appeal with the village clerk. Such notice of appeal must be filed within ten days from the date of issuance of the report denying the certificate of payment. The village administrator may grant a variance from the requirements of the code only when the applicant can prove by a preponderance of the evidence that: 
(1)  Compliance with the requirements of the code will place an extreme hardship on the applicant; or 
(2)  Physical conditions make compliance impossible. 
(c)  The village administrator shall hold a hearing on the appeal within three days of the filing of the notice of appeal. It shall render a written decision at the close of the hearing or within seven days of the close of the evidence, at the latest. 
(Ord. No. 13-032, § 2, 5-21-2013) 
ARTICLE XV. - INTERNATIONAL EXISTING BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 46-832. - International Existing Building Code adopted. 
    The village adopts the International Existing Building Code, 2015 Edition, including all appendix chapters, published by the International Code Council, for the control of building and structures as provided herein. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions, and terms of the adopted code are made a part hereof as if fully set forth herein, unless otherwise specifically provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 16-011, § 7, 3-1-2016) 
Sec. 46-833. - Revisions and exceptions to adopted code. 
    The following revisions and exceptions to the building code adopted pursuant to this article shall apply in the village: 
(1)  Section 101.1. Insert: Village of Lansing. 
(2)  Section 1401.2. Insert: the date of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 16-011, § 7, 3-1-2016) 
Chapter 48 - ENVIRONMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 48-1-48-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROL COMMISSION 

Sec. 48-20. - Created. 
    There is hereby created for the village an environmental control commission, referred to in this article as the "commission." 
(Code 1982, § 25-51; Ord. No. 267, § 2, 10-17-1972) 
Sec. 48-21. - Appointments. 
(a)  The environmental control commission shall consist of five members. The president of the board of trustees, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint the members. 
(b)  The environmental control commission shall consist of the following: 
(1)  One member shall be appointed from the zoning board of appeals; 
(2)  One member shall be appointed from the plan commission; and 
(3)  Three citizen members shall be appointed. 
(c)  The president of the board of trustees, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint the chairman of the commission. 
(Code 1982, § 25-52; Ord. No. 267, § 2, 10-17-1972; Ord. No. 289, § 1, 5-1-1973; Ord. No. 495, § 1, 9-19-1978) 
Sec. 48-22. - Duties. 
(a)  This environmental control commission shall determine that provisions of this chapter and chapter 30, pertaining to solid waste, are not being violated and to that end may conduct hearings and investigations. 
(b)  Findings of the commission shall be reported in writing to the president of the board of trustees and he shall then direct the village attorney and/or the village prosecutor to take appropriate action. 
(c)  Findings of the commission and any action taken thereon shall be reported in writing to the board of trustees within five days of such occurrence. 
(Code 1982, § 25-53; Ord. No. 267, § 2, 10-17-1972) 
Sec. 48-23. - Meetings. 
    All environmental control commission meetings shall be held at the call of the chairman or at the request of a majority of the commission members, pursuant to notice, as required by law. All meetings shall be open to the public, except as permitted by law. 
(Code 1982, § 25-54; Ord. No. 267, § 2, 10-17-1972) 
Sec. 48-24. - Terms. 
    All commission members shall be appointed for three-year terms, except that terms of office of members other than citizen members shall terminate, if not sooner, upon the termination of their respective positions as members of the zoning board of appeals or the plan commission. 
(Code 1982, § 25-55; Ord. No. 267, § 2, 10-17-1972) 
Sec. 48-25. - Removal. 
    Commission members may be removed from office by the president of the board of trustees by and with the consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 25-56; Ord. No. 267, § 2, 10-17-1972) 
Secs. 48-26-48-44. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Power of municipalities to define, prevent and abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 48-45. - Police chief's duty. 
    Whenever any condition declared as a nuisance by any section of this Code exists or shall be found on any premises within the village, the police chief is hereby authorized, in his discretion, to cause the same to be summarily abated in such a manner as he may direct and at the expense of the party permitting or maintaining said nuisances. 
(Code 1969, § 17.118.2; Code 1982, § 19-1; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Sec. 48-46. - Declaration. 
    It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and unlawful for any person within the village limits to do the following: 
(1)  Negligently conduct any business or use any premises as to create such an offensive smell as may taint the air and render it unwholesome to the neighborhood. 
(2)  Obstruct or encroach upon public highways, private ways, streets or commons. 
(3)  Establish, maintain and carry on any offensive or unwholesome business within the village limits or within one mile of the limits thereof. 
(4)  Establish a cemetery within the village limits or within one mile of the limits thereof, without having first obtained permission to do so by an ordinance duly passed by the president and board of trustees. 
(5)  Stack or store, except in an enclosed place, any lumber, laths, boards, stones, bricks, cement or other building materials, in stacks or piles, exceeding six feet in height, or in such a manner as to likely topple or fall, or in stacks or piles the width of which at any point exceeds the width thereof at ground level. 
(6)  Cause or suffer any animal or vegetable matter, swill, suds, garbage, filth, stable drippings, manure or offal, or noisome substance of any kind, to be collected or deposited, or to remain in any place in the village to the prejudice of others. 
(7)  Permit or allow any pool, pond or body of stagnant water to be or remain upon any lot, grounds or premises. 
(8)  Corrupt or render unwholesome or injure the water of any drinking hydrant, spring, stream, pond or lake. 
(9)  Cause or suffer grass, leaves, underbrush or other combustible material to be collected, deposited or to remain on any premises in such quantities and in such condition as to materially increase the danger to the property of others by fire. 
(Code 1969, §§ 12.103, 17.118.1; Code 1982, §§ 14-4, 19-2) 
State Law reference- Power of board of trustees to define, prevent and abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 
Sec. 48-47. - Attractive nuisances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, keep, maintain or permit to remain unguarded any device or condition having the characteristics of an attractive nuisance likely to attract children and hazardous to their safety or health. 
(Code 1969, § 17.103; Code 1982, § 19-3) 
Secs. 48-48-48-66. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NUISANCES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY 

Sec. 48-67. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nuisance means any condition or use of premises or of building exteriors which is detrimental to the property of others or which causes or tends to cause substantial diminution in the value of other property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located. The term "nuisance" includes, but is not limited to, the keeping, the depositing on, or the scattering over the premises of any of the following: 
(1)  Lumber, junk, trash, garbage, refuse or debris. 
(2)  Abandoned, discarded or unused objects or equipment such as the following: 
a.  Automobiles; 
b.  Furniture; 
c.  Stoves; 
d.  Refrigerators; 
e.  Freezers; 
f.  Cans; or 
g.  Containers. 
(Code 1982, § 19-16; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-68. - Enforcement; injunctions and abatements. 
    Enforcement of this article may be accomplished by the village in any manner authorized by law, and in addition, any person who by reason of another's violation of any provision of this article, suffers special damage to himself different from that suffered by other property owners throughout the village generally, may bring an action to enjoin or otherwise abate an existing violation. 
(Code 1982, § 19-17; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-69. - Owner's duty to prohibit nuisance and maintain property values. 
    No person owning, leasing, occupying or having charge of any premises shall maintain or keep any nuisance thereon, nor shall any such person keep or maintain such premises in a manner causing substantial diminution in the value of other property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located. 
(Code 1982, § 19-18; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-70. - Owner's duty to abate upon written notice. 
    The owner, tenants, lessees and/or occupants of any lot within the village corporate limits upon which a nuisance exists shall jointly and severally abate said nuisance within a reasonable time after receiving written notification from the village so to do. 
(Code 1982, § 19-19; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-71. - Notice. 
    Notice may be given by or on behalf of the village attorney, or by any other village officer or employee authorized to give such notice, to abate a nuisance or cease and desist from continuing such nuisance or violation of law. 
(Code 1982, § 19-20; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-72. - Costs and expenses associated with abatement. 
    The costs and expenses referred to in section 48-73 may include, but are not limited to, any and all direct costs and expenses related to the following items: 
(1)  Personnel salaries and benefits; 
(2)  Operational overhead; 
(3)  Rent; 
(4)  Interest; 
(5)  Fees for experts or consultants; and 
(6)  Legal costs or expenses, including the following: 
a.  Attorney fees; 
b.  Arising from claims against the village as a consequence of the nuisance or violation; and 
c.  Arising from procedures associated with collecting monies due hereunder. 
(Code 1982, § 19-21; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-73. - Person failing or neglecting to comply with notice responsible for costs and expenses of abatement. 
    Whenever any person fails, refuses or neglects to comply with the notice given within the time specified therein, or if such a time is not specified, then within a time reasonably sufficient to enable such compliance, the village shall abate the nuisance, and the costs and expenses of such abatement shall be collected from such persons who may have created, continued or suffered such nuisance to exist, in addition to any penalty or fine. 
(Code 1982, § 19-22; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-74. - Recurring violation. 
    The provisions of section 48-73 shall also apply to any person who received a notice as specified therein and thereafter the nuisance or violation was abated, but such person subsequently allowed or was responsible for a recurrence of the nuisance or violation. 
(Code 1982, § 19-23; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-75. - Village attorney's authority to waive liability. 
    The liability of any person for payment of costs and expenses provided for in section 48-73 may be waived in whole or in part by the village attorney in any case wherein he determines, in his sole discretion, that the failure or refusal of such person to comply with the notice therein involved, was based upon a good faith and bona fide issue of law or fact specially involved in the circumstances of the case. Any village attorney determination or decision in this regard shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1982, § 19-24; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-76. - Civil action authorized for recovery of monies. 
    Monies due the village pursuant to sections 48-72 through 48-75 may be recovered in an appropriate civil action. 
(Code 1982, § 19-25; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-77. - Exterior storage of nonoperating vehicles prohibited after ten days. 
    No person in charge of or in control of premises, whether as owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or otherwise shall allow any partially dismantled, wrecked, junked, discarded or otherwise nonoperating motor vehicle to remain on such property longer than ten days; and no person shall leave any such vehicle on any property within the village for a longer time than ten days; except that this section shall not apply with regard to any vehicle in an enclosed building or so located upon the premises as not to be readily visible from any public place or from any surrounding private property. 
(Code 1982, § 19-26; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-78. - Business enterprise exception. 
    This division shall not apply with regard to any vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place, other than in a residential district, and operated in a lawful manner, when the keeping or maintenance of such vehicle is necessary to the operation of such business enterprise, or with regard to a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the village or any other public agency or entity. 
(Code 1982, § 19-27; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980) 
Sec. 48-79. - Abatement authorized for public health, safety and welfare reasons; owner responsible for costs and expenses. 
    The police chief, the health officer, the village president or the village board of trustees is each hereby authorized to abate any nuisance existing on private property in the village whether such nuisance is specifically recognized by ordinance or not, whenever he determines that said nuisance is dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare of the village residents. The costs and expenses, as set forth in sections 48-72 and 48-73, of abating said nuisance shall be billed to the owners, jointly and severally, said bill to be recoverable in a suit at law. 
(Code 1982, § 19-28; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 2-5-1980; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
Secs. 48-80-48-98. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WEEDS 

Sec. 48-99. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Weeds means burdock, ragweed (giant), ragweed (common), thistle, cockleburr, jimson, blue vervain, common milk weed, wild carrot, poison ivy, wild mustard, rough pigweed, lamb's-quarters, wild lettuce, curled dock, smart weeds (all varieties), poison hemlock, wild hemp and all other weeds of a like kind which, due to the dissemination of pollen, are injurious to the health of persons. 
(Code 1969, § 11.101; Code 1982, § 19-41) 
Sec. 48-100. - Declared nuisance; growth prohibited. 
    Any weeds found growing in any lot or tract of land in the village are hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for any person to permit any such weeds to grow or remain in any such place. 
(Code 1969, § 11.201; Code 1982, § 19-42) 
Sec. 48-101. - Prohibited height. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to permit any weeds, grass or plants, other than trees, bushes, flowers or other ornamental plants to grow to a height exceeding six inches anywhere in the village. Any such weeds or plants exceeding such height are hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1969, § 11.203; Code 1982, § 19-43; Ord. No. 12-024, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 48-102. - Owner's or occupant's duty to destroy. 
    Any person owning, leasing, occupying or controlling any plot or tract of land within the village is hereby required to cut, pull, destroy or chemically treat with an effective weed killer all weeds and weed plants upon such plot or tract of land so owned, leased, occupied or controlled by him before they reach a seed-bearing stage and to prevent such weeds from perpetuating themselves. 
(Code 1969, § 11.202; Code 1982, § 19-44; Ord. No. 13-056, § 1, 12-3-2013) 
Sec. 48-103. - Notice. 
    It shall be the building commissioner's duty to serve or cause to be served a notice upon the owner or occupant of any premises on which weeds or plants are permitted to grow in violation of the provisions of this division, and to demand the abatement of the nuisance within a timely manner. 
(Code 1969, § 11.204; Code 1982, § 19-45; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000; Ord. No. 13-034, § 1, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 48-104. - Building commissioner authorized to abate; owner or occupant liable for costs and expenses. 
    If a person served with a notice to remove nuisance plants does not abate the nuisance within ten days, the building commissioner may proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an account of the expense of the abatement, and such expense shall be charged to and paid by such owner or occupant. 
(Code 1969, § 11.205; Code 1982, § 19-46; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
State Law reference- Power of municipalities to provide for the destruction of weeds at the expense of the owners of the premises, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-6, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7. 
Sec. 48-105. - Notice of lien-Filing. 
    If the building commissioner causes weeds to be cut by the village or by someone directed to cut them on the village's behalf, the village or the person performing the service by village authority, in its or his own name, may file, within 60 days after such cost and expense of removal is incurred, a notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds in the county or in the office of the registrar of titles of the county, if the real estate affected is registered under the Torrons System. 
(Code 1969, § 11.206.1; Code 1982, § 19-47; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
State Law reference- Cost of cutting weeds as lien, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7. 
Sec. 48-106. - Same-Mailed if address known. 
    Notice of lien claims under this division shall be mailed to the owner of the premises, if his address is known. 
(Code 1969, § 11.206.3; Code 1982, § 19-48) 
Sec. 48-107. - Same-Contents. 
    The notice of lien under this division shall consist of a sworn statement setting out the following: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; 
(2)  The amount of money representing the costs and expenses incurred or payable for the service; and 
(3)  The dates when such costs and expenses was incurred by the village. 
(Code 1969, § 11.206.2; Code 1982, § 19-49) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7. 
Sec. 48-108. - Foreclosure rights not affected by any failure to record or receive notice of lien. 
    The village clerk's failure to record the notice of lien, to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for such costs of removal as provided in this article. 
(Code 1969, § 11.206.4; Code 1982, § 19-50) 
Sec. 48-109. - Payment; filing of release. 
    Upon payment of the costs and expenses after the notice of lien under this division has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release shall be filed of record in the same manner as the filing notice of said lien. 
(Code 1969, § 11.206.5; Code 1982, § 19-51) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7. 
Sec. 48-110. - Foreclosure; disposition of monies; village attorney's authority to commence. 
(a)  Property subject to a lien for unpaid weed removal charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be in equity in the village's name. 
(b)  The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings, in the village's name, in any court having jurisdiction over such matter against any property for which such bill has remained unpaid 60 days after it has been rendered. 
(Code 1969, § 11.207; Code 1982, § 19-52) 
Secs. 48-111-48-128. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DUTCH ELM DISEASE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dutch elm disease, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-11 et seq. 

Sec. 48-129. - Superintendent's authority to enforce. 
    The superintendent of public works or his authorized agent shall perform the duties set forth in this article and shall enforce the provisions of this article. He may have such assistance as the board of trustees shall from time to time provide. 
(Code 1969, § 17.202; Code 1982, § 19-66) 
Sec. 48-130. - Nuisance declared; defined. 
(a)  All species and varieties of elm trees (trees of genus Ulmus ) infected with the fungus known as the Dutch elm disease ( Certostomella ulmi ) as determined by laboratory analysis by the section of applied botany and plant pathology, state natural history survey, or by laboratories approved by said agency, are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(b)  All species and varieties of elm trees that are dead or substantially dead and all dead elm wood to which the bark is still attached, which, because of their condition, may serve as a breeding place for the European elm bark beetle ( Scolytus multristriatus ), and the native elm bark beetle ( Hylurgopinus rufipes ), or any other carrier of said disease, are hereby declared to be public nuisances. 
(Code 1969, § 17.201; Code 1982, § 19-67) 
Sec. 48-131. - Trees on village property to be removed or destroyed. 
    Any elm tree or dead elm wood on property owned by the village which is a public nuisance, as defined in this division, shall be promptly removed and burned under the supervision of the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1969, § 17.207; Code 1982, § 19-68) 
Sec. 48-132. - Inspections; unlawful interference. 
(a)  The superintendent of public works is authorized and empowered to enter upon any lot or parcel of land in the village, at any reasonable hour, for the purpose of inspecting any elm trees or dead elm wood situated thereon, and he may remove such specimens from any such trees as are required for the purposes of the laboratory analysis referred to in this article, or to determine whether such tree, because it is dead, or substantially dead, may serve as a breeding place for any carrier of Dutch elm disease. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to take any action to prevent the superintendent of public works from entering on any lot or parcel of land in the village or the purpose of such inspection or to interfere with the superintendent of public works in the performance of any duty provided for under the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 17.204; Code 1982, § 19-69) 
Sec. 48-133. - Abatement by property owner. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of any lot or parcel of land in the village to permit or maintain on any such lot or parcel of land any dead elm wood or elm tree which is a public nuisance, as described in section 48-114, and it shall be the duty of the owner of such to promptly remove and burn any such elm tree or dead elm wood under the supervision and direction of the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1969, § 17.203; Code 1982, § 19-70) 
Sec. 48-134. - Notice-Requiring compliance. 
    If on laboratory analysis of specimens removed from any elm tree by the superintendent of public works it is determined that such tree is a public nuisance under section 48-114(a), or if the superintendent of public works determines that any dead or substantially dead elm trees, or dead elm wood, is a public nuisance, as provided in section 48-114(b), the superintendent of public works shall serve, or cause to be served, upon the owner of record of the lot or parcel of land on which such tree or dead elm wood is located, a written notice requiring such owner to comply with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 17.205; Code 1982, § 19-71) 
Sec. 48-135. - Same-Service. 
    The service of the notice described in section 48-118 shall be by personal service if the owner of the lot or parcel of land on which an infected elm tree is located is a village resident. If such owner cannot be found in the village, or is a nonresident of the village, written notice shall be served by registered mail and by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the village. 
(Code 1969, § 17.205; Code 1982, § 19-72) 
Sec. 48-136. - Failure to comply; superintendent's authority to remove; property owner liable for costs. 
    If any person upon whom a notice under this division is served fails, neglects or refuses to remove and destroy by burning, an elm tree or dead elm wood, within ten days after service of such notice, the superintendent of public works may proceed to remove and burn such tree or dead elm wood and assess the cost thereof against the owner of such lot or parcel of land and the amount of such cost shall be paid by the owner to the village. 
(Code 1969, § 17.205; Code 1982, § 19-73) 
Sec. 48-137. - Payment of removal costs additional to any penalty imposed under this article. 
    If the village removes from any lot or parcel of land in the village, any infected, dead or substantially dead elm tree or dead elm wood, which is a public nuisance under section 48-114, the assessment of the cost of the work done by the village against the owner of the lot or parcel of land involved shall be in addition to the penalties imposed for any violation or noncompliance with any provision of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 17.206; Code 1982, § 19-74) 
Secs. 48-138-48-157. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NOISE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 48-158-48-177. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SOUND TRUCKS 

Sec. 48-178. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Sound-amplifying equipment means any machine or device for the amplification of the human voice, music or any other sound. The term "sound-amplifying equipment" does not include the following: 
(1)  Standard automobile radios when used and heard only by the occupants of the vehicle in which installed; or 
(2)  Warning devices on authorized emergency vehicles or horns or other warning devices on other vehicles used only for traffic safety purposes. 
    Sound truck means any vehicle having mounted thereon or attached thereto any sound-amplifying equipment. 
(Code 1969, § 23.214; Code 1982, § 18-51) 
Sec. 48-179. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing contained in this division shall be construed to prohibit the use of amplifying equipment in connection with any athletic, competitive, recreational or public event held on public playgrounds, athletic fields or in public parks. 
(Code 1969, § 23.214; Code 1982, § 18-52) 
Sec. 48-180. - Compliance required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or cause to be used in the village any sound truck, with its sound-amplifying equipment in operation, except in compliance with the regulations in this division. 
(Code 1969, § 23.214; Code 1982, § 18-53) 
Sec. 48-181. - Sounds permitted. 
    The only sounds permitted in sound trucks are music or human speech. 
(Code 1969, § 23.214; Code 1982, § 18-54) 
Sec. 48-182. - Hours of operation. 
    The operation of sound trucks is permitted for three hours each day, except on Sundays when no operation shall be authorized. The permitted three hours of operation shall be between the hours of noon and 1:00 p.m. and between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(Code 1969, § 23.214; Code 1982, § 18-55) 
Sec. 48-183. - Traveling speed. 
    Sound-amplifying equipment shall not be operated unless the sound truck, upon which such equipment is mounted, is operated at a speed of at least ten miles per hour, except when such truck is stopped or impeded by traffic. Where stopped by traffic, the sound-amplifying equipment shall not be operated for longer than one minute at each stop. 
(Code 1969, § 23.214; Code 1982, § 18-56) 
Sec. 48-184. - Quiet zones. 
    Sound from sound trucks shall not be issued within 100 yards of any hospital, school (during school hours) or church during services. 
(Code 1969, § 23.214; Code 1982, § 18-57) 
Sec. 48-185. - Human speech volume. 
    The sound of human speech shall be controlled so that it will not be audible from a distance in excess of 100 feet from the sound truck, and so that the volume is not unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing or a nuisance to persons within the area of audibility. 
(Code 1969, § 23.214; Code 1982, § 18-58) 
Sec. 48-186. - Wattage. 
    No sound-amplifying equipment on sound trucks shall be operated with an excess of 15 watts of power in the last stage of amplification. 
(Code 1969, § 23.214; Code 1982, § 18-59) 
Chapter 50 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal fire prevention and protection, 65 ILCS 5/24-11-6 et seq.; Fire Protection Training Act, 50 ILCS 740/1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Fire departments, 65 ILCS 5/11-6-1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 50-1. - Established. 
    There is hereby created and established a fire department. All members of such fire department shall be regarded as village officers. The fire department shall be composed of fulltime employees and paid on-call/parttime employees; however, the fire department's paid on-call/parttime employees, as such, shall not be entitled to any benefits of this Code relating to pensions and tenure. 
(Code 1982, § 11-126; Ord. No. 251, § 1, 9-21-1971) 
Sec. 50-2. - Composition. 
(a)  The fire department shall consist of the following: 
(1)  One fire chief, who shall be the department head and who shall have command of and supervision over all department officers, members and employees; 
(2)  One deputy chief/EMT-P; 
(3)  One or more lieutenants/EMT-P; 
(4)  One or more fire engineers/EMT-P; 
(5)  One or more firefighters/EMT-P; and 
(6)  Such other members as may be provided for from time to time by the president and board of trustees. 
(b)  Fire lieutenants/EMT-P, fire engineers/EMT-P and firefighters/EMT-P shall hold a permanent rank. 
(c)  The positions of fire chief, and deputy chief shall be "exempt rank" duty assignments. 
(d)  The existing permanent rank position of captain is hereby eliminated, effective immediately. Those persons presently holding the rank of captain may continue to do so, however, upon the retirement, death, removal or promotion of any such individual, that rank shall expire and no vacancy shall exist with respect to said rank. 
(e)  Including the positions contained in subsection (a) of this section, the fire department shall consist of the following: 
(1)  One deputy chief/EMT-Ps; 
(2)  Four fire lieutenants/EMT-Ps; 
(3)  Six fire engineers/EMT-Ps; 
(4)  An unspecified number of firefighter/EMT-Ps; and 
(5)  Such fire department clerks, clerk operators and such other members as may be provided for by the mayor and board of trustees; provided, however, that any person holding rank in the fire department upon the adoption of this section shall continue to hold said rank, but no person may be appointed to such rank if the appointment would increase the number of lieutenants or engineers above the number herein provided and in no event shall the total number of lieutenants and engineers exceed the number of ten. 
(Code 1969, § 10.101.1; Code 1982, § 11-127; Ord. No. 223, § 1, 4-21-1970; Ord. No. 251, § 1, 9-21-1971; Ord. No. 459, § 2, 12-6-1977; Ord. No. 546, § 1, 8-7-1979; Ord. No. 91-027, § 1, 12-17-1991; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000; Ord. No. 03-003, § 1, 2-18-2003; Ord. No. 05-019, § 1, 8-16-2005; Ord. No. 15-024, §§ 1-3, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 50-3. - Organization; controlled by the board of fire and police commissioners. 
    The fire department shall be organized and the officers thereof shall be appointed and shall function by the rules and regulations and be subject to the control of the board of fire and police commissioners. 
(Code 1982, § 11-128; Ord. No. 251, § 1, 9-21-1971) 
Sec. 50-4. - Appointment of fire chief and deputy fire chief. 
(a)  The fire chief shall be appointed by the president by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees for a term of one year beginning May first and until his successor is appointed and qualifies. 
(b)  The deputy chief shall be appointed by the fire chief by and with the advice and consent of the president for a term of one year beginning May first and until his successor is appointed and qualifies. 
(Ord. No. 05-019, § 2, 8-16-2005; Ord. No. 13-023, § 18, 5-7-2013; Ord. No. 15-024, §§ 4, 5, 7-21-2015; Ord. No. 18-016, § 2, 5-1-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-024, § 4, adopted July 21, 2015, changed the title of § 50-4 from "Appointment of fire chief and assistant fire chief" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 50-5. - Bond. 
    The fire chief and each regular fireman shall execute, at the time of their appointment to the village, a bond in the amount to be established by the corporate authorities with sureties to be approved by the corporate authorities and conditioned as required by law. 
(Code 1969, § 19.114; Ord. No. 00-006, § 1, 4-18-2000) 
State Law reference- Bond of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3. 
Sec. 50-6. - Compensation. 
    All firemen shall receive such compensation as provided from time to time by the president and board of trustees or as is provided in the annual appropriation ordinance.
