The stop work order constitutes a suspension of the permit. 
(2)  No site development permit shall be permanently suspended or revoked until a hearing is held by the planning and zoning board of appeals. The written notice of such hearing shall be served on the permittee and shall state: 
a.  The grounds for compliant or reasons for suspension or revocation; and 
b.  The time and place of the hearing. 
(3)  At the hearing, the permittee shall be given an opportunity to present evidence on his behalf. At the conclusion of the hearing, the planning and zoning board of appeals shall determine whether the permit shall be suspended or revoked. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall prevent the village from taking such other lawful action to prevent or remedy any violations. All costs connected therewith shall accrue to the person responsible. 
(Ord. No. 08-013, §§ 1400.0-1403.0, 6-17-2008) 
Sec. 52-58. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. 
(a)  This article is not intended to repeal, abrogate or impair any existing easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. 
(b)  Where this article and other ordinance, easements, covenants, or deed restrictions conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. 
(c)  This article is intended to repeal the original ordinance or resolution which was adopted to meet the national flood insurance program regulations, but is not intended to repeal the resolution which the village passed in order to establish initial eligibility for the program. 
(Ord. No. 08-013, §§ 1500.0-1503.0, 6-17-2008) 
Sec. 52-59. - Severability. 
    The provisions and sections of this article shall be deemed separable and the invalidity of any portion of this article shall not affect the validity of the remainder. 
(Ord. No. 08-013, § 1600.0, 6-17-2008) 
Sec. 52-60. - Effective date. 
    This article shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval and publication, as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 08-013, § 1700.0, 6-17-2008) 
Chapter 54 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Plan commission, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Official map. 
    At anytime before or after the formal adoption of the official comprehensive plan by the corporate authorities, an official map may be designated by ordinance, which map may consist of the whole area included within the official comprehensive plan, or one or more separate geographical or functional parts, and may include all or any part of the contiguous unincorporated area within 11/2 miles from the village corporate limits. All the requirements for a public hearing, filing of the adoption notice with the county recorder of deeds and filing of said plan and ordinances, including the official map, with the village clerk shall be complied with as provided for by law. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1210; Code 1982, § 23-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-6. 
Sec. 54-2. - Subdivision regulation beyond limits. 
    No map or plat of any subdivision or resubdivision presented for record affecting land within the village corporate limits or within the territory which is not more than 11/2 miles beyond the corporate limits, except as otherwise provided in 65 ILCS 5/11-12-9 shall be entitled to record or shall be valid, unless the subdivision shown thereon provides for standards of design, and standards governing the following in conformity with the requirements of the ordinances, including the official map and state laws: 
(1)  Streets, alleys, public ways; 
(2)  Ways for public service facilities; 
(3)  Streetlights; 
(4)  Public grounds; 
(5)  Size of lots to be used for residential purposes; 
(6)  Stormwater and floodwater runoff channels and basins; 
(7)  Water supply and distribution; and 
(8)  Sanitary sewers and sewage collection and treatment. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1210.2; Code 1982, § 23-2) 
State Law reference- Jurisdictional boundary lines, agreements, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-9. 
Secs. 54-3-54-21. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VILLAGE PLAN 

Sec. 54-22. - Adopted. 
    The comprehensive plan of public improvements looking to the present and future development of the village which plan was prepared and recommended in May of 2014 to the village board by the village plan commission and was adopted by the village on July 15, 2014. Said comprehensive plan is the comprehensive plan for the Village of Lansing. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1210.3; Code 1982, § 23-11; Ord. No. 16-009, § 1, 3-1-2016) 
Sec. 54-23. - Incorporated. 
    The official plan, attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived, is hereby made a part of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1210.3; Code 1982, § 23-12) 
Sec. 54-24. - Objectives. 
    The official plan as adopted in this article, includes and recognizes, the following objectives: 
(1)  First. To maintain the village character and its environs as essentially a residential community, with commercial and light industrial enterprises permitted in order to maintain a proper balance of property valuations. 
(2)  Second. For the promotion of the public health, safety and convenience and for the attainment of reasonable and practical utility and attractiveness, and for the maintenance and protection of property values, all future developments in the village and its environs shall provide that: 
a.  Adequate streetlighting, water supply, sanitary and drainage facilities shall be constructed and maintained; 
b.  Highways, streets and sidewalks shall be of adequate width and be so constructed and maintained as to avoid the creation of hazardous conditions; 
c.  Railroad crossings and grade separations shall be constructed and maintained to provide adequate public safety and convenience; 
d.  Landscaping of public and private areas shall be controlled to avoid the creation of hazardous conditions; and 
e.  The locations and architectural design, where applicable, of public buildings, schools, parks, recreational facilities, parking areas and airports shall be controlled in accordance with the best public interest. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1210.3; Code 1982, § 23-13) 
Sec. 54-25. - Contents. 
    The official plan as adopted in this article includes: 
(1)  The May 2014 comprehensive plan as prepared by the village plan commission and adopted on July 15, 2014, and the notations, references, boundaries and other matters shown thereon. 
(2)  The village zoning ordinance heretofore adopted by the president and board of trustees as set forth in chapter 56. 
(3)  Subdivision regulations heretofore adopted by the president and board of trustees as referenced in chapter 55, to regulate and control the future physical development of the village and contiguous territory as authorized by law. 
(4)  The specifications for street construction and paving heretofore adopted by the president and board of trustees as set forth in chapter 27. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1210.3; Code 1982, § 23-14; Ord. No. 16-009, § 2, 3-1-2016) 
Sec. 54-26. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the enforcing officer, who shall be designated by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, to enforce the requirements of the official plan. The enforcing officer may call upon any other departments or officials of the village to furnish him with such information or assistance as he may deem necessary for the observance or enforcement of the official plan. It shall be the duty of such other departments or officials to furnish such information or assistance whenever requested. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1210.6; Code 1982, § 23-15) 
Secs. 54-27-54-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PLAN COMMISSION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-46. - Established. 
    There is hereby created a plan commission for the village. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1201; Code 1982, § 23-26; Ord. No. 83-026, § 1, 10-18-1983; Ord. No. 86-033, § 5, 12-2-1986) 
Sec. 54-47. - Notice of appointments. 
    The plan commission shall be advised in writing by the village president of all appointments to the commission, including elective dates, termination dates and changes in appointments within ten calendar days of such appointments or changes. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1202.3; Code 1982, § 23-30) 
Sec. 54-48. - Voting procedure. 
    The adoption and later changes or alterations of rules and regulations of organization and procedure for the plan commission shall be by a majority vote of all commission members; provided, however, every member shall be furnished a copy of such proposed rules and regulations at least ten days before consideration for adoption. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1206; Code 1982, § 23-34) 
Sec. 54-49. - Entitled to copies of all ordinances, plans and data relative to public improvements. 
    The village clerk shall, upon request, furnish the plan commission, for its consideration, a copy of all ordinances, plans and data relative to public improvements of any nature. The plan commission may report in relation thereto if it deems a report necessary or advisable, for the consideration of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1208; Code 1982, § 23-35) 
Sec. 54-50. - Expenditures must be approved by the village president and board of trustees. 
    Expenditures for aerial or other maps, field studies, secretarial and technical assistance, professional service and other plan commission needs may be made or contracted for, but only as provided for and approved by the village president and the board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1209.2; Code 1982, § 23-36) 
Sec. 54-51. - Records of proceedings must be kept; public inspection. 
    The plan commission shall keep written records of its proceedings, which shall be open at any and all times to proper inspection. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1206; Code 1982, § 23-37) 
Secs. 54-52-54-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - POWERS AND DUTIES 

Sec. 54-71. - Established. 
    The plan commission shall have the powers and duties set forth in this division. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1207; Code 1982, § 23-46) 
Sec. 54-72. - Comprehensive plan-Generally. 
    The plan commission may prepare and recommend to the board a comprehensive plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of the village and contiguous unincorporated territory no more than 11/2 miles beyond the village corporate limits and not included in any other municipality. Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts, each of which, when adopted, shall be the official comprehensive plan, or part thereof, of the village. Such plan shall be advisory, except as to such part thereof as has been implemented by ordinances duly enacted by the village. All requirements for a public hearing, filing of the adoption notice with the county recorder of deeds and filing of said plan and ordinances with the village clerk shall be complied with as provided by law. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1207.1; Code 1982, § 23-47) 
Sec. 54-73. - Same-Subdivisions; streets; public places. 
    To provide for the health, safety, comfort and convenience of the inhabitants of the village and contiguous territory, a comprehensive plan shall establish reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and for resubdivision of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment in respect to public improvements as herein defined and shall become regulatory only when adopted by ordinance establishing reasonable requirements governing the following: 
(1)  Location, width, course and surfacing of public streets and highways, alleys and ways for public service facilities; 
(2)  Curbs, gutters and sidewalks; 
(3)  Streetlights; 
(4)  Parks, playgrounds and school grounds; 
(5)  Size of lots to be used for residential purposes; 
(6)  Stormwater drainage; 
(7)  Water supply and distribution; and 
(8)  Sanitary sewers and sewage collection and treatment. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1207.2; Code 1982, § 23-48) 
Sec. 54-74. - Same-Amendments. 
    The plan commission may from time to time recommend to the president and board of trustees such changes in the official comprehensive plan, or any part thereof, as may be deemed necessary by the president and board of trustees or by the plan commission. Such changes shall become part of the official plan after their approval by the plan commission and their adoption by the president and board of trustees as amendments to this article. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.1207.4, 2.1210.5; Code 1982, § 23-49) 
Sec. 54-75. - Same-Prepare and recommend specific improvements. 
    The plan commission may prepare and recommend to the board of trustees, from time to time, plans and/or recommendations for specific improvements in pursuance of the official comprehensive plan. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1207.5; Code 1982, § 23-50) 
Sec. 54-76. - Same-Aid officials with implementation. 
    The plan commission may give aid to the village officials charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced within the official comprehensive plan, or parts thereof, to further the making of such improvements and generally to promote the realization of the official comprehensive plan. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1207.6; Code 1982, § 23-51) 
Sec. 54-77. - Designate annexation; recommend zoning classification. 
    The plan commission may designate land suitable for annexation to the village and the recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1207.3; Code 1982, § 23-52) 
Sec. 54-78. - Create publicity. 
    The plan commission may arrange for and conduct publicity relative to its activities for the general purpose of public understanding. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1207.7; Code 1982, § 23-53) 
Sec. 54-79. - Intergovernmental cooperation. 
    The plan commission may consult and cooperate with other municipal and county plan commissions functioning in the area and with the Northeastern Illinois Planning Commission, to the end that coordinated planning for the village, county and metropolitan area will be encouraged. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1207.8; Code 1982, § 23-54) 
Sec. 54-80. - Annual report required. 
    The plan commission shall file an annual report with the village president and board of trustees setting forth its actions and recommendations for the fiscal year. 
(Code 1969, §§ 2.1206, 2.1207.9; Code 1982, § 23-55) 
Sec. 54-81. - Powers conferred by board. 
    The plan commission may exercise such powers, germane to the powers granted under the authority of an act of the state general assembly entitled "Illinois Municipal Code" approved May 29, 1961, and effective July 1, 1961, and as amended, as may be conferred by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1969, § 2.1207.10; Code 1982, § 23-56) 
Secs. 54-82-54-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION 

Sec. 54-100. - Short title. 
    The commission established herein shall be known as the "Village of Lansing Economic Development Commission." 
(Code 1982, § 23-71; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1601), 11-17-1981; Ord. No. 87-005, § 1, 3-3-1987) 
Sec. 54-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chairman means the chairman of the economic development commission as provided for hereunder. 
    Commission means the economic development commission of the village as created by this article. 
    Secretary means the secretary of the economic development commission as provided for hereunder. 
    Village board means the president and board of trustees of the village. 
(Code 1982, § 23-72; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1602), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-102. - Established. 
    An economic development commission is hereby established in and for the village. 
(Code 1982, § 23-73; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1603), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-103. - Composition. 
    The commission shall consist of seven members: 
(1)  Three members shall be members of the village chamber of commerce; and 
(2)  Four members shall be representatives of the public as a whole. 
(Code 1982, § 23-74; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1604), 11-17-1981; Ord. No. 87-005, § 2, 3-3-1987) 
Sec. 54-104. - Appointment; compensation. 
    The commission members shall be appointed by the village president, with the advise and consent of the board of trustees and shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1982, § 23-75; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1605), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-105. - Terms; initial appointments. 
    The commission members shall be appointed for a term of four years. The initial appointments shall be as follows: 
(1)  One member appointed to serve until April 30, 1988. 
(2)  Two members appointed to serve until April 30, 1989. 
(3)  Two members appointed to serve until April 30, 1990. 
(4)  Two members appointed to serve until April 30, 1991. 
(Code 1982, § 23-76; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1606), 11-17-1981; Ord. No. 87-005, § 3, 3-3-1987) 
Sec. 54-106. - Vacancies filled by president and board of trustees. 
    Vacancies occurring in the commission shall be filled by the village president and board of trustees as provided for in this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 23-77; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1607), 11-17-1981; Ord. No. 87-005, § 5, 3-3-1987) 
Sec. 54-107. - Village president's authority to remove. 
    The village president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall have the authority to remove any commission member from office whenever, in his discretion, the best interests of the village shall be served thereby. 
(Code 1982, § 23-78; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1608), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-108. - Officers appointed by village president. 
    The village president shall appoint the chairman and secretary of the commission. 
(Code 1982, § 23-79; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1609), 11-17-1981; Ord. No. 87-005, § 4, 3-3-1987) 
Sec. 54-109. - Duties of officers. 
(a)  Chairman. It shall be the duty of the chairman to preside over all commission meetings. In his absence, a chairman pro tempore may be elected to preside. 
(b)  Secretary. It shall be the secretary's duty to keep a record of all commission proceedings, transmit its recommendations to the village president, board of trustees and plan commission and perform such other duties as are usually performed by the secretary of a deliberative body. 
(Code 1982, § 23-80; Ord. No. 688, § 1(2.1610), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-110. - Governing rules and procedures adopted. 
    The commission shall adopt a set of rules to govern its own meetings and procedures. The rules may be amended from time to time, but only upon notice to all members that said proposed amendments shall be acted upon as a specified meeting. A majority vote of the commission shall be required for the approval of the proposed amendment. 
(Code 1982, § 23-81; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1611), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-111. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings. The commission shall meet in regular session at least once a month at a time and place selected by vote of its members. 
(b)  Special meetings; notice. The corporate authorities, the chairman or any three commission members shall have the authority to call special meetings of the commission. Written notice of special meetings shall be given to all members. 
(Code 1982, § 23-82; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1612), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-112. - Member absences; successor appointments. 
    Absence from four consecutive regular meetings without the commission's formal consent shall be deemed to constitute a retirement of a member, and the vacancy created shall be filled thereafter by the village president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, by the appointment of a successor to fill the unexpired term of office. 
(Code 1982, § 23-83; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1613), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-113. - Powers and duties. 
    The economic development commission shall have the following powers and duties to: 
(1)  Confer with and advise the village president, board of trustees and plan commission on all matters concerning the village's industrial development. 
(2)  Advertise the industrial advantages and opportunities of the village within the means provided by any appropriation made therefor by the corporate authorities. 
(3)  Collect data and information as to the type of industries best suited to the village. 
(4)  Develop, compile and coordinate information regarding available areas suitable for industrial development. 
(5)  Encourage the proper zoning and orderly development of areas suitable for industrial development and to promote the interest of industrialization of such village areas. 
(6)  Aid the village president, board of trustees and plan commission in the attraction of new industries and in the encouragement of expansion by existing industries and businesses. 
(7)  Cooperate with all community groups which are dedicated to orderly industrial and economic expansion of the village, and to furnish them such aid and advice as is deemed appropriate. 
(8)  Cooperate with all industries and businesses in the village in the solution of any community problems which they might have, and to encourage the management of such concerns to have a healthy and constructive interest in the village's welfare. 
(9)  Periodically survey the overall village condition from the standpoint of determining whether the village has a community climate and furnishes such services and facilities as are conducive to industrial and economic expansion. 
(10)  Recommend to the corporate authorities the leasing, sale or use of village-owned properties for industrial purposes. 
(Code 1982, § 23-84; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1614), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-114. - Acting in advisory capacity. 
    Except as may otherwise be provided by ordinance, the powers and duties of the economic development commission are of an advisory nature only, and the commission shall not have any powers or duties which conflict with or supersede the powers and duties of other village commissions or boards. 
(Code 1982, § 23-85; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1615), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-115. - Village officials to cooperate. 
    All officials and division heads of the village shall cooperate with the commission and render all reasonable assistance. 
(Code 1982, § 23-86; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1616), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-116. - Prohibited from incurring liability. 
    Neither the commission, nor any member thereof shall incur any financial liability in the village's name. 
(Code 1982, § 23-87; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1617), 11-17-1981) 
Sec. 54-117. - Annual report required. 
    The commission shall render annually a full report of its work to the village president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1982, § 23-88; Ord. No. 668, § 1(2.1618), 11-17-1981) 
Secs. 54-118-54-136. - Reserved.
